RATING: 7
Bizarrely, my copy of this game, which I have had for over a year, is unplayed.  Instead I've played on other people's sets at a local gaming club.  Despite being quite a good player I have failed to ever win at this, and it is a source of personal frustration.
Okay, its got a large random factor with the dice and a popularity/shouting factor with the trading and the cards throw an extra random element into the mix, but I should win sometime, surely....?

RATING: 8
I would originally have rated this as a 9 but I'm bored with it now even with the numerous scenarios around. If the game lasts under an hour it's fine but you get the occassional one that just drags. However, I still think it's the perfect gateway game and will always select it when introducing newbies. I always preferred the Seafarers version but am quite happy with just the base game now. Cities & Knights tries to make the game something that it's not. Das Buch has some interesting scenarios though.

RATING: 3
I don't have any visceral hate for the game, I just wish it didn't take as long to play. One thing in particular that I dislike is similar to Terra Mystica; the critical decisions are all front loaded in the game (settlement placements and early expansion), and there is a permanence in the area/point controls. Catan just takes less time is the upside.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Perhaps I just over-played this one in its prime. Mostly, I just don't like games that take an hour and a half to play but you can often tell who's going to win in the first 30 minutes (or at least who is going to lose... but they're still stuck playing). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I like the game but the only problem I have with it is there is a lot of luck involved with the die role. Don't get me wrong, I like some luck in my games. But this one requires too much luck in order to win. For example, I played my 13 year old daughter and son and we all kept rolling 9s all of the time, which gave my daughter tons of resources. She clobbered us, getting 10 points before my son and I got to five points. I bought this game expecting a lot more strategy and was dissapointed.

Edit: I have played this a few more times and, while I still don't see a ton of strategy in this game, I am seeing more possibilities. I think the expansions will probably go a long way toward increasing replayability. I increased the rating from a 7 to a 8.

Edit 2: I got Cities and Knights and it makes this game a solid 9 for me. We're having a lot of fun with it!

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
My feelings towards Settlers are somewhat ambivalent. There are some aspects of this game that I consider quite ingenious. Not within the game itself but how works in a group of people. It's like a catalyst for social interaction and it doesn't take long for even the most casual gamer to really get into the negotiating and plotting of plans. And I love to watch new players as they starts to see their little village expand on the island. Their look changes - like something deep inside, something childish and playful, clicks into place. And I think, 'Now you're hooked alright. Hooked good and proper". 

On the same token it can get long, repetitive and frustrating - and you really need exactly 4 people to play it. My rating fluctuates between 5-7. So I'll settle with a 6 for now.

The Swedish Edition (Dan-spil) is rather low quality and the title involves one of the worst translations ever. Additionally, the Swedish rules are just plain awful.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
If I'm going to play a Euro, it should be exciting, and Settlers is certainly that.  The dice rolls really make the game--they let the drama of not getting what you need, of being forced to make new plans, rise up.  My only complaint is that you can be out of the game before your first turn if your initial set up isn't well thought out.  That is a huge barrier for new players versus experienced players, but the game seems to have done alright for itself.  Certainly worthy of its status, and I don't understand why it isn't ranked higher.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
[I]tl;dr - The trading and resource gathering is interesting -- and it was a trailblazer -- but for many people, there are more interesting games out there.[/I]
[COLOR=#CCCCFF]____________________________[/COLOR]

Look, Catan got me into gaming. I can't deny that I've loved and played it a lot. But Catan (especially with no expansions) just isn't interesting anymore. I have played it upwards of thirty times online against AIs, and as such I'm pretty much played out on the game. Diversify your hexes, go for largest army or longest road (whichever has less competition), and trade only as much as necessary. Spread out and diversify your resources early, then bulk up on cities mid-game. I don't know, strategies vary, but I just feel like I'm always playing Catan on rails. It feels solved. 

So yes, Catan is a great gateway game. It's exciting for new players who've never played a German-style game before. But I don't need to buy the game, or its expansions -- there's no need to. I've got plenty of other games that scratch that itch, and while I'm happy to recommend it, there's no need for me to personally own it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2015 május
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My first impression is: this is the best family game in 20 years and that's before I even knew about BGG! After my eyes have been opened wide by BGG, I would still say this' the best family game in 20 years (over the likes of Monopoly, Scrabble, Risk) but my attention was diverted to those of Puerto Rico, Twilight Imperium III, and Android...
Thus I brought down my grading for Catan to 8 from 10 as I would like to try out the others first (and the BGG grading is based on willingness to play). But my impression remained the same for Catan: it's the best family game in 20 years!

RATING: 10
This was my introduction to European games, and it still stands as one of the very best.  Short enough to get played often, but long enough to be satisfying.  Simple enough to teach casual gamers to play (and they like and understand it), but still a very engaging and fun game.  Has lots of decision making and player interaction, and requires a good mix of luck, strategy, and trading.  Loving civilization-type games, I really like the way this one plays.

Also, I made my own board, which makes it look awesome:
www.boardgamegeek.com/image/152673

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
One has to give credit for Catan for being a groundbraking game that paved the way for what modern boardgames are today. There is something appealing in the the theme, but games have evolved tremendously in the last decade and while groundbraking in the 90's, Catan simply falls short these days.

Simply put, I find Catan to be an awful game of dice-rolling randomness that takes way too long to boot. It looks nicer than Monopoly, but gameplay-wise the latter is better.. and that's saying a lot, since it's not much of a game either. As a family game Catan might be passable, but it creates so much frustration that I doubt it would be much fun. 

Even the iPhone app is waste of money.. I would not play it unless I wanted to piss myself off on purpose.

That can't be it. It's a keeper, as it's MY gateway game.

RATING: 6
A classic. The one drawback I can think of is that the luck of dice (especially if 7 is thrown repeatedly) can swing things uncontrollably towards one player. Better might have been to let 7 be some other action, and make the robber a less common roll, like 2 or 12, say. The 3-player game works much better than the 4-player because in the 4-player one player always gets locked out with no choice but to twiddle their thumbs.

RATING: 8
I love this game, there are so many strategies and so many ways to win that the replay value is virtually limitless. Radmonization of the game board ensures you will pretty much never play the same game twice. It seems overwhelming to new players who have never played but usually within 2-3 turns they seem catch on and always end up really enjoying it. This has become a new staple during family holidays & birthdays, everyone always asks to make sure I brought it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A great interactive and social experience. Easy to teach and hilarious when you both swap the same cards (i.e. wood for wood) with a fellow player as you have asked for the resource in the wrong way for the umpteenth time. Great re-playability and the fishermen mini-extension balances the non-harbour costal settlements. A great family game and a classic. Would have loved to have played this in 1995 when it was released - the UK was just not as exposed to these "euro" games for some reason. If my mum will play and enjoy this game, trust me, ANYONE will.

RATING: 8
Although it doesn't look like it, Settlers is the modern day Monopoly in success and play.  The game has you roll two dice in order to grab resources and there's also a lot of negotiation in it too.

That being said, there can be a chance that a player gets hosed because of unfortunate set up and die rolls, which makes this game far from perfect.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Probably my favorite "casual" game and one that I always recommend to newbies.  For people that prefer a "skill" game, the dice rolls can be extremely frustrating.  In a game with skilled players, it often comes down to who got the right rolls at the right time.  Even the best player/strategy cannot recover from a resource freeze that lasts several turns.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Catan seems to get a lot of bad press, but I can't for the life of me figure out why, I think it's great.

It's got such good player interaction - its not just the quantity but also the type: all of the trading, blocking, and the robber  aspects of it create this "screw you" kind of atmosphere that always seems to create really good banter around the table.

It's a good game to play with a range of levels of experience of gamer. The randomness of the dice rolls takes away a lot of the potential for a more experienced player to just crush weaker players, and means that even when you're losing you feel like "maybe in the next few turns several people will roll a 2, and my fortunes will change!" 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The first game that I became really hooked on.  A game that when I first started playing it, it was what I was always thinking about.  Unfortunately the trading aspect can make or break the game and can turn a fun game into a frustrating experience.  It has grown kinda stale, and the dice make for an extremely luck filled experience where a lot of times you cannot control anything.  I still think it works great as a gateway game, and was what I used to get many of my friends interested in the hobby.

RATING: 8
This game was my starting line for getting away from mainstream market games like Chess, Sorry, or Sequence.

IMO, this game sets the bar for table-top gaming, and every gamer must play at least once. If you play another game but it wasn't as fun as Catan, don't buy it. If you play another game and it was more fun than Catan, buy it.

RATING: 10
A guy I knew from GW gaming showed us Settlers... I loved it. Later on in college, a friend showed me the copy he picked up during a visit to Germany. The rest is history! I absolutely love this game. My personal favorite of the millenium. I have introduced countless people to Euros through this game, and only a handfull have not enjoyed themselves. When I think about Eurogames, I think about Settlers of Catan.UPDATE: I finally have grown a little weary of Settlers. It is an amazing game, for sure, but I realize that there are many more games out there to be discovered. I'll still play it gladly if requested, but will probably push for Cities and Knights over the basic game. I do, however, give in to the fact that Settlers is the biggest deal as far as my board gaming history goes, and for that reason it now gets a 10, even though I'm a lot less likely to play it.

RATING: 5
A fun, light game combining several of the elements that I like. The random element can be problematic but the use of 2 dice keeps the probability curve flat enough for the most part. Easy to pick up and makes a great family or lunchtime game, though after a while your group may want something meatier.

[update]After moving on to meatier games myself and revisting this one, the flaws in this game are more readily evident. The random element of the base game is far too prominent for my tastes. Still probably a good "gentle" introduction for others into more complex games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
As with many other gamers, Catan introduced me to the world of designer board games. It was a huge hit with my friends, my roommates, my family, and even me. I say this because I rarely desire to play it.

I've become Cataned out, most likely because I've moved on to greener pastures (with other sheep). My tastes in games have become more clear and I've developed a palate that is more defined, making Catan slip in my regards. Add to that the fact that my brother always wants to play Catan and I've become a little burned out on it.

However, it's a classic, both in the history books and in my mind. I've played enough games to realize that Catan is still one of my favorites, despite my hesitance to play it sometimes. I'm more willing to try new things and introduce a friend or family member to a game that is perhaps a little more thrilling or deep or thematic. All that said, Catan is a splendid game.

RATING: 10
This game gets a 9+1=10. Here's why:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
6+ plays, 3-4 players (base game). 6 players (base & expansion)
LIKE: the resource harvesting and trading
DISLIKE: Some randomness. The robber bugs me. The game can get hostile and too long with 6 players. Low production on a turn can lead to frustration over time.
OVERALL: Solid game, can be fun. Great player interaction.

UPDATE: I am now against the expansions. The base game is good, but with 4 players, one player can get blocked out from the precious coast. Sometimes there are turns when a player cannot do anything (no production, robber, monopoly, etc), so this makes the 5-6 player versions horribly long and tedious. (downrated)

RATING: 1
I just hate this game, it feels so superficial with trades that are just so uninteresting and pointless choices. I have never felt like I wasted as much time as I do with Catan. The only reason I would play this is if my friends don't want to do or play anything else, and then it is purely for their company, with no real engagement with the game on my part.

I know its supposed to be excused for its bad mechanics and little depth because it is a gateway game, but I can name so many games that can show people what games are really capable of with just as little complexity. Even party games would do a far better job than this.

RATING: 9
Great interactions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The Emperor's new clothes?  Well, I reckon it feels like that.  

To me, this is the gaming equivalent of Morrisey's music.  Many friends are telling you that it's wonderful, but it just grates, feels like the dirge that the old cow died of, and bores the pants off of you.  

There's really only one so called "Classic Euro" on this Forum that I just don't like and this is it.  What on earth is all the fuss about!  I just found it dull and too luck based.  I can understand why some would say it was a good introduction to German Games, but it has been surpassed by many others.  Lost Cities is much easier and more elegant, Ticket to Ride is vastly superior, easier, better made and more fun.  If you want to place things, then there are much better games.  If you want depth you've got games like Wallenstein.  Then there's the quality of the components (mediocre at best).  So what gives?  It's palpably not the worst game in the world, but, for the above reasons,  it's not for me I'm afraid.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Played Settlers again, as part of a team with my husband against other people at the Ballard Library Board Game Night.  And we utterly demolished our competition.  So, some of the players were close, but we made the best trades and had the best strategy.  We won with the longest road (no surprise for me) and it was the first time my husband and won, so that was awesome.  All in all it was a good night!

Played this at the Library again, and without mercy, I stomped my opponents, dividing them with my longest wall, creating a wood monopoly, and making some very smart trades.  My husband was almost tied with me - it was an extremely competitive and very close game.  It was great!

RATING: 8
To me, Settlers of Catan is the best game ever made. The base game is just what the name says: a basic game, originally designed way more complex.
As it is, it is already a lot of fun. The varying game setup takes care for fun for quite a while.
But the real strength of Settlers lies in its multiple expansion. 
Moreover, Settlers provides a wonderful platform to create own scenarios, and this is where the real fun starts.
Settlers is the type of game that you don't get tired of. If you do, just vary it and it is an entirely new game. Up to now, I haven't met anyone who doesn't like it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
its a very, very cool game indeed. working your way to victory means being very friendly but also deceive your opponents by either bringing then of the track with trading or by offering then what they need to simply build a street whilst you can get the final victory point with that city your going to build right away.

swearing and being an aggressive or arrogant derp doesn't really help your game plan so I think being polite and friendly during the game gives you the best game experience.

there are some cons though.

there is little fun playing against people who don't have a lot of experience playing strategy games.
settlers of catan requires some sort of foresight into what's going to happen on the board to make it the silently competitive game it is meant to be.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The 800-pound gorilla of board games!  I really can't say much bad about Settlers.  The dice-rolling doesn't overshadow the deeper, more strategic nature of the game.  The random layout of the tiles (at setup) and the random arrangement of the outside trading bonuses provides tons of replay potential.  The development cards are a nice mechanism for sprucing up gameplay and provide more options.

My only criticism is that Settlers isn't very heavy/deep and I tend to prefer heavier/deeper games.  It falls into that nebulous middle category – not too heavy and not too light.  But it's Settlers and it's fun and I hope I get to play more games of it in the future.

And no Settlers review would be complete without the obligatory "I've got wood for sheep."  There, I said it.  Happy?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
[b]Affordability[/b] - [microbadge=39227]
[b]Functionality[/b] - [microbadge=39223]
[b]Originality[/b] - [microbadge=39224]
[b]Quality[/b] - [microbadge=39226]
[b]Reusability[/b] - [microbadge=39222]
[b]Variability[/b] - [microbadge=39225]

[b]Solo Variant[/b] - [filepage=103265]Carcassonnatan[/filepage] by [user=panchocarnie]Guthrie Allen[/user]

:thumbsup: The randomized setup process is fun as the world comes to life with unique features and artwork.
:thumbsup: There is a good deal of strategic thinking and planning during the early phases.

[microbadge=30754][c] [/c]Some different victory paths may be explored, yet there is not a lot of depth to learn.
[microbadge=30754][c] [/c]Balance issues make the later phases almost too easy at times, so that it is a race to the end.

:thumbsdown: There is far too much reliance on the dice, and the majority of the time is spent rolling continuously.
:thumbsdown: The amount of time feels bloated and adds a snowballing effect of monotony and boredom.

RATING: 7
ganhei do blog Adoradores de Catan, do Keymaker (Jefferson Oliveira)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Pretty much tied with Boggle for my favorite game. Settlers has so much room for change with the unique board for every game, and the complete arbitrariness of luck on the dice roles that I almost never get tired of playing. The game is great both for 3 or 4 players, with each situation providing for a very different kind of game. It's also possible to combine two sets of the game to play with 5-7 players (though I wouldn't recommend going over 6), and without needing to buy any of the expensive expansions. Every time I introduce a friend to this game, they get hooked by about half-way through the first game. Settlers is a great strategy game which doesn't rely solely on brute force and has no military based. Rather, one relies on trading resources as well as timely and intelligent use of them buy, barter and build one's way to victory. Highly addicting, but you'll never regret getting hooked!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Well, everybody says that we all need to know the classics. So here I was learning the classic Catan. It would be a hell of a game if I didn't know any other games other than Risk or Monopoly. But knowing so much games nowadays makes this game a bad choice for gateway. There are so much better games to show as gateway. The luck in this game bothers a lot and I can see expert gamers hating this game simply because there is no logic in negociate with someone that is winning, and this guy will be frustrated 'till he is not winning anymore.

I understand the value of this game in the time it showed up, but nowadays we have so much better games.

RATING: 7
FAMILY, STRATEGY

The iconic Eurogame. Gather goods and trade them to build roads, settlements, cities, and purchase development cards. It's not my favorite game, but it's very popular. I greatly prefer with with 4 players.

Maggie and I played the two-player variant at:
http://nick.borko.org/games/Catan2Players.pdf

There's also an "official" two-player variant by Klaus Teuber in the files area of this game.

Recommended with 3-4 players (best 4). 60-120 mins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Ah, Catan. A game every gamer should love for putting board gaming on the map, and a game every gamer should hate for being such a bad game. I know, nostalgia is a strong thing, and this game was the 'only' real game back in the days, but that doesn't take away the fact that the mechanics of the game (maybe theme too, but since it is a euro, let's not take this into consideration) are terribly old-fashioned. Lots of better games out there! 

Theme (artwork/story/...)
0.5/2
Gameplay (smooth play/player interaction/strategy&tactics/depth)
3.5/5
Fun factor (can you afford a smile during play?)
1.5/3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of the first games that I started playing.  Players tries to collect resources based on the dice rolls and the houses built on the resource tiles.  With the resources, players can build houses, roads, upgrade houses or buy event cards. Players can trade resources among themselves or with the boardgame so as to acquire resources they lack.  Players can also move a bandit piece which will disallow players to collect resources from the resource tile if the dice roll number 7.

Good points: Easy to play and understand

Bad points: The key of the game resides on the initial position of the 2 houses players placed on the resource tiles.  If 1 player can get resources almost every round in the game, then the player have a high chance to win the game.  The bandit to stop the winning player from taking resources has too small effect on the winning player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

klassiker. dette er et must for alle brettspill interesserte. Første gode strategispillet jeg lærte for 8 år siden og vi spiller det fremdeles. enkle regler og alltid et nytt spill siden man lager et nytt spillbrett for hver gang man spiller.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The perennial game - a classic. My game group played countless games over the years, before we even heard of BGG. We've had marathon gaming nights lasting until dawn. We even keep a game log (complete with questions/answers to complex game situations and a list of winners).

Even though SoC is a dice game with a med-high luck factor, my group believes that you can effectively strategize and change tactics depending on what's rolled and what resources people have. Why build a settlement on the 8 or 9 when the 10 or 11 is hot? What do you do when 3 is rolled 3 times in a row and the 6 hasn't been rolled all game? Where's the best place to put the robber, on a hot number or a more likely number? 

The player interaction level is fairly high too. Screw someone too early in the game, you have an enemy working against you. If you take the lead too early, you're a marked player. We love to talk during trades too (look, my sheep is better!). And perish the thought of trading someone with 7+ points, you'll be heckled for the rest of the game. Oh look, so-and-so has all those development cards, must be victory points, they are in the lead! Hours of fun!

I rate plain SoC higher than the expansions because it's fast-paced and easy, and we can get in multiple games in a night. Also, SoC games are typically close games where everyone has an active role. Even if it's a blowout, it's usually quick and painless. 

Played SoC dozens of times before I started tracking my games played (approx. 50-100 games).

UPDATE: Finally played this again after a long hiatus. We started with the sample board and starting positions to even out the board for the 2 new players. Turned out, the sample board was awful - poor settlement and road placements that didn't make sense (for example, some second round choices settlement and road placements would have been better in other places). 

New version: Flimsy board pieces, ports are permanently set on border pieces, but they don't sit well to frame the hexagonal board. 

Tracked on family list (grooven)!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Warm and fuzzy. Catan is a good game for beginners but is mainly based on luck. Best part of Catan is undeniably trading. Besides this is a very easy game to learn.

RATING: 9

Traded for this game. THANKS! :D

RATING: 7
Great and fun to play, but with some flaws:
-No fixed number of turns,when the players are trying to screw each other the game can last a long time.
-The trading with other players, while fundamental, can lead to kingmaking- "I don't want him to play so I'll give you all my resources so you can win first."
-It is possible to spend time getting annoyed by the everyone but you collecting resources, and the robber seemingly spending its entire time on your tiles.

Having said that, the game is still fun to play, but I prefer to play similar, more modern games that are annoying less of the time.

There are those who cite the rolling of the dice every turn as a sign that Settlers is light on strategy, but it is a rare game of Catan where luck outweighs strategy. Decisions on road, settlement and city placement are never easy.

RATING: 9

I have played this more times than my log of plays suggests--probably more like 8 or 10. Initially I found the luck frustrating, but I have learned that much of my frustration came from an overly simplistic understanding of how to place settlements, which led to my not having settlements on a broad enough variety of numbers and resources. Initial placement is maybe a bit too important, but as I have gotten better at that aspect of the game I've enjoyed the game as a whole much more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In Catan (formerly The Settlers of Catan), players try to be the dominant force on the island of Catan by building settlements, cities, and roads. On each turn dice are rolled to determine what resources the island produces. Players collect these resources (cards)—wood, grain, brick, sheep, or stone—to build up their civilizations to get to 10 victory points and win the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The game that got me into modern board gaming. I've easily played Catan 200+ times--mostly over the span of 2 years when Settlers and Carcassonne were somehow enough to satiate my desire for tabletop gaming. These days, I just never really want to play it. Maybe to try out an expansion or two, but not much beyond that.

There are still things I appreciate about Settlers--the modular board setup, negotiation, intuitive set of resources to manage in order to race to 10 victory points, spatial elements that involve indirect conflict in settlement planning, and so on.

Certain things that have gotten old include unpleasantly high degree of luck in resource rolls; Constructing buildings doesn't really *do* anything other than help get you more resource cards (want more gameplay function!); And the game can really break down if people aren't willing to make good, interesting trades (see: luck). It's really a pretty simple game when it gets down to it. And there is a significant runaway leader problem, or at least a runaway loser problem. Resources, dice, Settlers.

(Own base + 5-6p + Traders & Barbarians)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

f

RATING: 7
Catan is really good at destroying friendships forever, the hallmark of a good game.

I can't say anything good about it that hasn't been said before, so I'll say something bad about it instead.

The one thing I don't like about Catan is that I find it a little too easy to get an early lead from mean positioning of my initial roads, etc., which basically subtly screws over other players for the entirety of the rest of the game.

RATING: 4.5
Not very good. I think the positive reviews are largely a factor of it having been good in its time.

It's very easy to end up getting no resources or resources that others already have, so you end up unable to do anything and unable to trade for what you need. Possibly, if you bought the expansion for more players, but play with the original player count and an extra starting city, this would be mitigated.

But as it is, it's a trading game which has a pretty good chance of denying you from trading, and that's just not good gaming.

RATING: 3
This is definitely a game that has fallen in rating as I have played more games. This game has forever pushed me away from any "player generated trading" mechanic in other games. Otherwise the very minor advantage in dice rolls will snowball if allowed to get to a certain threshold above other players. Playing this game showed me how even the smallest of engine builders can leave no room for the other players to catch up and become competitive again. .

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
A true masterpiece of a game. Doesn't seem like it could be so fun, to grow crops on a hexagonal board. But there is something about the game that makes it fun. Guess it's the combination of hoping that the dice will score your crops together with the trading part of the game. Also fun to build, try to block other players and plan in the beginning where to put your starting markers. The robber is surely also part of the games success. The game is a nice mixed between skill, luck and social skills.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I really like Settlers of Catan and find it pretty simple to teach and play. The game board setup is a bit awkward at first but once the pieces are in place it's fine.

It can also be a bit too luck dependant and can get annoying when you've picked settlement start points on statistically more likely numbers, only to have them barely come up for the whole game! 

Still good fun though but can last a bit long sometimes which isn't fun, especially if you are losing.

For me is already a traditional game, with some flaws but fun to play.

RATING: 6.5
One of the best games for introducing people to board games, since Settlers is simple, short, and has a fun trading dynamic. Unfortunately the strategic element is lacking and the game is completely dominated by dice rolls. It's appropriate for a relaxed, not intense gaming environment, but don't expect the game to confront you with many difficult choices.

The cooperative trading element of the game almost always breaks down near the end, because once someone is close to winning everyone else refuses to trade with that person.

Includes:
[thing=2807][/thing]

[thing=4103][/thing]
[thing=926][/thing]
[thing=4101][/thing]

Ah, "Settlers."  The granddaddy of all modern boardgaming.  Among the items on my bucket list is an afternoon spent drinking heavy German beers with Klaus Teuber while playing the original first printing of Settlers.

As for playing the base game only, I'm not as interested.  Add in 5-6 players with C&K and Seafarers, playing the Oceana scenario, and we're in business.  It turns the bland, but timeless experience into a dramatic opera of risk, intrigue (no relation to the crappy progress card...), and one-upmanship.  That said, I still prefer other games, and this one is really showing its age based on modern design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Still not at all convinced ... our group gets frustrated at being blocked in / not having the right resources, and the lack of a decent trading mentality. Big runaway leader problem. No way back if you get behind early. Not a lot going for it, really.

RATING: 5

The luck factor where you get turn after turn receiving no resources whatsoever is frustrating, to say the least.  Once you are on the backfoot, it is very difficult to come back.  The game is also too long for what it delivers.

RATING: 6
The most overrated game on earth. When I first got into games I told people about it they asked if I meant games like monopoly. Now they ask if I mean games like Catan. When I first tried to get my group of friends into games I was trying to get them to sample several games. This was the second one they played. They grabbed onto it and would not let go. Most of them bought it. It was all they wanted to play for over a year. In that time my collection went from around 10 games to around 50. And all they wanted to play was Catan. It is a GOOD game. It is not gospel.

RATING: 6
Despite the flak it might get, I still enjoy this game maybe once a year.  Personally I feel the expansions to this game do it nothing but harm!  Settlers should be quick and simple, with player interaction and trading as its main driver.  People say the expansions fix things like the value of sheep.  I say who cares!  Why do all the resources need to be equal? Keep Catan simple, don't try to dress it up with awkward accessories.

RATING: 9
Favorite game to play with the family.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Catan is a very solid game that combines strategy of completing a network with trading with other players. The game has a few downfalls in that it bases resources collection off a dice throw which can be frustrating if the odds of a number being rolled don't actually show up during your game. This along with the case of the strong getting stronger makes the game very hard to come back from behind if things go bad or unlucky early.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Summary at bottom. Note that this review does not include the extensions for Catan!

Classic and a fair buy. Good for kids and casual players in terms of pace and content, as it's not too complicated yet you don't feel insulted by the weight of the game.

That being said, the game is relatively linear with little strategy required. One simply follows the sequence of collecting resources, trading with players and building settlement after settlement. It's not excruciatingly boring, but once you've played the game a couple times one may get stale of the predictable, slow-paced grind.

That being said, the game does include a sort of disruption mechanic to hinder other players, but it's completely based off of luck so not much thought required there either.

TLDR: Decent relaxing game. Great family game considering it runs along at a tolerable pace and is easy enough to grasp for the young and old. However, it requires little strategy and becomes rather stale after a couple of sessions.

It is extremely important to remember that this review is purely based off of the base game. There are several add-ons available that add a mountain of content and different play styles, that likely make the game a lot more compelling. However, I have played few sessions with them, so I suggest you take a look at the reviews for those as well.

It's a very good game for a bunch of inexperienced players since they will have lots of fun turning sheep into wood.

The gaming industry has changed and grown since the mid-1990s, but Catan will always hold a special place in my heart.  I still enjoy playing it a few times/year, and it won't be leaving my collection any time soon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
My copy must be nearly twenty-something years old and I remember playing it quite fondly back when I got it. What I most enjoy about this old edition is the lovely wooden blocks and hex illustrations that have sadly only gotten uglier wit the obtusely detailed plastic miniatures. So there's something to like about this game.

Unfortunately, every time I have got this game out of the closet I'm reminded that I very rarely enjoy playing it. The huge setup customization is nice, but the game is just excrusiatingly boring and luck-dependent. I recently taught it to my girlfriend and we seemed to be enjoying ourselves for a while, but quickly descended to one of us (admittedly, mostly me) being frustrated with the map layout and die luck. Whatever it is about the mechanics of this game, it seems more effective at inciting violent crimes than fun gameplay. This is sure to be merely my own local issue, but I've found it difficult to want to keep playing it more than a few games within a year or so. 
It has some positives, more than mentioned in the first paragraph, but it's just not my cup of tea.

RATING: 6.6
Juego muy aclamado, pero que para mi gusto no tiene tanto que ofrecer. Es cierto, se tiene control en varias decisiones, donde colocar tus asentamientos y expandirte, pero hay partidas que definitivamente las probabilidades te juegan tan mala pasada que sientes que no tienes control de nada, el rezago del último jugador es bastante triste.

Eso si, no es aburrido, es un buen juego para 4 jugadores de duración media, aunque creo que si durara 1 hora cumpliría mejor su rol, con duraciones de 1 hora y 30 o 2 horas pierde gracia.

RATING: 7
My original gateway board game, really where I first got into the hobby. I still think it's one of the standard and best euros out there, and deserves its place in history for being a game which appeals to a multitude of people despite being a euro and a more heavier game than most amerithrash.

The part I dislike most about the game is the reliance of rolls to snowball into the later game. If you don't get great rolls early, it's very easy to quickly be pigeonholed into a boring, helpless position and vice versa. There is very rarely any playing from behind and the ending of the game is very anticlimactic. 

Overall, I still really enjoy the game and would be happy if pulled out just for familiarity but I would almost always want to pull out other games. Great gateway game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I gets better when you apply some houserules from 'the book' (I think this only exists in German).

I own many of the expansions, so the game is still varied. Some rules / scenarios I haven't even played once.

RATING: 5
I like that this game revitalized the board game industry. It's like the Monopoly of the current generation: an economic themed dice fest that takes forever and yet every body plays it. But I dislike playing it at times for the following reasons:
1. Dice luck is overwhelming.
2. Choices are obvious, you either have the resources to build what you want or you need to try acquire them some how. Acquiring is limited to lucky die rolls or trading.
3. If you are winning you might as well go take a nap because trade embargoes and robbers are coming your way.

RATING: 5
___________________
\_______GER_______/
Damit hatte meine Catan-Sammlung begonnen.
Von  Frank dann dieses sehr schöne Holzspielbrett für 6 Spieler zum Geburtstag bekommen.
Aber wenn man ehrlich ist, dann ist Catan mit 6 Spielern nicht wirklich lustig: es dauert viel zu lange bis man selber wieder an der Reihe ist (nur um dann evt. doch nichts machen zu können ...).
Mit 2 Spielern ist es eigentlich vollkommen uninteressant, da keiner der beiden wirklich zum Handeln bereit ist. Mit 3 bis 4 Spielern spielt es sich noch am Besten.
Eigentlich spielt es sich am PC oder Tablet noch am interessantesten weil am Schnellsten (und der PC verweigert das Handeln nicht aus Prinzip). 
Ich bin mir nicht sicher, wann bei mir Catan wieder auf den Spieltisch kommt.

Das [thing=2807]Ergänzungs-Set für 5 und 6 Spieler[/thing] ist eine einfache Karten- und Material-Ergänzung, um auch ohne Seefahrer oder Städte Überbau mit mehr als 4 Spielern das Basisspiel spielen zu können.
In der Realität ist Catan mit mehr als 4 Spielern nicht wirklich lustig gewesen. Aber da ich so ein schönes Holzbrett für die große Catan Version bis zu 6 Spielern geschenkt bekommen hatte musste diese Erweiterung einfach  sein.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
It's popular for hard core gamers to dismiss this game in favor of more elite, less mainstream games, but Settlers of Catan stands in my opinion as one of the best games ever designed. It's important to note expansions should be added at your own risk. I feel they just muck up a perfectly elegant design with unneeded additives and try to turn the game into something it's not. The core, 4-player game is the only version I want to play. If I want to play something else, there are other great games.

RATING: 8
As the descriptions are "9: Excellent - very much enjoy playing." and "10: Outstanding - will always enjoy playing."
This has to be a 9.5 - I only haven't enjoyed it much when halfway through my first play I realised that dominating sheep and having no source of brick was a fatal error, and another time when a friend trolled us by taking twice the amount of time to complete moves than he should have, when he already knew what he was going to do.
2-player variants aren't as enjoyable either, but none of the boxes suggest playing with 2 players, despite some expansions allowing you to play with 2 players.

Absolutely essential game for any board game fan!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Wow. Game boxes used to be so ... drab!  It's brown with some brown on it. Yawn. The game is still the same though.

After not playing Settlers for ten years or so, and playing it 4 times in a month, I think I'm a bit Settler'd out. It's a good game, but it's definitely been surpassed (for me) in complexity and fun by later games.

UPDATE: I think I've identified what "gets me" about Settlers. If you are the player that falls behind -- and there's almost always a player that falls behind -- there is very little you can do to dig your way out of the hole you're in. In the rare game that doesn't have this happen -- like the game I played tonight, which ended with 9-8-7 points -- the game is a fun contest all the way through, but boy does it suck to be the pre-destined loser.

4/2012: Updated rating to be more realistic. Settlers is still quite a good game, even if it's not one I want to play a lot of.

RATING: 10
I rarely see true mastery in game design, but, at least in my opinion, Settlers of Catan has it. The game is based enough on luck that a newbie can reasonably have a chance but based enough on skill that experienced players will have the edge. The social aspect of this game is brilliant. Half the fun is not spent actually playing the game, but rather playing with friends or complete strangers and making stupid jokes about "building a walmart" that "buys out the other settlements". If you can, purchase this game. You won't regret it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
Lots of conversation with this game, can be very fun, but it is also possible to get shut down early. Dice are so fickle, we can have a whole game where 11 or 3 or ? isn't rolled, or 5 is rolled only three times ... it can drive you insane.

I know I have not played this very much, but I don't think I ever want to play it again. I have found something worse than a runaway leader - a completely equal game, where no one really becomes 'the threat'; I was surprised how tedious that situation was.

In the end my biggest problem with settlers is not the dice directly, but the lack of viable long term strategy.  This is another per-turn optimization game.  For some unknown reason, as much as I hate its problems, I'll keep playing it.

RATING: 7.5

The game can be played with 2-4 players (where 3 players is optimal between spacial and crowded), takes about 60-90 minutes. The game is charming and fun but after couple of plays You might want to go for something more complex.

RATING: 7

To play quickly, you have to realize when, no matter how trade you can do, you can't do anything and will have to pass. Also, initial placement is *critical*, as is early expansion (and block opponents growth). So it can be clear early on that you are boned, but you still have play the game out until an opponent gets 10 VP.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great game to be played with friends & family (you can play it with a 12 yo kid, no problem).

It has an interesting replayability. The game mechanism is fairly simple:

You start with setting 2 cities on 2 ressources (on the board obviously), then it goes:
- Throw the die
- Collect ressources (everybody who has a building on the collectable ressources)
- Trade with the other players if needed
- Expand your roads, build a new city or buy a special card
- Repeat until you win 12 victory points (by creating cities and having specific cards)

The good point of this game is that even if it is not your turn, you can partially play by collecting ressources.

And this is the strength of Catan: No one gets bored!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Since re-discovering boardgames about a year ago, after a gap of 25 or so years, I've encountered many superb games, some that are so-so, and a few stinkers. This is easily the worst. All it takes is a string of unlucky dice rolls at the start and you're knackered for the whole game. Other players will move ahead and their success breeds more success. I wouldn't say that the winner is determined in the first few rounds, but the loser usually is. It is much like Monopoly in that respect.
I simply do not think this works as a four player game, the board is too small and one player, the one who is unlucky with the early dice, will inevitably find that they're boxed in, unable to expand. The game is slightly better with three players but the in-built problem caused by being at the mercy of the dice remains. I've played Settlers of Catan a dozen or so times and in almost every game there has been one player who sits there turn after turn unable to do anything useful, forced to continue the game knowing they have no chance of winning. In that respect it is unlike Monopoly, which at least eliminates the players in the worst positions. 
It is wrong to consider this a gateway game. Yes, it is simple, but for at least one player sitting round the table it is likely to be the most tediously frustrating game imaginable. The experience, I would have thought, would be capable of putting newcomers to boardgames off for life. 
And don't even get me started on that chuffing robber.
Update. OK, I've given this a load more tries. My rating of 2 remains if this is played with 4 people, but I'd increase it to 5 if playing with 3.
Further update. Seafarers of Catan rescues this. Rating with this expansion: 6.5.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
2005-2006-ban a Carcassone mellett ez volt a másik játék, amit az "újabbak" közt volt szerencsém kipróbálni (új alatt azt értem, hogy nem activity és társai). Rám a kettő közül ez volt nagyobb hatással. Számomra addig ismeretlen elemek (pl. az alkudozás, a nyersanyagszerzési mód, stb.) nagyon színessé és vonzóvá tették a játékot, annak ellenére, hogy nem igazán voltam benne jó. Mára kicsit megkopott a varázsa, sok jobbat láttam már, de most is szívesen játszanék fele, főleg hogy van egy kiegem, amit még nem próbáltam!
---
Kipróbáltam a kieggel is. Nos nem rossz játék ez a Catan, de így hogy több mint 400 féle játékot ismerek, azt mondom, hogy vannak abból az időszakból olyanok, amik sokkal jobban kiállták az idő próbáját (El Grande, Tigris, Hannibál), bár a felsoroltak mindegyike eleve komolyabb játék, mint ez. Ma már csak nosztalgikus okokból ülök le a Catanhoz.
---
Újra előkerült, ebből is látszik, hogy még ennyi játék ismeretében sem zárkózom el tőle, de azért már nem az a megkerülhetetlen játék, ami 10 éve volt. Tegnap 2 partit játszottunk, és 10-8-4 ill. 10-4-4 lett az eredmény kb. azonos képességű játékosok közt (nem mindkétszer ugyanaz nyert, és nem is pont ugyanaz volt a játékosok összetétele). Ha az induló 2-2-2 pontokat nem számoljuk, akkor 8-6-2 illetve 8-2-2 a végeredmény. Az első parti másfél óra volt, a második 1 óra. Több játékossal simán lehet 2 óra feletti a játék, ehhez képest nevetségesen nagy a végeredményben mutatkozó különbség. A második partiban fél óra elteltével látszott, hogy ki lesz a győztes, és nem lehetett ellene mit tenni. Szerintem többek közt ezért áldozott le egy kicsit a Catan csillaga. De nosztalgiának továbbra is jöhet, csak fenntartásokkal fogom kezelni.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Played more times than I care to mention, and have used most of the expansions. A great game of expansion and resource management, with player interaction built in through resource trading.

A good quality product, easy to pick up, and has plenty of longevity. Laden with potential innuendo - the call of I got wood for sheep echoes around the gaming table every time this is played, which says more about our mental maturity than the game itself!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After all these years I still really like this game! The player interaction (trading, robber dynamics, etc.) is really the key to the fun here. There's no down time, because during any player's turn there can be haggling and extortion happening.

I think Settlers is at its best when played quickly with only 3-4 players and minimal add-ons.

Update: 4-16-2007
This is the game that got me into this hobby.  I loved it and even played this 2 player and still loved it.  I thought it was the greatest game ever in the world.  I don't know if it is a good or bad thing, but the aforementioned sentiments has passed.  I find the gameplay/strategies in this game to be elementary and dull.  Really, the only exciting thing going on the game is seeing where the dice will fall.  Those two bones greatly affect how you are going to do in the game.  Of course there are somethings you can do to help you out, but the luck in this game is significant.  This game is hard to rate as I respect it and have nostalgic baggage that comes with it but I just don't want to play it more than I have to.
Update: 9 -> 6

RATING: 9
Real fun game when played with the right people AND when you're not crunched on time. Game can go fast, but I've also had games go well over two hours due to randomized tile placement. The length isn't a bother for me, but I can see how it'd be a turn off for some. In regards to gameplay, it's an excellent game that utilizes dice rolling probability, hand management, resource gathering, and network building all very well. Difficulty is low and will forever be an enjoyable classic strategy game for any experience level. Recommended Players: 4.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An awesome game, and one I can definitely understand why it's called a modern classic!  Catan is a simple game to pick up, but has a great layer of strategy in terms of where to build to help you acquire resources, where to move the robber, and when to buy and play development cards.  You really can't stay out of each other's way in this game; if you want to win, you have to do some blocking and backstabbing, which makes the game a lot of fun.

My two slight knocks against the game are that the game is only for 3-4 players and requires hacks or expansions to do 2 or more than 4 players, and a blunder early on is typically so significant that, unless your opponents make a similar one, you will never recover and are just on a slow march to an inevitable loss.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Obligatory.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Quite simply, the best game I have ever played.

This was my first Eurogame and I am truthfully not sure if I would have become as hooked as I am now playing any other game.  I believe that this remains the best game to introduce nongamers to when trying to convert them to Eurogames.  Further, if the nongamer has a dice game background, such as Monopoly, it makes my argument stronger as they will be comfortable with the dice roll.  The rules are quite simple and after a ten minute quick explanation and quick couple of rounds, most newbies will have things down pat.

Settlers has some randomness to the game as resource production is determined through the roll of dice, but more often then not I find that the person who manages their resources best wins the game.  Trading plays a very important roll in this as people who are able to complete more trades improve their position more often then not.  This game is a lot of fun and very addicting!  A must have for every gamer and a great way to send you down the path of gaming for nongamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Interesting mechanics, but quite repetitive after a few games and I believe relied more than it should on luck. Still has some good moments.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The most interesting family game I have played so far. Simple rules, plenty of strategy, lots of interaction. Luck is a large factor, but can be overcome by skilled play. Nongamers love dice though, making this one of the best introductory games.

RATING: 10
This is the game that got helped me rediscover my love for boardgames.  Up until I played Catan (circa 2005) the games I mainly played were Risk!, Samurai Swords (Ikusa), and Strat-o-matic Bball.  Catan served its purpose well of a gateway game.  I played this game (usually 1-3 in one sitting) and its variants once a week with a gaming group (usually 4-6 players) for about 2 years.  Catan led me to playing other games from other publishers and is no longer played much at all.  Nonetheless, Catan is in my hall of fame.

RATING: 10

People say that Catan introduced concepts that other games have since perfected, but I can think of no others that balance all these facets so seamlessly. A classic for a reason.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Spiel des Jahres 1995[/b]
[b]Deutscher Spiele Preis 1995[/b]

[i]Posted: 10/2/04, Rated: 9[/i]

[i]The Settlers of Catan[/i] focuses on colony building and trading. There is no combat element to be found anywhere in this game, although a player can be a bit ruthless with the placement of the "bandit" piece. This lack of simulated armed conflict makes [i]Settlers[/i] an easy game to recommend for children.
 
The game board can be randomly created, which definitely adds to the game's replayability. Interaction between players is essential to winning this game -- another plus. Lastly, the resources are represented by cards, so there aren't any complex money transactions that would require a calculator to compute. 

[i]The Settlers of Catan[/i] offers innovative gameplay, is easy to understand, does not attempt to model violent conflicts, and above all is fun to play. I am looking forward to introducing many of my friends to this great game.

[i]Updated: 4/22/06, Rated: 8[/i]

[i]The Settlers of Catan[/i] was one of the first "Eurogames" that I played.  Since that time, I've developed a bit more perspective.  I still really like it, but it has lost some of its luster.  On your turn, a bad roll can benefit your opponents more than yourself.  Enough of those rolls, and the other players can prevent you from developing (with 3 or four players).  Trading in desperation just makes matters worse.  If this scenario happens to you, you're effectively removed from contention, sometimes very early in the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]Spiel des Jahres 1995[/b]
[b]Deutscher Spiele Preis 1995[/b]

[i]Posted: 10/2/04, Rated: 9[/i]

[i]The Settlers of Catan[/i] focuses on colony building and trading. There is no combat element to be found anywhere in this game, although a player can be a bit ruthless with the placement of the "bandit" piece. This lack of simulated armed conflict makes [i]Settlers[/i] an easy game to recommend for children.
 
The game board can be randomly created, which definitely adds to the game's replayability. Interaction between players is essential to winning this game -- another plus. Lastly, the resources are represented by cards, so there aren't any complex money transactions that would require a calculator to compute. 

[i]The Settlers of Catan[/i] offers innovative gameplay, is easy to understand, does not attempt to model violent conflicts, and above all is fun to play. I am looking forward to introducing many of my friends to this great game.

[i]Updated: 4/22/06, Rated: 8[/i]

[i]The Settlers of Catan[/i] was one of the first "Eurogames" that I played.  Since that time, I've developed a bit more perspective.  I still really like it, but it has lost some of its luster.  On your turn, a bad roll can benefit your opponents more than yourself.  Enough of those rolls, and the other players can prevent you from developing (with 3 or four players).  Trading in desperation just makes matters worse.  If this scenario happens to you, you're effectively removed from contention, sometimes very early in the game.

[i]Updated: 1/2/10, Rated: 9[/i]

Here we are in 2010, and I now own the 4th edition of [i]Settlers of Catan[/i].  I traded away my copy of the 3rd edition so that my set could be compatible with the version of [i][gameid=325][/i] which is currently available.  And I forgot how good this game really is.

Yes, I still get upset about poor rolls.  However, that frustration is due in part to poor planning: if I can branch out quickly enough, then I can settle on enough numbers to generate resources.  The social aspect of the game is also blossoming as my sons get older and more astute.  The game deserves a "9."

In fact, it might be a 10 if it weren't for the components.  The tiles in the 4th Ed. are thicker, but they need to be twice as thick as they are now to have an appropriate amount of "heft."  The frame is a great idea, but the "puzzle tabs" don't fit perfectly well together, and they feel as though they would fray over time.

I think a perfect version of the game would require two copies.  On every hex tile in one copy, cut/punch/route a hole for the roll marker.  Also take out little edges for half of a road.  Now, glue the tile onto it's matching (unmodified) mate from the second set.  You will now have tiles twice as thick, with the ability to "inset" the rolling markers and the roads.  Coming up with a shape that could accommodate both a settlement and a city at the corners would be difficult: the best shape I can think of would be a rectangle, but distributing its shape amongst the three corners of adjacent hex pieces would be difficult.

The cards are thinner stock than those found in the 3rd Ed.; this is the one place where the game falls short.  The cards aren't a size for which I have found a readily-available sleeve, either.  The four player colors are red, white. blue, and [i]orange[/i], which is surprising when green or yellow should have been readily available.  The robber is now grey instead of black.  The cards and colors were better in the 3rd Ed.

The 4th Ed. is still a better version overall, and the gameplay still shines.  Still, if a game is going to get the magical "10" then it needs to be perfect in every way.  [i]The Settlers of Catan[/i] just barely misses the mark.

[i]Updated: 6/23/17, Rated: 6[/i]

Wow, where has the time gone?  Almost seven and a half years since I last updated this rating.  And the real reason for the three-point drop is that the base game by itself is...well, I guess the best way to say it is that it's showing its age.

I still enjoy the engine-building aspect of the game.  I can even accept capricious resource gathering via dice rolling.  Being able to negotiate with the currently-active player every turn reduces down time.  The combination of those factors can create a game with doldrums if the other players unite against you.

[i]Catan[/i] with expansion(s) is a better experience, but the base game on its own has dropped down in comparison to more modern offerings.

RATING: 7
A relatively easy to learn game that is enjoyable to play and gives everyone a chance to do well. My biggest gripe with this game is that I've found myself really "well-diversified" on numbers which, seems like a really good thing until I lose all the cards in my hand just before my turn. If it happened only on occasion or if I was hoarding resources it'd be easier to tolerate but sometimes it seems like it can happen every-other-turn or more and I try to use most/all of my resources on each turn. 

Besides my nit-picking there, this game really does well at rewarding good strategy and is enjoyable with a group.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Settlers is great for its accessibility to new players and the way the game encourages player interaction. The variable board setup adds replayability and long-term interest, while the (mostly) static number arrangement ensures the probabilities are always balanced, even when some resources are scarce. The element of luck can be overly strong at some times, particularly if one player gets a string of bad rolls at the beginning of the game. In other games (Tigris & Euphrates, Puerto Rico, etc.), the player can always take some productive action even when luck is not on his side; in Settlers, the player simply cannot act. I would like to see an official way to mitigate bad luck, but some version of the '[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/150443/the-famous-welfare-variant]welfare variant[/url]' should work well enough. While I appreciate that trading keeps players engaged, I do not enjoy the mechanic as much as other modes of player interaction, as I feel like I have to 'act' in order to play well. For this reason, the game isn't at the top of my list, but I do enjoy playing it with the right group. [8] (2012-03-23)

After many more plays of Settlers, my appreciation for the game -- and rating -- has improved greatly. Strings of good/bad luck can still hurt, but with good placement (diverse numbers) and repeated play, I don't see it as a major flaw in the game; rather, it is most often the result of a flaw in a player's initial placements. Sometimes it's not, but that's to be expected in a game with dice, and it's not likely to happen again in the next game (or if it does, it's an indication that the fault may in fact be with the player). I will now gladly recommend Settlers and will play it any time I am offered the chance to do so, especially with 4 players (3 is also ok; 5 and 6 work but 4 is preferable). I appreciate the fact that though the game is fairly simple (very few rules) and repetitive (each turn offers the same single mandatory action and few voluntary actions, compared to worker placement or role selection games), the game is still tense and exciting due to the competition for key settlement spots, the need to make a critical trade, and the fear of letting one player get too much of a lead before others are positioned to catch up. A great design worthy of all the praise it has received. [8 -> 10] (2014-01-22)

RATING: 3
Quick to learn and launch into. I have played this c6 times and now believe the moves and strategies to be substantially driven by the dice and much more than I originally thought. Admittedly things do tend to generally balance and strange dice result frequencies do occur, but I see it as a significant weakness in the game that players can sit around for 10 minutes (worst case 1 hour!) unable to make progress owing to none of their territories producing through weird dice rolls. Its a case of frantic activity or complete shut down. If this happens at the early development stage it is near impossible for a player to pull it back. I realised very slowly that I really dislike this aspect of any game and would need substantial persuasion to play this again so mark down to 4.

Years pass and I really dislike the dice mechanic for this game. Reduce rating to 3.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Still one of the best gateway games but it shows its age. It was what got me (and many many others) into gaming so I respect it for that. It has two significant flaws however: 1)you can practically lose the game before it even starts by choosing bad starting spots. This shouldn't be a problem for experienced players but it's a flaw that a "gateway" game shouldn't have. And 2) you live and die from the dice rolls especially in the beginning stages of the game. Getting an early advantage by building more cities/settlements (which then generate more resources) before others can is pretty huge.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It gets a 6 from me because in it's heyday, sometime in the mid 90's, it would have been a 9, and now I will never play it again if I can help it, so I will settle in for a 6.  Not offensive, but not gushing, either.  Classic gameplay, with classic rules that opened a whole new world to me, and spawned the creation of Robespierre the Thief.  Also "Help Me" spelled out by Ziskin.

RATING: N/A
Catan used to be one of my favorite games, but it has since lost some of its luster with me and my group. Too much randomness in what is a fairly deep strategy game (randomness is good in a light "filler" type of game), trading seems lackluster with some groups (no fault of the game, but my group) and there's too much importance with initial placement of your villages when you don't even know what tiles are coming out. Ready to trade this with my expansions. I own the red box Mayfair edition (the one with the "pilgrim" looking folks on the cover).

RATING: 6
I've played this on various computer games, and it's always bored the living whiz out of me.  ALWAYS.

But, hundreds of thousands of copies sold can't be wrong, right?

EDIT:  Played this and had a great time.  It did run a little long even for as reasonably streamlined as our turns were, but that was nothing that couldn't be solved by say, playing to 8 rather than 10.

What I really liked about it, is if I had to come up with one game that encompassed all that it meant to be a game, with negotiation, strategy, and luck in all equal parts...  this would be that game.

08-15-11:  This game always takes just a hair longer than it aught to.  It's probably me that causes it, too.  In the end though, I'd rather play almost anything else.

Oh, and grind the development stack.  You can't go wrong.

SOLD.

09-18-11:  I think one of the things about this game going too long, is that it's a bit of a fractal representation of everyone on the board.  That is, the story doesn't really ever arc even as a winner is emerging.  People still trade, because it's helping their individual positions anyway.  The guy on the board who is getting the most shit, will find a way to get even more shit just as well getting his 10th point as he is getting his 7th point.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Brilliant--extremely fun and a model for combining social interaction and strategy in a game.  The rulebook is obtuse, this is best learned by playing.

Those with some appreciation for economics will also love how features of real markets--profit, fluctuating prices, and comparative advantage--emerge without being dictated in the rules.

Get the 5-6 player expansion and use it even for 4-player games; the more open island keeps players who get off to a slow start from becoming frustrated in their attempts to build.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Brilliant.  A model for including social interaction in a strategy game.  Extremely fun even for first-time players.  The rulebook is a bit obtuse--teach new players by including them in the game.

Play with the 5-6 player expansion, when playing with 4 or more players, and use the rule that allows players to build (in sequence) on every turn.  This prevents players off to a slow start--or the last in line--from being frustrated, and makes for a more balanced game.

Those with some appreciation of modern economics will be delighted by the emergence during the game of features of real-world markets, such as fluctuating prices, comparative advantage, and profit.  This changes by end-game when players start to worry about someone winning and start working to thwart one another.  Perhaps there's a lesson in that. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
The production values are average and the gameplay isn't terribly diverse, but the randomly assigned board makes each game exciting and different. Players need to plan for VP growth as well as expansion in order to get to the better resources before their rivals or so as not to get webbed into a corner. Haggling with friends (or frenemies) in order to get resources to flip a wasted turn into something productive is always fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
This will always hold a special place. It's a timeless classic that has its share of flaws, but it really has helped bring a lot of people into modern board gaming. It's fun to play once in a blue moon, especially as a gateway for non-gamers and new gamers. It's tense with hoping for certain resource numbers to appear, racing to take space before your opponents, and pushing your luck with hand size limits and the robber. It's interactive through negotiating trade with your opponents and through the building race.

To help mitigate the overly swingy luck factor that I find to be the biggest flaw, I like to use a stack of cards with perfect probability distribution instead of dice, and also a board setup calculated for fairness by the Better Settlers website. (Side note:  I had a friend who was opposed to this deliberate balancing saying it was out of the spirit of the game, but then the game we played ended up with final scores of 9-9-9-10. I have never seen a 4 player game so close! Everyone was one turn away from victory.) The kingmaking aspect can get a little mean, so hopefully players don't take it personally.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I'm gratified that this game has finally broken into the mainstream...15 years after it was developed.  This gives me hope that better games like Puerto Rico will eventually be in every household.

I admire Settlers for what it did for the board-gaming hobby, but it's not a great game.  The majority of time, you're going through scripted motions and waiting for the dice to fall.  There's little tactical variability, little need to be adaptive -- the whole game plays out on the basis of just a handful of key decisions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Although it is starting to age, but I have only played one of the expansions once, and it did bring great flavour to it.

RATING: 8.4
Ah Catan, the gateway game.  Solid game for family gaming and initial entry into board games.  Start with two towns and roads with limited resources, expand your roads, build more towns and upgrade to cities to accrue more resources on each random resource roll.  Interact with other players to trade resources.  For me, this game was best with the knights and cities upgrade.

RATING: 6
This is one of the first board games of the new generation that I played, cuz that's what everyone said to do.  It's an okay game, but since, I've played many a better game.

UPDATE:  Lowered from an 8 because, since moving on to more euro games, I've NEVER come back to this...not once.  And, since becoming more aware of the current board-game scene, I can't believe so many people consider a game so heavily based on player-to-player free-form trading to be such a good gateway game.  I often times have a tough time getting my "non-gamers" to follow the very specific basic rules of a game, let alone making up free-form trade offers based on resource needs that they don't understand yet.

RATING: 4
There’s little new to say about the Settlers of Catan, one of the most successful and played games of all times, the one that shares with Carcassonne the honour of having changed - for the worse - the way games are made and played today: as the father of all eurogames, Settlers is the «game for everyone» par excellence, as it’s easy enough to grasp, fairly quick to play, moderately fun and it even requires a pinch of strategy; sadly though it’s boring, themeless and devoid of any real interaction among players as well, let alone ramdomness. [i](November 2011)[/i]

[b]Update[/b] - Although it makes for a decent gateway game (but there are many more better at that), I still can’t stand Catan and shun it whenever I can: this is why during my Fall 2015 rating revise I lowered its rating to 4, which better reflects my feeling towards it.

Not a huge fan of the expansions that add more players, or that make the game more complicated, but the Traders and Barbarians expansion adds little variants that keep the game fresh.

Brilliant game by a brilliant game designer.

RATING: 6
This is a game I used to *really like. It was my first intro to German-style gaming. It had innovative ideas, good production value and easy to learn/play rules. HOWEVER, after about 10+ games I started to resent the fact that Lady Luck decided the course of my production more than I did. Nor could I stand the tedious wait for game-end, if after set-up, I was barrred from growth by others' placements.

Sometimes, turns can take forever, making the wait to play between turns too long. This is because there are multiple actions a player can take on their turn, instead of just one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
With four players, this is about as perfect a game as I could hope for. I've lured more people into gaming with this game than anything else. My only complaint is if the ore and brick end up having rare numbers on them, you're going to be in for an excruciating game. Also, I've seen people through no fault of their own get boxed into an area and thus it becomes an impossibility for them to win (because there aren't enough victory points in the deck, and that ends up being their only option). That sort of thing doesn't bother me so much in conflict-oriented games, but in a game like Settlers, it can be a drag. Still, this game is usually a tremendously entertaining time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a classic, of course, and deserves praise for its innovations. My experience with this game is that it's very tense but not always for the right reasons. Randomness plays a big part in the resources available and the roll of the dice; the heavy negotiation of the game is driven by imbalances caused by the dice. The problem with the negotiation element - really the heart of the game when the endgame comes into view - is that games seem to be won when a player is led into misperceving that trades will allow another player to win. A mistake is made and the game is less won by the player than given to the player. The theme here is very, very weak and the whole exercise seems pretty dry which could have made up for some of my issues with gameplay.Generally, it's good but I'd prefer to play something else now that there are better options available.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This is one of the absolute classics that brought board gaming to a broader audience. So it has its place in board game history next to being an enormous commercial success. I rate it so low because I never really enjoyed playing it. My introduction to board games came from the likes of Kiesling, Kramer and Knizia and the luck ridden mechanics of Catan never appealed to me.

I don't like the fact that in a 4 player game, halfway through it's obvious which two players are going to win and which two players are out. There's negotiation to mitigate bad luck and lagging behind, but it strongly depends on the player group how this pans out.  

Ah well. Personal taste and all.

RATING: 8.15

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
50 plays:

Such elegant design! So few choices, but ones that matter! Such good use of randomness! Such simple compensation for being behind! Such pressure and reason to negotiate! So many ways to win! Just a perfect game, satisfying nearly every time I've ever played. It's true that if you aren't good at it, you won't win... that's not the same as "the player behind can't catch up".

And nearly immune to analysis paralysis, because so few options are open each turn. It can get a bit stuck in complex negotiation proposals.

Trying to play this with eight-year-olds showed me Catan's flaws, however. When the dice do nothing for you for several rounds, the game can get frustrating and boring. My daughter actually burst into tears at one point because she was getting so many sheep, and nothing but sheep!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4

At it's heart, it still relies more on that luck than on decisions.

There was a time when I loved this game.  But I know now that I was merely naive.  I've moved on, never to return again.

RATING: 7
評分:ForLight:8 ForHard:6.5 複雜度:4 互婊度:8

如果要擴廣紙板型桌遊給新手，我認為這是一個不錯的選擇。但對於老手來說骰子運氣因素過強，而且也有其他更好的選擇。

給新手：
1.最初的二間房子的佈置占了勝負的一半，另一半則是骰運，嘴炮能發揮的作用出奇的低。
2.怖局策略分類:
 木磚建築型：擴張速度高及可封殺其他玩家的出路，標準穩定的打法。
 麥石升級型：初期注重升級，後期注重抽牌的戰術，但房子提供的分數會不足，是否擁有第四個房子就成為勝負關鍵，個人最喜歡的戰術。
 平均發展型：最注重玩家交際手段的怖局法，上位時很容易被封殺，個人不推薦。
 交易自閉型：若地圖的狀況很差，在放第一個房子時達不到上述策略，就可以先選專攻其中一種作物，然後第二個房子直接放在相對應的海港上，作物優先度麥＞木＞羊，這種打法只要等其他玩家來求你換你手上的東西就好。
