=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Ubiquitous multi-player game that is social enough and non-warlike enough that you might be able to convince your wife or girl-friend to play with you. The game is driven by rolling two D6 at the start of each player's turn that will determine which players will collect the various resources that are needed to build the structures in the game that you use to expand and produce victory points.

The game is therefore highly unpredictable, and can be frustrating when the dice behave as dice will. I would be less down on the randomness quotient if it played more quickly; but if you are unlucky early, you are in for a long night with little chance of recovery!

I have about exhausted the novelty this game once presented to me. The one line description I recently read, "lightly themed Yahtzee," pretty much sums it up for me...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
The game that started it all for me.  Found this on Xbox Live and ended up playing it all the time.  My other 60 dollar games collected dust. That game led me to this site, which led to my new boardgame obsession, which led to the Dark Side..and so on and so on.  I hesitate to give a game a 10 but according to the info on ratings: "Outstanding.  Always want to play and expect that will never change."  This is true for me with this game.  Unfortunately most of my gaming is 2 player, and the 2 player variants aren't nearly as enjoyable to me.  Fortunately the Xbox AI on hard is a good challenge, plus there's always live opponents..so when I need my fix I can get it.

Edited three years later from original comments above:  The game is no longer a 10 for me.  When I first got it it was really my only exposure to this type of board game.  Now that I've acquired and played many more games poor old Catan has kind of been left behind.  Still, for sheer nostalgia alone I still give this game an 8.

Rating lowered to a 6.  All of the above still apply but I would add the following.  Never play any flavor of SoC with more than 4.  More than that and the game breaks down to the point of boredom. RATING: 9
After more than 500 games played (mostly online), I can say that for experienced player this game is very well balanced. It's all about where you put your first settlements: if you know what you're doing, you cannot made a mistake.
Once you figure out what numbers can roll how often, even the dice doesn't add to randomness to much. It can surprise sometimes, but for me that's one of the joys of this game (I'll always remember game where we had like 6 two rolled and one 6 :D ).

It was still kind of fun, not a problem per se, just seemed to fill some nice in gaming culture that I never quite understood. I was playing Um Reifenbreite around the same time and somehow it appealed to me a lot - even mor eluck, but it never pretended otherwise, nor drew a huge following of worshippers and torunaments at game cons and so on, just a plain simple luck fest of a cycle racing game ;-)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
One of the first Euro-style games I've played, and it is still one of the best introductory board games out there. It offers a great balance of luck and skill – but that isn't to say the dice can completely ruin a game's fun.

I love that the game offers a way to mitigate the amount of luck involved by allowing players the opportunity to spread their settlements across all options, granting them access to each of the possible die rolls. Trading is fun and keeps players interacting with one another. 

The modular board creates a new game every time.

Really, this game covers a lot of aspects that are present in hundreds of Euro-style games. If I have a friend who wants to get into board games, I will almost always introduce them to this one first.

S | 3-4  (*)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Like a lot of gamers out there, I owe a great debt to Catan. It is one of the reasons I got into boardgaming in the first place.

And that's probably the best thing about Catan: its simple rules, attractive components, short play time, fun trading mechanic, and rather friendly atmosphere mean that Catan is a superb introduction to the wonderful world of boardgaming. There's also relatively little down time in Catan, as you can potentially collect resources on anyone's turn (and turns don't take very long, anyway.) It can hold people's attention.

For the veteran board gamer, however, Catan falls short. Everything is really chance-dependent. That's not necessarily a deal-breaker (I love Eldritch Horror, after all!) but the problem is that there is a paucity of interesting decisions to be made. After you've picked where your first two settlements are, there's basically nothing you can do to tilt the odds further in your favor. The opening setup is interesting and requires a lot of thought, but after that you more or less sit back and let the dice happen. 

There's also a bad snowball effect--the player who is able to grab additional early settlements and cities (i.e., the player who had lucky early die rolls) stands the best chance of getting even more resources, and so forth. This can somewhat be rectified by all the other players refusing to trade with the leading player--but then a core mechanic of the game is destroyed if the players aren't trading. 

All in all, Catan will always have a soft spot in my heart as an excellent introduction to boardgaming. But once that introduction has been made, Catan itself can be left behind.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This is a remarkable gateway game.  Easy to learn and addictive.  Lots of chance and easily suffers from analysis paralysis, but those negatives don't overshadow the simple fun and tension this game creates.  My sister-in-law gave this to us many years ago, and it definitely elevated all of our board gaming interest to a new level.  We played like 80 games of it that first year.  Now, the original pales in comparison to the Seafarers expansion, which provides for the same gameplay with infinite board varieties.  Still, we always introduce the original first to friends, and we've introduced numerous friends to this.  A great game, especially for casual or newer gamers.

RATING: 6
Traded away 9/14

I can see why this kicked off the German Game craze, but for me it's just not that fun. In a 4-player game, 1 player inevitably gets stuck at 4 VP's, doesn't produce much, and sits there with almost nothing to do for 45+ minutes. Not a great time.

With 3 players the board is more open, but trading is harder with only 2 trading partners.

With 5, the board is once again open, but building on every turn makes the 7-card max basically worthless

6 is too long and too crowded.

Cities/Knights is excruciatingly long, and Seafarers adds some stuff that's basically the same as the base game, only played on blue hexes.

Cant see what the big fuss is about? The luck factor is huge. Chuck the dice, hope the fruit machine comes up all cherries for you, then pull your cards and unleash them on someone at the table you don't like. Nice hey? The game is entertaining and simple to play with a slick German design theme, which explains why so many people like it, but once again, little or no control over your destiny etc. Not much to be gained from this from anyone looking for a serious gaming experience. Must however be given credit for being one of the first Euro games that attracted a lot of new gamers to the hobby.

RATING: 4
The low rating for me is due to a few things. First, I dislike the setup time for this game. Second, table bumps can ruin this game. I don't like games that play better with expensive third party accessories (like a hex grid that the pieces can fit into to prevent jostling). Third, the game plays a little too simply for my tastes. And finally, it doesn't play well at two-player in my opinion. That is not a direct fault of the game, but as I play much of my games at 2 player, this falls flat in that area. I have little desire to play this and never suggest it on game nights.

RATING: 8
Ah, how many Thanksgiving weekends have I spent playing game after game of Settlers? There are certain people with whom I am always willing to play this game. I think I prefer to play with three players; with three, it's easy to win with only the simple strategy of making sure your starting locations cover all five resources. It becomes more challenging with more players--however, the potential for getting "locked in" to one corner of the board also increases.

RATING: 7
The one that started my "modern era" of boardgaming for me, and I still enjoy it, in spite of fairly frequent play.  What caught my attention immediately was the lack of downtime. Even if it wasn't your turn, you were actively involved in resource gathering and trades -- pretty revolutionary at the time.  Also the first modern game I got my parents to play willingly.  Pretty much the prototype of "make the best of what you get" games, which I particularly enjoy.

RATING: 6.75

Once you know you're just not going to win, it's a 30-60 minute grind of rolling, trading and building in a futile attempt to salvage something from a lost position. It is a good game though, I just have many better games to choose in a situation where Catan would be played.

RATING: 10
SoC isn't a perfect game.  It's not even a game that I like to play often.  A string of dice rolls that go in someone's favor will almost always give them the game since the rich get richer.  However, no other game I have has as much power to pull in non-gamers.  SoC's blend of building, trading, and conquering new territory is amazingly engaging for most people.  It's not until you've played it several times that its flaws appear, but by that time you can migrate budding gamers over to Puerto Rico.  ;-)

Apr 2011: Traded this away for Dice Town.

RATING: 6.5
Settlers is fun.  I know it's a landmark game, but I have to admit the more I play it the less I like it.  Maybe I've just had odd games, but so much depends on the dice rolls and the game can quickly become very boring if your numbers just won't come up (even if you've positioned well!).  So much is determined by the initial placement that, having played it a few times, it often feels like we're just playing out a predetermined script after the first settlements go down.

RATING: 10
THE classic game of the 90's. Belongs in every game collection. I still play this fairly often - just the basic game alone has surely cracked 100 plays, and throw in all the variants and expansions and this is an incredible system.
---
Version Notes: Overall, I think the 2005-ish re-issue of Die Siedler von Catan from Kosmos - featuering plastic pieces - is the most attractive, funcational version of the game. It has bright, pleasing graphics, the smaller resource cards are easy to manage, and the plastic inserts are the most functional inserts ever for a game. It is in German, though. But every version has its charms, even going back to the borderline-ugly Mayfair 1st and 2nd printings (the ones that used photos - I don't actually own either of those printings, but I'd like to just to add to my collection). The 2007 Mayfair edition (the bigger box) is probably the nicest version that Mayfair has done, and is comparable and even superior in some ways to the 2005 Kosmos edition, the first time Mayfair has gone their own way  and done something at least as good as Kosmos. It also has the advantage of being in English. I generally like Mayfair's 3rd printing better than most players - I think it's a nice, distinct set with its own flavor apart from the other versions - but I'd also agree that it's overall not as graphically effective as the other versions, being a little dark.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This was my introduction to german style games.  At the time, it was amazing.  It'll probably always have a bit of a soft spot in my heart.  

But now that I have more experience with the hobby, I just don't find the game that entertaining.  The "gateway" nature of the game means I usually only play with non-gamers.  That in turn means that the game is usually filled with frustrating distractions, confusion, and interminable trading phases.  Although I have no issue with the die rolling (even though I'm not usually a die-rolling person), I don't like the table-talk and kingmaking that the Robber induces on frequent sevens.  It's essentially a decent light Eurogame with some of my least favorite aspects of Monopoly and Risk tacked on.

With beginners, I'd rather play Ticket to Ride.  With gamers, I'd rather play something with more strategy and depth.  

Also, this game has been know to start nasty fights if played while intoxicated.

RATING: 4
The first Eurogame I ever played is still one of my favorites. There is a slight problem in the game with The Robber remaining in one place for too long (if a seven isn't rolled, it's difficult - though not impossible to move him) which can take away from the fun of the game for whoever is unlucky enough to have a settlement near him. Overall, the game is a fascinating and exciting tile-based game.

Update: Lowered my rating from 7 to 6. This was my first Euro and I have many fond memories of it, but I've found many other far superior games since and I can't say I've wanted to play Catan very often recently. I actually enjoy the two player card game much more than the original.

Update: Lowered my rating from 6 to 4 after a recent play. This game relies far too much on dice which can present the unfortunate situation of sitting around turn after turn with nothing to do. And while many people have commented on the luck of the dice, might I just add that working your ass off to collect three ore and then getting a worthless soldier card from the random-draw resource deck doesn't help the game. I have a hard time imagining myself wanting to pull this off the shelf again anytime soon. I'll always be thankful to this game for introducing me to the wider world of board games, but there are much better games out there and I can't see myself wanting to play this again.

I think the expansions changed that feeling. You have more control on you destiny, there are more ways to win. I enjoy playing Seafarers expansion. I wouldn't play without it now.

A good introduction game for new players.

I have a mixed feeling about this game. Still eager to play when someone suggests it... but do not enjoy every game of it.

RATING: 7
I use this game as an introduction to board gaming as it is such an easy game to pick up. The game works best with 3 players as 4 can be a bit crowded, but it also works with 2 players. To do this you create 2 separate islands with the same resources and same odds but with different merchants. When a 7 is rolled, instead of using the robbers, switch merchants. This works really well as the merchants allow for a HUGE advantage. 

A fun game to play for a few rounds, however after that game play can get a bit repetitive. 

Fun game with an unexpected amount of strategy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A classic that should be in the top ten. Many NEWNEWNEWBUYBUYBUYERS find this game 'dated', which is absurd really. Dated in what sense? How? Not only do I owe Settlers my entire existence as a game hobbyist, but it is a fantastic game that manages to appeal to both the strategic gamer and those who have only played mainstream games. As the groupthink wheel slowly turns and the NEWNEWNEWERS get sick of the 10-mechanics-and-a-pasted-theme Euros, when the simple, elegant loveliness of the classic Euros comes back in fashion, Settlers will return, slaughter the suitors and reclaim its crown. 

I love the dice. They add a tension and risk management to what might otherwise have been a dull resource conversion game (as if we need another one of those). 

COPY AND PASTE FROM MY GEEKLIST RANT:

Settlers of Catan's slide towards the bottom of the top 100 is proof again of the silliness of BGG's ratings system and its bias in favor of new-and-shiny games over the classics. Like Monopoly (which is also much better than BGG gives it credit for), Chess, and dozens of other older games, Settlers of Catan's popularity, age, and ubiquity work against it having a higher rating, but it is still one of the best introductory games and one of my favorite Eurogames. 

The saturated, consumerist board game market, with dozens of new releases every week, encourages players to shallowly rate games after one or two plays--which makes no sense since it often takes several plays to internalize the rules for even a simple game to the point where a player can focus on actually playing the game well. Market saturation encourages us to "take his word for it" and rate with the group (many members of which will be doing the same thing) so we that can unwrap the next package. 

Coupled with the saturated market is BGG's stranglehold on board game culture. The dominance of one information-outlet is not conducive to a free thinking environment, even in the case of user-generated content websites like BGG. A glimpse through the comments section for any top-100 game shows that raters are often repeating or paraphrasing the comments and judgements of other raters. Absolute democracy, which under-informed (because few of us have time enough to play any but our favorite games more than once or twice), user-generated content websites often resemble, encourages groupthink and the tyranny of the single persuasive voice. The practice that a few well known "game critics" have of passing judgement or rating games after a single play is intellectually dishonest and ethically suspect. 

Don't get me wrong, I love BGG and spend too much time here looking for new games, but the ratings system has never been much use to me beyond providing a starting point for game research. Giving anything but the most minor significance to which game lies where on the scale is the equivalent of basing judgements of worth and value on the results of a popularity contest. 

A thousand unwise voices rolled into one do not necessarily become one wise voice. It's too bad that Settlers may not show up on the first page of the top 100; it is a fantastic game, and one that I will play any time and anywhere.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
N/A
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I came to Settlers maybe a year or two into my gaming career, and as such, I think I have a very different view of the game whose first great gaming love was Settlers.

I've just never really enjoyed playing it. But I think I understand the game's popularity. It meshes together several different mechanics (one of which, importantly, is trading) in a simple and clean package, with enough luck that even new players can win. I can see how coming from a lifetime of Parker Bros. games this feels like the pinnacle of gaming.

As I said above, I think one of the reasons this game is so beloved is that it incorporates trading. There are plenty of trading games out there, but often that's ALL they are. Settlers, to this day, is one of the few games that is a hybrid board manipulation/building and trading game. I wish there were more games like this - I really believe trading being a part of a bigger whole is what has made this game so irreplaceable for many, many people.

That said, trading is one of the reasons I don't enjoy Settlers. Trading feels incredibly limited here - most of the time, people don't have anything to trade you, and if they do, they might have one of it and you just make very straightforward trades. You almost never have the opportunity to feel like you've got the upper hand on someone, like you're sneakily making a really excellent trade for yourself, or like you're making a bad trade for you because you're desperate for something (this really only happens if people have been denying you because you're in the lead). It's just too cut and dry for my tastes. Hell, Bohnanza has more variable and exciting deals.

I do like that resources always feel scarce and valuable. In my experience, you never tend to stockpile resources like you do in other games so losing a resource always feels like it's doing real harm.

But to me, it's always felt like the most interesting choice you make is made at the beginning when you place your initial settlements, and after that you're at the mercy of the dice (your rolls and other people's). It really feels like the die is the determining factor all too often (and the game runs too long for me to be okay with that). It's pretty easy for one player to get locked out of winning the game early on due to some bad rolls, and then just have to sit there watching everyone else expand. Blech.

And then there's the games that run some three hours for no good reason. Ughhhh.

I can be talked into playing this, but really, I'd be happy to never play again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Ah yes ... Klaus Teuber's smash hit, The Settlers of Catan (or as I like to call it, "Rolling for Resources").  The overwhelming influence of luck in this game really limits one's ability to strategize or make meaningful choices in general.  Resource collection is slow and painful, determined primarily by dice rolling and to a lesser extent, by whether one can entice others to trade.  Based on what one manages to collect and hold on to (keeping in mind that one is fucked over periodically by the robber), it is usually very obvious on any given turn what one should build/do.  Yes, I understand that this might seem overly simplistic, that there are multiple strategies to earning victory points besides building/upgrading settlements, such as vying for "Longest Road" or "Largest Army", or gathering Development cards, but which of these options can be pursued effectively comes down to the roll of the dice.  Perhaps the variety of potential choices is part of the appeal for gamers, while the simplified decision-making makes this fun for non-gamers as well.  In summary, a very overrated game, but still worthy of respect, since it has introduced many a gamer to the wide world of (far better) Euro games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
decent game, but nothing special.  I don't enjoy the type of interaction with trading the cards.  The interaction is similar to bohnanza in a way.  The use of dice combined with the trading aspect make this game for casual gamers.  There isn't much strategy involved and the players don't have much control over the anything unless they are willing to form alliances, collude with other players, be well liked enough.  3 of the most important aspects (trading of supplies, moving the robber, rolling of dice) are out of the player's control to an extent, which is why I don't care much for the game.  If I had to play this game as a gateway game to introduce boardgames to friends, I would.  That's about the only time I would be interested though.

I can be persuaded to play it again if I'm in the right mood, but I would rather play something else as I think that there are lot of other better eurogames out there!

RATING: 7
This was one of the first games that got us into the hobby. A visiting friend brought it while in town on the Fourth of July in 2009. We loved the game and in fact made a copy ourselves which got a few plays. Eventually we forgot about the game until we discovered the full depth of board games at Free Comic Book day at our FLCGS. We were excited to get a copy of Settlers as a wedding present in 2011; however, with so many other games we rarely get this to a table. It is still in the collection for when people we meet and become friends with mention "Have you heard about this game called Settlers of Something?". We can pull it out and show them before moving on to another gateway game that we enjoy more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The game that started all of this, well, for me anyway!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is simply a classic.  No other game changed board gaming more than Catan.  Without this game most of us would never have gotten into modern board gaming.

This is also the most deceptively cut throat euro out there.  For a game with "no conflict", I have seen more arguments and hurt feelings during this game than any other I've played.  And it's awesome.  I may not be able to attack you directly, but when I cut you off with my roads and then refuse to trade you that wheat you need after I played the "Monopoly" card and took all of yours...classic.

This game gets a lot of hate, but there is a reason so many people have played it.  The most common criticism is that initial placement is the most important aspect and then it's all luck and dice rolls.  I disagree.  This is a negotiation game.  All other game mechanics revolve around the trade mechanic.  Victory or defeat is all based on how well you can trade and convince other players to give you the resources you need to win.  If you play thinking that you can ignore this and win through mechanics alone, you are playing wrong.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
a classic

RATING: 7

Catan opened up the Euro gaming world to me. The strategy and gameplay really interested me to this whole new genre.

I still enjoy playing on occassions. It's not really a game that makes it out of the closet as much, maybe once every couple months. I enjoy the strategy factor combined with the luck factor Catan offers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5

However, it can't be denied that for many of us on the geek, this game is probably what brought us here in the first place. Very fun, very social, great combination of luck and planning, the perfect gateway game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My criterion for rating games



http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/147053/item/2300390#item2300390


1) Sense of wonder: Game changes each time with different strategies and initial placement of colonies and roads.

2) Meaningful/fun decisions. Lots of resource and card management. Throughout the game there are a lot of lucky dice rolls, but how you deal with the resources you have and trading will determine how well you do.

3) Player interaction:  Lots of player interaction with the dice rolls and trading as well as blocking on the board.

4) Components/artwork: Great components and the board if very cool.

5) Game length/complexity: Good game length. It can drag on at times and dice rolls will not go your way can be frustrating. However you can lower vp total if you want a quicker game. 


Bottom Line: FUN way to spend an evening. You can easily teach it to new players and there is some strategy and tough decisions as well as great fun as you roll dice and keep getting a "12" :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
This game is a classic!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is one of my favorites to bring out when there are 3 or 4 players at my house.  An excellent game that involves a touch of strategy, a forward-thinking perspective, and a lot of player interaction.

I only use the Event Cards for this - I think it speeds the game up by quite a bit, as there is the possibility with a few of the cards to reward EVERYONE playing with a resource card - which is usually a good thing.

This is one of the few games out there that can be played "AS IS".  What I mean by that is that there is no need for any house rules or other variants.  It is a very well balanced and finely designed game that does not need tweaking or modifications to make it play "better".  Not saying that is bad, but if you don't like to have to keep track of a bunch of house rules (Monopoly, Descent, etc.), then this game is perfect for you.

This game is also single-handedly responsible for the worst one-line cliche in all of gamedom - "I have wood for your sheep."  Although it is still funny to say, even if you aren't a Beavis and Butthead type fan.

Update: traded away along with the 5-6 expansion for Pandemic.

RATING: 8
My copy was the village bicycle for awhile when I was in college; it was probably played by upwards of 50 different people *before* I became more serious about board games.  Fortunately, it's still complete and in surprisingly good shape (worn, but not unplayably so).  As with many other gamers of my generation, this was the first German board game that I played.  I still enjoy it quite a bit, but since I've overplayed it to some extent, I don't like playing it more than once a month or so.  This 8 rating is more historic than anything else, at least at this time.

I found a copy of someone's math problem set in the box (ACM95, for friends reading this to whom that might have meaning).  It was there for at least 2 years before I found it.  I hope the guy didn't have to redo the whole homework set.

RATING: 3

RATING: 4.5
So Much praised, that I finally bought it:

Another major drawback for me is the excessive importance of the dice.
Overall Catan is more a mass-market not-very-balanced-and-enjoyable family game (like Risk or Monopoly) than a true beautiful and enjoyable eurogame.

RATING: 6
This is a fun and easy to teach game.  Yet it can be unbalanced in favor of the player or two who get to place their settlements first.  Often the board layout is such that a few prime locations exist, with valuable geography under high probability numbers.  Players choosing later can be very hard pressed to win.  Add to this a rich-get-richer problem, and the source of our love-hate relationship with this classic become clear.

Most games have some element of chance, this game seems to exaggerate the role of chance.  I think the initial setup is a huge part of this exaggeration.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.3
Main Positives: Attractive game! Even the components for certain versions is getting better. It encourages interaction which is important.

Fun Factor: High to Medium
Complexity: Medium
Replayability: Yes

Main Frustrations and Caveats:
It gets its boring moments like not being able to do anything all because of unlucky dice rolls but it shines when players interact especially during the trading part of the game.

RATING: 7
When I first opened up the box, I was intimidated by all the rulebooks.  However, I was pleasantly surprised to find that the gameplay is not complicated.  The game makes interesting use of dice roll statistics, although this can be frustrating too.  Players doing well tend to keep doing better; it can be tough to catch up.  But there always seems to be at least one elusive resource for each player.  We have played with 3 players, with 6 players (with the expansion), and with the second 2-player variant listed on Mayfair's website (each player plays only one color).  We greatly prefer the game with more than 2, since that allows players to trade cards with each other.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
(5/2011) I've played a couple of times in recent weeks. The experience has cemented my matured opinion of the game. Blah. Manila crushes it for fun and gateway value while still being an interesting game. So many other games are just plain better. The negotiation is limp. The decisions are almost false. The playtime can drag.
(2/2/10) This and San Juan make me question how I do my rankings. On the one hand, I want to rate games on a scale of how interesting I find them. On the other, I find that I want to rate them according how good they are at being what they are. Settlers is THE 'family' Euro. Luck, social interaction, a little screwage without player elimination, and tons of fun, all in an hour. I'll play it with newbies any day of the week. But will I bring it to game night? Unlikely.

Original comment: Great game. I love the interaction. The components are beautiful (although the tiles could be thicker and fit better in the frame on the new edition). A rich game without insanely complicated rules. I'm new to eurogames, so this one was a big eye-opener for me (pretty trite story I know). While I can imagine tiring of it ever so slightly, I think I will alway enjoy playing it with first-timers who still think monopoly is a good boardgame.

RATING: 7
As a wargamer and roleplayer who favors historical or fantasy settings, I resisted playing this game for some time. Recently, I finally broke down and played the game with all the hype.  I must admit, I enjoyed it, particularly the extorting of resources from a player to avoid targeting them with the robber (is that legal?...well, we we did it!)  The only thing I didn't like is the absolute abstraction of it all.  The game system is simple and elegant, but I personally have a hard time getting into a game that doesn't realistically (at some level) depict anything.  Even Memior 44, which is hardly realistic, at least allows to me feel like I'm involved in something concrete.  I guess I'll stick with my wargames.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
:sugar: :( :( :) :) There's easier gateway games; there's quicker short games; there's more interesting strategy games. There's games where a bad run of dice doesn't doom you. There's games that fulfill all of the above requirements that support fewer than 3 or more than 4 players out of the box. If Settlers wasn't the first mover in the marketplace of mass-market German-style boardgames it probably wouldn't have the rep it does. If you're looking for a first toe in the water, consider Ticket To Ride, Carcassonne, Scotland Yard, Pandemic, Dominion or Samarkand: Routes To Riches instead.

RATING: 8
A classic!  This game really turned my wife and I onto German games so it deserves an honorific 10. One problem with this game is that the luck of the dice can severely set back your strategy and you find yourself hoping it isn't going to be one of those dice-dominated games.

We like to use a "dice deck" to solve the above problem: a deck of 36 cards labelled 2-12 in the right proportions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Like so many others, for me Catan was the "gateway game" that brought me into the wider world of table tops past risk and monopoly.  

It rates a solid 7 for 

1) having an accessible shallow learning curve that's easy to pick up in less than 10 minutes
2) for being balanced enough to have multiple different paths to victory
3)for often forcing cooperating and trading between the players. 
4) and of course, for having a ton of map and number variation so you're never playing the same game twice.

As a downside, the game falls on the side of a little too random in my book.  There will be some play sessions where you swear your numbers will never come up.  The person who wins probably had a good strategy, but also wins with a fair amount of luck.  Yes this makes the game more accessible for some novice players, but it also makes it the kind of game that I'm more reluctant to walk into.  

I've found that the "Oh I just got screwed by bad rolls" mindset is mitigated when you:

A) make the map bigger with expansion sets
B) increase the number of victory points required to win

However, this can greatly extend the length of the game depending on how efficient your opponents end their turn
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Birthday gift 2008 from Brittney.
This game shows its strength because it is one of the most frustrating games I have ever played, yet I love it and keep coming back for more. It creates intense rivalries that do not exist outside of this game among my friends.

I am pretty sick of this game at the moment. I need to take a nice long break. It's frustrating for me that this is the game that gets requested most often by my fiance and my friends. There are so many other games I would rather play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Random resource generation? Eh, not really. You take control of nodes as a gambled investment on gaining resources. You always know the odds something will be rolled, so it's a very economic bidding game in this way. 

That's why it's balanced - it's for repeated plays. Play this with the same group and it won't matter if you go 2 games in a row not getting many resources, because the next 2 games may play out much different. And the routes to victory (especially in expansions) becomes so fleshed out that maximum resource generation isn't as required.


---


Has so many mechanics within. Games that have better mechanics also sacrifice elements that Catan weaves together. A strong game. You can play it if you're in the mood for trading, building things from resources, area control, and so on. Not many games can give you that.

The variety of gameplay in settlers makes it a game most gaming groups won't be too worried to play, because whatever gaming mood they are in, it's likely Catan will give them what they want. And if their gaming mood changes next week, Catan may still have what they want. At least a little bit of it. 

That makes this game continually hit the table. It's one we usually are cool with playing no matter what mood we're in, because it has a little bit of something for every mood. Not many games can do that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A classic.  Better with 4 then with 3, since with 3 players a lot more seems to depend on the die rolls.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I'm sure this was a relatively good game 20 years ago, but now that there are dozens of games I'd rather play, I find it annoying it still sees so much play.

Its flaws have been discussed at length by others, but just to state the biggest ones:

1. The dice rolls are quite overwhelming in this game, especially considering the economic snowballing in this game. Players who get good dice rolls early are at a disproportionate advantage, and similarly players who get bad rolls early are at a huge disadvantage.

2. The solution the game uses for this problem is to incorporate a bash-the-leader/take that mechanism via the robber. Unfortunately, this just uses one bad mechanic (i.e. bash-the-leader) to cover up another (i.e. randomness/runaway leader).

3. There are literally turns where you get to make no choices. It's not even that unlikely for that to happen multiple turns in a row.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Probably a 4, but we called sheep 'Dolly' back when this was the only game we had, and that never really got old and is worth about a point. (Update: Not anymore it isn't.)

I have fond memories of opening this game straight from the hobby shop, setting it up, and freaking out about the *unbelievably complex* rules.  Then bringing it to my friends' apartment and practically needing to run out for smelling salts.

Like tons of other people here, I'm very happy I found this game and for the dozen or so times we played it, it was amazing.  But then came Puerto Rico, then Power Grid, and nobody has shown the slightest bit of interest since.  I don't blame them.

RATING: 6
I've been noticing this oddly Monopoly-esque backlash against Catan recently. Popular things tend to get picked on, I guess.

Which is a shame, because Catan was and still is a great introductory board game, and a great game in its own right. Yes, it relies a little bit too much on luck, and yes, you can get screwed over by bad starting placement, but you can overcome this with clever negotiations against people and judicial use of the robber. It tends to run a little long, especially with 4 players, but it's not a big deal.

RATING: 7.5
After playing on and off for years on various phone/tablets, I broke down and bought the board game to play with my kids.  It's too heady for my 5-year-old, but both my 7 and 10 year old daughters enjoyed it.  The game, which runs a little longer than some of our favorites (Forbidden Island, Ticket To Ride) was perfect for myself and the 10-year-old.  The 7-year-old had a good time but was a bit jacked up during play.  I'm not sure if it was because she was losing interest or just being 7.  Either way, we completed the first game and I got a thumb's up from both kids.  

Update, in future game plays, both the 7 and 10 year old had a good time.  Once they fully understood the game, what it takes to win, and could estimate how much time was left (because the youngest gets a bit bored), it became more enjoyable.  Since they like this game, I'm thinking Stone Age will be our next purchase.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Everyone just seems to love this game. And for good reason. It is fun. Deep enough for serious gamers and with enough luck for casual gamers. Play this and you may never play monopoly and its like again.

The Seafarers expansion is enjoyable and easy to add on. The cities and knights expansion has a ton of rules, adding to an already large set, and is not recommended for the not-so-serious gamer group. 

The 5-6 player expansions are nice because they allow for a bigger party, but the game tends to slow down too much for our tastes with the higher number of players. It seems like eons between turns. I would recommend keeping it to 3 or 4 players.

RATING: 5
"Catan" was one of my early board gaming experiences, and perhaps I wasn't up to the task when I tackled it. Whatever the reason, I found the game exceedingly dry and dull. Trading seems to lie at the heart of it, but nobody at my table wanted to trade with anyone. Thus, we just kind of played in isolation, taking our turns until the game was finally finished. RATING: 7
My first German game, the allure died off only after two months of regular full day (read noon to the wee hours, we had sessions ending at 5 AM for a while there) play sessions with everyone I know and I have easily logged over 100 games of this. I still enjoy dragging this out every once in a while. Siedler mainly has a niche for the very casual atmosphere it creates, plenty of time for table talk, banter, and such during the game, one of the reasons it has such broad cross-over appeal methinks. I made the mistake of playing this with a deck of dice for a period of time, essentially trying to turn this into something that it shouldn't be, I'm back to the dice again, and the game has been getting some more play.

This game is interesting in that unlike most modern gateway games, it is actually very prone to position-destroying mistakes when you first set up the board and stake your initial claim. Most people who like it tend to play it a fair bit, especially when they first get it, and in that setting the random boards and initial set-up are a good deal of the allure, but it does tend to make the game a bit dicey when you mix "serious" gamers with newer players, as it is very easy to sink yourself with a poor initial placement and end up sitting around for the game doing a lot of nothing because of that. I would go so far as to say that the initial placement is at least half of the game, with another 1/4 being trading skills and board play and the final 1/4 being luck of the roll and development draw. Take it for what it's worth. I probably wouldn't like it as much as I do if I played it for the first time today, but I do have fond memories of this one and still enjoy pulling it out on occasion with the right group.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This is main stream game that I would not play out of choice.  However I would run screaming from the room unlike Clue, Monopoly, Risk, Escape from Colditz...

A classic worth a visit now and then.

It takes no skill to build on the best spots... and even that doesn't always win as the nature of luck means you can see a string of ten 11's in a row.  This is a great concept, but you need to accept that this game offers very little real control to the players.

RATING: 8
Settlers of Catan is among my first boardgames along Tikal. It has been a really big hit in its time and I think it's fun today. The excessive dependence from luck in the game could be a problem, but it is a good starting point for people who has never played boardgames before.

We play Catan with our own House Rules concerning the Cities-expansion. We do not use the Knights portion of the expansion, only the cities, because we wanted to create a commerce and development centered gaming experience. 

A rarely played game but always has its own place on the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
F&%k all the elitist, snotnose backlash this game gets from people who think they've "moved on" to supposedly superior fare like PUERTO RICO- SETTLERS is the definitive Eurogame and the absolute best in its class, a truly transcendant title that encompasses the best that gaming has to offer.  Direct and meaningful player interaction, luck and strategy, long term planning and situational flexibility, competition, and a sense of narrative development serve to ensure that SETTLERS will long outlive the 5000 or so inferior European designs that have followed in its wake.  This is truly one of the watershed titles in the hobby on par with DUNGEONS AND DRAGONS and MAGIC: THE GATHERING in terms of industry impact, accessibility, and paradigm shifting.  It saddens me to see folks say how they've somehow burned out on SETTLERS when this is one of the rare games that has virtually unlimited replayability and is almost always a unique and fun experience.  You don't like the dice?  Go do Sudoku puzzles and cram your statistics textbook up your ass.  The dice make the game dramatic, variable, and it forces players to adapt and adjust throughout the game.  With trading, you are _never_ screwed unless you're one of those shrewish gamers who's afraid to speak up at the table to get what you want.  Without a doubt, one of the greatest games ever published and a timeless classic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Good gateway game, but definitely not for me.

Pros: 
- Easy to learn
- interesting mechanic for new table top gamers
- Trading aspect can bring out good social interactions

Cons:
- Too many dead turns. Most games have it bad enough waiting for other people's turns. Having nothing to do on your own turn due to RNG/robber makes for unpleasant play.
- Frontloaded decision making. A good chunk of the strategic play is frontloaded. The setup is (or at least feels) extremely important and starting a game from behind feels bad. Large Hate aspect here too.
- Poor scaling. Game plays extremely differently with different number of players. The board size remains the same, but players increase. With 4 players the board is very cramped, with 2, you have much more 

Overall, the biggest Con is the number and prevalence of hate mechanics which leads to feeling bad (even on your own turn!). There are explicit hate mechanics (using robber. stealing away the longest road. knight cards, monopoly cards) as well as un-escapable ones that are just a core part of the game (blocking people off during setup/expanding, esp at larger player counts).

The main draw then becomes enjoying RNG and dice rolling or trading, which is not enough for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
very good family game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.75
The resource adquisition method is so random and relentless that makes me feel a mere observator of my own games. Even when I win. It severely damages the flow and elegance of the game.
This game wouldn't hit BGGs top 200 if released this year.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This boardgame is based on board control and resource management.

I prefer playing this with the cards instead of rolling the dice. The stack will have one 2 card (representing a die roll of two), two cards with a 3 (representing 2 dice adding up to a three.) Make sure you put the appropriate number of cards in the deck to the odds of rolling a particular number (more for 7 than 2 or 12).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The official rules lead to a game that plays too long for what it delivers. Tweaking it to play faster makes it fun. My tweak is that if a player rolls dice and wouldn't get any resources, they get to pick any resource they want and get 1 unit of it. Just the player who rolled the dice, not everyone.

Early in the game, this tweak happens to give an advantage to the player who has the worst territories (ones that get rolled least). Late in the game, a player with good territories will reap more rewards than whoever's relying on the tweak.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fantastic strategy game with a hint of luck added to it. Played regularly with friends and on my iPad.

The random board aspect is both good and bad.  Occasionally the randomness is problematic, and that can lead to unbalanced resource distribution.  Still, a fun one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
This was my second ‘genuine’ boardgame I ever played (after Avalon Hill’s Civilization), and the experience was not pleasant. I played with 3 players, and we were soon leafing through the rules to establish whether we’d done anything wrong. We were rolling dice and growing, but there wasn't any sense of progression or challenge. I then played a few games with 4 players, and became intimately familiar with the rather annoying phenomenon of getting no useful resources for a long period of time simply because the dice (of course) didn’t land on their expected values. The standard reply is that you need to trade to alleviate this problem, and that the leaders should be excluded from trade. And that brings me to the heart of the issue I have with Settlers. It's not really the fact that 2D6 determine which resources get produced; no, it's that the game relies on people actively recognising that someone is doing too well, and then simply excluding him from participation in the game to a considerable extent until they catch up. I want to feel engaged, not given the proverbial cold shoulder until the rest have decided that it's okay to play with me again.

A second though lesser issue I have is that the game also doesn’t give you a meaningful choice what to with the dice as in, for example, Yspahan or Troyes. Settlers is all about reacting in a fairly uninteresting manner to a completely random input. Your only choice deals with whom to trade, and perhaps, guesstimating considerably, where to place a house. I know of lots of games which [i]do[/i] present me with interesting choices along the way.

Settlers deserves humoungous credit for its relative simplicity, the introduction of resources and being able to trade them with others to the general public, and presence of dice—which are a quite familiar and necessary element to many non-gamers; and so opening the eyes of quite a lot of people to the availability of games other than Monopoly or Risk. But as a [i]game[/i] I find it boring because there is very little to do and grating because I am expected to bash leaders in the most obvious of ways.

If, on the other hand, you and your group like to negotiate... then this title is fairly staple material.

[b]Update[/b] Auctioned off with the rest of the Settlers boardgame paraphernalia. It feels like a great burden has been lifted off my shoulders. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
[b]Dad - ~2002
Gifted away the newer copy my dad gave me to my brother-in-law; kept the old[/b] 

[u][b]My history with Catan[/b][/u]
Since my dad passed away my mother has been slowly trying to clean up the house.  I was helping her out in the guest room where the games were stored and she offered the Catan games to me.  Those games are important to me for a couple reasons. 
[b]1.[/b] Catan is the "gateway" game that got me into gaming and... 
[b]2.[/b] It's the game that reminds me most of my dad who has since passed away and introduced me to the game.  We had [i]many[/i] game plays with these copies with friends and family.  It also includes handwritten notes/summaries of different games we've had, along with a stupid plastic trophy we got out of a grab bag at [url=http://www.mclintocks.com/]F.McLintocks[/url] on a vacation to Morro Bay.  

Not an absolute favorite game, but one I will ALWAYS come back to for those reasons.

We like to randomize the layout of the tiles and the layout of the numbers (for the dice rolls).  This game is important to me because is was my "gateway" game that got me into gaming.  It's also the game that reminds me most of my dad who has since passed away.  Not a favorite game, but one I will ALWAYS come back to for those reasons.

I'm not sure how it happened, but we call the robber the Buddha-bum.  I think my dad started this because he never could remember to call him the robber.  Anyhow, it stuck and we still call it that.  We also have added a cheap dollar-store trophy that goes to the Victor of Catan.

[b]Expansions owned:[/b]
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/2807/catan-5-6-player-extension][i]5-6 Player Extension][/i][/geekurl]
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/926/catan-cities-knights][i]Cities & Knights[/i][/geekurl]
--- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/4101/catan-cities-knights-5-6-player-extension][i]5-6 Player Extension[/i][/geekurl]
Fun expansion with pirates.  One could easily get blocked out of getting troops/wheat.  If this happens when the pirates land and you're not helping protect the island you lose a city.  I've found if I lose my cities, I lose the game.
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/325/catan-seafarers][i]Seafarers[/i][/geekurl]
--- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/4103/catan-seafarers-5-6-player-extension][i]5-6 Player Extension[/i][/geekurl]
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/27760/catan-traders-barbarians][i]Traders & Barbarians[/i][/geekurl]
[-]- [geekurl=/boardgame/3972/catan-portable-edition][i]Portable Edition[/i][/geekurl] - Just like the base game, but with peg-like components so that it could be played while traveling, etc.[/-] [i]traded away at KublaCon 2016[/i]

RATING: 7
This game is a classic family game.  For many it was their gateway to bigger and better things in the euro world.  My biggest complaint with vanilla SoC is the endgame grinds, trading ceases and it seems like many turns are spent rolling dice and passing as the players behind seek to inflict "Take That!" cards or robber assaults on the leader.  C & K increases options but also increases playing time for a game that already overstays its welcome in my opinion.  I am interested in trying some of the elements in Traders & Barbarians that would mitigate some of the luck and give more options for VPs.

RATING: 7
The very one that really got me inte boardgaming and that made me frequently play boardgames.
And the game is still very fun to play, hoard commodities and enjoy when the other players beg at your feet to bargain. Or despair when you realize that your buddy stabs you in the back by trapping you to one corner or even worse feel the hairs rising when there is nothing to do to prevent your opponent from playing the knight that gives him two more points and in a clever strike gain the trade route and on the top of that flash som victory point cards, all this takes him from last place to victory... A thrill each time:-D
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Unlike many others, I started my tabletop with wargaming and Warhammer, and met Catan far later. I really enjoyed my first few games, and later my brother bought it, and left it with me.

This is where I fell out of love with it, and decided it is not the game for me. After one two many games where I was left with several turns with nothing to do, I just realised that it very quickly can become a not fun game to play.

The reliance of luck is not only related to whether you win or lose the game, but even worse, bad luck can leave you for several turns of NOTHING to do. That for me breaks this game. When for 2 or 3 turns I can't do anything, this is not fun. I like games where a bit of good or bad luck can decide, but let me take risks, let me try to affect the outcome!

Pro:
- Easy to learn
- Nice feeling of 'building a little empire'
- Trading is nice when people let you

Con:
- Luck that decides whether you can even play.
- Each game very 'samey'
- Not very interesting after the first few games
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My introduction to eurogames. I don't understand the apparent hate toward this game. The base game is fun and simple enough to teach new people quickly. The game also has enough expansions to keep veteran players busy for quite a while. If the luck of dice rolls isn't your thing there are decks of cards (I think in the Traders and Barbarians expansion) to take their place for a more even distribution of resources.

RATING: 9
This would be my desert island game. 
It has all the key feature of a great game
	• infinite replayability
	• player interaction (trading)
	• multiple ways to win in case luck is working against you
	• players are involved in each turn 
	• Anyone can win even a newcomer. 
	• very satisfying play - I'm always ready to play again. 
	
This game gets played in our house. It may be the only game that everyone enjoys.

RATING: 5
*The* modern classic.
However, I don't like it that much mainly because attacks only target one specific opponent instead of all of them. That means that coalitions against one player are not only possible, but an inherent and frequent feature of the game. Some may like that, but I don't.

But the team game variant (2 vs. 2 players) which can be played in the Catan Online World doesn't have this problem.
I therefore like it *much* better than the original! :) I'd rate it with a whopping 9 (in combination with both the Cities & Knights and the Seafarers expansion, I have never tried it with just the base game).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
21-Mar-2014 
I feel like I'm missing something with this game that seems to be hugely popular that I feel is reasonably fun to play but nothing spectacular.

I find if one player starts to pull ahead on victory points it's too hard to catch them up and stop them winning.

How you place your settlements at the start of the game is crucial. If you make a poor job of that then it can screw your whole game up and makes it very difficult to recover.

Edit 06-Mar-2017
With hindsight I feel I judged this game a little too harshly!  Settlers of Catan is over 20 years old and in that context it's a groundbreaking game.  It's a very good gateway game, but it's starting to show its age a little nowadays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

I think it lacks a bit of confrontation, and thus sometimes get's a bit repetive and even a little boring after long a drawn out game.

RATING: 8
This game a golden classic. It was a gateway for me (and many others) to the world of boardgaming. I like the interaction between players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Components: Beautiful, durable, functional components in a shoddy box. The most recent addition improves on the original design with an interlocking sea border and distinct art on each tile.

Experience: Update: Played a variant whereby the robber is a fountain, that allows everyone on the fountain to get a resource when that hex produces (if not already on that hex), rather than stopping production on that hex. Makes the game much more enjoyable.

Update: This game hasn't aged well. The very beginning of the game, during initial placement, is the most interesting part. The rest of the game is too capricious. The dice rolls are too random, and even when they give me resources, it might not be at the right time or in the right order. The robber punishes players for being unlucky enough to not build on their own turn; and players use it to target not only the person in the lead, but whoever has built beside them. The Monopoly card is just mean. I dislike that each game has the same goals (get to ten points). Games feel very similar to each other. Too random; too mean; too long.

Previous:
Excellent. The modular board gives each game a distinct flavor, and I find the dice rolling to be a thrill, with players always hoping for the big payoff. There are several different ways to climb to the top; it's very satisfying to finally get an engine going.

It's interesting even during the initial placement, as I scour the board looking for the sweet spots, scarce resources, likely paths, etc.

This game has aged well. Except for one thing that now bothers me greatly (after losing in my most recent game). Like in a game of Risk, when a player starts to lose, that player might have to endure losing for a long time. And during that time, the player will have very few meaningful or interesting decisions. There are so many ways to get hosed in the game; if a player is not in a good position already, with a safety net, then that player can be in for a long, miserable ride.

First Played: 2002-01-01
Last Played: 2017-10-08
Plays (77):
? players: 52
2 players: 1
3 players: 10
4 players: 8
5 players: 3
7 players: 2
8 players: 1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
An interesting euro, but waaaaaay too much based on luck for me.  I also hate how a player can be "walled off" for the entire game and never really have a chance, regardless of their decisions.

RATING: 7.8
My first European designer board game. I fell in love with it right away and bought a bunch of expansions for it. Played it many times. A true classic that brought a lot of people to modern boardgames. That said, it feels rather dated now. The winner is often decided as much by the dice as by strategy, which can be frustrating to experienced gamers. It is still worth re-visiting occasionally though. Star Trek Catan, with its character-specific abilities, is a nice improvement on the original design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Odd that so many Eurogamers who seem to despise random elements are so infatuated with Settlers. This has just a little dice-rolling, which ensures that the effect of chance is huge. Bad runs on the six-siders can destroy any good plan -- and there's not too much you can do about it.
Still want to play more, though. :)

29/12/05 update: Played three-player with food stamps yesterday and it was a much better experience. The food stamps didn't undermine the scope for good play, but kept bad dice-rollers in the game. The only way I'd want to play in the future.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This was the game that got me out of mainstream board games and into hobby games. No doubt most gamers can say the same.

During the first few years of playing it, I would have rated it an easy 10. Always willing to play.

Over time however, new games work so much better and many of the mechanics in Catan just seem old, outdated and not fun.

Resource generation being random, means it's all too possible for a player to have a really bad game through no fault of their own.

Having played this so many times over the years, it's now got to the stage I only play this if somebody else picks it and even then, I'd rather not.

RATING: 5
This is one of those games where the randomness can really ruin it. I've played games where certain unlikely combinations of the dice were repeatedly rolled early in the game, which ended up turning it into a frustrating 90 minutes. And it's no better when the luck of the dice favors you; it just becomes a monotonous exercise in clamping down.

If the luck were taken out, I'd raise my rating to a 7 or so.

RATING: 5
This hasn't been the hit for us that we hoped given all the excitement about how it changed the world of games.  I know that the die rolling doesn't play the same role as it does in Monopoly and that it's all about playing the odds, but it can be seriously irritating when a 6 just never comes up, you can't get bricks (or whatever) and noone will trade them for you because they know you want them.  Might work better for us when the kids are older, so still prepared for it to surprise me...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A well designed game. The idea were you roll your dice then collect resources is different than most games I've played. Not to mentioned that the goal is just ten points... Which is just enough time for you to get your fair share of fun from the game, but at the same time not to over kill the amount of glory the game deserves. 
This game is also quite simple, meaning this game could be refered to as a gateway game. A gateway game is a game that leads people who pretty much only knows how to play checkers to play more games. Like "Power Grid", ""Ticket to Ride", "The Resistance", and many more.
However I would not give this a ten because... Well, the game really doesn't give you that much options to do things, in other words you can only do what the game itself gives you. 
So if you are a person who likes to kinda sit back and watch the show, or game so to speak (I know I do sometimes) then this is probably the game for you. I know I like to actually legit participate in a game when I play it and this game doesn't really allow it. But I find my own ways to strategise in this which is one of the reasons I gave it such a high rating. This game also deserves a high rating because it is a very, VERY good family game. So if you want to spend more time with your family, this would be a good game for you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I rate this game 9 because it is a great game but also considering the following...  We never play it anymore without Seafarers and almost never without Cities and Knights as well.  But Settlers is a terrific game even without the expansions.  The masterful balance of strategy and luck is just right.  You have to be able to adjust your strategy frequently. You can achieve a sense of accomplishment in obtaining one goal and then refocusing your effort to the next development in your game plan. It is exciting to disguise your agenda by building many things at once at the risk of someone (or yourself) rolling a 7 or the risk of an opponent building in your way.  One of my favorite things about this game, however, is to see the blank stare of quite clever people as the game is explained to them for the first time and then seeing how quickly they pick it up when we play.

RATING: 6
NEW COPY FOR TRADE...

I like this game, but I hardly play it any more.  My main beef with it is how limiting a starting position can be when playing at the max player limit (4/6).  Add that to the randomness of dice rolls, and the first several turns can reveal your end 30-45 minutes before it happens. Attention to probability mitigates only a portion of this, because there are always going to be placements that are more advantageous than others, especially with a random setup.  Moreover, the dice are what they are--random.

I accidentally traded this for Jambo in a math trade.  I can't say that I regret that trade one bit.  I think I'm just over Catan.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
If it was not for the fact that this game has been played in to the ground in the past, I would have rated it a 9. It stands as my first experience with European boardgames, back in 95. Wow, it still holds its own after ten plus years on the shelf. The game play is clean and simply elegent. I never did get into the expansions. We tried a few, and they just seemed to dilute its greatness. I recommend this game to any noob.

I do not recommend this game to a group  of six people using an expansion while several members look for excuses to get drunk.

RATING: 4
Played it once back in 2014 with either 5P or 6P and it took at least four hours. Turned me off from the game entirely until I decided to convince myself whether I still loathe it or not and to give it another shot. Played a 4P game in 75 minutes, feels a lot more manageable and reasonable. Luck-based production is infuriating, but can be mitigated if you're fortunate enough to be able to build along hexes that have a wide range of numbers. I'd play it again with friends who are casual board gamers, but that's about it. Bumping rating from 2.5 to 4.

RATING: 4
Resources are too tight, build options too limited, and there is almost no opportunity to screw a runaway leader. Somewhat improved by the expansions. Trading can't be taken seriously or the game will drag, but if you don't take it seriously the winner is essentially random based on who asks for the most from whomever's the most generous. This game hasn't come out of its box for a long time, but I can't quite bring myself to offload it. Not even much use as a gateway anymore, with such things TTR now widely available.

RATING: 6.5
At first I tought this game was excellent, but nowadays I think this game isn't that good as most people say it is. It is entertaining, that's true, but not very challenging. There's just too much luck involved in this game. The one thing I hate about the game is the trading. It only makes the players with the best cards (possibly due to lucky rolls) even stronger. This doesn't seem fair to me considering the players who had a bad start. Playing without trading would give this game an 8 rating. With the trading it's only a 6.

RATING: 7
Played 5+ x
This is a classic game. I don't think it will ever leave my collection because it's easy to teach, there are multiple strategies, it's got that great gambling sensation when you look forward to each dice roll, and it gets people involved all the time due to having to make trades. 

That being said, a lot of my board gaming friends don't like Catan because they've already played too much of it or they like heavier games or they don't like themeless games. 

3-5 players is the sweet spot. 6 players just takes too long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've played a number of games and for some reason it never did much for me, as it's not that evenly balanced without the add-ons. As the game set a new standard at the time, I have to rate it a 7. After all, it looks nice, and with the add-ons it can be a lot of fun, but too my liking it simply takes too long, especially when you've fallen behind and need to sit it out for two hours with little chance of winning. As a result this game hasn't been played for quite a while, as there are many superior games out there. Trading away to make room for other games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
2008-04-05 

Dave Loved the game and pushed for a 2nd, 3rd and 4th game - all with the basic setup but swapping colours for the 3rd/4th.

We all won once, Dave also winning a 2nd time.

The trading is the main means of interaction but being able to block off opponents' settlements and striving to win the Longest road card

Luck is a strong factor in deciding the victor, but I think a better player would win more times. 

Strong similarities to Monopoly - the shared board, gathering cards, trading, the 'building an empire' theme - but with tons of advantages (trading more strongly necessiated by the mechanics, opportunities to take down the leader, no knockouts)... I can understand why this game was the one to introduce Eurogaming to America.

Incidentally, the board was slightly bent and caused much aggro.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A true classic, and one I'm glad to own.


Expansions owned:
- Seafarers
- Cities and Knights
- Fishermen of Catan
- The Great River
- Event Cards

[Expansions inside Seafarers box.]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The more I play Settlers, the less I enjoy it. The game is simple and good at drawing in new gamers, but the longer the game goes, the more the design frustrates me. The dice mechanic for getting resources just feels so very, very wrong and disappointing. I like dice and do not have an aversion to their use in a game. However, in a game you should always have the power and option to do something on your turn with your die rolls; Settlers denies you this. You could have a Settlers game where nearly all your rolls give you nothing and your opponents are rewarded - leaving you with nothing to do but end you turn. Meanwhile, games like Alien Frontiers and Kingsburg use your die rolls as a mechanic to gain resources, but in those games you always have options for using your dice even if the roll is bad. If I wanted a game with resource management and trading that makes all players active on each others turn, I think I could find a more enjoyable game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

Update 04/2013: Y'know, it's been YEARS I've been playing this, and I'm still very unlikely to turn down a game of it.  A true classic, the one that started it all.  EVERYONE needs this game.

RATING: 9
One of the most played games in the modern age of board games, Settlers of Catan (or simply Catan) is a building and bartering game that has you trading with your opponents and collecting resources to build the roads, cities, and settlements to try to win the game. A modern day classic to many who have played it and a game that helped me get back into the world of board games, Catan is a board game I play at least once a year and is so popular that it's even sold at big name retailers like Walmart.  If you have yet to play or want to get someone back into the joy of playing board games, sit down and play Catan, you won't regret it.

RATING: 9
Really fun and excellent gateway to Eurogames (is it THE first real Euro?). Beware the dice. With some players the dice feels like a constant problem that just messes up your plans. Use a dice deck for these players. Others will simply see the luck of the dice as just part of the game and will be ok with the base game.

[Gave to a friend.]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.8
Initial placement is crucial in this game in which you build villages connected by roads. Villages can be turned into cities, which are worth 2 points instead of 1 for a village, and they produce double the amount of resources (wood, stone, sheep, ore, grain). Production is determined by throwing dice. If you have a village or city on a tile with the correct number you obtain resources.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

I do find that this is a good game to break people outside of the more traditional styles of American gaming.

See Cities and Knights if you are looking for a little more depth.

See Seafarers if you are looking to play with more than 3 people.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Catan was truly my gateway game at the early years of the XXI century (i never get to knew Carcassone at the time and, anyway, it won´t qualify) so, it sets another standard point at my rating list.
Englobing just a few more mechanics and set up work than a vintage, Catan has already most of the features of a modern eurogame, though at small level. 
Easy to grasp, with fast playing turns in a suitable short overall playing time and keeping pure chance at low level, it was perhaps the first non abstract game that could provide the feeling of really taking your destiny into your hands while building something.
Nice to go along with family, friends or even maybe light gamers (who knows), Catan still remains a quality product and enjoyable, if one is by now not tired of playing it again and again.

RATING: 5
THE stereotypical "gateway game".  Theme is pasted-on, but there's enough of a challenge for gamers while being easy enough for non-gamers.  Probably best known for the trading mechanics.  I prefer to leave this on the shelf unless I'm trying to introduce non-gamers into gaming.  Otherwise, I'll go for more meaty games.

I'm lowering my rating.  The more I play, the less I enjoy it.  The game seems to last way longer than I prefer, and I grow tired of the randomness.  I still prefer the 10vp goal over the higher vp goal from the expansions, but I think starting with a city and a village (rather than 2 villages) is the way to go.  There's also the Rich Get Richer problem here.

Update: Traded away, as I won't ever recommend it, and plenty of other gamers I know already own it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A classic but unfortunately not fun for me anymore. Some players will not trade with you and once you remove trading, it becomes as tedious as Monopoly as you wait for your turn to roll dice and build something or hope the dice other people roll fall in your favor. Waiting for half the game or more isn't a fun game at all.

Experience does improve if trading exists but the strategies seem straightforward and are beholden to dice rolls. Look for ways to score points quickest and get a good spread of numbers to maximize the amount of resources you are getting. Often times high numbers are targets for blockage and the small sampling of dice rolls means even lower level numbers can pay off as frequently as higher ones.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

RATING: 6

This is a bit of a fatal flaw in my book, and I only really break this out with very new people, or once a year or so.

Would recommend, even if I know nothing about your tastes, as the game has very broad appeal.  My rating is higher than my true feelings at this point, but there was a time when it was clearly an 8. RATING: 6
(2008 - Feb)
Too much dependence on the dice-roll. You can choose good positions at start, but if in the first few rounds you don't get your numbers on the dice while others do, then they will "surround" you, so you will not be able to expand. And if you cannot expand, it does not matter if later on you get the rolls you want, because you're trapped and you have NO chance of winning.
However, it's a good game to start with boardgames.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Catan is not aging well for me.

The decisions you make during the setup round are essentially the most important decisions of the whole game, which makes the rest of the game seem to drag.

There's also a lot of random swings (even if you use a card deck instead of the dice).

Lastly, the end of the game is often a kingmaking situation. What Player A does will decide whether Player B or Player C wins. Even without that, the end drags out as everyone refuses to trade with the leader... slowly getting all players up to the 8-9 point range.

Without a doubt, Catan is far better than the majority of "family board games" that came before. But I think I may be ready to put this one out to pasture, since there are now much better games available--games with none of these issues and a lot more positive aspects besides.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Forever a classic, and the game that got me into board games.  Perfect starter game for those who haven't made the leap from Monopoly to Agricola.

Pros:
Simple to learn and enough luck for beginners to have fun
Variable game board
Rewarding expansion
Trading

Cons:
Too much luck(dice and card deck) for those who love strategy games
5-6 player expansion not included
No 2 player game

Play it till your bored, then buy Cities and Knights.

RATING: 7

Two years later. . . finally played it again. This time with a "food stamp" cube given to anyone who didn't get a resource that dice roll. You can trade food stamp cubes equal to your current number of victory points for any one resource card. Also, no rolls of 7 allowed on the first two rounds. These rules helped a lot!
