RATING: 3
The single most overrated game imaginable, Settlers is in no way, shape, or form an enjoyable experience. The amount of randomness in tile placement in high which then translates to each player having a number of turns with no meaningful decisions to be made thanks to the die-rolling aspect of it. In addition to its randomness, the trading system and thief placement allows for "kingmaking", making the little strategy that may have already been used go to waste.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Settlers is an absolute classic. It is one of my personal favorites and it is the "gateway game" that allowed me to bring countless new players into gaming. It is the quintessential resource management game. It uses a tile-laying mechanism similar to that of [gameid=58], which ensures a different board layout every game. Players then populate this map with settlements to obtain resources like wood and stone that can be used to build more structures and roads. There are several routes to victory and discovering different strategies and other subtleties of play ensures a high replayability factor. Most importantly, it gives players the opportunity to ask the age-old question, "Do you have wood for sheep?"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I've never played this at a table, but I have 20 plus plays online. Decent game, some important decision making and negotiation, but also a LOT of random luck. Nothing more frustrating than playing correctly and losing because the last time around the board the dice roll doesn't give you ONE commodity that you need.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[December 2014 - 7]
The gateway game. Like many, it was one of the first few games I played to get into the hobby. I enjoy it, but the trading and the dice-rolling luck ultimately play too big of a role in the game. Especially with the dice, if your numbers aren't coming up, it means your opponents' numbers likely are, so its sort of double whammy and the gap between the leaders and losers widens (I have the same complaint about Machi Koro). You'd think the trading might balance that, but if you have nothing to trade, because your numbers aren't coming up, then you're out of luck there, too. Meanwhile the leaders can trade and widen the gap. All that wouldn't be so bad if it were a shorter game, but it's a little lengthy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Only fun with played with non-pedants, this game is deceptively rule-based. The most fun to be had exists in trading and deception, and then only arises after hefty doses of alcohol. At this point it's not a bad little game.

Most tedious when setting up. The remainder is virtually entirely dice rolls and small trades.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I didn't play Catan at the height of its popularity. I played much later and it did not do its reputation justice. I found this game very dry and not terribly exciting. The key mechanism is on getting resources through die rolls and if your numbers just so happen to never come up - you're out of luck. It could be argued that you're supposed to plan around this by spreading your towns to the most likely places, or trying to cover a wide spread, etc, but in the early game you have no real say in this.

The trading is okay, but since this is a 'gateway' game, most new players take the 'Monopoly Method' to trading: they just won't. This can be mitigated somewhat with the sea trading spaces, but then once again you're beholden to the mercy of the dice to get the resources you need for those spaces.

Overall, this game just has not stood the test of time. The over-reliance on dice rolls is a complete turn off for the SO and I since there's little you can do to mitigate them. The other aspects of the game did not make up for this failure either. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
In the past I enjoyed playing the game a lot as it was the first board game I bought. Now I consider the gameplay of The Settlers of Catan as very predictible. Once a player builds the third settlement or the first city, he/she collects resources more frequently. Then, with more resources the player founds another cities/settlements faster than others. This is simply an unstoppable process. What is more, players that didn't manage to expand quickly, collect fewer resources and have no fun. The Settlers of Catan was a kind of basis to create new, much better games so don't waste time on this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.75
Settlers of Catan

IMNSHO, this is the best multiplayer negotiation game ever to hit the market!  It has an incredible depth to its strategy that gets overlooked by “gamers” because they dislike the amount of luck in the game.  I used to despise the luck factor because I wanted to win if I was the best player at the table.  Now I'm just as interested in who I get to play with.  and the great amount of luck in Settlers makes the outcome of each game unpredictable even when I am playing with non-gamer friends.  At the same time, I am never bored during these games because the optimal strategy is in continual flux.  I am always amazed by how difficult it is to determine the value of each resource as the game proceeds.  Learning how to negotiate with different types of players is another aspect that never gets boring.  I have played this game well over 50 times and I still enjoy it.  This is unusual for me as I normally get tired of games that I can play with non-gamers after 1 - 3 tries.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Considered *the* German game by many, sold a bazillion copies and spawned many expansions. Players begin on an island made up of hextiles. Dice are rolled to generate resources, resources are traded and spent to build settlements, cities, roads and resource cards. Victory points are earned for these builds and first to ten points wins. One of the "must own" games. If it has a flaw, it is the dice can reduce a player's role in the game to watching it for 75 minutes. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Updated 3/17/2011:

While I used to enjoy Settlers of Catan, I have come to the conclusion that the level of randomness ruins the game. While it can be enjoyable when all players are positioned well and the rolls are distributed evenly, it can be a totally maddening experience for some players when they're not.

Bad rolls leave some players with few or undesirable resources to swap, resulting in other players having little incentive to participate in trades with them. This can make the game feel mean-spirited to the struggling players, as can situations where other players use the robber to steal and block, preventing them from advancing their position in the game.  This results in an exercise of futility, turn after frustrating turn.

I'm unlikely to play this game very often in the future.

RATING: 10
Area control; Dice rolling; Hand management; Modular board; Route building; Trading;
Players gain resources when dice are rolled at the start of each player's turn. During active player's turn, they perform as many actions as their resources allow them to. Race to 10 victory points.

RATING: 7
Very popular with family & non-gamer friends. One of the better "intro to gaming" game out there. Key selling points are: a) it is not difficult for non-gamers to learn & enjoy 2) no 'wait-for-my-turn' downtime 3) no elimination of players 4) various strategies to win 5) good mutual gains from trading & player interaction 6) fast play and little "analysis" factor . Hard to go wrong with this choice. After getting your pals hooked, move them on to bigger & better games! Also, playing settlers gives enough satifaction to satiate that "gamer itch" addiction. Just don't burn out on it... go play something else! Only downside is that is best for 4 and we often end up with 5 for the night... 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This is the bread & butter game for much of my gaming circle.  It is almost perfect.  Skill typically wins, but there is always a chance to get lucky.  Even a moderately skilled player has a chance to win despite better players at the table, which makes it fun and competitive for all.  And the board changes every game, so there is no preset optimal build.  Add in the fact that you can trade, you can take hostile action with the robber and that the game punishes hoarding and it is just really well done.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
My intro into the Euros and I hardly looked back at the Avalon Hill type games again. Truly groundbreaking in my game playing experience. The idea that you take a turn, and roll the dice, but you may not get resources and your opponents may get them - brilliant! Keeps everyone engaged throughout the game - and nobody is eliminated and can play all the way thru till the end. Wonderful! I love this game and we play it frequently - but we certainly don't play it to death.

RATING: 8
Truly brilliant game design that was a progenitor of countless games to follow. The only flaw is that when you play, one player invariably gets beaten by the dice. He hasn't chosen poor starting numbers -- not notably worse than any other player, anyway -- yet his numbers just don't come up. By halfway into the game, he's just become little more than a prop, trading fodder for the other players to use in trying to achieve victory. The randomness won't bite you every time, but it will bite you some of the time. And for that reason, no matter how much I respect the game as a forefather of the genre, I can't rate it more than an 8.

RATING: 6

I love negotiations games, and in this one you can negotiate about everything. I really enjoy it when some people get upset and talk about cheating when I offer goods to someone for placing the robber on a specific person, or when you "buy the rights" to build a settlement in a certain spot. Brilliant game, but after hundreds of games I really prefer something else.

RATING: 5
The classic "gateway game" for people who aren't gamers. Simple enough to teach the layperson without intimidating them into quitting, and random enough that the novice has a chance against the expert. Once they play this, they'll want to see what the other games on the shelf are like. 

UPDATE: Not sure if it's the plethora of newer Eurogames I've been exposed to since Catan or not, but this game seems stale and out-of-date to me now. Really not digging the randomness added by the dice. A string of unlucky rolls can ruin the experience for one or more players who will sit with few resources and nothing to trade. Rating downgrade.

RATING: N/A
I know, I know... this game is the quintessential introduction game to board gaming. Everyone knows it, some hate it, others love it. I am in the boat that can never turn down a game of Catan! This was seriously the game that opened my eyes to ACUTAL board games, you know, the fun ones. Prior to Catan I thought Hasbro was one of the few companies making board games. WRONG! There are soooo many! WHAT?!??!

Anyways... I very much enjoy trying to convince someone to give me a sheep or wood so I can finally build my road or city. This game has completely replaced Monopoly for me... will never play Monopoly again. This game is just...better!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Catan is a great way to introduce people to euro board games. The familiar dice roll to start your turn helps make it a great gateway for people only familiar with mass-market, roll-and-move games. It has a nice balance of simplicity and strategy. There is enough luck and interactive trading to keep things from getting stale. The variable setup plus all the expansions give it longevity and great replay value. The best thing we did was sort our pieces and expansion parts into adjustable tackle box flats and pack it all into a carrying case. It's our "Settlers to go" kit. I must have played between 50-100 games of Settlers before we found BGG, so my stats on this game are very under-reported.

RATING: 5
I feel that popular opinion on this game is leaning more in my favor these days - the only game of Catan I've ever enjoyed was my first one, when I was new to the hobby. It's resource-generation system is pretty poor, and it's not even high on my 'gateway game' list any more.

Many will argue that it's main selling point is that it encourages trading and keeps it relevant to the core gameplay. While accurate, is this trading actually fun? I need sheep but have wood, so I exchange my wood for your sheep. I now have the sheep that I need. I'd rather have a better system for me to generate my own sheep!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Was OK at first, but became tiresome for me after a few plays; fun depends on the group and its willingness to trade.  Good potential for interactivity, but my group tended to not trade since we didnt want to help other players too much.  If an essential commodity is scarce due to randomness, a player who has the scarce commodity is even less willing to trade (since they want to use it themselves), and so a bottleneck emerges to strangle trading. But at least the game can move along quickly. The main flaw is that the extent you participate in the game is dependent chiefly on luck, and (to make things worse) is exponentially tied to having luck in the initial few turns.  The result: deadly boring games for those players not initially producing many commodities (esp longer 5-6 player games are terrible)-- there simply isnt enough for these players to do.  Sure, the game is short, so it can have its place, esp. with non- or casual gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
1st Euro - or at least Gateway Game to bringing Euro's to US en masse.

Although I am painfully bored of this game having played updwards of 500 games, I can find no room in my heart to give this classic any less than a perfect 10.  I think, for me at least, this was the game that helped bring games from overseas to America and continues to help bring about the mainstream board game revolution that we all hope and pray continues to grow. 

Update: Victorious!  That's right, my countless hours of Catan-ing finally paid dividends...literally.  I took down the Settlers of Catan Mega-Tourney at the Strategicon last week and got 100 bucks to spend on more games.  Yay sheep!!

Update 2: Victorious again! Won the US Settlers Championship at GenCon and got an all expenses paid trip from Mayfair to Germany to represent the good ol' US of A.  I was the highest English speaking finisher coming in at 8th in the world out of 56 competitors from 28 countries.   Awesome experience.  Wouldn't trade it for anything.

From there it is all down hill in a game that practically plays itself and has few meaningful choices. Trades can become interesting on certain set ups, but more often than not, nobody ever seems to have a real strong motivation to trade - thus, making the game a waiting game until you roll the right resources you need.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
(Not)* Gaming nirvana.  And it gets even better with Cities and Knights!

This game really shines with random hex and chit distribution.  I really love thinking about how to best exploit the limited resources on the map; and throwing down my roads, settlements, and cities in various winding and twisting configurations.  There's no need to worry if an opponent takes a spot I want as long as I set myself up in a good trade position, and not get tempted by the deceptive chits that whisper odds that may never play out.  It's a wheeling and dealing puzzly game where every move is a calculated gamble.  It's a pirate in a merchant's clothing, and I'm always up for a game.

2017 Update after owning the game for ten years: I hate the way you can trap people early in this game and they'll just sit there with nothing to do.  I also get kind of bored waiting for my resources to roll. It feels too slow, even when it goes fast.

*Ten'ish year update

RATING: 5
The game that got my group into the hobby. We have since moved on, but it still holds an honorary spot in my collection. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Overall I think this is a terrific game and a fun way to kill some time by engaging in some friendly back-stabbing. There are a few tiny flaws that occasionally get in the way of the game for me, but in general I think the design allows for a nice balance between luck and strategy. And I think luck is as important a part of gameplay as strategy, so I appreciate the attention to balance in games like this. 

The highlights of the game for me are the player interaction (through trading and "unholy alliances") and the resource management. Thinks like the "Longest Road" and "Largest Army" also provide some flexibility to strategy, and reward players for doing more than just building up settlements and cities. Building roads and buying soldiers are an important part of the game, but I think those added bonuses give the game some extra punch. All in all I think the point system is very flexible and allows for players to pursue a variety of strategies, most of which will remain viable for the entire game. 

The only thing I don't like about the game is the way that resource tiles are assigned fixed numbers for dice rolling. I can't tell you how many games have become once sided slaughterfests because the dice refuse to roll anything other than five or ten (and it's always five or ten, never six or eight). In most games I've played one resource will remain scare due to the number system, which is fine and indeed a part of the game, but occasionally a "sheep tyrant" will emerge and destroy us all. When the game takes on a sense of inevitability it becomes a lot less entertaining and rewarding. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
These days it feels too random, but considering I haven't played any game as much as this one, and still enjoy a game now and then, this needs to be rated high. It is an absolute classic. The dice rolls can make or break your game, but there is strategy involved to mitigate some of that. 

This is a game that is extremely easy to teach someone and is a great way to nudge someone into the hobby.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A great gateway game, but also introduced me to a number of issues I have since judged all games by. A player should not be eliminated from a potential win by the beginning turns and a leader should not be able to continue his run towards victory so easily. Sure he can be robbed or denied a trade, but for such a cutthroat style of board setup, the actual chances to screw your neighbor are low. I moved on, although I enjoyed my time in Catan.

60-90m (too long!), best with 4 players. 10+ plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Easy and simple, like everyone, especially the less gamers. Excellent to play in the company of family. The high degree of chance for me is the worst thing about it can spoil the little strategy that you have built, but is the fun of the game.

RATING: 6.75
Not terribly impressed with the box and component quality.  The frame and tiles always pop up at one corner or another and are thinner and less rigid than I have seen in other games.  Quality would suggest a much lower SRP than $40.  Rather than being about building roads, settlements, etc, the games seems to be more about buying the development cards since you can build your army and collect free VPs.  Also, the robber is a little too powerful and comes into play too frequently.  I want to love this game and will keep playing it, but these features seem to cause a little too much tension at the table.

RATING: 10
Amazing game and fun to replay...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
As a lot of people will say, this is a great gateway game. However, after playing it a lot, and then being introduced to a number of other strategy board games, with each new game I learn the Settlers of Catan falls further on my list. At this point, I can't see ever playing it again unless it's the only game available. I no longer enjoy the game for a number of reasons: (1) the base game only plays 3-4 players, which is an awkward requirement. I'm not a fan of games that can't support a minimum of two players. Also, four players is too crowded and takes too long. Five players (with the expansion) is great because then there is a build phase between every turn. (2) This game is TERRIBLE when it comes to the "everyone gang up on whoever is currently winning!" mentality. No one wants to trade with the player who is winning, and if someone does then usually at least one player will get mad and insist that it's the worst decision ever, even if both players mutually benefit. Furthermore, if you are in first place and everyone stops interacting with you then there isn't much you can do strategy-wise to secure the win. You have to sit back and wait for random numbers to be rolled and hope to get what you need. Otherwise, the game slows down to a crawl until someone else takes over as first player and other players will finally trade with you again. (3) Even when you play the odds and build next to the numbers with the higher probabilities of being rolled, usually those numbers are targeted with the thief, and it's never a guarantee that the number will be rolled and you will get your resources. (4) After playing the game a number of times, even with the expansions, every game starts to feel the same and so, for the time and money commitment, I'd rather play and buy different games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I know that Settlers is a very popular game and the word in the media is that this is one of the greatest games ever for various reasons. I generally enjoy the game. However I hate to be a downer but I feel like it's the "best game" for people that are non-gamers or just casual gamers. It has a lot of merits but there are some things I don't like about it. For one thing, the game seems to drag because it's tough for players to just accept that no one is going to give them 3 ore or 3 wheat for their one measly wool, and this causes the game to drag. Also I have found that for some reason when people get screwed in this game they tend to be personally hurt. I have seen couples get into fights over this game, so I make a point not to take it very seriously when I play as part of a group with my wife :)

RATING: 7

The games easy to learn, interactivity and non aggressive theme make it perfect for a family, or new gamers.  The depth of stratagy and complexity of trading maintain it as a reasonable game for experianced gamers.  If I hadn't already played the games a couple hundred times, I probably would still reccommend it to most game sessions.

The citys and knights expansion is still my favorate variant.

RATING: 8
I have gotten a lot of enjoyment out of this game, and taught it to many people.  It remains the best game for introducing non-gamers to gaming, in part because it is very elegantly designed - does a lot with relatively few rules and components.  Also the die rolling, while an annoyance to experienced gamers, does help create some excitement for the general populace.

Even though there is very little strategy left in this for me, I still really enjoy teaching it to new players and watching their learning process.  Plus the trading is still a lot of fun.

I really don't like this game. Still, I can't get rid of it because it's the staple board game for non-hobbyists right now and it does help bridge people over to better games. I just really don't like the randomness of the game. Some games can go great and be very enjoyable, but it seems more often than not that the combination of bad rolls, bad placement opportunities, and stubborn players leads to one or more players effectively getting eliminated because he or she can not do anything.  

It doesn't get much play and so I don't mind the occasional game, but I swear i'll hide it if it starts to get overly suggested.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Update 2017 -- Enough with the badmouthing of this classic.  My previous comments can be summarized,  "I'd rather play checkers with my cat." 

Actually this game is very much like Monopoly.  I think that's why it's such a great gateway.  It has the horror of the "dead-money" player -- just like Monopoly.  It allows senseless, reckless, free trading -- just like Monopoly.  And also, like Monopoly, you pretty much know who is going to win forty minutes before the game is over.  Yawn, Daddy-O, yawn!  It manages to paint the mean, pointlessness of Monopoly onto a resource gathering area control game.  A bridge to escape those types of games.

(I've recently had two games of this that have made me reconsider the final statement...as well as drop this game by a full point.  They were two excruciatingly painful games.)  When it's good, it's really, really good, but you can have an occasionally frustrating run of bad dice.

RATING: 8
The granddaddy of gateway games was my personal introduction to modern board games. It was my first euro and I was fascinated by the "victory points" and variable board. Before SoC I didn't know anything existed outside of Monopoly, Risk, Scrabble, etc. However, repeat plays have revealed not all is new and perfect here. Although very good with 4 players, I don't find it works with 3 or 2. The dice can be cruel, making your statistically superior strategy worthless. There can still be a runaway leader problem even with the robber and other players reluctance to trade with the leader. Also, if you happen to get boxed in early in the game there is nothing you can do to catch up.  

Seafarers, Helpers, Fishermen, and 5-6 player expansions included.

RATING: 3
This game is way too luck based for my likes. For new players, it's not a very forgiving game. Poor initial placement of villages is something you can't really recover from. That means that new players, haphazardly placing their villages, will have little chance of winning once they understand what is going on halfway through the game. There are better "intro" games than Settlers, IMO.

RATING: 9
Yet another follower-placement game (the First that I've owned, in fact!). It's strength lies in replayability, as the gameboard is never the same. And luck goes the same for that matter!

As this game can be played with 2 players, I strongly recommend to gather up at least the third one. In two player games, there's just no need in trading, which in my opinion is one of the most intriguing aspect of the game as it enforces conversation and diplomacy, which is absent from two-player games.

Totally recommended for fans of games like Carcassonne!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.25
[2016-05-31] I have a love/hate sense of this game. I want it to be better, but I'm not sure how to go about that. 

1. Have the Robber default back to the Desert tile after one round anywhere else. He won't stay long to impede a runaway leader, but he also won't stall an already lagging player.

Trading can result in a more luck-driven, dice rolling grind if no one is willing to trade. Maybe there could be more incentive: 

2. Players may draw a resource card token (per the Welfare variant rules) if they accepted a trade offer made by another player.

see also: 
The famous WELFARE variant
[url]https://boardgamegeek.com/article/1325958#1325958[/url]

Change luck for strategy: use 3 dice!!
[url]https://boardgamegeek.com/article/1162329#1162329[/url]

RATING: 8
Here it is, the game that got me into real board games. For that alone it deserves a high rating. The most unique board that is random every time with many classic game elements including trade, building, dice rolling, and victory points. The artwork and pieces are all high quality, though I'm still a little torn at whether I like the newer version or not.  As for pure gameplay, the dice do matter a fair amount but at least its based on probabilities.  Still, those games where it seems like 4s and 10s are rolled more than an 8 or 6 can be annoying.  I like playing this every so often, it really doesnt get old.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
Catan is a classic. I don't even need to review this game because everyone has played this game and if you haven't, you actually have and just don't remember that it was called Catan. There are a handful of go-to games out there for me that are easy setup, light-medium weight for chill nights or straight gateway games for new players or people who hate board games because they hate monopoly. This game is very rewarding each time the dice rolls that one resource you have been waiting for the whole game but also extremely punishing if you did not position yourself for success. There is definitely possibility and even probability for a runaway player who just absolutely dominates the round. Also, players positioned poorly will be punished relentlessly for about an hour and have to watch other players accomplish everything they need and more.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Very good strategy board game, not that difficult to learn, yet more challenging and interesting than Monopoly, and with multiple ways of trying to win.  Great player involvement even when it's not your turn.  "[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/150443]Welfare variant[/url]" (= Foodstamps) [[filepage=22173]PDF[/filepage]] is a must to minimize the frustration of randomness and too much dependence on luck, plus speed up the game and prevent runaway leaders (closely related is the [thread=1184279]Poverty is No Shame variant[/thread], which feels more like regular Settlers but just gives players some control over what numbers are rolled - see my thoughts on both [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/15951421#15951421]here[/url]).  Another option is to [thread=134095]roll three dice[/thread] and pick two.  Game play can also be improved and made more even with the Event cards.  I also suggest using a [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/article/15950941#15950941]score track[/url].  

Here's a website that creates `balanced maps' for starting resources, and is even used in some tournaments: [url=http://bettersettlers.com/]bettersettlers.com[/url].

Also owned: 
[gameid=2807] - Base game add-on for playing with five to six players.  As much fun as the base game with three to four players.
[gameid=20038] - Potential to improve Settlers by eliminating some randomness and adding some strategy and events.  The Earthquake event can be a bit harsh early in the game though, so we've ignored that.  Overall, it seems to improve the game and make it more balanced.  This along with the Foodstamp variant are must-plays for Settlers of Catan.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a wonderful game; or at least it was for a couple hundred plays. I picked this up on a whim at a comic store down the street to play with my friends before we'd go out drinking. Except we had a hard time leaving the table. Soon we were scheduling Settlers evenings and playing repeatedly till the wee hours. Ah, those competitive nights of playing Settlers when somebody always wanted "one more game."

It seems unfair to rate this game against today's games, but I revere it as the landmark game it is and all the enjoyment it gave me, so I'll bump it up a notch. I'd be hard pressed to sit through a play of it now, however. At least give me Elasund which has a lot more going on. For expansions, I recall Seafarers and Cities & Knights as both being worth it.

This game brought me back into the hobby and, by association, to BGG, so it will always have a place of reverence in my heart.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Some might be confused why I rate this game so low. The reason is that I stick to the description of BGG rating descriptions and I definitely pass on this game if there is anything else available for playing. The main reason for my rating is that the luck is affecting the personal strategy in a way that can simply break your position in the and will make it impossible for to win. Definitely a good game to present to players who only know simple games for instance but not really something that is worth playing for a competitive thrill. I definitely suggest Korsar or Keltis. Those are much better Knizia games in my oppinion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A game everyone should try once. Is it a classic? Probably. After the jokes are worn thin, the game endures. Regardless there are plenty of other games I love to play that owe Settlers a royalty check. Or at least a thank you card, most kids leave their folks in a lurch, so don't hold your breath.

Tueber has milked this sucker to the point of irrelevancy and each rendition sells, so I guess it is a bonafide classic. Is it plagiarism to steal from yourself, or just a sign of limited creativity?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This is an excellent game as a game, but it also has a social interaction component that few games offer.  My favorite Settlers story comes from my friend Andy, who played a game in which all his opponents were extremely agreeable when it came to trading ("anyone trade me a sheep and a wood for a wood?  I need a sheep?"  "Sure!")  He was way too smart to do this.  Halfway through the game he realized he was hopelessly behind...

We always call this game "Settlers", but you can't find it using the Search function on BGG if you type in "Settlers".  It's stupid.

RATING: 7
The classic gateway game imo. This game got me truly invested into wanting to experience more strategy games. I owe it a lot.

However this game became to repetitive.  Due to the reliance on luck, I have really become turned off by this game. From someone that had most of his strategy based on the social game, it became to common of an occurrence for luck to run the game. I won the first 11 times I played, then would win every other for awhile until I hit a point where I would win like a normal human. 

I really have just played this game too much and have lost interest in the strategy. Great game to get you into strategy gaming, just hard to play consistently once you find others.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
my son like it
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Bought the game and 4-6 player expansion for $50-$70 (I forget) MANY years ago. After many games, I started to keep a Hall Of Fame paper where we recorded: Game Length, # of Players, Who won and what position did they place, and Least and Most common Dice Roll #. We have 91 games that we kept record of on the HOF (I won 41 of them :) ). I have played over 100 games of Catan. This has been one of the best game purchases I've ever made. 

BUT, that was years ago. Back then, this game was a 10 easy. Now, with the way games are changing and new mechanics being created, I'd say it's a 7. We still play it, but it doesn't get chosen many times (perhaps because we've played it so many times).

Couple notes:
My gaming group and family aren't big fans of chance, luck/lack of luck, or ganging up on. Therefore, most of the time we played without trading. This was mainly to stop bad players from giving the person winning what they needed to win... Too many times I'd be winning and I'd convince a silly player to trade me a terrible trade and game over. It's not much fun when that happens.

Another variant we did was, we played a lot of game (maybe 50%) without the thief. If you rolled a 7, you just picked someone to steal from. 

Another variant we ALWAYS played with, and I think this helps the game, is that you could negotiate. If you're about to be stolen from, you can ask the thief "what do you want?" He says "wood", you hand him a wood and thus protect your other precious resources. OR he says "wood" and you need wood, so you say "good luck" and then he picks randomly. This addition was always nice to have. 

When we played with the thief, you could negotiate with the thief and say, "I'll give you what you want IF you block my 12 and not my 6" etc... this rule is also great. Everyone is happy. Of course sometimes the thief says, "nice try" and just smacks the thief down on your 6 that has 3 cities on it. BOOM.

So, if you haven't played the game before. Get it. Play it. You'll enjoy it. I don't think you'll get 100 games out of it like I did, but you'll get some good mileage on it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Despite all the criticism here on BGG, I generally enjoy this game.  One can see immediately why it is considered the quintessential gateway game: it has loads of player interaction and involvement and with resource collection and trading occurring for everyone each turn, everyone stays engaged.  I particularly like that the momentum builds as the game progresses, and when there is not a runaway leader, it is sometimes not clear who will win as the end approaches.  Settlers is clearly a classic deserving of all of its fame.

Having said that, with time I have downgraded my rating from an 8 to a 6.5, as dependency on the dice rolls make's it difficult to control one's destiny, and there sometimes can be a real runaway leader problem.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Have for trade: 
Settlers of Catan - Mayfair 4th Edition
18 Terrain Hexes: 4 grain, 4 wood, 3 ore, 3 brick, 3 wool, 1 desert

Mayfair 3rd Edition 
2 desert hexes

Want: Settlers of Catan - Mayfair 4TH Edition
25 Resource Cards (5 of Each Resource: Ore, Grain, Lumber, Wool, Brick)  
Development Cards: 6 Soldier, 1 Monopoly, 1 Roadbuilding, 1 Yr of Plenty
2 "Building Costs" Cards
4 Cities any color or combo of colors
5 Settlements any color or combo of colors
16 Roads any color or combo of colors

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Optimizing for the right mix of resources (e.g. getting brick and lumber to start), likely resources (likely hexes), and route planning (getting ports, blocking opponents) make for a great mix of strategic elements.

Simple to learn, but yet some strategic death.

The game is marred somewhat by "accumulated advantage", once you fall behind it's hopeless and that's usually obvious to everyone.  If players are paying attention they will cease trading with the leader, which helps to some degree.

Also marred somewhat by too much randomness in the consequences of dice throws and who gets the the resources.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I played this game (and its expansions, Seafarers and Cities & Knights) several times a week for several years. It can be very frustrating when none of your numbers are rolled. 
I use a house rule to mitigate no numbers being rolled especially at the beginning of the game. When you don't get any cards on a roll, you get a penny or other marker. You can trade these markers in on your turn for a resource: you turn in the same number as your current score. These markers can never be taken away and do not count against card limits, etc.
It's been a while since I've played much. My Mayfair 3rd edition is really worn out, so I've collected the various 4th edition game and expansions, with the intent that I'd start playing it occasionally again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
One of the first "gateway" games I played when getting into the hobby back when I was in college circa 2009. 

Your first choice of where to settle will determine the outcome of the game, which I dislike. Also do not enjoy the dice being so prominent in determining the fate of the game. The dice are why trading exists in Catan, but I don't enjoy trading either. The "building" feels hollow and I'd rather play anything else sans Monopoly. Decision-making feels very limited and each turn is brief and unfulfilling. How about some Uno?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The game is so frustrating.
Worked well as a gateway game, but now I hate it. How can I want to play a game where for 3 full rounds you don't get any resource while the guy with colonies on the 3-4 or even 12 keep gathering goods? How can you want to play a game where you draw knights that let you randomly draw exactly the resource you don't need, and the other guys draw monopoles and free streets?
And of course noone wants to trade with you for just 1 resource, so you're stuck with all but one resource for the thing you want to build... and won't get the one you need for 5 rounds or more, until you can trade 4 for the one you desperately need... if in the meantime noone has rolled a 7.
Wasted time. Wasted energies and frustrations.

RATING: 10
This is THE game, the first german game I played in 1996 and was a total revelation. It literally changed my life, 10 years later and I have nearly 1400 german games. Siedler had such radical design ideas, the modular board, the probablity theory in play, the player interaction, but above all the positive progression to a winning target. Such a huge influence on gaming, and Klaus Teuber deserves the rich rewards it's earnt him.

RATING: 9

As the game approaches the end, it becomes all the more tense as everyone realizes the clock is ticking.  While some feel it is "run of the mill" or has "too much luck", I find the design ground-breaking and brilliant.  It still holds up today - many years later.  Grade: A-

RATING: 7

I've viewed with grudging interest some of the mini-expansions that have been appearing, and hope that/wonder whether those event cards would help "flatten the curve" for the production rolls.  Given the number of actual rolls made in the game, it seems like either 6 or 8 is always missed the whole time!  That's wacky.

RATING: 6
Played with: 4-6.

Catan is the essential to everyones board game collection in my opinion.  Easy to learn, easy to play and most importantly it teaches some fundamentals that will hopefully bring new players into other styles of boardgames. 

The BGG rating on this currently a 7 which I believe is fair as the game does become stale after a lot of rounds, and people begin to figure out the best strategies to win games.  That said, I think everyone should own Catan and if you want to help people jump into board games this is the perfect starting point for most people.

RATING: 8
This is the game that kicked off my board game renaissance, and is one I keep going back to.  Even those who aren't generally interested in board games will sit down for an hour or two to play a good game of Catan.  Even after several dozen games, I'm still not bored with the mechanics and gameplay, and can't see it happening in the near future.  Highest recommendation, for both board game enthusiasts who haven't yet played this classic, and are looking for a mildly complicated game to play with non-gamers, or for those just getting interested in gaming and are looking for a good entry-level game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Sorry, hard-core gamers.  I continue to like this game a lot & I am not tired of it.  If I could find more interested players I would purchase all the variants.  

The luck of the dice certainly dominates the game.  I recently went 12 rounds without getting any resources or if I did, my opponents stole my lonely resource before I could use it.  So I had nothing to trade, nothing to use.  After that experience, I lowered the rating on the game.  I prefer games with less dependency on the dice rolls.

Having the longest road helps VP's but I have noticed I win more often if I concentrate on upgrading settlements to cities as quickly as possible, especially surrounding one product numbered a 6 or 8, and connecting to a port that gives an exchange advantage.  I buy cards when I fail to have enough to upgrade settlements (otherwise my products always get stolen)--potentially 9 products & 3 turns might get you the largest army whereas it takes a minimum of 10 products & 5 turns to maybe get the longest road.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I've been playing [thing=84431][/thing] for the iPad, and as much fun as it is, I've come to realize that a big part of doing well in Catan is choosing the right starting location. If you choose poorly, you're in for a long night. That's kind of frustrating. Still, every face-to-face game of Catan I've played has been a lot of fun. If I got to play more often, I could see it being one of my favorites.

That said, a big part of my fascination with Catan is due to the various "print-and-play" expansions in the File section and elsewhere online.  My wife is into arts and crafts, and it's cool to have found a place where her hobbies intersect. For the base game, we've done the [thing=42147]Harbormaster,[/thing] the [filepage=6452]Jungle[/filepage] and the [filepage=6453]Volcano.[/filepage] See my entry for [thing=325]Seafarers[/thing] for more. Naturally, I have yet to play any of these variants.

I really want to own [thing=926]Cities & Knights,[/thing] but we hardly ever play Settlers as it is, so I can't really justify it. I'm on the fence about [thing=27760]Traders & Barbarians[/thing] for the same reason, especially since we effectively own half of it.

RATING: 5
I read an article about this game before playing it: straightforward rules, short games, strategic depth, replayability - the Eurogame genre of board games sounded fascinating. Having been raised on Monopoly and Risk (Why the heck do they still make them? And with in many editions?) this was a breath of fresh air from the outside.

I still do enjoy this game, but I prefer others that are deeper, have a theme I like more, are quicker (for in-between plays), or ones that I haven't tried yet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
At first I wasn't too impressed with this game- I came into the hobby late and it did not stand above the more recent games that I played alongside it.  The look of the geometric board and the graphics never really excited me.  After about 10 plays tho, I'm really happy with it and it's becoming a simple, easygoing favorite.  I'm won over by it's gameplay.  I think the randomness of the dice help keep the game fresh.  I like it best with three players so there's more room to expand.  It's a family favorite as well.

Note: After many plays I think this game is a bit long.  It can drag early on.

Update:  After playing so many other games, I've come back to Settlers with a lot of respect.  I think if I could only have one Euro it would be this one.  It's such a cool little system, and it's a game group recruiting tool as well.  Normal folks, like family and non- gamers, enjoy and request it.  I love the die rolls for resources and the modular board.  It's got expansion, developing an economy, and risk management.   I like the way the pace quickens as people start producing more goods.  I wish I could play Settlers and  all its variations more often.  Sadly, most gamers I know feel it's old hat by now- but I still sneak in plenty of family games!  Like ASL, Settlers is all about working the bell curve on 2D6.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This game literally made my brother-in-law break up with his boyfriend.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
At first the trading aspect is fun, but after a short time unless you're playing with experienced players, the trading part basically becomes a game of go fish.  And you want it to be a game of go fish because if it's not, the added time of negotiation will make poking your eyes out with the robber by the end seem a better alternative. The initial setup and race to good spots is interesting but short lived.  Then comes an interminable 1.5-2 hours I can only liken to the last half of  The Return of the King where Sam and Frodo spend an equivalent amount of time flopping around on the side of Mount Doom.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I don't hate Settlers, but I could live without it. The thing that kills it for me is the fact that a player can be stuck with nothing to do turn after turn and there's nothing they can do about it. I don't mind luck in games, but when it reduces a player to a spectator, then I'd rather play something else.

The thing that I think bothers me even more than that is the playing time. I could live with the luck if this was a 45 minute game. In fact, if this was a 45 minute game I'd probably love it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
[Dice rolling, Resource Management, Building, Trading] [3P:3, 4P:3] A question: how is this better than Monopoly? The random resources are the worst aspect of the game. It's got the same basic problem as any game that uses a random mechanism to bestow resources - if luck is against you, you don't get anything. Zilch. Zip. There's no workaround. There are no alternative paths to victory. You NEED your numbers to be rolled. Yes, it will statistically even out, over several *games*, not the same game. Since Settlers takes up to two hours (or even more, aka "The Settlers Game from Hell" which I've been stuck in), that just doesn't cut it. In addition, the theme is remarkably uninspiring. Why are the resources random? We don't know. Somehow the sheep in this game don't grow wool on a regular basis. The trading is boring, consisting of people asking for the same things over and over - if brick is never rolled, *no one has it*. Gah. I don't see how this hooked so many people. This is "The New Monopoly". Avoid.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Now that I've tried Cities & Knights, I am less in love with the base game. But it is a classic with good reason. There is a lot of race tension, can go really quick, and more interaction than most other games we play. Yeah, it seems light compared to lots of other games, but to me, it really has a great balance of *fun* and competition. The only real problem gamers have with this game is that it's been overplayed. And so many gamers are allergic to dice. 

Still, I continue to be amazed at how much non-gamers love this and are willing to play this above any other Euro. Simple as this game may ultimately be, it sure captures the essence of gaming in a non-threatening way.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I love this game.  The production of resource mechanic means it's very difficult for players to be cut out entirely even if others refuse to trade, and in all the games I've played there's never been a serious dispute.  The variety of contributing elements to a win, the modular design for freshness...for me, it's perfect.  I look forward to someday getting the expansion and trying out 5 or 6 players. (9) 2011-04-08

UPDATE - I've played the 5-6 player expansion and like it.  Each player having the option to build at the end of each turn means your plans haven't been lost by the time it takes to go round the table, but in merry circumstances it does help to have someone 'chair' each round.  'Any building? Any other business? No?' (still a 9) 2016-12-08

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I am definitely in the camp that says this is one of the all-time great games. I will never "out-grow" this game. Even when it has hit the table a little too often, and I want a break from it, I still get into this game. We have had so many extremely close games that I am sure I will always play it. The only reason it isn't a "10" is that I can get a little burned-out sometimes. It doesn't last long, though. This is probably my favorite gateway, though TTR is my go-to.

Do NOT play a two-player variant.  It is horrible that way. 

See my full review at:
http://zwischen-zug.blogspot.com/2011/07/game-that-settles-in-never-to-leave.html
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Catan is a classic which can be recommended for both newbies and veterans. It's nicely expandable too and translated in many languages.

+ Nice combination of dice rolling, card drawing, building and trade.
+ Lots of interaction between players.
+ Relies heavily on luck, which keeps things fresh and gives newbies a chance...
- ...but can also be frustrating and prevent all strategic gameplay.
- Gets pretty crowded even with four players.

Review based on several plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent game, but remember that cities mean that you get *twice* the resource cards for the hexes they're adjacent to, not *one* per city -- and one resource per settlement and two per city that border on that resource.  Sometimes building in a port area can be helpful.  I like the newer (if more cheaply made) version of this game.  More fun to play if you use the "Cities and Knights" expansion.

It's a great game as a starting off point, but I rarely pull this game out now unless someone else really wants to play it.

RATING: 7.2
This was my, like many others, introduction to German board games.  We played this week in week out for 6 years between 1997-2003.  Up to that point I had no idea about the existance of similar games.
The flexibility in being able to mix several expansions and create your own worlds is fantastic.  The only negative is that in a 3/4 player game there is always one player far behind the others, and their game is over relatively quickly.

RATING: 10
In the beginning I thought this game would be more about the luck of the dice then strategy, but after my 1st game I have found that it is how you utilize the dice rolls to win the game. People who say this is all about rolling the dice and taking resources are not seeing the complete and total genius of this game. I have been gaming for over 20 years and this is a "must have" for every strategic gamer.

For all that I've played it, I still enjoy the experience - though I'd often rather play something else. Not because Settlers is bad, but because I've played Settlers about twice as much as my other games combined.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6
Esse jogo é uma excelente maneira de introduzir novos jogadores brasileiros ao mundo do jogos modernos. Ele é rápido, cada partida dura em média 50 minutos. As regras são fáceis de explicar (10 minutos). A jogabilidade é fantástica pois permite uma série de possibilidades e o peso dos dados (sorte) é pequeno em comparação aos jogos tradicionais do Brasil. Na realidade a sorte no CATAN "é para todos" já que o valor dos dados pode prejudicar ou beneficiar vários jogadores ao mesmo tempo. Outro fator importantíssimo é que todos os jogadores sempre crescem, uns mais que outros, mas sempre crescem. O tabuleiro formado de peças hexagonais, fato novo para o brasileiro, o que gera sempre um jogo diferente do outro devido a disponibilidade e organização dos recursos. Recomendo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I can only think of 3 games I've played hundreds of times and this is one of them. It has relatively simple rules and a randomness associated with setup and resource production which leads some people to believe that this game is more luck than skill. They are wrong. A combination of strategy , trading, and diplomacy can overcome bad initial setups and bad rolls of the dice.

The only thing that stops very experienced players from winning the vast majority of games against less experienced players is that the less experienced players learn after a few games that their only chance is to gang up on the more experienced/skilled player if it looks like they're in the lead. And that leads to more experienced players adopting strategies that make it appear as if they're behind in the first half of the game even though they're setting themselves up for a sprint at the end . . .

One thing I particularly love about this game are the slow-the-leader mechanisms (robber, trading embargoes, development cards) that makes it possible for people to come back from behind and win, which keeps everyone engaged, and makes this game fun to play even when player age and/or skill level is a wide range.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
This game has grown boring in my book. 
Too much luck dependant to my taste.
I only see myself playing this again if using a variant to mitigate the luck of the dice roll (e.g. Giving players a token each time a roll gives nothing to them, so later they might chance 10 of said tokens for any one resource). Otherwise, this game would be broken in my opinion. 

Definitely I won't play this again using  the official rules.

RATING: 6
Just the base game doesn't have enough to it to hold my attention squarely anymore. I'll teach it if somebody really wants to learn it, but I tend to hang out with board game crowds where everyone either already knows it or already knows it's a little too random and pre-determined for them. I like to play with the traditional randomized board setup on a single, hexagonal island, with the dice chits in alphabetical order. I say this because there are lots of variants, even on the base game. I've also played the Cities & Knights expansion, and while that's more interesting, it's also too long without adding enough depth. I think I've never played the 5-6 player version, even though I think the off-turn building rule change sounds pretty fun.

RATING: 9
Ok, lots of gamers have moved on from here and it tends to get a lot of flak.  However...this is still THE gateway game for many people, and it still sells by the bucketload.  It's fun, accessible, and there's nothing else out there that gives the same feeling.

Yes, it can sometimes be unbalanced and a bit random, but good play can mitigate all of that.  4P is the most balanced; 3P can suffer from runaway leader, and the 5-6P expansion is a bad implementation.

I've played literally hundreds of times, and will still come back for more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This is where it all started for me. After years of only playing games based upon luck (Monoply, Game of Life, Risk etc) I discovered Settlers of Catan; a game where your choices actually have an influence on the outcome of the game.

If had this game in my possession for about 12 years now, and we still play it regularly (althought most of the times with expensions).

Upsides of the game
- not very difficult to explain so you can play it with almost everyone;
- trading your commodities.

Why don't I rate the game with an eight? There is still to much luck involved in the Settles of Catan. And once you've played the game with one or more expansions the base-game gets a bit dull. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
A great family game, beginner game, or game for people who don't want to think too hard. Players get that good building-something feeling. Trading is fun too. Over the years, the role dice play in the game has gotten tiresome. This used to be an 8 for me. 

A good test of character is to see how upset someone gets when they have to lose their cards to the robber, when someone places the robber on one of their tiles, or when its their turn to place the robber :) Each of these challenges can reveal something unique about the players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good game for an active and talkative group. Some strategy mixed with a healthy dose of luck, but usually not so much that it seems based on it. The dice rolls typically pan out near averages over the course of a game due to the number of rolls. 

Not a lot of depth and once you have played this game a few times it will get stale as an experience. It is a very strong "gateway" game, but for people who are familiar with board games and mechanics, it will not be a very strong overall experience.

This game is definitely family friendly as well, but due to the complexity of the rules and of negotiation, it's not recommended for young children (10 and up are fine, 8-10 if they are advanced intellectually). 

Games don't take too long either, although they can drag if negotiations are too frequent. 

Overall, a 7, with the main faults being the level of luck and the fact that you really need an active group of players to have fun, since trading is such an integral part of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

29/10/2016: I really hate the random aspect of this game, from the setup until the end.

RATING: 8
2016
====

Catan is my family's favorite board game. As a gift to my oldest son a couple of years ago, Catan stands as possibly the best bang for our buck game purchase... well... ever. Whenever we have 2 hours to spare (rare these days) we break out this staple and rock and roll. Recently my family has taken to colluding against me (3 on 1) from the start. This doesn't bother me one bit as it adds a real edge to the game for me and presents quite a challenge to my wining prospects. I tend to not be a fan of explicit negotiation in games, but when it works it's exquisite.

[2014.03.01]
I like its general appeal and the ability to get in a quality game with people who wouldn't otherwise play games.

RATING: 8.741
Fabulous game that probably cemented my interest in Eurogames.  Probably more luck than you think, but a really nice game.    "We shall not cease from exploration, and the end of all our exploring will be to arrive where we started and know the place for the first time". T S. Eliot.  This quote reminds me of Settlers.  You buy it as a gateway game, go mad buying so many other games that you take it a bit for granted, but when you come back to Settlers after a break, you are reminded again that is it simply a brilliant piece of boardgaming (18/12/08 - Rating 9). UPDATE: Push to ten in that it is the cornerstone game for me (5/4/10 - Rating 10). UPDATE: This is still a very enjoyable game (and still a 10) (24/11/12). UPDATE: My new rating system is to 3 decimal places, so that when I eventually rate every game, I can do a top 100.  This is still a brilliant game, which for me is still an enjoyable experience.  So, the 3 decimal places, I rate is a 9.728 (Dec 2015). UPDATE: Maybe familiarity does breed contempt for my views now on Catan?  I still really like the game / series, but there are now for me better board gaming experiences I would rather go to.  Still rightly a classic, but I think I have reach a point where nothing is left to surprise or further delight me with this game (Rating 8.741, Feb 17).

RATING: 7
It's been 10 years since I played my first game of Catan. It is still an all-time classic for me.  I know that with it being more than 20 years old now that it definitely feels dated among all the other games that have come out.  A lot has happened since my first game of Catan.  But it still and always will have an honoured place in my heart. Once you accept the parameters and that this is a fortune-of-luck game, then it's all fine. I forever will love the aesthetic and I still enjoy the nostalgia. So there we go. My first crush I don't mind revisiting from time to time (especially with Seafarers or C&K as part of it).

Legacy comment (from 2008): What a fantastic game!  I had to buy it after playing it for the first time -- making this the second game I have ever bought new (1st was "Khet").  The trading really makes this game engaging across the table.

RATING: 5
[b]Recommended player count: 3-4[/b]

[b]Why I got rid of it:[/b]

I found the game simply over stayed its welcome by going on too long for what it was. The inter-player trading aspect only served to exacerbate that. If you don't get a good start by getting a good position on the map, prepare to endure a long game with frustratingly little you can do about it.

RATING: 7
Enjoyable introductory "German style" game. Within this genre of game, it is easy to learn, and the play moves along quickly with very limited pauses for strategizing. There is a bit of what I call a "Risk factor" in this game, namely that it often becomes clear who is going to win while there is still a fair amount of time left in the game. It is always annoying when you have to spend 20 minutes or more playing out a game that you know you've lost.

RATING: 7
The game that opened mine, and alot of others' eyes to a world beyond monopoly.  A classic.  I find I never tire of playing, and I don't mind the dependability on probability.  Not a deep. or heavy game in any sense, but it's hard to say if there are many better light, or gateway games.

UPDATE:  Although Settlers is a true classic, that would find it near impossible to ever leave my collection, I have to sadly say my rating has fallen to 7.  I still believe Settlers can offer a wonderful gateway experience, but with Elasund taking charge in the house of Catan, it rarely finds table time.  This great Teuber game I will always have a debt to for opening my eyes, but now, with the apple biten I no longer find paradise in this garden.



=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Newbies who think they've graduated to "real" board games love to denigrate this game for some reason, but it's really pretty unique if you look at it in the context of most other euros. It can drag a little, but overall I think this game still holds up and is fun to play.

Expansions owned:

[b][thing=325][/thing][/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Not your usual board game (Sorry, Clue, Monopoly) in that you don't have a token that you move around a board the number of spaces rolled on the dice. The "board" in this game is made up of hexagon tiles of 5 different resources that are randomly placed in a honeycomb and randomly assigned a number between 2 and 12. The ability to change the layout of the board allows for countless replay-ability. A great game for people looking to branch out from the standard board games, but I imagine it would be a little overwhelming to grasp the rules by simply reading the rule book included, it would be best to find someone with experience to teach you the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's hard to score this game as although its gameplay value is beyond dispute, the level of inherent randomness is way too high for most players. As a result, once every player is in possession of the fundamental skills needed to play, the winner is pretty much decided by the roll of the dice. Try substituting cards for the dice to cut down on the luck factor.

On the other hand, this game is just so much plain old fun that it is hard for me (and everyone else) to keep from playing from time to time. Just don't take it too seriously. This game is never followed by sessions of analyzing who did what wrong or right, if you know what I mean. Real solid games are almost always followed up by such discussions in our group. This is not such a game.

RATING: 6
Overall, I like Settlers of Catan - the mechanics and gameplay are overall smooth while there are plenty of decisions to make. Where I take issue, however, is with the complete lack of ability to affect the dice rolls...I've played games where the dice rolls are overall pretty even, allowing for constant forward momentum, but I've also played others where a player (feels like always me, but that's probably just confirmation bias) rolls nothing of use for several turns in a row, effectively cutting them off at the knees. There are so many expansions to this game that it's probably been sorted somewhere along the way, but there are just other games that I would rather play instead.

RATING: 7
The old, venerable "got wood for sheep?" classic.  Probably the best known game in my collection among my friends, most of whom are not gamers.  The good is that Settlers is extremely easy to explain: roll, trade, build, next player.  Play is as fast as people can seal trade deals, and there is a good deal of player interaction.  The bad is that the game is just a little too long these days has been eclipsed by newer designs.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
In my opinion, Settlers of Catan is quickly becoming one of 'the' new classics of the modern gaming age.  This is a perfect gateway game for those that lived on Monopoly and Life and want to take their board game experience to a new level.  That being said, you can only play this game so many dozens of times before it gets old.  Luckily, Mayfair Games gave us expansions.  To remove some of the luck aspect, I highly recommend this rule from the expansions: whenever a production roll results in a player receiving no resources (except on a "7"), that player receives 1 gold.  2 gold can be traded for one resource of the player's choice during their turn.

I own three copies of this game.  One is my personal copy and the other is still in shrink and unpunched.  It's signed by Klaus Teuber.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
This is an excellent game to bring casual game players into the universe of European-style strategy and resource games. I've hooked any number of people on Catan after just a couple of plays.

The game also lends itself to a moderate amount of customization. People create their own house rules easily, dramatically changing the strategy. The expansions and ability to create random or custom maps also adds to its re-playability.

Catan's greatest weakness is in the, often, random distribution of land tiles and number markers. Poor distribution can lead to long, tedious games or severely unbalanced gameplay. A little less random distribution tend to even this out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Sold. 2007 Mayfair edition

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I'm very torn on this game. I played it after being introduced to more modern designer games, so the flaws with Catan were very apparent. In board games and video games, I hate having my ability to act removed from me. 

Between bad dice rolls and relying on players to trade goods, I can wait 10 minutes to take my turn only to roll the dice and pass. I don't like the excitement of taking my turn turning in to disappointment when no one will trade me a sheep for 2 of my wheat, or just having the dice (once again) fail to roll my areas. 

At the same time, having an "average" game is pretty enjoyable. And I think my wife put it best when she said that the game is most fun when everyone is relaxed and willing to trade, rather than being cutthroat and always denying one another.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Kristof, Fre, Robby, tom

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[Original comment] This is currently the favorite game in our family (April 2005). It has most of the features we enjoy about gaming. There is a lot of interaction and negotiation with other players; the gameboard is different every time; there are enough important factors to consider that no single strategy will win every time; there is just enough randomness to make it interesting (and sometimes frustrating); the rules are not complicated; the game time is just right (we can now play a 5-player game in about an hour); and players have a number of options almost every turn, to require some decision-making. It's an excellent family game.

Update February 2006 -- We usually play with 6 players now, and it is still a family favorite.

(December 2006) And now, we're playing with 7 players, and it's still a favorite, although we've had to modify some rules to play with that many.

May 2009 -- This is still a family favorite, and we play it often.

October 2011 -- This long-time family favorite continues to be at or near the top of our selection lists for game days. We always play with at least 5 players, which makes for a crowded map. The negotiations, blocking, the moans over the dice rolls, and the surprises (like stealing the Longest Road to win the game) keep it high on our list of favorites. I doubt we will ever tire of this game, which is about as high a compliment as can be made.

November 2012 -- We may play this game forever. Our daughter and son-in-law purchased the fancy version with wood tiles, which makes the game much more attractive. It continues to be a family favorite.

2013-November:  We haven't changed our minds about this game -- it's still a family favorite.

RATING: 10
A classic!  Spent many sleepless nights at Denny's with friends over this game.  Played it since the first Mayfair English version came out.  I'm glad to see that it is finally catching on to the mainstream gaming community!  Bit too much luck is involved with the dice rolls at times, but the game is well balanced over time.  Loved by my guy friends and gal friends, gamers and non-gamers alike.  Scoring is simple, and almost every game everyone gets the feeling that they are somewhat close to winning.  Perhaps not the best game ever made in the modern time, but definitely the first of the best that opened the door for many more to come -- for that, it deserves a 10!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Finally, after hearing about it for many years, I got to play it recently and can't get enough. I quickly ramped up from being a beatable newbie to worthy opponent after picking up the strategies and tactics after one game. Lives up to billing as "Game of the Century". Our version is original Settlers; this is "house" game owned by my son.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dunno what to say about Settlers that hasn't been said.  It's pretty easy to pick up but meatier and more interesting than, say, Carcassonne for me (if not as interesting to look at on the table...).  I enjoy playing Settlers quite a bit and it still got one of the most positive receptions among my lighter euro group friends I've played with.  I think, as some of the ATers have pointed out in the past, the attractive thing about the game is that it's a design that crosses a lot of boundaries.  There is trading and building with victory points but it also has a number of screwage elements like the robber and has some randomness in the design.  This is definitely a crossover in almost all sense of the word.

RATING: 7
What's extraordinary, I made (with a little help of my wife) a home version of this game. Without any printing or photocoping. Just various kinds of paper, scissor, glue, crayons, felt-tip pens. Yes, I was desperate that time. Some things happen once in a lifetime :-). What can be irritating in the game are the dice (randomness). On the other hand the trade aspect is great. It's a good gateway game (not so family anyway) and I can play it from time to time.

RATING: 7
Like many, Settlers was our first foray into board-gaming and to this day it's still a gem to play. The game's biggest draw for us is the player interaction - players gain resources out of turn if their numbers come up. Combine this with lots of resource trading and Settlers is a load of fun with little downtime.

I haven't played this game in years (we almost exclusively play 2P now). I'd have to revisit to see how it holds up.

Kept in my collection more for nostalgia value these days I guess, although it might see a revival one day.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The original is still very good at what it does. This is the board game that you introduce to someone who thinks Monopoly and Clue are the sum total of what board games represent. Sit this one down in front of them, get them to try it out a few times, and then slowly introduce them to actual GAMES! 
I mean, there's a renaissance out there people!

There are games on the market that create experiences you could only have if you had an actual working TARDIS: WWII battles, pursuing Jack the Ripper down a twisted branching alleyway, or defending King Arthur from a betraying errant knight.
I marvel at the current artistry of the Golden Age of game design. We truly live in interesting times.

You know what? Don't play this game with people who've only ever played YHATZEE and BUNKO. Screw 'em!  If they've limited their experience of game mechanics to the intricacies of Chutes and Ladders, then this game is too good for 'em! They're in the Dark ages (which is a great expansion for Dominion, by the way).
Let those people go. You can't save them. They're weighing you down. Cut the rope. 
Move on.

RATING: 5
I don't get the fascination people have with this game.

Luck is a deciding factor in this game, it features lengthy periods of down time (when all you do is roll the dice because you have no resources, and that roll is more likely to help others than you), and has king-making issues.

Basically, if you like "strategy" games like Monopoly, you should love this one. Otherwise, I don't get how anyone likes it.

RATING: 5
Game that introduced me to gaming. Of course I will always love it for that. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
For many players this is the introduction game to the hobby, but not for me as I learn to enjoy euros through other games. That is maybe why I don’t have the same nostalgia associated with this game as many other gamers. The game is fairly straightforward to explain, where the phases are distinct and simple. During the game there is usually not much thinking about how to use your resources, but there is definitely an amount of resource management.

What it comes down to in most game in my experience is two things, die rolling and initial set up. If you get your machine going in the beginning of the game you are hard to stop. The robber is simply not enough to stop and by not trading with him you might lose out on that too. That is also my main complaints about the game; there is too much luck and circumstances. 

I like to play this game with either 3 or 4 players. With 4 players the board is a little tighter, so players can be shut-in, but that is generally in the end game anyway.

RATING: 4
Eight plays: twice with no expansions, thrice with Cities & Knights, once with fishermen, one five-player game with both Cities & Knights and Seafarers, once six-player with Seafarers.

Catan is tolerable with just the base game and four players; it's luck-heavy, and your most important decision happens in the first five minutes, but it's over fairly quickly. It's also probably not too bad with four players and just Seafarers. However, when you add on expansions that significantly increase the length and complexity, it just becomes a bore. I think I would even go so far as to say that I actually loathe it in those situations.

I'm willing to give it one more try if forced to, but otherwise I'm done with this.

RATING: 9
This is another game that is great with 6 people (we have the expansion set).  I love the negotiating of resources - I've always liked Monopoly because of this, and the same principles apply in Catan.  The fact that dice rolls can affect who wins the game is not the best game mechanic, because there may be too much chance involved.  But if your placements are evenly spread out among many numbers you can limit this risk - which is a good game strategy.
