=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The Settlers of Catan may well be the single greatest board game ever designed. Like many other German games, it combines simple rules and a short playing time with the potential for intricate strategy and battles of wits. But Catan is arguably the best example of bringing all these elements into perfect balance.

Catan satisfies a wide range of people, even those who normally hate board games, since it is the players themselves that choose the character of each game. It can be as cutthroat or as amiable as you want (or both!). It also excels at keeping every player actively involved at all times, both through the ingenious system of resource production and the constant opportunities for trading and deal-making. I could go on, but others already have.

I have no hesitation in recommending Settlers of Catan to pretty much anyone. From there, you may choose to explore more complex or more simple-structure games, but Catan is good for all!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This being a very popular game, often referred to as a gateway game, I had high expectations for my first play. I was a little disappointed, although it is clear this is a good game. The most disappointing element is that this game is essentially Monopoly, as the rich get richer and the poor fade away. When someone isn't producing, they have no opportunity to trade and are essentially out of the game. There's little balancing there, as the only thing such players can hope for is pity. (There's no pity in this sort of game. Altruism is almost never a factor in a game unless no one is actually playing to win.) I imagine the German expansion with the helper cards (somewhat recreated in the Star Trek variant) and/or the cards that replace the dice would be a bit of an improvement, but at that point you almost have a different game. Regardless, I'll be willing to play. There's something absurdly fun about people begging for sheep.

RATING: 5
Ezzel kerültem kapcsolatba újra a társasjátékok világával. A maga idejében jól ki volt használva. Akkoriban rendkívül izgalmasnak találtam. A nyersanyagok kockával kidobása viszont egyre jobban idegesített. Nem mintha zavarna, ha egy játékban sok múlik a szerencsén, de bosszantó ha a nyavalyás sorsvetőn ilyen sok múlik. És a többi játékos kínlódását is alig tudom kivárni. És az se tetszik, hogy kialakulhat egy olyan helyzet, hogy még azért is küzdeni kell ,hogy élvezzem a játékot, mert alig maradt lehetőségem a játékban a terjeszkedésre és/vagy a kereskedésre. Szóval most ott pihen a szekrényben, mert minek üljek le olyan játékhoz ami csak felidegesít. Végül a sírját az újdonság utáni vágyam ásta meg.

De ha jobban belegondolok a hetes dobásokkal lett tele a tököm.

A mobilon azért ott van. Hosszabb utazáson még mindig el lehet vele ütni az időt. Az AI nem gondolkozik sokat. :)

RATING: 10
A beautifully simple game.  The rules can be taught in a couple of minutes and due to the changing board and dice roles every game is different.  I've played literally hundreds of games and they're always fun.  Yes, sometimes you can have run away winners, and with the huge amounts of luck involved you can have a very poor game without really doing anything wrong, but the game is quick enough to play a few times an evening.  The more you play the more you find ways to mitigate against all the dice roles and maximise your resources, and quite quickly you find the number of games where you think you were unlucky dramatically starts to drop.

RATING: 7
The classic German game.  The game is pretty simple compared to most other popular German games, but can still involve quite complex strategies in the form of trades and bluffing.  Trade is an essential part of the game, which means everyone's involved at all times, especially with five or six players.  It does have a fairly significant luck component, but competent players can hedge their bets.  A good choice for people just starting with German games.

RATING: 6
I like this game when the dice cooperate, and I hate it when they don't. They usually don't. There's nothing worse than waiting 15 minute before you can do anything because the right numbers didn't come up.

It's so strange that this is the ultimate gateway game. It guess it makes some sense from the perspective of complexity. It's got some interesting mechanics without being hard to learn. But it has such huge flaws. Every game seems to drag about 20 minutes too long. Careful planning can be ruined by unlucky dice rolls. And the difference between winning and losing is actually very subtle. Getting those last two points is crazy tricky for a game that's supposed to be relatively simple.

RATING: 7.5
I've probably played this a hundred times by now and while I'll still play it, it's never going to be my first choice. There's a lot of luck involved, which can be frustrating but also can make for memorable games and really dramatic moments. For a more "even" game, it's easy to swap in a card deck for die rolls but I feel like the game loses some charm this way. Annoyingly, in a game where the ideal choice is usually fairly obvious, there tends to be a lot of analysis paralysis when newer players know they can work out the odds but take a long time to do so. Having a "longest turn" card which subtracts VPs is a great addition when everyone has similar levels of experience with the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've been in the gaming scene long enough to know that this title is not the end all be all of gaming.  If anyone were to tell me that this was their favorite board game, I would have to ask them if they had played any other euro games.  I can't but think that anyone who had tried several titles would have to know that the genre has evolved since Catan.

Still, Catan is not completely obsolete.  It occupies a unique position in that it is light years ahead of Parker Brothers in terms of depth, but still accessible enough to be interesting to new players who are not immersed in board gaming.  This makes it valuable as a gateway game.  I still use this to introduce friends to serious board gaming.

The gameplay itself is perhaps better than people give it credit for.  The negotiations for resources are always interesting.

The biggest problem with the game comes down to how much the dice can deny unlucky players a chance to enter the game.  Good placement and smart trading can only take you so far, but I've played numerous games in which for the first several turns only three numbers were rolled.  There are house rules and expansions that help smooth out the distribution of resources, but ultimately a pig-headed group can ruin your game.

That is not an unforgivable feature of a game.  Most games are more fun with better players, but some games just do a better job of making sure the players have to really work to hold their lead.

Ultimately, I think this a title that is well worth owning.  Even though I don't really play it with my regular game group any more, I still enjoy introducing it to new players or taking it for a spin for old time's sake.  Gaming has moved on from Settlers, which may make it seem like it's gotten worse, but it's still as strong of title as it ever was.  If you don't have it, you may not need to buy it, but if you do have it, you probably shouldn't sell it.  You'll eventually be glad you still have it.

It is worth mentioning that Catan now has approximately one million expansions and more seem to come out all the time.  Perhaps they've found a way to reproduce?  At any rate, these expansions do make the game better.  However, I think this is more worthwhile as a means of extending the life of your current copy of the game than as a reason for buying the base game.

Right now, Catan with two expansions costs around $80 ($100 for a six player board).  With three you're looking at $120 ($140 for six players).  I have had fun playing with the expansions, but I don't think the experience was worth that much, especially when Archipelago is only $60 and doesn't need expansions to be awesome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent Board Game, One Of the Best Board Games EVER! I love this Game and I am obsessed with it. (So my Girlfriend!) Recommended.

RATING: 7
Played this to death many years before I even got into the hobby. Doesn't get to the table much nowadays though. Always happy to join in on a game however and will even suggest it for nostalgia's sake.

I like a balanced game of Settlers, but unfortunately not every game is balanced. Either I don't receive many resources and can hardly do anything, or I receive plenty of resources and end up feeling guilty towards the other players.

I'm not a huge fan of the 'will you trade your wool for my brick' mechanic. Many times people just don't want to trade with me (it feels like) or I feel like I ended up helping them more than myself.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Incluye expansion 5~6 jugadores. Revendido por V.Karku

Los jugadores ya avezados lo encontraran quiza con "poca chicha", pero yo lo considero un buen juego para iniciarse en las mecanicas de los "modernos" juegos de mesa. facil de comprender y apto para todos los publicos. 

En mi opinion destacan las fases de negociacion. esos "oveja por ladrillo?"..."dos ovejas por ladrillo?" son ya un clasico del mundillo. 

Las expansiones le vienen bien para "darle vidilla" y mejorar versatilidad (el original solo admite 3 o 4 jugadores).

de hecho ese es en mi opinion el principal defecto del juego: que se creó inicialmente para 3-4 (y SOLO 3-4) jugadores, luego fue expandido y DESPUES DE ESO fue cuando salió la expansión para adaptarlo a 5-6 jugadores... mas luego las expansiones para adaptar las expansiones existentes a 5-6 jugadores. un desperre y un caos. 

quisieron evitar vender un nuevo juego base con el que las expansiones antiguas no fueran compatibles y en mi opinion fue peor el remedio que la enfermedad. :/

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Still one of the best "gateway" games if you're trying to branch out from Sorry, Monopoly, Clue, or party games.  Over time if you find that you love this game and start playing more Euros, you may find that the luck element in Catan can occasionally make the game miserable for someone playing. The rich get richer if you are left far behind by bad dice rolling, and don't gain any resources, and are then not someone anyone wants to trade with. This chain reaction can lead to someone watching everyone else play Settlers of Catan. 

That said, this was the game that launched me into Eurogames, and I'll always play it with a group of new initiates to the hobby.

RATING: 7
Siedler! An excellent game that I dislike. Now, it’s quite easy to coax me into playing, and play will be fun and intense, but to be good at this game you cannot rely on luck and placement alone; you need to enjoy and be good at trading, negotiating, and manipulating your co-players in order to overcome shortages, bad die rolls, and poor odds. Good at this I am not; neither do I enjoy it. Still, a great game.

RATING: 7
Rating based off of first game that I played and taught my 8 year-old twin daughters. They learned it pretty easily, though the game took a while because of one of the girls not keeping her hand in order, especially later when we all started getting more cards. I won with 11 points after I played a Knight to take the Biggest Army card from one of my girls (who ended up with 7 points down from 9 and could have won the next turn otherwise) and my other daughter finished with 9 points. So it was a really close game and we were all in it to the end. Trading went well and they picked up on that quickly and were good sports about it. 

My one complaint so early in my experience with the game is the components, and that was reflecting in my rating. They aren't the greatest. The perimeter puzzle pieces are kind of flimsy and bend easily with humidity. Considering the game came out so long ago, perhaps they just didn't make component's as thick back then? 

My rating will likely go up with more plays. I like the simplicity of it and I love that my kids really like it, so that means it will get more play and that's always part of ratings for me. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3

Les partides s'assemblen molt entre si. Els jugadors molt competitius ignoren la part de negociar que té el joc, el que el fa encara més depenent de l'atzar. La col·locació inicial és molt important, et pot deixar fora de la partida...

RATING: 8
Truly one of the best gateway games ever.  Base game can get old after a few dozen plays and the dice can sometimes be frustrating.  Game can be obnoxious if you get screwed early by the starting placement.  Few games are as dependent on the starting placement as Settlers, which can hinder newbies who try to pick up the game as it goes.  There is a lot more tension, conflict, and interaction than you would expect.  A classic I don't think will be replaced.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I mean, it's a classic, and the game that got me into board games. With that said, it's very rare this one comes out any more. The reliance on dice for everything takes quite a lot of the joy out of it. I could play amazingly well and still be messed about by factors entirely out of my control. I like the randomness of dice when they make me think on my feet and be flexible with strategy. I'm less thrilled when they make me completely uncompetitive. With that said, it's still fun, and does plenty right with the selling aspects, and multiple strategies to victory. The benchmark.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Tough to say anything bad about this one. Easy rules, strategic depth, meaningful choices, beautiful components, just the right length, a gateway for many people to eurogames. I find it really works best with 4 players (or maybe 3), but more than that really changes the dynamics. So much depends on the initial placement that it can be frustrating for someone new, so the recommended setup can ease this. I still love to play it and I can't see that ever changing. I don't understand the burnout some people feel on this game, there really is still nothing quite like it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It's quite a shame that it has become "cool to hate" on Catan. Still a highly entertaining game that can be quite cutthroat among experienced players. I personally find it best with 4 and I'm not a fan of the 5-6 player expansions much, and nor is it as good with 3, but still worth periodically revisiting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

**Update (01/09/06): Lowered rating to a 7.  This usually only gets played with six people, so my rating reflects how horribly long it can be with that many.  I'd give this game an 8 with four players and a 6 or less with six playrs.

RATING: 5
This is a classic entry point to Eurogames for newbies.  However, it can be frustrating for new players if they place their initial settlements badly.  It is not so fun for me because it is heavily dependent on dice rolls.  And then there is the fact that the game can take forever as people try to request ridiculous offers for resources.  Near the end of the game, nobody should be trading with any player that has a chance of winning, so that should speed things up... but then players end up stuck, not being able to make progress on their own, and then possibly losing half of their hand to the Robber.

RATING: 7

The strategy employed by my friends was different than the one I used on my own.  Simple to understand and easy to set up, Catan is a great introductory board game for the uninitiated (like myself). 

Now that I own a digital copy on my Playstation, I've been trying to play as much as I can to stay fresh.

RATING: 8
A light game with good depth of strategy and high repeat play value. 
Modular board is easily disrupted from table knocks so difficult to play with little kids around.
There is a lot (too much) strategy in the setup and a somewhat premature ending (ends just when things start to get going).
The limited use of dice adds a nice 'take that' mechanic, spices things up nicely without being too random.

RATING: 6.5
A tad luck-heavy with the robber and the resource gathering, and what I really don't like is the deadlock mechanic - once a road is set, there's no undoing it. It's nice that this makes the game progress, and it adds some underhanded conflicts to a seemingly low-conflict game - but I really don't like how this makes you unable to recover from mistakes.

But then, I only played the game like three times, and a long time ago. My assessment meanwhile might change. But I still do like games where it's possible to grab land from each other after and counteract against a strike of luck, and Settlers doesn't appear to easily allow that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
For a Euro type game, there is luck involved.  Although the trade mechanic is fun, it really is all about selecting the best location to establish your towns/cities.

If your numbers don't come up often, then you will quickly fall behind.  Initial placement, luck of the die and cards make a very large difference at the start of the game, but can be compensated via inter-player trade.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is the perfect middle-weight resource management, trading, and route-building Euro. Many games do some of the things that Catan does better - for example Bohnhanza is a better light trading game, and Genoa is a better heavy trading game. However, there is something about Catan that is lovely. It's deep enough to bring people into the fray while still being light enough (and intelligible enough) that folks who don't know much about modern Euro gaming can still easily jump in.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It is only fitting that my very first post to this board be towards the first game that opened my eyes to a different level of board games -- and BoardGameGeek.

I would actually have given The Settlers of Catan a "10", if it were not for the expansions -- which are even better than the base game, in my opinion.

In any case, this was my first experience with a game of this type.  I grew up in a world of Monopoly, Life, Sorry!, Yahtzee, etc. -- all okay games in themselves, especially when playing with friends and family.  This, however, was the first non video game that really involved some strategy and thought -- and officially blew all of those previous family games out of the water.  It was an instant hit for this family of three!

We rarely play it these days due to our enjoyment of the expansions, but I would still look forward to playing it, if I did not have the expansions at my fingertips.

Overall, a wonderful game that involves thought and strategy, but is not overly deep to frighten gamers new to this realm.  I can definitely see why this is used as a "gateway game".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I know this places me firmly in the minority, but I dislike this game. Settlers actually delayed by a few years my reunion with boardgaming ("This is the *premier* example of Eurogames?!?").  Two major complaints: 1)Initial placement seems to have an unusually large impact on the game (since the first few placements will be made on higher probability resources); 2) The trading aspect of the game really turns me off, since some players can be quite capricious during trading (but maybe that's more a comment on some of the folks I've gamed with).  Some of the expansions/variations do provide improvements on the basic game.  I'll still play this game, but I'll pick almost anything else if given the chance.

RATING: 9
Great game. Now I can see why this is the game people are always talking about when they're talking about gateway games and modern boardgames. A true classic, which I can see getting a lot of plays, most of which are balanced. There is a moderate amount of luck, but a good player almost always will beat a bad player. It's also making success with people who aren't "gamers" and they even requested to play another matches. I really recommend this to anyone, it's easy, relatively quick, has lots of interaction, an adequate amount of luck and pretty components.

RATING: 6
This game was my first encounter with modern board games. The basic idea is great which grant you a ton of theme. We used to play it a lot, and im still happy to get it on the desk. It has easy rules, which means it is easy to teach. The robber is also a great addition to stop someone who is in front of you in terms of points.

Pros / Cons:
-Every game is different because of the constantly changing map and due to this always different opportunities.
-I love the trading mechanics that completly kills the downtime in the game.
-You roll a 7 and immediatelly start laughing while you are looking into the victim eyes is a fantastic feeling.

-I absolutely hate to be tricked by luck, so these dices are killing me sometimes (even if im on 8 and we always roll just 4-5-6 for example).
-You can be blocked right after the first few turns, and after this you don't have chance to overcome it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
2-21-10
Lowered my rating from an 8 to a 6 now that I've played both ways (randomizing the board and playing the 'beginner' setup). I realize this game isn't as much fun as I once hoped.  It's too random as to who is getting which resources, you can't really get any type of momentum going unless the dice are in your favor.  You can trade, sure, but if you have the same junk everyone else wants, you're out of luck.

You can get built in if other people are able to expand faster than you, and it can get to the point in a 4-player game where one or two people get 'eliminated' by the halfway mark of the game.

It takes too long for the level of depth.  Two hours for this game is absurd!  There needs to be more points in the deck as otherwise it's just not a wise investment.  Too many knight cards.

The social aspect of the game is fun but the game itself doesn't feel much more fun than games like Monopoly, because really, if you don't get the dice rolls and don't have the right stuff to trade, you lose - just like Monopoly.  At least in Monopoly when you get to the point where you know you can't win, you can just trade away your money and properties and go do something fun.  Here you get stuck being useless until somebody finally gets 10 points.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Catan the base game is so fundamental to board games mainly for 3 reasons:

1.) It brought together a couple nifty mechanisms, most of all the modular hex board and trading,
2.) it kicked of the golden age of board games,
3.) it is the base for its expansion Cities & Knights, which is a truly formidable game.

Still good to play with young people, but usually I'll insist on playing Cities & Knights instead.

RATING: 6
This game suffers from a lot of criticism due to its popularity.  But it remains one of the gold standards of gaming.

It is fun, relatively quick, simple and accessible.

And it's more than a gateway game : it represents the fun that board games can provide at a more elemental level, or the creativity that games can generate through its myriad official and unofficial expansions and house rules.

An essential part of the core of any games collection.

RATING: 9
A classic, and highly rated in my collection because of its interactiveness and ability to be played by many family members.  This is truely a break-out game for introducing new players to board games. 

I have many of the expansions and variants, and have had fun building historical expansions.  (I modeled my own Settlers of Cannan with sculpey and cards, and have turned it into a historically educational variant...)  

You have a wide range of complexity, and a great deal of luck within the game, making it addaptable to many audiences.  Finnaly, the end game is very visually appealing, with all the pieces and tiles togther.  

Downside is storing all the pieces and parts, keeping instructions of all the variants, and setup time for many of the variants.  Another down side is getting players to not roll the dice into the board!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

But it is somewhat strict on the number of players: 3 or 4 only. (more with expansions)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This was a completely new gaming experience when I first played this. There's a lot of luck with the resource generation, but it is really a matter of "covering all the numbers", or making sure you can generate/trade resources whenever you can. Easy to play, but filled with a wide range of strategies, and just the right amount of luck. I've used this as a gateway game to convert several Scrabble die-hards into enthusiastic Settlers fans! The Cities & Knights expansion adds another layer of complexity, and more tension. The 5-6 player expansions add yet another dimension to the game, with the addition of the "special build" reactionary phase. Seafarers seems to be suited for scenario play, but not much else. Initial rating: "8". Peaked at "9", briefly with the 5-6 player expansion.

Update (05/28/2009): 6 F2F plays. This is turning out to be a frustrating game, in terms of the trends in dice rolling. Some games are simply dominated by an preponderance of 5's, 9's, 10's... any number that I happen to NOT be on. Or it could go the other way; there have been games where several people sit around and cannot do anything, simply because the rolls are not coming up in the frequency that they should be based on statistics. Either the dice are funky (which mean don't play with the dice that came with the game), or this is just one of those things. The Law of Large Numbers indicates that eventually, EVENTUALLY, the dice will start rolling favorably. But this trough of bad luck could last most of the entire game, making play extremely frustrating. It may be time to start using the "number cards", because this is starting to break the game for me, as well as others. This is evidenced by the fact that most meetup members refuse to play this game because of its excessive randomness. Dropping to a "7".

Update (08/17/2010): Lately, it hasn't gotten the love it once engendered. Downgrading to a "6".

Update (12/21/2013): It has been 4.5 years since last play. It is a significant achievement in the world of board gaming, truly a "classic" in every meaning of the word right up there with Monopoly--a game that is even "better" than Monopoly. It was a great game for the period, but the group has moved on to greener pastures. It looks like the game doesn't have the legs we thought it had; since there is too much unmitigated randomness, it has alienated most of the veteran gamers I know. But, the design is a perfect blend of competition, negotiation/trading, randomness, and skill, with a very accessible rule set and game mechanics, I am sure it will continue to bring in and endear many new generations of board gamers to come. Still holding at a "6".

Update (03/13/2015): 7 F2F plays. Finally! After nearly six years, we played a 4-player, base Catan game! It's like a homecoming. We forgot some of the basic rules, but the fun was back. Nice, quick romp, just like Dominion--a classic that you never forget. Still a "6".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is the game that started it all for me. Now it's four years later, and no matter how many other games I try I can always be convinced to go back and play a game of Settlers.

This game is everything a board game should be. It's simple enough on the surface that anyone can pick it up, but there's enough depth of strategy that you'll be just as entertained on the 50th play through. Games are long enough to be satisfying, but you don't have to give up an afternoon to play. It has the perfect level of randomness; skilled players win more often than not, but it doesn't mean they always do (which keeps it fun for all). Last of all, the shifting board and the importance of politics make this game endlessly replayable.

The only con I can see is that sessions of this game have on occasion almost descended into fisticuffs over particularly jerk trades.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

There is no strategy and there is only one path to victory, all players are aiming at the same thing, and loads, loads, loads of pure luck. Don't waste your time.

RATING: 7
Some gamers I know really do treat this game as a "disposable" gateway game but, actually, I'd be quite happy to play it again.  It is possible that I might have overrated it simply because I haven't played it for ages.  One thing I do recall is that the die rolling does make it very random.  The are simply not enough rolls of the two dice in the game to get close to the distribution of totals that you use as a basis for deciding how to place settlements, which is often quite disheartening.  Perhaps too random for a gamers' game and too complicated for a family game, but quite good fun none-the-less.

RATING: 3
Frustrating and slow to get moving if the dice abhor you from the start. The game gets better once more towns are built and there is an economy for real trading to occur. 

Regardless, there is no mechanism to affect dice rolls. If you have nothing worthwhile to trade and roll badly then you sit idle while your opponent's roads/towns corral you to a steady cancerous death. Unforgiving for a gateway game. This game will make you hate bad dice more than Monopoly. How did this game start a revolution?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
Great overall game, good for group interaction.  Concept and strategy are very good with multiple and dynamic paths to victory.  Games are usually balanced but lopsided ones happen occasionally.  Dice rolling means a small luck factor, but it's strategic enough that a few bad rolls won't break you.  Highly replayable.  Trading aspect is interesting also and means very little downtime during other players' turns.  The fact that gamers and non-gamers alike enjoy it is a big plus also ("no, not another movie... how about a game of Settlers?").  The cost of expansions and the possibility of a player being blocked off early in the game keep this from a higher rating.  BGG users have suggested several good variations for this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I want to like this game more. I just can't stand the luck element. There are times in the game where I have terrible luck and do nothing while everyone around me is collecting rescources and building stuff.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Not a game I seek out, but one I will always play if suggested by other people.

A math professor friend of mine taught me that the key to the game is analyzing the opening board.  You can always get beat by the luck of the dice, but knowing where the place settlements at the start of the game will mitigate random chance to significant margins.  Once you do that, the game itself becomes academic, unless at least two of the other players are similarly capable.

Basically, once you know the secret of Catan, you can only play against other people who also know the secret.  Unless you enjoy beating up on freshmen.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
We play Settlers at lunch time when running our school holiday program, Kraftworks for Kids. The program is for kids aged 9 - 14. The kids really enjoy this game. We pair up the beginners with one of the Leaders while those who have played a few games are able to play without assistance. Sometimes we don't finish the game by the end of lunch but it can easily be resumed at the end of the day while waiting for parents to arrive. Lots of fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The very essense of what makes a game elegant: simple rules, fun to play and there's nothing in the game that doesn't have a place or that shouldn't be there. OK, it's a probability-based game, so you can play optimally and still lose, while the random setup occasionally produces a board so imbalanced that the start player effectively wins by placing his first settlement. Overall though, a superlative game with bags of appeal to both gamers and families alike that would have entirely eclipsed Monopoly by now, if only Settlers were better known. This is the gateway game that I turn to whenever I'm playing with casually interested 'non gamers'. It's never missed yet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

The base game is probably the best, although I'm happy with the expansions and C&K in particular adds some interest.

RATING: 8
I love this game. I love building up settlements and cities, trying to balance my need for different resources against the desire to corner the market on one of them. The dice roll to determine resource draws (and to enact hand size penalty) means that early-game positioning provides real advantages but keeps comebacks possible.

The only complaints that I have are that politicking takes some of the fun out (everyone hates me because I am ahead! :[ ), and bargaining can stretch the game out too long -- the game is on the long side to begin with, so hagglers can make it seem interminable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I used to love this game, but compared to how far board games have come it has not aged well. Luck plays much too high a part and unlike newer games, the entire course of the game is determined in the first 5 minutes while you place your settlements. This can be crippling for beginner players, as there is no way to recover mid to late game if you make a poor start. But even good placement can mean nothing if the dice gods are not in your favor. Newer games allow for mistakes and provide greater player control. As it is I would be happy never playing this again. This had once been my go to gateway intro title, but that slot has been replaced by Alhambra, Lords of Waterdeep, and Stone Age. Compared to these titles Catan is clunky and inelegant.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The popularity of the game is understandable, and it undoubtedly makes for a reasonable gateway game. Safe to say it's not one for me, and I've often deliberately sat out when others want to play it.

Like: The control over territory is interesting, with the ability to block certain routes and attempt to control certain resource types.

Dislike: All of the randomness brought about by constant dice rolling, with no way to mitigate it at all. The feeling of other people getting resources on your turn, while you get nothing and are unable to build, is incredibly infuriating. Potentially group-specific, but the discussion around trading can drag on for far too long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This game takes some time to setup and go over the rules, however it's simple once you have the hang of it.  It has just the right amount of strategy and luck to make it enjoyable for everyone.  In the game we played we were shorted brick so it was a scramble to build much with those components so we spent most of our time trading in goods for what we needed.  Rock and Wheat were in over abundance.

RATING: 6.5
Spiel des Jahres 1995
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
1995 Spiel des Jahres Winner
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An amazing, well-balanced, fun game with tremendous replay value.  I don't understand why some game fiends get snobbish about not wanting to play SoC, like they're above the game, deriding it as a newb game.  It persists to this day as--by far--the best selling import, and was profoundly influential in the explosion of the hobby for a reason.  I recall vividly, how when I viewed the back of the box to decide if I would buy SoC, I became extremely excited about how the game board is rearranged every play, which launches the replayablity into orbit.  The gameplay is impacted by luck via rolling dice, but the game is a winner, regardless.  The player interaction is superb in the trading of resource cards.  A player that is close to winning will find themselves unable to negotiate trades and that is a great catch up mechanic.  The player who is close to winning will also get frequent visits from the robber as well.  I have fond memories of many stimulating Settlers games played and I look forward to more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Another "easy to get into, hard to master" game. The rules are simple, the bits are nice and the gameplay is well studied, but what really makes this game shine is player interaction. Great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Random. I like the interactive element, but the game suffers from critically maiming players if dice rolls are unfavorable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
It's Catan...

I didn't like this game very much, but it's what got most of everyone I know into hobby gaming. I owe thanks to it, but that's it. 

I view the expansions as additional modules. Some I like more than others, but in the end, I put it all under the Catan blanket rating because when I think Catan, I think about all of it as a whole.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Not much to be said about this one, as everyone in the world knows this game.  Nice game to introduce to non-gamers, quick to teach, has good replayability, and has sufficient randomness to prevent experienced players from hosing the newbies.  My problems with this game are plentiful, however:  it takes far, far too long to play - it's a simple game but games can be strangled by unlucky dice rolls or poor settlement placement which drags the game out significantly.  This is made worse if a player has been blocked because they didn't get early access to the road-building materials, which seems to happen to at least one player every game.

A classic game that has its problems, a nice one to keep for introducing to new gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Game plays quickly and provides solid level of interaction without being overwhelming. Enjoyable experience.

Update July 20, 2013
As geek user Glamorous Mucus says, "I actively avoid this game. Too repetitive, too few decisions, too much annoying futzing around with the resource cards, great potential for a randomly-selected runaway loser." Often the reason is because this game is played as a gateway with casual gamers which means, as a geek user Chally says, "that the game is usually filled with frustrating distractions, confusion, and interminable trading phases. Although I have no issue with the die rolling (even though I'm not usually a die-rolling person), I don't like the table-talk and kingmaking that the Robber induces on frequent sevens. It's essentially a decent light Eurogame with some of my least favorite aspects of Monopoly and Risk tacked on." While the experience can be okay with experienced gamers, why settle for a fine or okay 1995 game experience given what's out there now. I wouldn't even use it as a a gateway because it's too long for what it is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Catan (or Settlers of Catan as I will always remember it), is a good game. It holds up by having a very timeless quality to it. People can approach the game having never played anything like it, and they will quickly be able to understand and embrace its gameplay because it has a combination of elements that are at once familiar, but also unique in how the game presents them. 

Nowadays, I find that the game doesn't fit any sort of niche that satisfies what I look for a in a game. It's too random for when I'm wanting a satisfying strategic experience; it's too casual for when I'm wanting to get engrossed in a game; and yet it usually takes too long for a game I would like to play casually. 

I think Catan is the archetypal "gateway game", in that, I would only ever play it when using it as such (and know it would thrive being played in that capacity), but I have no real desire to ever play it of my own volition. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The dice rolling drives me up the wall. As does the area control aspect of it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is the game that reinvented the board gaming  hobby, opening the eyes of the masses to the possibility that there was more to board games than Risk and Monopoly.

Settlers' popularity actually makes complete sense. The game is quite easy for new players to grasp giving it wide reach in terms of its potential audience. But what makes it really unique is that the game play appeals on so many different levels. Whether you like building stuff, or managing resources, or trading and negotiating, or rolling dice, or collecting sets, or building an economic engine... there really is something there for everyone to enjoy.

One of the real highlights for me is the free-trade mechanic, which I haven't seen much elsewhere. The economy self-regulates based on the availability of resources and stage of the game. Someone might pay you three resources for that brick now, but two minutes later its worthless! It's fun to figure out what kind of deals you can pull together each turn and it also keeps everyone constantly engaged.

Obviously the variability of the game is a huge plus. The hexes are laid out in a random order each game, the numbers which determine resource frequency will also change. You can try out different strategies by using development cards or ports. And there are some neat organic catch-up mechanics like the robber and negotiation, which mix things up and lead to many very close games.

I have played probably 200+ actual person to person games of Settlers and I still really enjoy it. These days I play it most often with the family or with newbies as there are better games for a truly strategic head to head. But nevertheless this is a versatile, elegant and highly repayable game - a must have for any collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
An excellent gateway game for the hobby and a game we still break out a few times a year but especially anytime we have new people over that aren't 'boardgamers'.  The rules are simple and easy to pick up quickly and the sense of accomplishment at completing houses, cities and roads keeps people coming back.  The minimal direct conflict (except the Robber) keeps things on the tranquil side.
5-6 player expansions work well in a jam but ideally we stick to 4-players as it minimizes the down time (a killer for new players).

RATING: 6
Some seem bothered by the dice rolling in this game, but I believe that this limited randomness makes the game interesting. Its ratings seem a bit inflated by the nostalgia of those for which this was the "gateway". 

UPDATE: The Xbox Live release of this has bumped it up a bit for me simply because it allows the game to be played much much faster.

RATING: 4
I host the local tabletop gaming club and was given a large amount of Catan and expansions and I hate nearly every aspect. I hate the set up time, I don't particularly care for the rulebook, the gameplay always seems to confuse new gamers and feels dated. I feel like we're all just rolling dice hoping to get some card to use to dump little bits of wood on a slippery pile of cardboard, outstaying it's welcome before the runaway leader is declared victorious. Its too easy for someone to get behind and not be able to catch up. I don't feel much thematically from it either. 
I also have Settlers of Canaan, which is very similar, but a static board, and I much prefer it for that. I can see the appeal in a Catan board, but even then, that's an investment I don't think I want to bother with. And it's not like I hate euros, I own a number of them and enjoy them very much, many times easier to play and teach than other styles (e.g. fillers, wargames, etc). 
I mean, Catan has been around and I'm sure it can and is a great game, but none of it seems to click with me or the majority of other players that were participating along with. I'm really starting to think that I'd be better off trading/selling the $150 worth of Catan stuff and repurposing it into a variety of newer games.

RATING: 7
Civilization:City building:Resource Management:Trading:Negoiation

100  plays (most were computer version or online): Very addicting game in the discovery stage even though it is mostly luck dependant, especially when playing with equally skilled players. This is a classic example of how luck and dice do not automatically mean the game will be bad or broken, it is one of the main reasons the game is so fun but it can also get occasionally frustrating when the dice work against you. Expansions add a few more choices/decisions but the C&K is the only one worth the money and sometimes regular Settlers is really all you want. Rating this fairly high due to high fun factor and that "let's play again feeling", also this has high replay value and a few paths to Victory. My theory is the "greed" aspect of it is why it's so fun as well as "take that" when cutting off your opponet's road.

[u]UPDATE[/u]: After 100 plays this fell a little from a 9 but only a classic could see 100 plays and my rating won't ever fall below 8.5 even though it doesn't see much play now. It also gains extra points for it's "uncanny" ability to win over non-gamers to the hobby and we found some ways to play with 2 players as well. 

[u]UPDATE[/u]:8.5 => 7.5 What can I say, after playing a lot more other games I now don't like playing this much (mostly due to the high luck factor), it especially becomes too long for what it is with 4 people. If you are new(ish) to the hobby this is still a great choice.

RATING: 9
I struggled with this rating.  If you'd asked me in 2003, I'd have given this in 10.  I grew up playing classic American games (Monopoly, Stratego, Risk, etc.) and this was the first "eurogame" I played.  I played this game exclusively for a couple of years and then though "if I have so much fun playing this, maybe there are other, even better games out there!"  Then I got Puerto Rico and the rest was history.  I played this again a few months ago for the first time in years and kind of hated it.  Just so random.  But if you're just getting into the hobby this is a great place to start.

RATING: 8

Luck plays a big role in the game, but a good mix of strategy/tactics and trading skills can make a difference. Some games turn out to be pretty tense and I've seen a few harsh quarrels arise, but everything is forgotten eventually (at least until the next game).

RATING: 4
I will forever be thankful that Settlers introduced me to the world of board gaming, but it just doesn't hit the spot like it used to.

Trading is vital, but it also tends to consume a lot of time. You also can't effectively pre-plan your turn because your own dice roll will change what you can do. You don't realize how slow this game can be until you play some fast games.

Also not a huge fan of dice with no alteration mechanism like you have in Stone Age, Castles of Burgundy, Alien Frontiers, Euphoria, Kingsburg, etc. Pretty hard to inject any of those mechanics into Settlers though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Still a classic but a bit burnt out on it.  You randomly generate a board using hex tiles, each with a terrain on it and each with a number.  Each turn you roll two dice and anyone who has a town or city built at a corner of the hex gets a resource card corresponding to the terrain.  Then you turn in the cards to build roads, towns, cities, or special action cards.  There is some fun strategy to where to build your towns and roads and outmaneuvering your opponents.  In some sense, this is a civ lite, building up your little empire.  I enjoyed working out the strategies but now that I have them down, I get frustrated by the element of luck as bad rolls can really blow the game.  Sometimes the two dice just want to reward the player who claimed the "2" tile for no good reason.  :P
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a must have game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I appreciate this game in the context of its historical contributions to our hobby.

But it's not that good.

Everything it does has been improved on by some other game.  There are better trading games.  There are better games with variable boards.  There are better set collecting games.  

Also, there's a lot of downtime, particularly when there's one resource in short supply, and everybody's angling for the same thing.  And any early leader is going to get pummeled by the other players - usually well beyond the point where they can get back in the game.

It's not a bad game, per se.  There are just so many better options now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Nostalgia makes me want to play Catan once every six months or so, but I always end up disinterested by the end of the game. It doesn't take many plays to see how erratic dice rolls (e.g. when a two is rolled more often than a six) or missing out on the best starting placements can take players out of the game. Catan is an important milestone in the history of board games, but newer games have improved on what it has to offer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I'd still be interested in playing vanilla Catan. Played several hundred times prior to logging plays on BGG.

RATING: 7
Who doesn't enjoy Settlers of Catan?  A really fun game to play with the family and a great gateway game.  I prefer to play with the gold variant. If you don't get any resources on a roll you get a gold coin.  On your turn two gold coins can be traded in for any one resource.  This makes that game move at a much quicker pace and nobody is bogged down for multiple rounds without getting any resources.

RATING: 9
I give Settlers a 10 - it's not my favorite game (that award goes to Twilight Struggle), but I have to recognize what Settlers of Catan has done for board games.  It's introduced a lot of my non-gaming friends to a new world of board games.  For that, and elegant gameplay, I give Settlers a perfect 10.

Update (Summer 2012):  Moved to a 9, as I rarely play it anymore.  But it's still a classic, and incredibly important to the hobby.

RATING: 10
This new classic is a favorite that I have played many times.  Build a colony to get 10 points before the other players. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fun game, perhaps I've played it too much!  One of the most reliably varying simpler games around due to the dynamic board setup, such that it's always a good battle with 4+ people as each game will be so different.  The one thing that stands out is that periods of dice droughts in the mid-game can make the game feel a real drag sometimes, as it's like watching your teeth get slowly pulled, seeing the game slowly slipping away, and with nothing you can do... all while taking depressing two second turns (with your one or two resource cards) while everyone else takes long turns doing many things.  But that aside, it's certainly a fun game.  And definitely enjoy the Cities and Knights expansion as well to spice things up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
I really like the degree of social interaction in this game versus the other Euro style games in my collection, and it's always easy to find a group to play with. This is one of the games that got several of my friends involved in the hobby.

The only reason I don't suggest (or play) this game more often is that it can easily lead to out-of-game conflict among some competitive gamers.

Traded for Puerto Rico after I realized everyone I play games with owns their own copy, and it's my duty to bring more unique games to the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

But later it turned out that the starting positions almost decide for 40% if you will win this game or not. That plus the fact that I played this too many times, makes me not want to play this again, unless it will be with other people I haven't played with.

I give this game a 6 with the Seafarers expansion.

RATING: 7.5
A solid and fun game and can be quite tense towards the end of the game. Lots of player interaction and the robber can often prevent runaway leader problems.

There is a huge hidden strategic element in this game. So far it seems that trying to trade a lot is a great strategy towards winning along with trying to get your settlements on different numbers as opposed to getting a few big numbers to cut down on robber screwage.

RATING: 9
Got this in the mail.  Wife, daughter, and I played it, and it was a very nice game.  Since we've played Settlers of Canaan so much, it's hard to stop calling the robber the plague.

I like the replayability of this game with the mixing up of terrain hexes and port tokens.

Downside: harder to setup and no point tracker.

Update: Since sold Canaan. I really enjoy this with Seafarers and the Fishermen of Catan (Traders & Barbarians).  Family likes it that way too.  One of my favorite games.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I think Settlers illustrates well how not to implement randomness in a game.  Random battles work well as risk management.  After all, the players in, say, Nexus Ops, get to build up troops and at least see the satisfaction of something happening that they caused, even if it's the hot laser death of their own strike force.  Random income, on the other hand, means a highly frustrating experience for the players whose numbers don't come up, since for them nothing happens at all.  It just isn't fun to sit and watch other people grabbing goods.  For all the game's virtues, and there are many, there are too many turns where the only thing to do is roll the dice and pass building.  (Trading is great in theory, but if you don't get any resources anyone else wants due to crappy dice rolls, you're not trading anything, no matter how much of a social butterfly and great negotiator you may be.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
SdJ 1995. The game that started it all - already a classic. excellent introductory game. very user friendly, but flawed trading system, makes it heavy initial position/dice dependent

I hate wooden dice.  I am surprised, given the country's engineering reputation, that German games would come with dice that are made of a material that is non-homogeneous thus reducing the randomness of the roll.  "What?!  A 12 again?!"

***On the 10 year anniversary, it's time to move this down.  I know!  It's heretical, but really, I only want to play this once every couple of years or so.  It's too long as a four player game (excruciatingly so for the one player that gets squeezed early), and too lucky for the length as a 3 player game.***

RATING: 8.5
the classic - very tight and competitive in standard 4 player version, with a nice definite ending
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very solid game. Some odd issues with getting locked into an area with no room for expansion whatsoever, which can certainly be annoying enough to want to quit, but those moments are honestly pretty far between. It's easy enough for casual players to pick it up quickly, and just complex enough to build strategies around screwing other players (which is something I generally enjoy). 

The randomization is also off-putting, but the ability to trade with other players and the pace of the game help mitigate that a bit. 

My final gripe would be the openness of victory conditions. As soon as someone is close to winning, everyone sees it immediately and guns for that player/refuses to trade anything with them. 

Overall, very fun game that I'd recommend when you have some more casual players around. Great entry level game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4.5
Rolling for resources. 

I. hate. it. 

Not getting that resource? Nothing to do in your turn but pass. Not being able to do anything in your turn is just a bad game mechanic. This game is such a bore fest. Yes, you can mitigate it somewhat by smartly placing your starting towns, and negotiate for trades but still at the core, this game is frustrating to play.

This is much more tolerable on PC version where downtime is very small, but in real life with others sitting on table?

My gateway game: This is the game that got me into the hobby! Still one of my favorite games (especially when played in conjunction with the Cities & Knights).
I was introduced to this game back during my Junior year of high school where I played it once (2005). I purchased the game on New Year's Eve 2007. However, I never really got a chance to play it that much because I knew that we would need 3 or more players...
Fast forward to January 2016: I had joined my gaming group, and I got to start playing the game again. After this, I had started learning about other games, but this one is a classic!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Unlike most here, I DIDN'T play it to death in the 90s, so it's fresh to me. And I like it! Right up there with TtR IMO.  A very skillfully designed game. Fun to boot. Its elegance is part of its appeal, so I have no desire to play any of the subsequent versions-- at that point I'd rather play something more modern. The Atlantic got it right: "Settlers' recipe for success can therefore be seen as this: a well-designed game, devoid of a geeky patina, incubated by early adoption into a nerd culture that has become increasingly mainstream."

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game deserves an emphatic 10 because it is a landmark in the development of modern boardgaming. It showed that the best rules-mechanical insights of wargames could be brought to bear to other kinds of boardgames to improve their designs too. Today's games are more interesting and challenging than all but a few favourites from my childhood.

Klaus Teuber didn't do this single-handed, but Settlers was a big contribution. It's great fun to play, and will long continue to win many new fans.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6
This is a great game! I wouldn't turn down a game of it if asked.
It's different every time you play but this is more of a lucky game that let's you think you are in control and that strategy is involved. You make decisions that's true, but most of the time the decision you make is obvious or the only choice you have. This game I know very well and may that's part of my problem, the unpredictable random nature of the dice role is too random? This game does escalate well if not evenly and the race for the final few points is enjoyed by one or two at most. .. often the other players have been left behind and for them the game ended a few rounds ago. Still for all my nit picking complaints...I wouldn't turn down a game.... is that this games magic?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My gateway game and probably yours, too.  Though I've arguably "moved on" from this game, I'll never pass up a chance to play it.  My wife enjoys playing vanilla, but I like adding the River (you might hate it, but I like it), Fisherman, Catan event cards, and Cities and Knights.  Looking to add Seafarers but I need an older copy.

A lot of people hate on Settlers after they graduate to other gaming mechanics, but I think this is wrong.  Settlers is what it is - a VERY well-thought out game that offers much replayability (tiles, resource markers).  

Combining Settlers with its expansions--I like to play with The Great River, Fisherman, Event Cards (for the events only), Harbormaster, and Cities and Knights--makes for a long, but enjoyable, experience.

I would recommend this game to anyone trying to get into board gaming, and I'd gladly play Settlers with anyone, even after all these years.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Settlers definitely has its place in the history of euro games. That said, the state of the art has advanced, and viewed objectively, Settlers isn't all that great of a game. Luck plays a huge role, and while it can be mitigated somewhat, it is always an issue. Additionally, it is very common for at least one player to be out of contention early. It's no fun to sit around and wait for the game to end. Kingmaking is another major problem. Those players out of contention early?  They often deck the game by how and if they trade towards the end. That's no fun. I've played literally hundreds of games of Settlers, mostly on Xbox Live, as well as in several tournaments. Looking at my library, there are very few instances where I'd rather play Settlers than any of my other four player games. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Relatively a good game. Positives- always ok if you are experienced and can get on intersections of diverse resources, strategy and politics are very high and it's not really hard to teach. Negatives: gate teed to always start a fight in groups with one or more competitive people. Argument over rules and always having people voice to the fairness of the game. And random chance could have players stuck in a slump for many turns on end where they do nothing at all. 

Overall the first second and third playthroughs are awesome, after that the politics of the game and chance and prefrencial treatments/attacks on players will upset people and usually dampens the whole night. Great for a group with no spikes that want to win and tons of people that are happy playing even if they lose. E.G. Sometimes I lose on purpose so others won't flip table!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
like everybody else... this is what started it all for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Catan is an important game in terms of nostalgia and its impact on the hobby, but it hasn't stood the test of time very well. It is noted mainly for its trading and accessible empire building mechanics. The major downsides are how critical one's starting position is (a big disadvantage for new players), a lack of dynamic interaction, and the limitations and monotony of rolling dice for production. I will only play with the Cities and Knights expansion (the base game feels a bit "samey" after several rounds), and only when the mood strikes me (which is less and less). All that being said, Settlers is an admirable gateway game for kids or those who are new to the hobby.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I really enjoy this game, although I rarely have the chance to play at home as it requires more then 2 players. It's competitive, but as you aren't playing directly against the other players, and rely on good relations to make successful trades, it avoids overly aggressive play. The variety of ways to earn victory points means each person can choose a strategy to suit them. This is a well rounded game, and its use as an educational tool is excellent to see.

RATING: 4
Disgusting for several reasons
1) After the initial placement of settlements it is easy to tell who is most likely to win.  I hate the fact that the likelyhood of a win is influenced by your ability to roll a high number in determining placement.  
2) There are two types of players.  The loud ones who beat you into trading with them so they'll just shut up.  And the ones who aren't sure what they want to do.  
3) There are very few interesting decissions.  Often the game plays itself.  It's like Ticket to ride, but without the tension.

RATING: 9.5
Euro gaming's biggest star: dice-directed resources that lead to building settlements and cities for increased power. This 3-4 player game involves all players through most of the game, offers decent challenges, excellent expansions, medium learning but easy to play -- and good for those who have wood for sheep.

MEGA PLUS: excellent iOS app
HUGE PLUS: involvement
BIG PLUS: expansions, challenge, ease of play
BIG MINUS: length of play, 5+ player expansions are poor

RATING: 10
This game is a staple in our house, and the favorite go-to game among all our friends.  Occasionally we'll venture away from the game to try another, but we always come back to Catan.  The game is extremely repayable as the board game is set up differently each time you play, offering different strategies and obstacles to overcome every time.  This game isn't too heavy.  It doesn't feel like a game of chess, but it's not all up to the dice rolls either.  The balance between luck and strategy is like milk and cookies, a perfect balance and combination.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I'm playing my first game with some friends, some have played, others haven't.
The game dragged terribly (over two hours for a 4 player basic game, after setting up and going over the rules - but it seemed like three or four hours of play), especially when players asked again and again (and again and again) about the same trades that no one wanted to take them up on.
One player spent the last hour of the game involved in another conversation entirely, and not paying attention at all, but then got the "Monopoly" card, and was able to win the game.
I can't believe that the game has such a broken card that a player who isn't even trying can luck into it and gain 6 victory points in one turn to win.

Yes, I could be persuaded to play again, because I have friends who love this game, and I enjoy playing games with them.
I will also keep my travel edition for classroom use (although I may have to "lose" the monopoly card).

RATING: 6
2015-10-01: Despite my previous comments, I do still find myself wanting to play this one and it is requested in the game group. I'm thinking I might try some of the scarcity variants to help offset the die-rolls. Re-rating to a 6 (from 5).

2015-03-26: My initial rating here was a 7, but I think I'm going to downgrade that. I've re-bought this one and replayed it several times in the last month. What I've noticed, especially for new players, is frustration when you don't get any new resources on your turn and "can't do anything!" It has that sensation of a roll-and-move, where you essentially can't move anywhere. Yes, trading should help to mitigate that, but sometimes no one will trade.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Perfect blend of strategy and chance. While I can sympathize with those who say there is too much randomness here, I have consistently seen strong players win by positioning themselves to take advantage of probability. Mitigating the risks of chance is a big part of this game. Brilliant in its accessibility and broad appeal.

EDIT: After playing a few more times with casual gamers, I'm reducing the grade to an 8. The set up and site selection, unless you use a pre-set configuration, really does set some at a severe disadvantage. While I don't mind at all the randomness of the dice roll, it is never fun when you don't feel you have much of a chance from turn one, which can happen in this game. Also, I find that getting to that last victory point or two can be painfully slow. I usually target a number a point or two lower than recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
My vote for the best game ever invented.  Should be played as is, without expansions.  I don't care if its ranked 100 or whatever: Settlers is the greatest.  Even 15 years on there are still no better games out there.
Why?  First would be that every game is different, right from the start.  The modular board presents the players with a significantly different challenge each time - not many games do that.  Second, there is very little downtime.  Third, there is genuine end-game tension, not present in most multiplayer euros.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
IIRC, I first played Settlers in 2006. Played 2-3 times, tops. There was some curiosity about modern boardgaming, so I thought I'd get a companion game to Settlers for the group, which ultimately ended up being Carcassonne. In other words, I pulled a standard Gateway maneuver many years after these two games were released, but I left Settlers behind so quickly it never made an impression on me. I played a lot of Carc (about 20 sessions), but half of that was at the request of more casual, non-gamer friends. So they responded to the "gateway game" while I was off and running. 

I say all of this because I came back to Settlers recently (10/28/09) for one session just to see how it would strike me as a died-in-the-wool, hardcore gamer. I don't have any nostalgia for this game. I never experienced it as the only game in town or as the forerunner of a whole movement. 

So to me, in 2009, Settlers is a distinctive but fairly unengaging game. In essence, the game is built around a random distribution of goods that is, in theory, corrected by manipulation of the odds and player negotiation. In practice neither of these things really do enough for the game. It does play quickly and simply. I've also read that 4-player Settlers is inevitably "an exercise in futility for one player, an exercise in false hope for another, and a real contest between the other two." That's been my experience as well. 

As gateway games go: TtR < Settlers < Carc < Pandemic. Althought as a cooperative, Pandemic doesn't really introduce people to the mainstream. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent.  A good gate-way introduction for non-gamers.  There is plenty of player interaction.  With the luck element anyone has a chance of winning.

RATING: 7

RATING: 4
Played too much probably, but after trying out many of the various expansions it is hard to get into a game without using at least some expansion. Good for introducing people to tabletop gaming, but, even then, they'll probably also want to use an expansion after a game or two. 

Replaying again after playing many other games, the dice rolling determines too much of the gameplay for this to be enjoyable. If the numbers aren't in your favor, there is nothing in the middle of the game you can do to change that.

RATING: 6.5
I have a lot of the respect for the designer, Klaus Teuber - it is a well balanced game with a 'story arc' as the game progresses (e.g. from everyone needing brick/wood to build roads/settlements to wheat/ore for cities, etc.) The downside is it's a tad long for the fun value (esp. when there are 1-2 'scarce' resources on the board), and luck is a bit high for more - the 'risk management' aspect of it only kicks in over multiple plays and you coold be stuck with a 2-3 hr game getting screwed by the dice rolls

(NB best expansion for this is Cities & Knights of Catan)

RATING: 8
This is a great game and the classic gateway game. Great balance and enough different ways to win to make each game interesting. I think the reason why it's a great gateway game is because at the start of each turn your options for your next move are usually very clear and it's just a matter of choosing one or the other and pressing your luck. New players pick up on this quickly and it gives what some might call the "illusion of strategy" without making the game feel completely luck based. Recommended to any potential gamers out there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
Another incredible game.  I don't play it as much anymore, but it still comes out occasionally.  However, for people who are just new to the hobby, it's a great way to get them hooked.  and with the expansions, it just soars.  A high level of randomness turns me off a bit but this is also what appeals to non-gamers who have grown up on Monopoly and other "Roll and Move" games.
5/10/09 Update: This games rating has gone up to a 9 for the number of times we play it.  Easily over 50 ftof games in the last 2 months.  Has to be a 9 if it's played that much.  I now use it to convince all my "Non-gaming" friends to try board games.

RATING: 9
50+ plays.

+ The #1 best gateway game in existence.  Enjoyable whether you are old or young, male or female, casual or hardcore, math-oriented or language-oriented, quiet or loud, etc.
+ Game has perfect pacing.  There are always resources to collect and trades to make.
+ Social elements (negotiation)
+ An ideal mix of skill and luck

- Runaway leader problem
- Depth is good but not excellent
- Randomness (dice)

RATING: 7

Maybe the dice are loaded. Because the game is so simple I just added Seafarers to try and make it more challenging.

RATING: 8.5
This is the game that got me hooked into euro style games.  Though you can get screwed by the dice rolls, you have a lot of control by trading and prioritizing builds.  The trading also keeps you involved, even when it's not your turn.  If you play often enough and for long enough, the luck tends to even out, and its a matter making good decisions.  I like that between the longest road, the robber baron, and special development cards, the lead can go back and forth, and someone can come from out of nowhere for the win.

RATING: 5
Great game. 

After six plays I think it's time to move on... Still will be used as a gateway game at family gatherings. I introduced it to my 58 year old mother recently and she smoked my girlfriend and me on her second game. She really enjoyed it and wants to play it more.

Update: The last time we played this we had a very severe case of 'gang up on the leader'. Which was me. I had ten or eleven turns of no one trading with me and the robber was constantly moved onto my spaces. It was terribly frustrating, but I kept my cool.

My cousin Tom, who had the best chance of overtaking me, says he probably won't ever play the game again, which is fine with me. 

In the end I won by piling up on resource cards and stealing the Largest Army card.

Downgraded rating from a 7 to a 6.

RATING: 8
Sure I had played Empire Builder and History of the World in the early 90's, and Supremacy and Axis & Allies back in the 80's, but Settlers is THE game that started the revolution for me. Efficient rules. Wonderful, pervasive theme. A little bit of negotiation. It's the roll of the dice and the fact that I've played the hell out of it that causes me to give it only a 7 versus everything else that is out there, but it will always be a nostalgic favorite.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I can see why this game helped launch a movement. The actual mechanics are easier to see than explain on paper; the turns take just about the right length for me and give you interesting enough things to do. Of course, the hole you may be digging for yourself is your own grave as you drop further and further behind if you don't start off fairly strong or at least competitive. The midgame on can feel like a total drag if you're just treading water without much way of improvement.

The new Mayfair version is pretty nice, and there's absolutely no reason to get the older one instead. However, there's very little reason *to* get the new one if you have the old one unless sliding tiles was a real annoyance for you. In fact, I'm not sure how well the puzzle pieces will wear over time, and it wasn't that easy to get the hexes in it around the edges.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
An extremely unimpressive game, to say the very least. The game pieces are poorly designed, the outcome of the game dependent on chance and the charity of others. There are some redeeming features however, including a geomorphic map and the fact that player interaction is strongly encouraged. The father of German games and epitome of everything I hate about German board games. No violence, weak supporting pieces - uggggghhh! Hopefully, this scathing indictment of a universally loved classic will go a long way towards balancing out the heavily biased opinions of gamers who started playing only from the mid 90&#039;s onwards, and do not know any better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I find the robber ruins this game for me. I understand the intent is to "bring down" a player who has obtained a point lead, but I find that this mechanic is oppressive--the player who takes the lead is often completely locked out of doing anything for multiple turns. It also entices players to run a "secret game" by hoarding development cards... which makes the robber more active, which makes the leader's game more difficult. Essentially, whoever takes the early lead loses. ...And the game is entirely unenjoyable for her besides.

As a result, I've introduced three relatively simple house rules that I don't feel unbalance the game, and help lessen the impact of the robber without completely removing the intention of it:

1) If you roll a seven and the robber is not on the desert, return the robber to the desert. Resolve oversized hands as normal. After resolving hand sizes, take one free resource of the player's choice from the bank as a "reward" for routing the robber. (Thus the player who rolled the robber _may_ begin the turn with 8 cards.)

2) A person playing a soldier card MUST move the soldier (as normal), but may *optionally* move the robber to the desert (if he is not there already) and take one resource of the player's choice from the bank as a reward. 

3) After the robber blocks an area from resource generation, return him to the desert.

...The first two rules help keep a single player from getting repeatedly drubbed by the robber; the third rule helps keep the robber from completely spoiling one hex for essentially half of the game (in my experience, the robber really only ever goes back and forth between the two "best" places to put him).

-- OR --

...A simpler alternative is that the robber simply blocks production; it does not steal a card. The player who places the robber instead takes a single resource of their choice from the bank.

With this alternative, a player in the lead may be deprived of some production, but may still play her hand (and produce from other hexes), and "stay in the game", albeit with a penalty that shouldn't be crippling.

Another house rule I recommend (to make the game feel less "mean") is that the robber MUST be moved to the player with the highest visible score. If there are two players tied for first place, the robber will attack the player with more cards in her hand. If two or more players are still tied, it will attack one randomly (roll a die). ...The player placing the robber may still choose which hex to move the robber to, and the robber MUST still move when played.

For me, at least, these rules give this old game a few more legs and helps reduce frustration for most players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

There always appears to be one logical choice of action given your hand of cards, and given your roll. The trading element is extremely dependent on the group you game with. New gamers tend to trade not at all since they are unsure of the value of things.

[UPDATE] After further playings, I'm lowering the score. The game can come to a standstill if the right resources don't come up.
