RATING: 8
Settlers is a very good intro game for newbies (myself included).  The game rates high for it's trading and building aspects.  The biggest flaw I find is the randomness of the game, which doesn't become evident until the end of the game.  I haven't played it enough to isolate when it happens but after settlements have been upgraded to cities, the player with the best rolls (and positions) clearly pulls ahead.  The other players can only hope for 7's to activate the robber.  Overall, a highly enjoyable game. It clearly deserves its popularity.

RATING: 7.5
Nice, fun little game that I play when gaming time is short or I want a change of pace from a massive/complicated/long war game.  This game has almost infinite replay value due to the nature of the setup, but there are several strategies that work well no matter what the setup outcome looks like.  Not the "greatest game ever" as many claim, but it is fun, easy to learn, and got me introduced me to "German Style" games.  Game is great in its basic form or coupled with the available expansions (Knights & Cities is the best in my opinion). One thing I don't care for, the amount of luck involved in the die rolls for resources.  But, I guess it all evens out in the end.  Give this game a try!

This game will always be in my collection.

RATING: 7
Catan is good for beginners, gateway game etc. 

The more experienced gamers start to get put off by it for the simple reason that too much of the mechanic is put down to luck. It's just a fact that too much of the time people who should have won don't and those who aren't so hot can get very lucky. Therefore, it's kind of like a slot machine at a casino if you get a group of competent gamers playing each other, i.e. it boils down to a gambling, uncontrolled game of sorts.




Oops forgot one final point. .. It's not that fun after a while...it's just kinda there chugging away....meh

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Like many, this was my introduction to modern board games.  I was immediately captivated by this fascinating creation.  It's strategic, but it has random dice rolling!  It's competitive but there's no player elimination!  You'll likely get stomped your first game, but once you have the basics down, most games come down to a close finish.  

My wife and I soon bought our own copy and played and played, and introduced it to new people.  After a while, and a lot of plays, the game started to irk me more and more.  I disliked getting screwed over by a string of streaky dice rolls.  I disliked everyone ganging up on one player with the robber.  I disliked that the five resources were not evenly balanced.  I disliked other players making suboptimal trades with each other.  I started to discover other, newer (clearly better! lol) games, and began to turn up my nose at lowly Catan.

I've since come back around.  There are other better gateway games that have come along (e.g. Ticket to Ride, Splendor, Dominion).  There are other games I'd rather play on most any given game night.  But I enjoy it for what it is:  a solid light-middleweight euro that's fun to dust off every once in a while.  It's not the be all end all of strategy games.  But even in spite of its unprecedented success, it has a unique mix of mechanics, strategy and interaction that has never been duplicated.

approximate number of plays (pre-2017):  50+
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

Some complain about the luck of the dice, which is a legitimate criticism.  But we use a deck of dice cards and have had no problems with errant laws of probability since.

RATING: 7.5


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The famous Monopoly-killer.  This is the new "classic" family game and is often credited with kicking off the Euro revolution in the States.  The fishermen expansion helps make the outside coastal tiles a bit more balanced; it should almost be included in the base game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Ah, the literal gateway game. Nobody needs my opinion, because everyone's heard of and played Catan. 

Honestly, I played approximately 300 games in high school and early college to great success, back when I didn't know much about board games, but now you'd have to really convince me (or butter me up with some great snacks) to get me back to the table for this one. This game is a combination of infuriating bad luck, backstabbing "friends", and someone being a poor sport by the end, which is really not my cup of tea. I did recently play with a bunch of expansions and houserules a friend had mashed up, which made the game more interesting and complicated, but also incredibly long and needlessly complex, so I'm not sure that was actually a net win. 

I will fully admit that this game singlehandedly created a generation of board gamers (including myself), who would never have moved on from Scrabble and Monopoly if it weren't for Catan, and it's honestly not a bad game, it just really doesn't live up to the hype now that I have games in my collection much better suited for my personality and life. It should be noted, however, that I am just not a fan of competitive games by and large, so that's a major reason this game hasn't withstood the test of time for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.9
堅実なゲーム。いくつか点数の取り方があり、運もあり、交渉もあり・・・でも、それに慣れるまで時間がかかる。まだ回数を重ねていないので、毎回何かのルールを間違える。たとえば、街を建てる場所、７の処理のカード上限。堅実なゲームであるので、ルール間違えがあると自分の中では、失敗と思ってしまう。統計データで、プレイの難易度も2.4もある。やはり、初心者にはルールが多い。
もう一つ、やはりダイスの運に泣かされるのがキライ。上級者は最初の段階で最適な場所とりが完了しているので、面白いかもしれないが、初心者はそれも良くわからない。上級者は、最初の陣地とりが頭を使う・・・というが、言い換えれば、この陣地とりで決まり、あとはおまけ？なのだろうか、と思ってしまう。

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This game deserves the accolades it gets; it probably opened the North American doors to German/Eurogames and I'm very thankful for that. I like a lot about the game - it's essentially a multiplayer solitaire (which I tend to like), has an interesting theme, and most people I've played it with really enjoy it. It's also quick to learn - the basegame seems to play best with 3.

The trading portion of a player's turn, however, is poorly designed; it greatly increases gametime and creates some confusion for the very small price of increasing interaction. This tone, indeed, has created some spillover problems for games of Settlers I've played - I've played with players who have used their knowledge of what other players want to affect drawing cards from other players during the Robber phase.

Also, be wary if you plan on buying this: there's about 20 different expansions for it (5-6 player expansion, Seafarers of Catan, Seafarers of Catan 5-6 player expansion, which is different, Knights of Catan, Knights of Catan 5-6 players ... )  so you could really be dropping a lot of money before you're done.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game over all, but the level of randomization in this game always left me wanting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Igazi klasszikus.
A Catan esetében a szabályok elsajátítására, tanulmányozására nem kell napokat áldozni az életünkből. De még órákat sem. Ez nem jelenti, hogy nem lehetnek vitás kérdések. :D Elég könnyen átlátható akár már első próbálkozásra. Lássuk be, rendkívül nagy a szerencse szerepe ebben a játékban is. Hiába próbálunk úgy helyezkedni, hogy a könnyebben kidobható számokat tartalmazó mezőkkel érintkezzen a településünk, városunk, ha utána mégis ritkán jönnek elő azok a számok. Szerencsére azért ez nem egy felturbózott szerencsejáték csupán. A kereskedéssel meg kell próbálni a céljaink eléréséhez nélkülözhetetlen nyersanyagok beszerzését. Ez jó kis interakciót biztosít a játékostársak között. A győzelemhez szükséges 10 pontot meg egyáltalán nem olyan könnyű elérni.
Az tetszik a Catanban, hogy ha egy család úgy dönt, hogy csak az alapjátékot veszi meg, akkor is rengetegszer újra játszható a társas, mert a területlapkák elhelyezése szabadon variálható, meg persze az azokon szereplő számok is. Ez is olyan játék, ahol több úton is el lehet jutni a győzelemhez. Van, aki csak a települések, városok építésére áll rá, van aki a fejlesztési kártyákat gyűjti, van, aki mindenféleképpen birtokolni szeretné a leghosszabb út címét, stb. Ráadásul nagyon hangulatosak az illusztrációk. Nekünk már a műanyag figurás változat van meg, de nem érzem gagyinak ezt sem. Biztosan más érzés fabábukkal játszani, de nekem ezzel sincs gondom, itt legalább részletesebb egy-egy elem kidolgozása.
Azért 4 fővel ez sem a legrövidebb játék, mind a két menet kb. másfél óra volt.
Egyébként az, hogy minden egyes dobásnál figyelsz, hogy kapsz-e nyersanyagot, minimálisra csökkenti az üresjáratot két köröd között. Persze előfordulnak olyan szerencsétlen szériák, hogy akár két teljes kör is végig megy, te meg csak ülsz és szomorúan nézed az egy szál erőforrásodat a kezedben, ami sehogyan sem képes az osztódással szaporodásra.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A surprisingly aggressive game, playing it again after all these years.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
12/04 (This is my initial review, which differs greatly from my new review below.  Just goes to show how group morale plays in a gaming experience)

Eh? That was it...how boring.  I thought this game was going to be AMAZING. Maybe it's the fact that the 4 players wanted to keep turning their head to America's Funniest Home Videos playing in the background.

Regardless: roll the dice (hope it's yours), collect resource, trade, build.  Repeate ad nauseaum.

This was not my first "German" game, but I have to say the lack of conflict (long time Magic:TG player) bored me.  I hated the 2-player Settlers card game as well.  Perhaps I would appreciate Teuber's Lowenherz/Domaine more.

I'm going to keep this I guess just to have, but I will probably sell the 2 expansions I bought for it.  I know the Cities & Knights expansion adds more conflict, but why bother when there are so many other games that do it without expansion.
=====================================================
12/7/06 (this is an updated review of the game, my previous experience with Settlers was dreadful.  I 
knew my first try didn't fairly give the game a chance and requested to play it again 2 years later)

Finally got a chance to play a real game of Settlers and I enjoyed it.  There are multiple strategies to win (do you keep getting Production cards getting random VPs or perhaps the largest army having control over the robber and shutting down your opponents supply, or try to have the largest civilization netting you more supply, maybe picking up the longest road along the way).

We had a fun time with trade too, but if you're in short supply of a particular resource and people see you're winning, expect to have a trade embargo put on you (unless they're just that desparate).  That was my only negative experience in the game, because I had a boring 3 rounds where no one would help me and I had to do some inefficient trades with my port and watch them all catch up, and suddenly they were all against each other since I wasn't king of the hill anymore.

As the board fills up, lessening available real estate, trade becomes increasingly dominant as people compete for resources to upgrade settlements to cities.  Have you positioned yourself to control that supply?  Or did you choose another path to victory, silently waiting to reveal your Production Cards for VPs?  Are you shutting down that supply with your soldiers?  Is someone trying to steal "Longest Road" from you, racing you or trying to cut yours off?  This kind of nail-biting tension occurs at the end.

When I was finished playing, I was still thinking about the game and what I could have done better.

RATING: 7.25
A modern classic, involving planning, negotiation, and a bit of chance. I'm not really fond of the trading aspect, but as long as you're not playing with people who constantly try to cajole you into making unfavorable trades, or people who just make any trade they're offered to be nice, it works fine in Settlers.

Expansions add flavor but also length. Usually not a worthwhile trade-off for my tastes. If you fall behind in the base game, the end is not so far away, if you fall behind when using expansions, a significant portion of your life passes while you wait for the end.

RATING: 7
I got a lot of enjoyment out of Settlers, and occasionally still do with online play. It just doesn't grab me much now. I've long thought that its mechanics of balancing cooperation with competition worked brilliantly, a very different kind of game from AmeriTrash's straight competition. But in repeated playing, games always reached a tipping point where there was no more trading, no more interaction, and it was a straight competition to get to the finish. Perhaps that's how it was designed to be. But it just doesn't leave enough variation to the pattern of the game. Eventually, I was willing to part with Settlers, knowing that it would not be hard to re-acquire if I wished to, in order to make room for something else in my collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
CRITIQUE OF SETTLERS OF CATAN
Settlers of Catan is a mixed bag for me. I appreciate many aspects of the game: the variable setup of the board, the trading (a Euro game with interaction!), the different paths to victory, the short playing time. But on the other hand there are many things the game could do better.

The trading in Settlers has none of the fun of the trading in a game like Bohnanza, where you actually have to trade in order to do what you want. In Settlers, trading is entirely optional, and very often frustrating with less experienced players. It's annoying to watch the player in last place trade freely with the leader, giving them exactly what they need to win. In my opinion, the most important use of trading is as a catch-up mechanic, but everyone has to be on board, understand what's going on, and trade strategically for the purpose of keeping the game close. Unfortunately, this sours the game's main interactive element, making it feel very much like "bash the leader" style play.

The Robber is the same, and the use of the robber also increases the boredom factor by slowing the flow of resources in the game.

I do like the conversion of resources into roads, settlements, or cards, but the flow of these resources is based on a roll of the dice, which make it all too easy in Settlers to have a turn in which you can do nothing. For me, this is a BIG negative, because doing nothing is not fun. Furthermore, the imbalance in the relative value of the resources undermines the "multiple paths to victory" aspect of the game.

The decisions in Settlers are fairly interesting, and give the game another way for players to interact (by means of the area control aspect of the game). Unfortunately, every interaction is just a variation on the theme of "blocking." And the fact that your network of roads and settlements is developed so slowly means that there is little recourse for a blocked player. Unlike worker placement games, in which blocking only works for a single turn, blocking in Settlers is often permanent.

None of this prevents the game from being fun, but it does make it less fun than other games I own. Finally, there is the production value of the game: Settlers has sub-par components. Mayfair should be embarrassed to put out a groundbreaking game like this with such shoddy bits. I could list all the defects, but honestly only the rulebook seems like a quality product. Aesthetically the game could have been much better done.

I ended up giving away my copy of Settlers, which I had never had the urge to get to the table. I've played the game several times, with experienced players, but just never enjoyed it as much as I enjoy other games.

[b]Purchase/Selling History[/b]:

[b]Rating: 8[/b]
[i]Design rating[/i]: [b]4.5[/b]
[i]Component rating[/i]: [b].5[/b]
[i]Willingness to play rating[/i]: [b]1.5[/b]
[i]Fun rating[/i]: [b]1.5[/b]

[b]Players considerations[/b]: 
A little empty with 2, but best with 4, also even better with 5-6, but can be really impossible for someone in the wrong starting position to catch up.
 
[b]My thoughts[/b]:
Pretty much impossible to come back as you fall behind, but that's not the fault of this game. The genius, rather, is that you continually want to try again to win next time.

RATING: 8.5

What this game really did for me was become a gateway game for my wife and another couple. When I was with the three of them, we usually just played cards or dominoes.

This truly opened up the horizon for them and since then, I have introduced many more games that went over really well. I now have two "groups" of players which means games come out that much more frequently.

RATING: 6
While not my favourite trading game, I like Settlers. It's easy to teach and fast to play, making it a solid introduction to the hobby (though you probably knew that). Luck in the dice rolls can have a big impact, though it is sort of balanced with the thief, which acts as a "bash the leader" mechanism. 

Its luck factor gives the impression to have a larger impact than the one it actually has. This is both good and bad: good because it means skill is still important, bad because even though it can be mitigated, some players will simply refuse to play, arguing it's completely luck driven.

RATING: 9
I feel like this one is a gold standard.  It's deep enough for repeated play by serious gamers while easy enough to be enjoyed by newcomers and casual gamers.  It's shocking to me that it isn't rated higher.  Maybe there's a bias against it because it's popular and you can buy it at some mainstream stores.  

I was kind of against Catan myself before I played it.  It's hard to get excited about an agriculture based game.  It seems like the most boring thing you could spend an hour involved with. However, first appearances can be deceiving.  Catan is super well balanced, each game is different and there are multiple strategies to winning.  I would be embarrassed if I didn't have this in my collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is the game that got me into the hobby, as seems to be the case for a lot of people on BGG. It also appears that many have abandoned the game as too "random." I've toyed with posting a defense of Catan in the forums, but I think there are several threads already discussing that. In short, the strategy is certainly obscured somewhat by the dice rolling mechanic, but to argue the game is random or luck based is far from the truth. After countless plays both in person and on XBox Live, I argue that the number of games that are severely tainted by absurd dice rolling statistics are fairly rare. Much more often, mistakes in judgement, or strokes of genius drive the outcome. Most importantly, getting the final 1-3 points often feels like a rewarding puzzle. Throw in that there is usually at least one other person vying for those points, and you have a quite satisfying climax.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Really simple and yet enjoyable game. Everyone starts with placing two villages on the board. These villages share borders with tiles of grain, wool and other raw materials. To get something from these tiles, you have to throw the numbers on these tiles with two dices. A little bit of luck is required. However, some numbers are more commonly thrown with two dices (6, 7, 8) then others (2 or 12), so the locations of your starting villages are important. You can use the raw materials to expand your two starting villages into a large network of villages and cities (which get you even more raw materials). Main goal is to first get to ten points (villages are 1 point, cities are worth 2).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have never seen the appeal of Settlers as a gateway game.  My non-gamer friends and family were bored by it.  I don't mind dice-rolling but the mindless monotony of rolling for resources stupefies me.  The trading aspect can be fun, though with a little experience players know what not to trade.  My kids do enjoy picking the card out of an opponents hand when they play the thief.  This game is especially unpleasant on BSW.   

My ten-year-old son loves the game however.

RATING: 3
[size=12][b]Top 300 or higher board games list[/b][/size]

[size=12][b]Why I dislike Catan:[/b][/size]
- I dislike the route/network building mechanic in this game.
- The game lacks meaningful decisions because there is no way to mitigate bad dice rolls and the choices to make are often obvious.
- At least one player is often left with the worst possible starting position and is hence bound to lose. 

[size=12][b]VERDICT:[/b] Not willing to play this game[/size]

RATING: 6
I enjoy this, if mainly for the fact that it's easy to play with friends. My issue is, I suppose, that by game end everyone has 8 or 9 VPs, and everyone is just waiting for the right die rolls to get the exact resource they need to build the next city and gain the final VP. 

New players can quickly compete with "veterans", which is both good and bad. On one hand, new players aren't left with nothing to do, nor frustrated by inexperience. On the other, there's not enough left to learn or improve, so each game plays very similarly.

RATING: 6
4 players. Some people refer to this as monopoly with sheep which is unfair. It can be very frustrating  when your resources don't come up for ages but the dice roll tends to balance out over time. Unfortunately if you put your initial settlements in bad locations it's very difficult to win. 2 hour games can be optimistic! Advantage of this game is the rules are easy to grasp.

I prefer using the dice cards to ensure 'fair' randomness and for the extra bonuses that can help all players and hinder the leader.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Okay so I finally played it. 2010-10-09

Against AI mind you. I can't allways play poker for money...

After 280 ratings I can add Catan to my lists of ratings and it is a rock solid 7. 

I know why some of you love it. The game offers great tension and plenty of choices. Part of it strength is also the reason why I can't rate it higher is that in the dutch rules you have to throw the dice at the start of your turn.
I started by saying that I won 2/3 games. The game I lost I had won if I didn't throw a 7... I had all the resources to upgrade. Stil had a chance if I drew the right card but didn't do so.
Obviously that adds to the fun . It's fine if I can play the game in 60 minutes. I will upgrade the rating to an 8 then.
By the looks of it my group will take close to two hours to finish the game. To be able to lose a game when you are five  to one favourite before YOU yourself roll the dice, anything but a seven, well that can be tough.

This probably won't ever be a personal favourite of mine but i have to say that I wouldn't have thought that a game with such a small ruleset  has so much replay potential.

If one player doesn't understand the trades and  or trades favorable towards on player the game is broken. 
If everyone plays it right and quick this is definately fun. I've played games I liked much more but this one is for the masses and I liked it.

Update : Essen thursday 2010 RATING 7=>5
Played it with the group at Karl's place. Karl,alain, gust. All were new to it and they didn't think much of the game. General feeling was that if the rolls are in your favour you do well. and if you are the first person to take the lead it will be hard to win.

RATING: 8

Update: Bumped the rating up to 8 after a very enjoyable 4 player game with my wife and 2 of my kids.  Luck still plays a big part but you can make the luck work for you by choosing the numbers that are rolled most and putting your settlements on as many numbers as possible.

RATING: 6
Can't rate a game higher if all that matters is just a dice roll :/ 

Many might say "more stuff matters than dice roll". OK, agreed, it matters where you place your stuff, according to what is the probability of the dice roll. Some trading element is there too. But if you roll your dice badly - there's nothing to trade :)

Place all your stuff around 7 and 8. Unless there's a robber around. Then place elsewhere. Generally it doesn't matter, it's random anyway

RATING: 4
A truly awful game.  Mechanically, it is clunky and poorly designed, and thematically, it is fairly uninteresting.  I really don't know how it ever became popular.  A good marketing campaign, I suppose.

Settlers is a good dipstick, though, for testing how experienced of a gamer a person is.  Do they own or enjoy Settlers of Catan?  Then they're inexperienced, and it is your responsibility to introduce them to legitimately good board games.

RATING: 7
I thought that I would love this game more, but it didn't really move me.  But objectively it is an excellent design.  My main design criticism is that I feel that whoever begins the game with the best board position has a big advantage, to the extent that he or she will probably win.  Strategy helps somewhat, but only somewhat.  You also can't gang up on the leader as effectively as in some other games.  Regardless, this game seems destined to become a classic.

RATING: 5
I've grown a bit tired of this game even though I haven't played it hundreds of times like some.  While I generally do pretty well in the game (hurray for trading games!), I don't like seeing people get boxed in early and/or incidentally robber-blocked to the point where they have little chance of remaining competitive.  While I don't mind losing too much myself, I'd rather that everyone feel like they're still in the game, rather than just taking turns while hoping someone else will win, so the game can end.

Strangely enough, I purchased Seafarers of Catan despite these sentiments.  Of course, I've heard that Seafarers does balance out a few resource issues, so maybe all hope is not lost.

RATING: 6
I'm not a big fan of Klaus Teuber's games and Settlers of Catan IS conventional game from Teuber. Nice idea that everytime the gameboard is different so the game is a little bit different too. But when the game starts: it's dice rolling, dice rolling… and guess what: dice rolling! If you don't get right numbers, then you'll loose. If you don't get a good start, you'll loose. Who gets the money, gets more money => rich comes richer. That is a feature which is distinguish of Teubers' games. I'm ready to play Settlers of Catan if someone wants to but it's not my favorite game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The new modern classic board game of our time and in that sense heir to [b]Monopoly[/b], considering [b]Catan's[/b] [i][b]huge[/b][/i] worldwide impact (which also lead to an insane amount of spin-offs, expansions and re-themes).

Still a good gateway game for absolute newcomers, although like [b]Monopoly[/b], it did not age very well ([b]Settlers of Catan[/b] is from 1995 and it simply can not compete with more modern games).

Back in 1995, this was a 10 for most people (including myself), which makes sense, as it marks a turning point for the board game hobby and will always be a milestone in the history of board games.

The first expansion ([b][thing=325][/thing][/b]) is great (and in my opinion even essential), while the other expansions did not do so well for me, as it always felt to me that the designers forcefully tried to transform the game into something more complex, which this game simply is not meant to be -- but I see that it made sense back then to keep the fans busy and make [i]a few[/i] $$.

It's "cool to hate" [b]Catan[/b] among avid board gamers nowadays, but what they often actually mean is that they burnt out on it and that it did not age well.

If you are reading this as a complete newcomber to the board game hobby: go ahead and give it a try, but make sure it's not the only game you will be playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Best played with 3 or 4 players (i.e., without the 5-6 player expansions), Settlers of Catan is a game that all gamers should have in their collection. The mechanics are easy to learn and the "in game" trading allows for interesting player-to-player social interactions. Although tha game is described as a 90-minute game, you may want to allocate a bit more time for it.

RATING: 4
Got this, then gave it away in frustration. I think everything about this game is so smart, but there is just too much luck involved for how long it takes. I can take some luck in a short game, but when you're over the hour mark and YOU CAN'T EVER GET A DICE ROLL TO GO YOUR WAY... I rarely get frustrated playing games, but one time I was covering every number except 2, 3 & 11, and the ONLY numbers that would appear were these three or the number where the thief was hanging out on my land. Which was right after a game where a similar scenario had occurred. Late in this game, I rolled the number where the thief was hanging out - which happened to be the sixth straight turn where I received NOTHING - so picked up the board, dumped everything on it into the box and handed it to one of the other players, telling them to never bring it into my house again. 

Trading is also a game mechanic I'm rarely in love with, especially when it can go on and on AND ON. And it does here. Even with limiting the number of trades a person can ask for, this game can still drag out. I have no idea why this game is so popular. Friends are not even allowed to mention it in my presence!

RATING: 7.6
Use to teach newbies, house rules include not moving robber on 7 roll, but instead choosing a resource of your choice from the supply.  Speeds up play and makes for a friendly game (until knight development cards start being played).

I have all expansions and enjoy more room to play, even with three people.  Better borders options are available and a must if serious with catan.

RATING: 6.5
Catan.  What can you hate about it?  I am sure this is one of the most common games that got most of us into the new era of board gaming. RATING: 5
Initial impressions after one play:  Nice ideas in this -- variable board, set collection, trading, etc.  But it's just too dice-driven for me.  If you roll badly, you lose.  You can't trade if you don't roll enough of your resources, and anyway, too much of the game is dependent upon initial placement.  Check out Breese's "Keythedral" for a diceless and somewhat heavier treatment of the settlers theme.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A classic game known to many, an unfortunate symbol of geek culture that can turn off many non-gamers. It's a game that's fine, nice mechanics like resource management and trading, multiple avenues to win. But the game is right down to luck: who gets to place their places in the best positions for resources at the very start, what dice rolls happen and who gets those resources, and who gets robbed the most etc. This means the strategy is almost not there, but it's easy to get into, and it's not going to actively turn away people like a long game of Monopoly or Munchkin does. Perfectly fine gateway that I'll play whenever, but I just don't care enough to win since there's not that much you can do to control it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
'Settlers' is a fantastic family game. Great for those occasions when you want to host a game that isn't focused on warfare. It really gets people interacting in a big way. Good or bad things can happen to you at any time, even on other players turns. The 5-6 player extensions are great, because they modify the gameplay further, allowing each player the chance to conduct some activity for themselves, on other players turns. It's definately not a game where you get bored waiting for your next turn to roll around. The rules are simple to pick up, and yet the game has tremendous potential for modification or adapting 'house rules'.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
As with so many others, this was the game that brought me into gaming, and I still play it fairly frequently today (since it's accessible and a lot of non-gamers are familiar with it). I generally prefer it with an expansion.

I want a real expansion, new resources, new cards, co-op play. I've seen Catan expansions with the last one, but this game is a play for awhile, keep on the back burner for newer players and pull this out every once in awhile for some epic (albeit old-school) gaming.

1995 ... old school. haha...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Like most other people, Settlers was one of the first Euros I played and it helped start me on the hobby. I can't add anything to the praise it has received. The design is inspired and clever all at the same time.

That said, I find myself not really wanting to play much any more, especially with four players. Part of this is due to luck as some games the rolls just don't go your way. Another part is the downtime. I find myself spacing off during other players turns. Most players I know are unwilling to trade because they are worried about helping you too much. Further, I try to not plan ahead too much as things can change a lot before the dice come back to you (roads block you, solider/robber steals cards, etc.). 

A biggest part, however, is the endgame. Just when it looks like someone will win, another player bashes them and further delays the game. I usually don't mind "beat up on the leader" as this is an important strategy for winning. For Settlers, however, it makes what should be a 30 minute game into one that is 60 hour or longer.

As such, it is the best game that I rarely have any desire to play. 

Note: online play against AI helps as it speeds things up considerably. I recommend, http://games.asobrain.com

Kept for nostalgia value and as a gateway game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of the best gateway games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
We have not yet played this with three or four players yet, so I can't give it a fair rating.  We tried many of the two player variants found here, but none of them really worked for us.  Probably the most fun part, the trading, was virtually non-existent.  As a result, the game became a basic resource/building game without too many frills.  However, there was a significant runaway leader "rich gets richer" problem---the first person to get a city saw their resources start to take off well beyond the other player.  There were few ways for the second player to come back.  There were a few games where the robber was parked solely on the losing player's side for most of the game.  As a result, this left a bad taste and drove us away from all things Catan for a long time (which we regretted since there [i]are[/i] some quite good two player Catan games).

To be fair, [GAMEID=13] looks like it would be a lot of fun with more people, but with just two there are much better games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I like that this game got a lot of non-gamers into real boardgames.  I consider this the first "real" boardgame I ever played (meaning, Monopoly and Checkers and such aren't real).  I like that it's innovative and original.  But now I don't play it anymore and I'll tell you why.

The biggest thing is that it's too random, luck-based, for how long it is.  I'm fine with randomness in a short game, but once you start adding expansions (and the game is too boring without them), the games can take 3-5 hours if you include setup and teardown.  That's way too much of a time investment considering how swingy the dice can be.

Now I will play this game occasionally with the cards that replace the dice (they come in the Traders and Barbarians expansion).  That system is absolutely great.  It keeps the same probabilities of rolls coming up, but it ensures that each die roll (5's, for instance) will actually come up a certain number of times, but without guaranteeing exactly how many times it will come up.  Brilliant.

But those cards have events on them which only exacerbate another problem the game has: the catch-up mechanisms.  There are waaaaay too many of them when you play with the cards and you have the fish (which involves the boot) and you're playing Cities and Knights (the 3 stacks of development cards).  These are my family's favorite things because without them the game doesn't seem meaty enough.  But these 3 elements all have catch-up mechanisms and basically, the best strategy is to not be in first place, be in second, and then as the first place player gets beat down, take his place towards the end of the game.

And like with luck, it's no fun to have a game have a lot of catch-up mechanisms if it's also very long.

In summary, Catan isn't elegant at all.  To play a fun game you need expansions and expansions add complexity and it's not elegant how they interact.  Other games are more meaty to begin with, or have expansions that are more elegant.  

This isn't a great game.  I know some people will say, "well it's a great way to get non-gamers into boardgames.  It's a gateway game."  Again it's too long for how random it is.  If you want the luck and light strategy, get them into Machi Koro, which is a third the timespan so you can play multiple times.  If you want something with better expansions get Alhambra, the Big Box.  Or if you want something that's already well-rounded and can handle large player counts while being very strategic, get 7 Wonders (has expansions) or Between Two Cities (shorter).

We don't need Catan any more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I respect Catan's legacy, but this game is glorified Monopoly. It's extremely random, slow, harsh, clunky and otherwise everything we shouldn't look for in a modern board game, let alone a gateway game. The dice decide whether or not you get to do anything, and the robber plus various development cards can set you back to square one when you're already behind. 

This is thought of as a great trading game and I simply can't see it. Given how hard it is to come across goods, let alone useful ones in the early game, players are usually incentivized to hoard their goods. And it punishes you for just playing; with bad luck you can go large portions of the game without doing anything. 

It's easy to teach and has nice components, but we should not settle for "It's better than Monopoly" these days.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.4
A top-notch game of building and development.  Of the 20(ish) people I’ve introduced this to, every single one has enjoyed it, and many have become real fans.  I’d suggest playing with resources face up when teaching people, since that will reduce the frustration of learning exactly what you need to build what.  The game is simple, yet it manages to have realistic production, trade, and building.  The ending is usually either very close, or such a blowout that it ends very quickly.

RATING: 9
One of my favorite games partly because it is the reason I entered the wonderful world of board gaming, and partly because it is a pretty darned good game. 

I really enjoy the trading part of the game that gives a lot of interaction even without direct conflict. Multiple ways of scoring. 

This was my go to game for introducing players to board gaming. They never really understood how to win the first game but almost everyone wanted to play again. 
Now maybe ticket to ride would be better but that is a bit to easy\limited for me. 

It doesn't get very much play anymore but when we do I always enjoy it. 

Cons
If you are tied down early it can be a boring stretch until finished. 

House rule? If you roll a seven You move the robber. Makes it a lot more fun and do not double punish you for the roll. (Note that we had two different ways of handling the robber in the rules so this might be the original way of using him. If not make it so :)

RATING: N/A
很想說…卡坦島，不解釋。

經典就是經典，
此遊戲要策略有策略（擺放地盤是策略），
要彼此攻訐有彼此攻訐（資源交換時），
要運氣有運氣（看那美麗的骰子～）。

不過我覺得玩這款遊戲的時候要注意，
因為此遊戲有「策略的成份」，
所以如果你太在意策略，你就會被骰子玩弄，
看那連出的數字2、3，以及連骰3次7的神妙經驗，
我會將卡坦定位在「派對」、「家庭」遊戲的範疇，
這樣就不會動太多的情緒，
在不知道什麼方面了阿～

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
First of all, I respect this game for being very good at its role as a gateway game, and see its place. That being said, I think it is overrated. The game drags too much if a clay or wood is in short supply (and if you do happen to get clay or wood, you have an incentive to put the robber on opposing clay/wood tiles, so that other people can't catch up, ,dragging the game on even more). If you get lucky in the beginning with the die rolls you can have a runaway leader problem. Also, while unlikely a player can be so blocked off that they are almost effectively eliminated.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

in the game i played, ppl are holding up resources on purpose and revenging each other with the robber.  I mean it maybe strategically correct, but as a gateway game this may put ppl off.  And i don't think this is a good way to make new friends :>

I would much rather use carcassone or tickets to ride as a gateway game

RATING: 8
I owned this for a few years but never broke it out because I'd heard and read that 'the only way to play this game is with 4'. Before BGG.

Fooey, the thing works well with 3, no problem. Might require 3 good gamers, though. 4 is good, no question, especially if some of the group are not so great gamers.

Been playing this for years now, it's a lot of fun.

RATING: 9
My copy is actually missing parts but I have friends who own it as well.  One of the first geekworthy board games I played.  Possibly my gateway game.  I still remember the day the group I was with first played the game and the amazement at the ability to do so many different things.  My only dislike of the base game is that the dice never seem to roll anywhere near the numers you would expect on the average.  Then again dice hate me more often than not.  I've advanced on to the expansions now but the base game still gets alot of credit for bringing me into the hobby.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Was the gateway game that got me into modern gaming.  Nowadays, I'd rather play something else, but I have acknowledge its success.  

However, the two main turnoffs for me are: The randomness can feel punishing, when a good strategy falls flat on its face because no 6s or 8s have been rolled, despite probability, and in my experience, in a 4 player game, 1 player usually spends the game stagnant, unable to really achieve much.  

The second, is that I don't like how critical the starting positioning is.  With experience players, I feel like I can accurately predict who will win 80% of the time based solely on where everyone starts.

RATING: 7
My very first contact with boardgames.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I'm a card-carrying Catan hater.  This game is practically built on a foundation of two things I loathe in games: too easy for bad luck to screw you, and too easy for the other players to collude to play kingmaker to screw you with the trading.

It's not the most unimaginably awful thing I've played, those are all in the Sorry/Monopoly/etc. category.  But it is easily my least favorite of all the "modern classics".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The game that got me and countless others into modern board gaming. Hasn't aged as well as other games mainly because of the chance of dice rolls but still an absolute classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
What started it all for me in this hobby/addiction.  I will always love this game.  Truly a classic that I will play anytime, anywhere.

In my opinion, this should be #1 in the BGG ratings.  I'm not even sure there would be a BGG, or at least a BGG in its present, popular form, if it weren't for Settlers of Catan.  That it has fallen to the 20s (update - now in the 30s) or so is a travesty and reflects the skew of BGG's ratings to new games.

The dice-rolling/resource mechanic in Settlers was so groundbreaking, probably more than any other mechanic since.  And the mechanic complements the design so seamlessly that it is impossible to think of the game with a better mechanic.  Settlers is a masterpiece of game design. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Great replay potential.  A good 'gateway' game for non=gamers.  Multiple paths to victory a plus.  It's easy to understand why the basic game is still popular after 18 years on the shelf.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Classic - I started my game addiction on this, Dominion, and Munchkin. The game generally plays well. I would usually rather play another game but, unlike Munchkin, there is a lot going on for Catan: Visual interest, variable setup, tactile pieces, and a healthy dose of luck.

It is too random (dice rolls determine everything) to be appreciably strategic, unless you and your opponents are really trading a lot of resources. In my experience, nobody every wanted to trade anything. Everyone has to be willing to take a bad trade and then be "owed one", I think. When resources are flowing freely, the game can be a lot of fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is basically a classic and is almost always the first game anyone buys. It was one of my first games to purchase and I've played it numerous times. It never gets old and is always a great game to introduce people to games as well as to recommend as a first purchase.

RATING: 6
The biggest thing that this classic lacks from its newer brethren is the consolation prize when a player gets nothing from the resource roll (newer games award a gold point; gold can be traded 2-for-1 for any resource and aren't counted for robber purposes in the meantime). This would probably be really good with that added in.

Play with real dice, not a dice deck.

RATING: 7.5
This was the second German game I ever played and loved it.  A great way to learn economics: scarcity of resources.  It has a luck factor which is good for new players.  This is what we use to introduce new players to german games, most who have never played a game like this so much, they buy it.  Still great fun.  Update: now for new people with very little game experience, we use Ticket to Ride as the gateway game, but we still use this game for lots of new people as well.
Updated rating to 7.5.

RATING: 5
Perhaps, the first great German game to introduce all other German games.  But then get over it!  It wears worse than Monopoly.  At least, when you've brokered a deal in Monopoly to get a set of properties, you've really done something game altering--more than just managing to score that brick you needed to build a road.  If people will play fast, then Settlers is bearable, but when it bogs down, it really bogs down.  I love luck management as part of a game, but in Settlers rarely do I feel that my choices made more of a difference than how the dice rolled over the course of the game.

RATING: 9
Oh, Settlers!  People hate on you, because you're not the best at everything.  They say other games are more fulfilling and entail less luck. Your modular board, your simple, but well balanced rules, your pleasing design, your friendliness with other people; I love it all.  Call me cliche, but this game is wonderful.

RATING: 6

This game is OK fun.  It seems the greatest strategic decision is in the initial placement decision.  There is fun trading, blocking, and taking your chance with the bonus cards.

SoC does feature a good amount of luck.  This can make it fun, as this, the robber, and others unwilling to trade with the leader make it easy for those behind to catch up.  I suppose this makes it accessible.

That much luck-factor for me, lowers the score.  However, I do have fun playing this game despite the luck factor.  It is interactive, goes back and forth quite a bit, and encourages alot of table talk.

I wouldn't want to play this everyday, but it does have a place in the collection as a good gateway or social game.

RATING: 7.5
A classic, no doubts about it. An elegant design, and a game of great "historical" importance. But nowadays I find it a little bit too luck based for my taste. Good players will usually beat bad players, but if everyone is good there' s really little you can do to offset a streak of bad die rolls: without cards you can do literally nothing, thus you have no control. Despite this, still a very good and fun game, but better designs are now available in its category.

RATING: 8
This game introduced our family to this new genre of gaming. I wish I had know about it 5 years ago! Everyone in the family likes this game, but to differing degrees. After a few game sessions my youngest son (currently 15 years old) became extremely frustrated with several series of extremely bad rolls of the dice.  We had read about the variation of using a deck of dice instead, so we tried that.  He has now declared that in the future he will only play Settlers with a deck of dice, thus insuring a uniform probability distribution.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I was really surprised by how little I liked this game - I had really been looking forward to playing it. I've only played once, so perhaps I haven't seen enough of the depth of the game yet.

I found the general theme to be kind of boring - I just couldn't get excited about building the little cities. The downtime was painful - there really wasn't anything to think about when the other players were taking their turns. Mostly, however, the thing I didn't like about the game was how I kept losing cards. Everytime someone rolled a 7, there was a good chance that I would lose 1/2 my cards. In addition, I really don't like games where others can steal my cards, something that follows the rolling of a 7. Finally, I just don't enjoy trading games. I'm not really interested in trying to keep track of everyone's hands so that I can make "shrewd" trades. As a result, I usually come up on the losing side of any trade.

I can see why folks like this game, It's just not a hit with me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Decent light euro.  A little high on the luck side but just means people need to understand risk management and adjust their strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game's popularity is well deserved. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
This was my Gateway Game. Played nearly 100 times since 2007 and will still play when asked. Since expanding my horizons, I have a hard time accepting that most of the game you are relying on random outcomes based on your placements, but everyone is in the same boat (albeit with different random outcomes that they want, some are better than others) so it's fine.

Asking for wood never gets old either.

The game is easy to teach and easy to play, I understand how it can be such a good intro game (or even a casual game). 

Expansions are nice as well - I like Cities and Knights and would prefer to play that variant all the time. Unfortunately it is difficult to add these new rules with the people who I play Catan with. 

On a regular night with my group, this game would not come out. On nights where I am around non-gamers or family this is an easy one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Settlers - as has been well chronicled by many other people - was a bridge game for me - that took me from the world of 'board games' as I knew them (think Monopoly, Scrabble, etc) to the world of modern/Euro type board games as I know them now (think bgg.com). At the time, I was blown away by this game and it made me catch the modern board game bug. I thought the mechanics and strategy were great.  Now, however that I've been exposed to many more (imo better) games, I'm actually not a fan of Settlers.  What I don't like about the game is that you are reliant on the trading aspect of the game for success.  Meaning if your opponents decide not to play nice and trade with you, you are sunk. I also don't love how the robber can freeze your progress of the game, and if others gang up on you your sunk. I don't typically mind the 'screw you' aspect of games, but in this case the robber combined with the trading dependencies make this game flawed for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I can't help but think that every game of Settlers I play comes down to sheer luck. I know the lands yield based on probability, but constant robbers, getting locked out of trades, and lucky victory point draws make any kind of strategy seem meaningless. To sum it up, it's an hour long experience of what could have been decided by a coin toss.

My feelings of the game aside, this is the one game that all of my non-gamer friends constantly nag me to play. It's an awesome tool to sucker them in to the world of boardgames. And for that, I thank you Settlers of Catan.

RATING: 7
Board Game PLAYED
FAMILY, Strategy, Negotiation, Dice Rolling, Hand management, Modular board, Trading, Rout/Network building
 
3-4
60'-120'

Complecity: M/L 2,37

1998-2006
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
For myself and many others, Catan was the 'gateway drug' that got me immersed into the hobby of strategic board games after previously only being exposed to overplayed 'Classics' like Monopoly or Risk, party games like Cranium and Trivial Pursuit, or a couple of complicated war games that took an entire day to play if you were lucky.

Catan (or Settlers of Catan when I first played it) hits a lot of key areas for a great board game - easy to understand and teach rules, excellent replayability with the board being different for each game, relatively short time period with games averaging 45-60 minutes, a variety of potential strategies and paths to victory, a lot of player interaction with trading, and gameplay that typically keeps all players with a shot at victory up to the very end. The only real knock against Catan may be it's theme - which can be a little vague (I guess it's early Medieval settlers on a newly discovered island??) and not necessarily the most appealing - and can feel a little tacked on (there's a reason why there are so many alternative versions of Catan - like Star Trek Catan).  But overall, this is an excellent game board game that is easily accessible to casual board-gamers and is definitely an essential part of any collection.

Adding to its value, there are also a variety of expansions that layer additional elements on top of the basic set.  By far the best expansion is Cities and Knights, which practically transforms Catan to a different game - while maintaining the same core mechanics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I really like the negotiations, and player interaction.  It's one fault in my opinion is how it heavily rewards those who are ahead.  Thus if you get several bad rolls in the beginning, you may just be patiently waiting for someone to win the game so you can start another one.  It is a lot of fun though, and very few games have even come close to being as addictive as this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Maybe I'm playing with the wrong people that are looking for trades that aren't there or maybe I've just gotten tired of the same thing over and over.

Based on 10+ plays.

RATING: 5
After placing first towns, almost no more major decisions. You cannot but do only action you can do with resources which dice rolls gave to you. Moreover, with bad rolls, you have nothing to do.

Not enough thematic feel.

UPDATE July 2007--------------------
SoC has a potential of being fun. Random map, resource production and management, some nastiness(monopoly, robber, etc.), luck and strategy... but the problem is that strategy often doesn't work.

To do any, you need resources. To get resources, you need good roll. To increase probability of getting resources, you need more settlements. But to build new settlement you need resources! So in the beginning of game, everyone has only two settlements and only three resources, getting good rolls can be crucial. Someone who gets enough resources first and build another settlement get huge advantage - she or he gets increased probability of getting resources, can take good place, and can block other players' expansion. In the middle of play after building four or five settlement there can be some ways of dealing with bad rolls, but in the beginning there is none.

Secondly, it is hard to save cards for future, you often have to do unwanted trade or build unwanted building. It is very bitter when you oards many cards only because you couldn't manage to get NEEDED resources and then robber comes out.

At last, I don't like the "sudden end." When having 8 or 9 VP and struggling for a couple of points, someone suddenly declares the end of game - it is not so pleasant. (Of course dice luck can be crucial here again) I wish there were end game.

Now I think SoC as a well-organized dice-race game...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I need this.. I love it. I play anytime someone has it but I don't own it yet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Also own: Barbarians Of Catan

RATING: 6
First impression: 6.5

A good game with a nice load of player interaction, but in my short experience it seems to be too long in playing time for what it is.

It have a respectable amount of luck involved, but as a light family game it can be a choice, maybe not my first choice, but neither my last. Definitely I'll be playing it in the future wit my family.

On the side of components production, I have to say that my Devir edition is just gorgeous with it's nicely detailed plastic models of towns, cities and roads, and the amazing illustration work of Michael Menzel.

I hope to find some expansions at a good price to see if the gameplay can be enhaced.

---------------------------------------------------------

Update: 7.5

After some more games I'm begining to think that Catan is as good gateway game as Ticket To Ride. In the first few games we didn't understand the role of the area control element of the game, but now is more clear and a lot more enjoyable. I'm seeking to buy the 5-6 players expasion as usually there is one more willing to play.

---------------------------------------------------------

Update after 18 Plays: 6.0

Maybe there is to much luck involved (or my dice are seriously adverse to the statistic normal distribution), and a 5 or 6 player game (with the expansion) can get too long or too chaotic. Some times I'll be willing to play it but maybe a slightly more common choice will be to play other game.

Still I hope some day I'll buy an expansion that will make the game shine again, because deep down I know I like the game...

RATING: 7.4
Usually fun, interesting combo of luck and strategy.  

The randomness of the die rolls usually leads to one player getting screwed every game, regardless of that player's skill level.  When you happen to be that player, it's a frustrating game.  If not, it can be a lot of fun.  The variable board is excellent.  Sometimes we use the official dice deck instead of rolling, and/or play that 2 and 12 activate each other.

Not a fan of the sea pieces in the 4th ed. Mine don't lay flat, which is sort of annoying.  

[i]*Own 5-6 player extension.[/i]

RATING: 3.3
El primer juego tras los clásicos (monopolio, risk, Stratego) que jugué. Lo compré el año 1997 y por flojera lo aprendí recién el 2004.
Muy entretenido pero puede cansar un poco la etapa de negociación para adquirir materias, cuando se transforma en un diálogo de sordos. No da respiro ni permite distracción, porque de lo contrario otro ha logrado un mejor acuerdo.
Tal vez el factor suerte (los dados) hacen que cuando a uno le va mal, pese a toda lógica, uno se desanime y quiera jugar algo más controlable.
UPDATE: en mi último juego, junto a Seafarers, en dos horas logré hacer dos caminos; es decir, me quedé con los dos puntos iniciales. Mala suerte total; aburrimiento total. Prefiero dedicarme a juegos con factor suerte menos importante o que se pueda revertir con un buen juego. En este caso, es practicamente irrevesible remontar la mala suerte con los dados. Y lo peor, se traduce en un juego interminable...a la media hora ya quieres que termine (y a esas alturas falta una hora y media)

RATING: 7
A little abstract, a little random, but positively tends to teach people 2d6 distribution, that's the good thing in times of all-present retarded calculator-owners. Tends to be punishing for lack of geometric planning and careless play as well as high hopes for rare numbers. In general not very rewarding, when you lose you fell like a loser, not like a next-turn-to-be-winner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Yes, it's luck-heavy, the rich get richer, and you can therefore be severely crippled by bad dice rolls early.  But with experienced players it flies by, those things tend to even out over time, and you can learn to mitigate bad luck (to an extent).  The caprice of the dice is part of the charm, IMHO.

A great gateway to the hobby for many, this is the game my group broke out when we last expanded...it's sort of a baseline game for "gamers", giving the opportunity for some easy sociable play.

My kids have learned to love this game, too, and the fact that they can grow up with this rather than Monopoly means a lot to me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
It had to be a 10. It is the one game that has seen the most plays in my collection of over 150 board games. Even after so many years it is the first one that gets picked when I want to introduce new people to the tabletop gaming fraternity. It's simple. The rules are easy to teach. People learn how to play and get into the game quickly. It provides a lot of player interaction. And almost every time this game is rolled out for a gaming session, it never stops at just one game, someone always says "Ooh, can we play again? I know what I want to try this time..." There is an element of luck, yes. But also the chance for negotiation and strategy.

RATING: 7
My first Euro game, and still a favorite. I played a ridiculous amount of Catan in college, and it led me in all sorts of directions, board game-wise.

I'd say it has minor runaway leader issues, and sometimes initial placement can be quite frustrating -- but neither detracts from what an excellent, replayable, and satisfying gateway Euro this is.

The probability aspect is one of my favorite elements, as it nicely modulates the randomness factor. I also particularly like seeing how things shake out when a vital resource is constrained for the whole game because of tile placement.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Settlers of Catan was the game that launched me into the hobby of gaming.  I found the ability to be strategic so refreshing over classic games yet there was still that familiar mechanic of dice rolling that brought along with it the factor of luck.  Its variable modular board does create a new start setup every time but the feel of the game play does not vary after the initial start phase.  The start phase is so crucial to how well you will do in the game depending on your ability to follow through on your initial plans, which I believe takes a little away from Catan.  I've found myself not wanting to play this game over and over as I originally did but am eternally thankful to it for giving me a new hobby.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I literally don't understand the attraction this game still has for people when there's so many better options for a gateway game. Can we just stop playing this game already?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
While this game gets a lot of love, I feel it is broken in many serious ways, particularly:
1) Runaway leader.
2) Virtual elimination (being confined early on/unable to ever build a 3rd city and having to continue playing for another 45 minutes is painful and boring).
3) Kingmaker (this happens a lot due to #2 combined with trading).

I give the game top marks for the board setup phase (great variations and replayability), and the theme plus trading idea is interesting. But sadly after a dozen or so plays, I still find the gameplay weak despite its classic status.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
A game that has problems with runaway leaders and leader-bashing at the same time. You usually can't do anything at all if the dice don't roll your way, and many times someone will be out of the running (but not allowed to leave) through no fault of his or her own. The only thing I like about it is the modular board, but that's not enough to save the game.

As far as I'm concerned, this is an interminable Snail's Pace Race that locks people out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.5
THIS GAME HAS BECOME OBSOLETE!

Pros:
1. Revolutionized the gaming industry

Cons:
1. Success is dependent on other players. It is counter-intuitive to help out other players when they are competing against you. This is not a mechanic you see often anymore (you see this in older games like Cosmic Encounter). Early in the game, it works "okay." But once a leader has been established, players typically choose to not trade with that player. This can even out the game, but it also makes it disadvantageous to have an early lead. Small World suffers from the same problem. If a game is dependent on negotiation, there need to be alliances. Fief is a game that works in this way. Settlers, on the other hand, falls flat if players aren't willing to work together. 
2. Takes too long for what it is (think Monopoly)
3. BORING! This game has absolutely no theme, the board is hard to read, and the choices just aren't interesting. 
4. Stale components
5. Perhaps most importantly, so many games have replaced this one. Every mechanic has been replicated and improved.

I'm glad I played it, but only to know that I never want to play again. Plain and simple, this game has no soul. I'd rather play Monopoly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played for the first time. Was an enjoyable game that I would play again. A great gateway game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Update - After playing a quite a few games, I have come back to this one and like it a lot more.  It is much more streamlined and strategic than I had thought previously. Plus the old Mayfair edition that I have has very average artwork.

I marvel at the design genius of Settlers, but not the game play. I just don't enjoy it all that much. In my opinion, it takes a bit too long to play.  The foodstamp variant helps balance the luck of the dice.  I have had little luck using this as a gateway game, many others work better.

RATING: 7
An OK mainstream game that most people have played by now. But as such, i'm all played out on this game. It relies too heavily on player negotiations for goods. This game did wonders for the boardgaming community, but it has overstayed its welcome in my collection. Get those player negotiations out of my strategy game, and outta my face! Time to grow up and play Castles of Burgundy.

RATING: 7
A near-perfect balance of analysis, excitement and both verbal and positional player interaction. Superb. See my review for more details: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/118883
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Still one of my favorites.  More "hardcore" gamers would scoff at that, but it has a lot of what I like in a game.  It is social (trading). All players are involved in every turn (dice rolls and trading). There is enough luck to make it interesting but enough skill that experience/strategy matters.  The theme is light-hearted and doesn't turn people off (a great thing for a gateway game).

On the downside, trading can be intimidating for new players.  The range in game time is actually fairly substantial.  Someone always seems to complain about the random board.  There is a lot of sheep on the board for it not meaning much (the Seafarers expansion helps with that).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not as fun as it used to be and a bit stale after so many plays, but it's still a staple in our gaming group. The resource gathering mechanic in Stone Age is far superior and less random. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I have played this game more than any other I know of. Although I don't get it to the table much anymore, it still has a very dear place in my heart. Wonderful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.01
The crimes of Catan are these:

1. With the random board setup and the rolling of dice there's simply too much randomness in acquiring resources for my liking. Even if you could find a path to gain wheat, it could be on a tile that only produces on a 3. I like modular boards, but Clash of Cultures at least starts the same for all players until you factor in the expansion. Mage Knight has a progression of tiles. Catan looks like it does because somebody stopped stirring the gumbo. Starting position can be painfully obvious for a starting player who has played the game enough, or I could see it being an AP nightmare for a newer player.

2. And about that dice rolling for resources. There's the chance you roll and other people get resources, but you don't. Since you received no resources, you might not be able to build anything nor trade for anything. This happened multiple times in the game for me. I just think a player's turn should be an advantage and in a number of cases nothing happened for me and other players gained resources.

"But you can gain resources when it isn't your turn."

Still doesn't take away the crap feeling of a dead turn. I dislike Acquire for when you have to place a tile out in an open area but at least you can buy stocks. Catan? You get nada during a dead turn. If I were to make a creed for game design, the lack of a dead turn has to be listed. It feels inexcusable for a gateway.

3. The robber.

This issue was low for me this time. I wasn't hit much with it, but it was placed in a couple of spots a lot during the game and even one player mentioned at least once how it was being placed in their area to a fault. It's basically a randomized take on bash the leader.

Significant for its influence versus its game play these days. Even if you are picking gateway games, 7 Wonders beats this and even that's slowly growing on me. We simply make better games now. Okay, we made better games before Catan but bygones.

Rating Potential: 6-6.5. I really don't see this moving up. 7 Wonders alone scratches virtually the same itch and does it without the random factor of the robber. Takenoko is similar in that they are both gateways, but I find it more enjoyable despite its flaws. Again, not that similar, but Keyflower is another game from a design standpoint that really beats this into the ground.

Update. I think it is stuck in the 6.01 range. Expansions might give it enough legs to bump it up, but I don't see the base game going to a 7. I see no need to buy it for the obvious lack of need to due to quality and somebody else will have a copy anyway so that's the 0 in the score. After that it is merely how often I want to play it, and I'm guessing this will sneak in a once a year kind of play even if I'm going "Why am I not playing  pretty much anything else I would bring instead?"

I might prefer this as a 5-6 player game with the additional special build phase. I'll have to see how it plays as a 4-player game. Really not worth playing as a 3-player game. Trading is too difficult to make it fun. Can be more AP prone, see The Longest Turn meme, than I would like for a gateway.

2nd play of 6 player game. Yeah, um no. I fully accept the fact that I took a risk in my initial placement of my second settlement and road so I didn't give up on longest road from the start, but I was instantly blocked and thus vastly did nothing the whole game. I started on a spot for gold with a 9 on it, and it ended up being one of the lesser numbers rolled. I seriously do not get the hype for the game. 1 good play in 5 has me wondering if this shouldn't go lower. Actually, updated to a 5. I'll debate putting it at a 4.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Trading mechanic makes this game evergreen classic. Despite having excitement via dice, the actual gameplay is pretty average and even dry by todays standards, but the trading makes the game much more lively! The rules are relatively simple at least for how deep game you get. It's deserving of its status as a classic eurogame that started it all. Still a good one, especially if you're introducing new people to modern boardgaming! Expansions.. meh.

2-Player Comment:
* Settlers of Catan wasn't designed for two, but internet is full of variants to try (especially if you also own Seafarers). I prefer normal rules even for two myself, but play to 7 points only. It's no match to 3-4p game though and for most people some variant is a must. 

Expansions:
+Catan: 5-6 player Extension
+Fishermen of Catan

RATING: 10
Great 4 player game if played quickly, though usually more even as a 3 player game. Slow players can spoil the game, simply because there is no excuse for AP; decisions are rarely difficult (initial settlement placement excepted). Has a lovely acceleration towards the end game, when 3 players (4 if you're lucky, but more typically someone is being crushed) are often in with a shot of winning if the dice roll their way. Fun with kids if you give them a smaller VP target (e.g. 7 or 8 vs. 10 for adult).
Liked this game enough to make a custom 3D board... guess it has to be a 10.

RATING: 3
I realize this is a classic and really set the stage for a lot of other games, and I appreciate the game from that perspective, but I just don't enjoy playing it at all. Every time I play it, I quickly lose all interest and have zero patience for it. I just find it a slow moving game, w too little player-to-player interaction, and minimal strategy. On top of that, I find games usually take at least 45 mins, especially because there is no 'internal clock' to end the game, so it just keeps dragging on as people try to accumulate enough resources to do anything. 

I have not played any of the expansions, so perhaps those could sway me, but I also don't have any desire to play this game, so the chances of me trying an expansion are low.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I've gotten into the hobby for a little more than a year as of this writing. I realize this game is now generally thought to be past its time, and its merits as a "gateway game" are questioned, but it was the gateway game for me and my game group, and we do go back to this game regularly.

I've found it useful as a parent, my kids have learned the basics of setting up a game, taking turns, rolling dice, gathering resources, building, etc. They don't like the robber much at all (who does), and I found it interesting and funny when they banish the robber to a part of the board that isn't inhabited, so it doesn't hurt anybody. 

When this game goes bad for a particular player, it definitely is frustrating eg. when the rolls aren't going your way or the robber is on you constantly as the rest of the table gangs up on you. And the 5-6 player expansion is not as enjoyable. Nevertheless the controlled but open negotiation of trades generally keeps people engaged throughout the game.

Our favourite "base game" is to add in the fish from Traders and Barbarians (takes away the desert, and gives the table another resource), and to also play with the Harbor Master to go along with the Longest Road and the Largest Army. 

The 10 rating is in part given to historical context of my own personal journey into this hobby, as it is far and away the game I've played the most, that I continue to enjoy. It's also boosted up by our "base game" add-ins from the expansions. "Vanilla" Catan I would rate around 8 out of 10. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A classic. Aged pretty well. Some will say it's just random dice rolling, and that might seem true on your first couple of plays, but there's much more to Catan than that. It's all about positioning, trading and managing your hand to avoid the thief.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The board game I've played most - over 50 online games, and over 25 in person, with 7 in one day once. I don't think it is as great with the expansion for 6, and I dislike the seafarers expansion. 

I've played this successfully as a teams game with the following rules: 
- sit across from each other
- cannot trade more than 1 resource on your turn to your teammate 
- each player needs to score 10
- can share 1 point from longest road or largest army with teammate for victory points
It reduces the trading aspect of the game, but adds a fun layer of backstabbery strategy.

RATING: 4
Not a bad game, exactly, but resource acquisition snowballs and there can be a runaway leader effect that can make the game very boring for players doing poorly. If it were shorter, this would be less of a concern.

My biggest problem with it, however, is how you can often end up with nothing to do on your turn. The bare minimum of good game design is that you should have meaningful choices to make on every turn, even if none of your options are very good.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.25
Good for its time, Settlers of Catan hasn't aged well. It remains a gateway to better fare.

It is far too long for such basic mechanics and lack of real strategic depth, and it suffers from highly formal (and utterly bland) game-end conditions, as well as a relative lack of variant approaches to success.

All of these things are probably what make it so good as a gateway: the obviousness of it all allows beginners to understand why they've won or lost, and the strong positive memories thus created tend to stick with players long after they've outgrown Settlers.

It's an important transitional piece, slightly better than other (older) games that also garner a degree of nostalgia (Risk; Monopoly), and it surely gives joy to a lot of people: over the board, however, it is deeply limited.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The variability of the board layout itself and numbered markers is what makes this a great game. You have to adjust strategies here. This also lends to high replayability. The dice add some randomness, but muffled some by the markers. The different ways to get points really adds to the fun and suspense. 

Clearly this game (and series) has been successful for a reason. You can think 3 moves ahead, or just go; either way, it's still fun. The trading aspect here is done very well. Monopoly in theory has trading, but the reality there is limited. 

Plays quickly once everyone knows how to play. 

Edit: Rating down due to overplaying it and the C&K expansion being better. After many plays, not liking the trading aspect as much as early on. Still a great series.
