RATING: 8
Played 22 times.
Last play was May 3, 2008.

This was fun.  It was enough different from Settlers of Cannan that I don't mind having both in my collection even though the primary reason we got this was to play with the 5-6 player expansion.

The close quarters and more evenly distibuted numbers really makes this game harder, and seems to suffer from a run-away leader problem that I didn't notice in Settlers of Cannan.

The last game we played was the first really close game - but that was because my husband didn't choose to win when he had the opportuntity and then gave me the exact trade I needed to get three points at once.

Just played the game with 3 players and it was a much closer game than when we play with 4.

I've decided I just don't like this game with 4 players.  There just isn't enough realestate and tempers get raised when one player out races another player to that critical corner.  There always seems to be one player that just doesn't have a chance.  Next time we play with 4 we are going to try and use the map for the 5-6 player expansion and see how that works. (This was just confirmed again in last nights game of cities and knights - and I was the player with NO chance.)

We just played a 4 player game of Cities and Knights and used the expansion tiles and it was a much more even game.  We didn't have as much running out of space issues and there wasn't ever a run-away leader.  But ther was still penty of tension.

RATING: 9
A modern classic, fantastic fun and the variability and two main routes to victory make for interesting and engaging games. Despite the replayability the rules and concept are straightforward enough that somebody that has never played this or any other 'Eurogame' will get involved and provided they didn't bungle the initial placement they stand a good chance of making a game of it. There's a balanced pre-placed layout in the rules that helps for the first game, it is pretty scripted for anybody who's familiar with the game though, whichever colour you get you'll know what you need to do at a glance - strictly for first games only.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I came late to the world of Catan, but after having the game's merits described to me, I took a chance and brought the box home from the game shop. 

I have never once been disappointed by this game. It's a perfect mix of strategy and simplicity. Everyone gamer I know loves this game, and there's good reason for it. The game mechanics are simple to learn and understand, but the strategy and luck elements keep it interesting (or frustrating) every time.

Setup time is relatively quick after the first few plays, and average game time has been around an hour depending on how chatty people get during trading and making up elaborate stories about why they're attempting to dominate sheep production.

I've never had this much fun simply playing a game and not caring whether I'm winning or losing. My experience with Settlers of Catan is becoming the standard by which I judge all other games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
My gateway game. The game that got me into this hobby. Family still loves to play it and asks for it regularly.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
There's something I don't like about Catan and I can't put my finger on what it is.  If I know in advance that my group will be playing Settlers, I'll probably skip game night.

I don't mind the dice.  I haven't played it enough to burn out on it.  I'm not one of those people that dislikes things just because they're popular.  It tends to drag a bit by the endgame, but I don't think that's the problem either.

In fact, it's a decent game, that I mostly enjoy while I'm playing it.  But I never, ever, ever want to play it, and I would rather play almost any other game instead of it.  Oftentimes, I'd rather not play any game at all.  I just don't know why.

UPDATE: I figured it out--if I'm playing Settlers than I'm not playing Keythedral, which is a somewhat similar game but ten times better.  Imagine wanting to play Race for the Galaxy but having someone say "Let's play Crazy Eights instead!"  That's what playing Settlers is like.

RATING: 8.3
This one of those games you can come back to time and time again! Simple game-play mechanics means it caters to gamers and non-gamers alike - but it still has enough depth of play to keep it interesting. Great player interaction as you jostle for space and resources. The open barter system for resources (where players can openly exchange resources) and quick turns means there is little down time and you're are consistently engaged through-out the game. Definitely worth getting the Seafarers expansion to add a bit more complexity!

RATING: 8
What can we say about Settlers that hasn't already been said?  The game is amazing.  It is probably the best trading/resource collection/building game ever.  I have played Settlers more than almost any other board game in my collection.  I have given numerous copies as gifts.  This is definitely the game that blew open the secret of the German gaming scene.  If played competitively the game can break down to collusion.  I really prefer the original German artwork to the latter Mayfair stuff.

Have two copies of first edition mayfair and also one copy of the anniversary edition gold box.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love this game - and so do my wife and mother-in-law.  In fact, they love it so much that the deal is my mother-in-law buys us the expansions and I teach them how to play the game.  So we play a combined 2D/3D variant of Settlers, Cities & Knights, Seafarers and Fishers, with event cards and the 5/6-player expansion if needed.  In fact, we have played this game with up to 9 people and still had a very enjoyable game.  I can't recommend it highly enough.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
10/11/99 Bought. I own the English third edition from Mayfair. 

11/17/09 I finally played using the fourth edition. And... I think the graphics are terrible. Especially the port icons being so tiny. One third the size of the ones in the 3rd edition, and hard to tell apart from across the table. Some of the hill hexes were throwing us old hands off. They had so much green in them we weren't sure whether they were hills (producing brick) or meadows (producing wool). It seems the graphics guy decided to make every hex unique. Well, that's all fine and good if you're creating art. But a game must be functional above all else. And its very difficult to sweep the 4th ed. board with your eye and get a grasp of what is what without a lot of pausing to squint at stuff. Could Mayfair leave well enough alone? Nooooo.  02/21/17 Gamed with the 4th edition again plus its 5/6 player expansion. Same comments. 

I'll let my initial rating stand, as its for my 3rd edition. But if I owned the 4th edition I'd rate Settlers a 5 for the ridiculous graphics. 

03/05/16 A three-player game with the English 5th edition. The graphics were *much* better than the 4th edition. I'm not a fan of the rule changes concerning VP card play after the game is over and mixed trading & building. I feel its "dumbs down" the game. I also think taking "The Settlers of" off the box is arrogant and stupid. If I owned this version I'd rate it a 7.5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Great game to play with everybody!

Build towns, get resources and be the first to get 10 points. Each game is different, and you will need a bit of luck to get your resources, but if you play well you can manage to win.

It only has one drawback: If you don't know where to build the first towns you can make a bad decisition and the rest of the game will be boring and frustrating. So it's very important to help new players in this step.

RATING: 4.5
Kolonisten van Catan
Yes, maybe I should rate this one higher, as it restarted my interest in board games 10 years ago (bought the original German version way back). And it served quite well to get more people around me into boardgames. 

For the first couple of years I had lots of fun with this, and would have rated it as an 8.

But I overplayed it (lots of people only wanted to play this game...) and got quite disappointed at the ridiculous amounts of expansions.
Now the fun factor has quite gone for me. One of the few games that I'd rather not play anymore but still don't want to give a low rating (due to showing me the Euro-way)

I'm really not interested in playing this anymore (so I should rate it an  3) unless it's with the Citizens & Knights expansion. But after Puerto Rico, I rarely played that one either...

I have played this so much I am “over” it but it deserves its credit. If someone has never played it, I would continue its use as a gateway.

RATING: 7
Definitely a solid game with well-balanced mechanics.  This game seems to work well both with new and experienced players, as everyone feels like they have a chance to win up until the end.  I still worry that the starting placement has too much of an impact on the rest of the game, but so far, I've not experienced any session where that's obviously been the case.  This one hit the table a lot in our group at first, especially when we're trying to push new players toward non-party games, but it has fallen out of favor lately due to a large influx of great new games.

RATING: 6
A lot of my friends love this game, and I can have a good time playing it, but it is certainly not a favorite.  Zero decisions available without having resources to spend and resource distribution is completely probability-based.  Every game I've played has resulted in notable frustration by at least 1 or 2 players who are resource-starved and therefore unable to participate.  Certainly not the sign of a good "gateway" game.  Components are great and I'd rather play this than some other games, but I only really keep it in my collection because others enjoy it.

RATING: 6
Players: 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
Best: 4
Expansions: 5-6 Players

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This is the game that introduced me to modern board gaming.  I have played this game many times over the past 20 years and it has special place in my heart for that reason. The game itself however is broken.  
Very high on luck with dice rolls, I try to mitigate this with getting a variety of numbers, but that does not always work. I have spent 5-6 turns in a row passing because all that was rolled were 4s 3s 11s and 7s and even with a lot of number options, get no resources.
Very easy to block a player with huge impact. If one player lucks out with numbers and blocks your road with one of his and beats you to a spot on the board, very early on you can tell that you have already lost.  The next 1.5 hours you go through the motions of playing for someone else to win.
Many flaws, I will likely not play this many more times in the future if I can help it.

This one gets a slight ratings increase because it is the best game to introduce to non-gamers and get them hooked on this lifelong hobby!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Game in a Nutshell: Players compete to settle and secure the best spots on a modular island. Roll dice to collect goods, trade with other players and spend to expand.

Played as: 3,4 player

Played with: Seafarers, Cities and Knights, 5-6 Player Expansion, and Plain

Pros: Good mix of luck, area control, player interaction and replayability make for an excellent, addictive game. Serves as an excellent gateway because of enough familiar mechanics combined with some fresh innovative ideas. 

Cons: It can be luck driven for players of equal experience. It's not unusual to see a person who benefits from some lucky roles early on have a sizable advantage as the game progresses.

Other: If you're reading this and haven't yet played it yourself, do yourself a favor and change that. It got me hooked to euros and more then a few people have gone out and bought it after just one game of me introducing it to them. However, having played this so much, I'd almost prefer playing any other game over this one given the choice. That still doesn't stop me from giving it big props for what this game has meant to the gaming community at large.

Best Use: One of the first gateway games people should be thinking of introducing the 'is it like monopoly?' crowd to.

RATING: 9
The game that started it all. You have to approach this with the right attitude. 1) Never complain if your numbers don't come up, but work with what you do get. 2) Lower your trading standards for new players or people who are clearly losing. 3) Don't be in first place. Go for second and then win suddenly!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I don't mind luck in games. I do mind luck/randomness in games if it solely determines if I can do anything at all during the game. Settlers unfortunately is such a game. The one and only mechanic that decides what resources you get during a turn, if any at all, is throwing dice. If the dice roll badly, you will get nothing during your turn. That is not just a bit of bad luck which can be mitigated through proper risk management - that is putting you out of the game for the turn, while other more fortunate players run away with the win.
This also results in a huge runaway leader problem, because whoever is the most lucky in the beginning of the game cannot be reeled in, as he will be the first to build all his stuff, get more resources, and further capitalize on his initial string of luck. Catch-up does not happen in Settlers.
Other than this, Settlers could have been quite a nice game with all its then-innovative elements. However, if the game decides whether or not I get to do anything on my turn, I'll pass. It's no better than a roll-and-move mechanic were certain locations you end up say "skip your next turn".

Finally, Settlers has been caught up by time - newer releases do what Settlers is trying to do much better anyway, so why bother? If somebody suggests playing this I will reluctantly accept if and only if nobody wants to play one of my suggestions instead. Fortunately I usually succeed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
We don't play it as often as we used to, but we've had many fun games of Settlers.  If it had a decent 2-player game, we would likely have played it a lot more.  The tile-constructed board, and differing scarcity of resources makes each game different, and gives the game enduring appeal.  The game naturally encourages players to target the leader, which gives some people the grumps, but also produces close finishes with most people "in the hunt" until the end.  Still a very enjoyable game, that often earns a place if we have a weekend away.

If I'd started logging plays 5 years earlier, this would probably have another 30 plays against it.

RATING: 9
CLASSIC

Two sheep for 1 wheat?

Brian (BBD): "When you all play Catan do you say things like, 'Hey, we should play a game of Catan!' when you ask people to play? Or do you say things like 'A large natural disaster has destroyed an entire island nation and reformed it with a completely different setup of natural landmarks. 4 hardy adventurers are needed to bring civilization to this untamed land. Much danger lies ahead, but this task is essential to bring balance. Do you have the guts to be one of those 4 chosen?'"

 "Also I will kick all yall asses in Catan. I swear on my confederate pride and the grave of Robert E. Lee. When my longest road cuts off your attempt to get to that sheep port, remember the South Will Rise Again."

BBD: "There is boring Catan and then there is "Real World: Catan" where danger lies ahead and the stakes are high"
Robin: "Probably the former, but should I be invited to a game of Catan with the latter, I will surely accept."


Me: "We never talk anymore, Twin."
Drunk Seth: "Yes we do! We talk all the time! I'm always asking you if you want to trade 2 grain for a wheat!"

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
02/08/2013: This game has been around a while and seems to have brought a lot of people into the hobby.  I started with Carcassonne but soon picked this up because of the sheer amount of "press" it gets around here...good and bad.  I think a lot of negativity has arose just because so many gamers have played it too much.

I think it's a very solid game that can have stretches of poor luck thrust upon you from the dice rolls.  Players are trying to build roads, settlements, and cities on the island of Catan, earning VP along the way.  The first to 10 VP is the winner.  Two things come to mind when I think of Catan - trading and those dice.  You collect resources based on the number rolled with the dice.  Usually, you'll get something, but there can be seemingly endless stretches where you get diddly.  One thing we just tried out was too use some coins (from the Settlers of America game) when someone receives zero resources on any turn.  They can then trade in two coins for any one resource.  That really helped a lot with the flow of the game and randomness of the dice.  However, it did seem to affect the other main mechanism of the game.

Trading is a big part of this game.  You must be willing to trade with any and all players throughout most of the game.  Someone is always needing resources and if you can find a trade that will help both players, you'll be successful.  However, when we played with the coins, that did seem to stymie the trading just a bit.  If you're asking for an Ore and you've got two or more coins in front of you, that made the other players hesitate regarding the trade.

Anyway, I'm really going on too long about this stuff.  The game is very good.  Very fun.  It runs a little long with my family though.  Our last play (with coins) was a solid hour and a half...and that was quick for us.  The components looks nice and are mostly good.  However, right from the get go, the framing tiles (the water) that goes around the main island were warped and unusable.  That wasn't a big deal; just set up the island and use the harbor tiles instead.  But when we played recently, I noticed that several of the tiles are staring to warp as well.  That's not cool.  I store my games in my bedroom closet so there shouldn't be an issue with "weather conditions."  And considering we've only played this half a dozen times, the game should be in pristine condition.  I'm a little upset about that.  Otherwise, the cards and dice, and wooden pieces are all standard, good quality.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I think this is a fun game.  The only problem is that people who have played it have often played it to death.  People that have not played it look at all of the tiles and pieces and assume it is too complicated.  I feel there are other games that provide a better gaming experience.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Finally got to play this classic, Prototype of the eurogames, and all the other honorifics it is known for... and having done so, I can say understand both sides: those who praise it, and those who praised it but now claim it's done.

It is simple enough that it can be called a gateway game and yet I can see why so many say it has durability. It is a cute resourse gathering and trading game; however it is soooo far from perfect. Its greatness comes from what it's done for boardgaming, but evaluating as it is now (and that's how it should be done), it's nowhere near a 10 or a 9. 

It does play fast, I don't see any serious issues with scalation and it can play from 3 to 6 (although you need the expansion, or you're stuck with 4), nice art and components, set up is no big deal... but the resourse gathering...

It is both why it can be a gateway game, and the reason a good deal of gamers (especially eurogamers) might have a problem: depends on dice roling. You can play the odds and search for the most likely numbers to come up during the placing of your cities at the beginning, but is still luck and you can have a hard time if it's not your day. 

In theory, the trading aspect it's there to make up for that, but if you're playing with people really trying to win (and while I understand not being a S.O.B. is good, I don't think I could blame someone for trying to win), they can really twist your arm in those trades, so you can probably get that much needed wood or brick, but at such a cost, you might as well not have.

It is fun and I want to play more, but in general, if I'm going to play an euro, I'd rather play those where your resources don't depend solely on rolling dice, but on strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2.37
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
I only occasionally suggest to play this, but I will always say yes to an offer to play it and enjoy it. So definitely between a 7 and 8 on the scale, leaning towards the 8 end.  It's not a brain burner, but it does require both light strategy and light tactics.  Negotiation/wheedling skill can be a large factor, but I haven't ever seen the game totally thrown by one player being particularly good at cajoling others.  This luck factor in this game tends to be blown out of proportion rather frequently here at the BGG.  Yes there are dice rolls involved, but the game gives you plenty of opportunities to mitigate the effect on you, if you wind up far behind and out of the game once then it may have been die rolls.  Twice in a row, then it probably is a bad strategy not a 'luck' issue.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Eh. It's a good game, but it also really irritates me. I dislike having to discard my hand when the thief is drawn, as it penalizes the main strategy of getting around another major flaw in the game: The dice rolls for resources. The game ends up boiling down to a competition for the resources that are statistically most likely to come up the most, and the harbors to offload them, which makes turn order way too important. 

Upgrading towns to cities doesn't seem worth the effort compared to building roads and development cards. The longest road and largest army will outright win the game for you. It's also too easy for players to get boxed in and screwed, or simply unlucky in their dice rolls. While there's a lot of good social interaction and strategy therein, other parts of the game seem determined to turn it into monopoly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This is a funny kind of game after you play a lot of it. Most of the decisions during the game are pretty obvious. You build what you can, you trade to build what you almost can. The initial placement seems to be the game. It's pretty interesting and usually decides the game. The rest of the game plays out pretty automatically and is just there to resolve who played the best in the placement phase. Still, I like it.

RATING: 7
[size=10][u][i][b]r{Initial Thoughts}r (after 5 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* A granddaddy of the Eurogame movement
* Initial placement of settlements seems to dictate final results
* Primacy of trading makes for distinctly different experiences based on gamer styles
* Expansion is the key (or, put differently, grow stagnant and die)
* Good for wresting gamers away from [b][GameID=1406][/b]
* Initial rating: [b]7/10[/b]

RATING: 2
Finally got to play it. It is a bit longer than I had expected, but it is enjoyable the first time. Okay for four players. After a second play, I had to downgrade the rating. It is possible for someone to spend the entire game doing nothing if the dice rolls are unfavorable. That nearly happened to me. It's one thing to have an element of chance or randomness, but to make someone sidelined for hours, that's not fun at all. It gets a "2" rating (rather than a 1), because I did enjoy it the FIRST time I played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First German-style board game I ever played.  I enjoy the mix of luck (die rolling to determine which resources are produced), strategy (where to put cities, where to build roads, what to build), and player interaction (trading resources).  The heavy reliance on luck for production is the primary downside; this isn't as intense as Puerto Rico or Louis XIV.

[Update: While I still enjoy playing this with new players (it's a great introductory game), it's a bit too luck-based for my current tastes.]

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A light gateway game and deserves its place in history. Little to no skill in the game. The game is heavily decided by luck. When you fall behind there is no mechanism to catch back up. You often have lost after initial city placement even if you don't realize it. Trading is lackluster - don't trade with the leader(s) and the leader usually is far enough ahead not to need to trade with the 2nd place player. Area control with roads is interesting but usually not possible for most players (at least 1 player always starts without wood and brick). This game would be more interesting with more resources to use, more strategic decisions about how to use those resources (rather than just playing as soon as possible), a larger board allowing for more area control, revamped trading rules to encourage trading, and a catch-up mechanism for the last place player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I probably won't play it more than once a year and probably only when asked, but I still find it to be a fun game. This will probably never leave my collection.

The interaction is fun, and is both light enough to attract casuals, and heavy enough to keep others interested. As my collection grows, I still don't mind breaking this out every now and then.

The only bummer is the luck factor which does consume a big part of the game. Hopefully an expansion can fix this. It is a really fun family game and I'd recommend it to anyone.

RATING: 10
Considered by many as one of the premiere “gateway” games, this is the title that got me into the much broader and deeper world of board games so, it holds a special place in my heart. Players are settling the world of Catan by trading resources and building settlements, cities and roads to be the first player to achieve the number of points needed to win the game. Easy, elegant, quick to pick up and explain and, of course, fun to play!  Trading and strategically placing key roads and buildings are well balanced. A must for any game household!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Collect and trade resources to be the first to expand your settlement to 10 points.

Plays: More than a dozen?
Type: VP engine = a game where you build an engine to collect victory points most efficiently.
Complexity: Family game = a game that is easy to teach and play.
# of players: 4.
Playing time: 90 mins.
Player interaction: Trading. Competition for scarce resources - settlement locations. Targeting - placing the robber.
Randomness: Medium - dice, but you can prepare for rolls to some extent.

Replayability: Medium. This is always a good experience and most people are fine to play again, but maybe not right away? There is some depth to explore.
Fun: Good fun. Trading makes it highly interactive. It's fun when your numbers come up, less fun when they don't.
Memorabiity: Not so high, it's still a VP engine that doesn't create stories.

Thematic integration: Weak.
Components: Nice.

Who will like this: Family gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
I changed my January 2011 rating of 7.9 down to 6.75 on 5/4/16, to reflect what I have been telling people for years - this is an excellent "gateway drug" game for getting people into the board gaming hobby, but it just isn't that much fun to me any longer.

A combination of expansionism and rolling dice, with a rudimentary card system on the side, this game is lean and mean.  Expand your abstract cities and roads based on the accrual of 4 resources; and do so in a way that makes life harder for the other folks on the board.  Many fundamental Euro game principles at play here, and thus many prospective gamers find it to be delightful. 

(Written 5/4/16)

RATING: 1

'Five' times to date. Pretty much every time they release a new expansion. *ssholes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In boardgaming culture, the term 'Gateway Game' applies to any game that reintroduces players to the hobby. These games generally have more strategic depth and interesting decision making than 'classic' board games.

Catan was my gateway game. I played the hell out of Catan when I first got it. I kept it in my car for quick access, I played it so often. It is an excellent game, with many exciting opportunities for player interactions.

Now that I have more experience with the hobby, there are a few aspects of Catan that bug me. I'm not a big fan of the dice-rolling aspect, but the game does a good job of keeping the playing field level. In a lot of games, one player can end up far ahead of the other players, though this situation doesn't come up too often. These criticisms aren't very big, but they are worth mentioning nonetheless.

Overall, Catan is an excellent game, and I would happily play it at any time.

Sidenote: Never make a 3 for 1 trade.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Better offerings include Attika, Anno 1503 & Magna Grecia for that "colony" feeling - with less luck, more strategy.

Ugh...never again.  Drags on WAY too long at times.  Rating down to 2 from 5.

RATING: 5
A good introduction to 'real' board games for most inexperienced gamers, however leaves me feeling bored about two turns after choosing the initial set up.  Mostly just luck-based stats after that.

Personally, I think the game is much too long for what it is.  Most meaningful choices in it are made before the game's start, then the rest of the game is just letting the winner pull slowly ahead of all the players enough to assure them that they were indeed the winner.

RATING: 5.5
Közel 20 évvel a megjelenését követően játszottam vele először, a pontszám ezt is tükrözi. Lehet, hogy a kilencvenes évek végén még bejött volna.

Android appja van csak meg, a dobozos táblást nem vállaltam be, mert ahhoz elég gyengécske szegény, hogy még a helyet is foglalja (az appot meg egy bundle akcióban vettem, kb egy gombóc fagyi áráért). Először a táblással játszottam, aztán adva neki egy újabb esélyt, megnéztem az appot is. Kár volt.

Maga a játék nem lenne rossz, ha nincs az a rettenetesen idegesítő dobókockás mechanizmus a termelésre, ami miatt körökig várnod kell, hogy megkapd az utolsó fádat az építkezéshez, mert senki sem hajlandó cserélni veled.

Szóval a mechanika így 20 évvel a kiadását követően már elég köhögős, és dühítő is olykor, tényleg csak megszállottaknak, dobókocka fetisisztáknak és azoknak ajánlom, akik még csak a Ki nevet a végén? - Gazdálkodj okosan! játékokig jutottak el a társasjátékok izgalmas világában.

A többiek ezt nyugodtan ki is hagyhatják...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It's not a perfect game, it's theme doesn't exactly match the mechanics and it does have that random element that probably drives some people nuts, but judging by the amount of time spent on the table it's still our gaming group's favorite game.  

I have bought the Seafarers expansion and played a game of that, but I personally prefer the original.  Settlers is an "island" generated by laying hexes of various resources (+ one desert), and then surrounding it by sea hexes.  Numbers (reflecting die rolls, which also includes probabilities in a simple dot system) are placed on each of resources, and the black piece -called The Robber- is placed in the desert.  The mechanic of placing settlements over corners of hexes and then a road segment adjacent to it seems at first blush to favor the player who places two settlements in a row, but that is not the case as smart roadbuilding and sticking to a sound strategy will win out in general.

The rolling of the dice to get resources makes a statistician want to play the resources with the best chance of coming up (6 and 8, because 7 moves the Robber), but if those resources are mainly wood and brick, then in the late game that doesn't help you very much.  You have to balance out the early game (building roads and settlements) with the late game (cities, soldier cards, and development cards).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Settlers was my first Euro game, the game that taught me how to say "Game of the Year" in German (even if I can't spell it), the first modular board game I ever played, and really my bridge game from role playing to board games.  I never knew games like Settlers existed until GenCon in 1997.  I played it a ton (many, many times before I started logging plays on BGG), and taught it to so many friends that I got sick of teaching the rules.  Even though it rarely sees the table these days, I still put it in my own personal Hall of Fame, and therefore rate it a 10.

RATING: 8
A fun game. I bought it to avoid playing with a person I don't like, and it gives my roommates and I something to do together.

I've played this several times with 2 players and with 2+ players (with the 5-6 player expansion). I have to say that 5/6 players can get a bit crowded, but often is the most fun. Playing with two is a bit slow, but the games are always really close.

However, the luck with rolling the dice can be frustrating, and the trading aspect often leaves my friends cranky at the table.

Still, a good game over all.

RATING: 7
Q
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
+1.5 strategy outweighs rule-book (Beginners seem to take to this game wonderfully)
+1 'Engine building' aspects are enjoyable
+1 good balance of "just doing my thing over here" and "take that!" mechanics which appeal to a broad range of players
+1 trading mechanic adds a whole layer of depth and strategy. 
+1 apparently very replayable (been a staple of a couple of my groups for years) which brings its rating up since I first owned it

-1 (up from .5 - more I play, the more playtime seems to lag) not the lightest game, with a little setup and a few minutes teaching time and an hour or  so to play
-1 players who make bad decisions early on can be left with little to do for almost an entire game. Predefined placements and pips for statistical likelihood help. 
-1 For whatever reason, this game seems to lead to more saltiness and hurt feelings than other games. Possibly the bluntness of the mechanics, possibly the fact that 'entirely do my own thing' is only an option for so long/if at all. 

A classic for a reason. May lose points over the years, but hasn't as of yet. Still the first boxed game I show new players.

Egyik játszópajtimnak van meg egy pár kiegészítővel együtt. Már rágtam a fülét egy ideje, hogy hozza már el egyszer! Aztán legutóbb nála játszottunk, úgyhogy nem volt kibúvó.
Remek játék, baromira élveztem!! Rendkívül egyszerű szabályok (csak az alappal játszottunk), nincs min sokat gondolkodni, és bevon a játék minden másik játékos körébe is. Az üzletelgetést minden játékban élvezem, itt is jókat mulattunk rajta; ami talán kicsit zavaró lehet, az a kocka, bár ezt most nem éreztem (most szerencsém volt, és jól jött ki nekem). Igazából némi izgalmat hoz, hogy várjak e még, vagy cseréljek...
Egy szó mint száz, nagyon klassz! Legközelebb bedobunk egy pár kiegészítőt is!

RATING: 7.5
"Die Siedler von Catan" - quasi der Urvater des modernen Eurogames und das Spiel, was Brettspielen salonfähigk gemacht hat. Es ist auch heute noch ein tolles Spiel und kann sich gegen moderne Vertreter durchaus behaupten. Und wer diesen Klassiker noch nie gespielt hat, sollte das unbedingt nachholen.Viele Mechaniken, die heute fast schon "Standard" sind, wurden hier eingeführt. Der Eine oder Andere wird sich eventuell am hohen Glücksfaktor (Würfelwurf = Ressourcenvergabe) stören, trotzdem wird "Siedler" ein Spiel sein, was man auch in 10 oder 20 Jahren noch auf den Tisch bringen wird.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
What on earth did the designers do to get you all rating this game so highly? Did they come round to each of your houses with a ham, tell you you're beautiful and touch you on the leg?!

This game is a lesson in self flagellation. Rolling dice and waiting for your number to come up so you can actually do something whilst your opponents get resources from rolling double 1 9 times in a row and shoot to victory is boring and not fun - a bad combo for any game.

Yeah so there's some strategy with road/settlement placement and trading, but that is also SO dependant on you having resources from those dice rolls that there's very little to do but watch if you haven't received what you need.

There clearly lies its mainstream popularity; anyone can win this game regardless of experience or skill, as at the end of the day its just down to dice.

Maybe the reason it slammed me so hard is because I expected it to be deeper with more strategic depth- this is really just a dice game disguised as a Euro.

RATING: 6
I don't really like Catan after playing it for the 10th time. You finally realize that if you don't place your first two settlements correctly then you are completely screwed throughout the game. This is not a game for people who are sore losers or can't handle watching those around them reap the rewards of the dice while you get screwed. Trading adds more social awkwardness. I think Catan is ONLY a good game with the expansions involved.

RATING: 9
Good game to play with family or group of boardgames and non-boardgamers. Random luck enough of a factor to allow newbies a chance to win with experienced players.  I  found game less enjoyable with expansions  and,  worse,  I lost the non-gamers who might have enjoyed it before  I  treasure the elegant simplicity of the base game. 

Good negotiations aspect and some small bit of take that. As someone who grew up on diplomacy int 1970's, I would never introduce that to your players myself, because it can bring out the worst in people.  This game is far better in teaching a skill set to young players without teaching them the bad aspects of a game like diplomacy. 

A hall of fame level game. A fixture in my top 10 and the  second oldest game deign among my top 10.

RATING: 3
I never understood what the big deal was.  It's just really boring.

I'd much rather be blowing up giant robots or something.

"I just got this new game today, it's supposed to be awesome! Let's play it."
"Sure! What's it all about?"
"Well, you play these settlers? on, like, an island? And you get this stuff to build roads."
"Yeah...? And then what happens?"
"Well... That's about it... I think... No, wait! you can trade the stuff with other people. And you can make your little house thingies bigger."
"Uh... Do you have to, like, fight off the other players or natives or something?"
"Umm... No. But there is a thief! He can really mess you up, I guess."
"That's cool.. So you track down the thief and kick his ass or something?"
"Hmm... No. He just sort of roams around and prevents you from doing stuff. But you can't really do anything to him."
"So, what you're telling me is that this is a game where we get wood and bricks on little cards in order to build roads and the only interaction is asking someone if they want to trade some boring shit with each other in order to... build some more roads...? And there's a thief but not really since it's just a random mechanic to screw people over. Right? You're telling me that this is a game about building a road?"
"Yeah... Pretty much..."

......
......

"You up for some Heavy Gear?"
"Awesome!"

RATING: 7
I like the game mechanics of SoC, especially the trading and the development cards. I can't help but feel that the first half of the game is mostly just sitting around waiting for good dice rolls to occur. And then the last third is about players wondering how to advance while avoiding helping the leader. I must try Catan with a dice deck (easily made from two decks of ordinary playing cards) to see if it plays better. Many people call Catan a good "gateway" game I think Hollywood Blockbuster or Carcassonne are much more accessible to the uninitiated. It might work better with those who are already on the verge of becoming geeks.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Like:[/b]
-Simplicity for what it achieves
-Trading
-Building stuff and receiving more stuff for it
-Many people know this game

[b]Dislike:[/b]
-Robber
-Having multiple turns without anything to do because your numbers didn't get rolled

The game I played the most before I really got into board gaming. I mean, what other game lets you build towns and cities, and gain increasingly more resources when you do so while also allowing you to negotiate with others; am i r8?! No wonder I considered this a masterpiece at the time.

If Dead of Winter has the meanest dice of all time, Catan probably has the meanest gaming piece of all time: the Robber. This little sh*t used to make the people I played with literally cry. Luckily, we all kinda realised this and only put it in someones place if that guy was far ahead.

Also, going through multiple rounds without getting anything just sucks, especially if all the others get huge amounts.

Catan: Cities & Knights is absolutely required for me to enjoy this game though.

While I'd rather play other games now, it still's got the advantage of being the simplest build, receive more and trade game I know of. Be careful not scare the new-lings away from the hobby with the robber though!

RATING: 7
What can I say? It started a trend and deserves every praise it gets. 

Becomes more interesting when played as a match over several games which alleviates the randomness. I love it that you always think you are in control but really are a slave to the dice. Also great is the 'surge from behind' so that you can win (and certainly fight) even when in an apparently hopeless position. 

I would like to see a good two-player variant and an official 'scoring' for 2nd (3rd) place to alleviate kingmaker problems.

Well worth the money then.

RATING: 8.8
What else can be said about this game that has not been said already?  No wonder why it was game of the year in 1995. You collect resources (wool, lumber, brick,ore, and wheat) to trade them in to build things, namely roads, settlements or cities.  You get points for the builings, first to 10 wins.  I'm looking forward to acquiring seafears and knights and cities.
It's become one of our groups favorites.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Luck-fest in a box. Nothing happens for you if the dice says NO.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A good solid game. I'm probably the 15th million person to say it... but it definitely is a very good "gateway" style game. There is the good old VP chase common to hundreds of other Euro games but there's also multiple paths to victory, trading, frustration and elation in the dice rolls, road/city building and a variable modular board which makes for a slightly different game each time. All in all a very good game... not quite great because it's still a bit too easy to be hosed by the dice no matter how hard you try to trade and negotiate your way out of the hole you are in when that damn robber is sitting on your production hex.

Above everything else this game produces fun sessions with a lot of chatter and banter. Lot's of "Why are you picking on me?" and "Move the robber there to stop him from getting the sheep he needs" type of conversations. Just for the level of interaction the game provides its worthy of its status as a good solid family game that can be played for fun without much concern who wins or loses.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Play it. Now! :o)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I will start by saying that I have played this game more than all the other games in my collection together, times 10.

The reason that I love this game is because it is the game that got me into gaming.  I think that I probably wouldn't play the games that I do today if it weren't for Catan.

However, I have never played a game that causes more division in friendships than Catan.  I have left the game table frustrated more times than I can count when I play Catan.  By nature in this game, every action that you take to progress yourself inhibits another player from winning.

Overall I rank this game a 6 because it is easy to understand, I played it frequently in my early years, but it is incredibly difficult to play without becoming incredibly competitive and frustrated.

RATING: 7
This game is perfect for a game night: simple to learn, little waiting times between player turns and finished quickly. For individual games it may be difficult to come back from a bad start but there is always time for a re-match. During a memorable vacation with friends, I lost the first seven games but came back and won three in a row. 

Pros: Simple rules, all players participate to the end, short game sessions
Cons: Chance important for outcome, difficult to get back from bad start

RATING: 8
Fun game with 3 players or 4.  Ideal moves evaporate quickly, and you are left with making the best of what's available.  Good trade off of benefiting yourself vs. messing with another player.  Can suffer from pick on the leader though, so if you don't like that, then be forewarned.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Classic Euro-game that proves to be both easy to learn, strategic enough to remain popular in my gaming group, and with dice rolls and tile placement, it feels new each game!!

update: As with most board gamers, Catan reaches it's limits soon enough.  My main issue with Catan stems from the resource collection. Often times it takes several turns for a player to get any resources.  This prevents them from playing or trading.  This can sometimes be negated by better starting placement of buildings, but the roll of the dice plays such a big part that often times the best placement yields poor results.  Possibly some house rules could be instituted or the a better expansion, such as Pirates and Traders.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I first played at Gen Con when I was substantially younger.

I like that you have to pay attention during other turns, and that it's not a hurry up and wait mechanic.  I like the balance of the different construction options, and the different ways to score points.  However, I've always won the same way- build the longest road, use it to spread out your villages and harness needed resources ports, and once you're out of villages and have your empire in the right position, build it up to cities.  The only exceptions are when you need a city for more wood or brick to build more roads or villages.

I don't like the kingmaker aspect, and that poor strategic decisions by losing players can hand victories to other players (When 'don't give him a brick, that's all he needs to win' is ignored).  I've benefited from this before, but I don't know that deceit belongs here.  

 Maybe next time I play I'll gun for 'largest army' and VP cards, even though I've never seen it work.

RATING: 3
Luck is a fine element in games, but the luck in this game can left you with nothing to do for several rounds and made you feel hopeless. Negotiation is another 'random' thing as it drags the game and whether to trade or not can be something not rationalized for certain players. It's still a good gateway for new boardgamers to understand certain boardgame concepts to facilitate teaching of more difficult games, but I can't really see the point of going back to Settlers once they've learned 'better' games.

RATING: 7.8
A trading game that is very fun to play, the robber can be a bit dull, but after reading online a good variant may be to not take a card from someone else when rolling a 7, but perhaps get to take a card that you would like from the bank.

That rule alone takes out exactly what is problematic with the game and the back-stabby nature of that rule. Otherwise, the game is fun, not too long, but also it is something that can be played with anyone as it's easy to explain.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As is the case for many, Catan was my first modern board game, and I loved it. I still do, even if playing it often leaves me a bit on the frustrated side. For the most part a very well designed game, the only complaint I have about Settlers is the pronounced role of luck, given that your ability to carry out any strategy is largely contingent on rolls of the dice. You can position yourself in theoretically the perfect position, but if you don't get the dice rolls, you don't get the goods. Within the scope of my experience, it is unusual for a game to seem to require so much strategy while having that strategy contingent on so very much good fortune.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

Even if you play with a standard initial placement (booooooooriiiiiiiiiiiiing) you are screwed if the other players leave you out of the negotiations.

A 6 only for how often it hits the table.

RATING: 6
My first real game away from Risk and Axis and Allies.  This was a classic in our game group for months until we moved onwards and upwards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have been on a bit of a rollercoaster ride with Settlers.  Like many others, this was the first Euro-style board game that I played, and it opened my eyes to a whole new way to game and a whole new type of game to play.  For that alone, it holds a special place in my heart.  I played this game almost exclusively for a year or more, and then became burned out on it.  There was a point when I didn't want to play it anymore.  But now that I play it with much more moderation, my opinion of it has increased again.  It has some great strategic decisions when it comes to placing your initial pieces, and the player interaction and replayability are fantastic.

You are certainly at the mercy of the dice in this game, and it is also possible that a player who is not winning can suffer when the other players jump on the leader, merely by sharing a space or two with the leader.  The game is not perfect, and sometimes a particular session just falls flat.  But the fact is that this is a great gateway game with a lot of strategy and a good dose of fun.  In reasonable amounts, it is quite enjoyable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
When it was made, Catan was a groundbreaking, interesting, beautiful, and unique game. There are some parts of the game I appreciate. I like the artwork, the trading, the cover and the font. However, I almost never enjoy playing this game. Catan is a grueling game that just makes people frustrated and angry at one another. In addition, the game is largely decided on starting position and dice rolls. I also feel as though there aren't many strategic in-game decisions. You mostly just build what you can given the resources you were lucky enough to get. The game is not deeply strategic at all. Once you know how to play this game (having played at least 5 times), your not at a big disadvantage to someone who considers them self a Catan master. And that wouldn't bother me except that so many people think that this game is so deeply strategic. Another aspect that frustrates me is depending on the board, sometimes you are screwed from the very start of the game, which then makes it hard to put on a happy face and finish. I will say this game is very satisfying to win, because of all the built up emotions throughout the game. "Oh c'mon I've been screwed by the robber all game!", "that's a horrible trade, you realize she is going to win the game now!", "Wow, you've gotten so lucky with those 10s, I wonder if we are ever going to roll a fricken 5!" . Klaus is an evil genius. No matter how frustrating this game is, he got people addicted to playing it even if it risks the health of important friendships. No matter how much Catan frustrates me, I can't hate this game, because this is the board game that got me in to board games, and for that I am forever thankful. And this game has paved the way for all the awesome new games we see today.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Also - if you get "trapped" and can't expand, the game gets boring as you're completely deprived of possibilities to do anything at all. 

It's a good game (along with Carcassonne and Ticket to ride) to introduce new people to boardgames, before moving on to heavier games - but that's about it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
[b]Settlers of Catan[/b] - Slovenian Edition (3rd 2007)

2-4 players (5-6 with expansion)

Has seen countless plays. Great game. I suppose my opinion might not last forever, its sheen may dull, but when? If one plays too often? It has been fun on a consistent basis, and am almost always willing to play it, which I cannot say for all games.

[b]The Pros[/b]
-lots of player interaction due to negotiation/diplomacy/trading 
-usually little down time (use a timer when playing with slow players!)
-opponents' plans can be disrupted in various ways
-multiple paths to victory
-multiple game variants (expansions)
-modular board =every game will be different
-very easy to learn
-not an overlong game, allowing 2 or more games to be played in one game night evening

[b]The Cons[/b]
Some might complain about the usage of dice. If dice are not your thing, you could use a [url=https://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgameexpansion/20038/catan-event-cards]dice deck[/url] to replace them. It is included within the event cards in [thing=27760][/thing].

However, I think luck usually doesn't play a major role. The "randomness" of the dice roll doesn't automatically mean luck rules this particular game.

For one, the usage of two dice lessens the randomness, making some number totals more statistically probable than other totals (ex. totals of six are much more probable than totals of two, because there are more possible combinations of the dice rolls. Whereas 3 and 3, 1 and 5, 4 and 2 all equal 6, only 1 and 1 equal 2). See: http://wizardofodds.com/gambling/dice/

As you gain experience, you learn to avoid building on those provinces, which will statistically provide less resources. A frequent mistake committed by novices. And if the best provinces have already been taken during the initial setup, an experienced player knows how to use the sea ports to his advantage (exchanging resources 2:1 or 3:1).

Even if one player does indeed have more luck with the dice, and beats the statistic probability overwhelmingly, this usually tends to balance itself out: 1) with the other players creating alliances against him, 2) with the brilliant Robber mechanism, which steals from those too rich with resources, 3) the clever usage of sea ports, and 4) trading with your allies as much as possible. The key is to make those trades, which benefit you more than your opponent.

A degree of randomness challenges one's ability in adapting to changing circumstances. Real life is all about this. But for those who do not like it, there are always the dice cards mentioned above.

Whereas strategy is the overall plan, tactics are the actual means used to gain an objective. This game has both. But of course this is not one of the heavy, deep or complex games, which I do like as well.

Interesting thoughts on board game design:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/822865/means-production-and-how-games-innovate

For Catan fans:
http://www.wsj.com/articles/the-packers-of-catan-green-bays-board-game-obsession-1421346102
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ag1V5XkwfUc

[IMG]https://cf.geekdo-static.com/mbs/mb_23954_0.png[/IMG]
On the benefits of trade -  Matt Ridley Ted Talk explaining David Ricardo
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iLuAk-F158A
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The one that started it all. If you don't like Catan, we can't be friends. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is one of the most accessible games for new players and it works well: rules are quick and easy to learn while players interact and have a great social time. However, with experience you can sometimes identify early who will win and who has no chance at all (having been blocked or no resource income). This is because the game does suffer from the luck factor; you always have one or two high probability numbers being rolled with extremely low frequency and vice versa. Whoever benefits over this first has a massive advantage. Also I often find my turns boring as the dice dictate what you are going to do most of the time; only ever receive wood and brick? Roads for you! I didn't want a road....! The game can also be overly long with experienced players, as at some point people will not trade, inhibit the current leader from winning and continue a long battle for largest army /longest road. Lastly, depends on the group, but the robber is used as vengeance for some people, for out of game reasons. Very frustrating especially if the person robbed was already coming last. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent. Can't say more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Once you've played this enough, it gets a little boring in my opinion, partially because you have a solid strategy and can win most of the time against less experienced, so you're just going through the motions. Against equally skill opponents, it depends who was targeted more by the robber and who got better rolls.

The dice roles can also affect a bit, and between 2 equal players, the dice will determine the game. Its a decent starting/gateway game I suppose but some level of gaming maturity is needed. Negotiation and trading makes it low/no downtime which I really love, but even so, there's just not enough control/variety for me to rate this higher. TBH, I haven't found a game that does the negotiation/trading so well in tandem while maintaining gameplay, but it must exist somewhere, so I really hope to find something better/more fulfilling than this game (if you know such a game, please tell me!). I also kind of think that the original game should just be 3-6P default and not have to need an expansion. And yes, I do like this at 5/6P counts since its more trading and more dynamic, even if the game stalls a bit more.

Plays: Many, 10+

RATING: 5
"after years of play its appeal is starting to diminish, the dice, the dice, it brings to much randomness even if I love the bargain aspect and the confrontational aspects."

[edit/update]: Played this last week after a couple of years on the shelf. A complete shock. It was terrible, boring, runaway leader, standstills and a stench of randomness. So we played it again - surely it was a better game than this according to the memories. It wasn't. The hobby owes a lot to this game but games have evolved a heck of a lot in 15 years and this game is a reminder of that. Sadly this is one of the worst euro games in my collection. A classic, yes; a good game in 2008, no.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I enjoy this game, but it is rather based on luck. Depending on who (if anyone) the dice favor, you can rack up points quickly, or sit around trying to trade your lone Brick for anything, anything at all. 

I've tried a couple different strategies with Catan and it seems that you can win from just about any position, unless the dice are being brutal. With even semi-decent placement you can usually trade for what you need or just buy Dev cards to improve your hand.

All in all, this is a fun game and a good gateway game.

RATING: 6.2
Rarely hits the table these days, but I'm a fan of this game and am disappointed that it  seems to have fallen out of favor with many. Perhaps in the avalanche of so many spin-offs, variations and spiritual successors people have lost sight of the original game. Or maybe it's a yardstick by which people measure their gamer cred? In any case, this is a great example of how a few simplified, interlocking mechanisms can add up to more than the sum of parts. I do tend to play with the "welfare" variant to speed things up.

RATING: 8
Very good game concept but quality of workmanship is low. Pieces warp quickly even when bagged and played in a low-moisture environment. This makes assembly of the board challenging and frustrating - moreso the more often it is played. Aside from that, Catan uses a relatively simple game mechanic that is easy to pick up on and fun to play. Best played with 4 players in order to maximize the trading/barter features and competition.

RATING: 4
I think the game is OK, but I'm not partial to the swinginess - luck has a huge role. On average, a presumably decent number like 5 or 9 will not be rolled a single time 1 out of 8 or so games. The last game I played, 47% of the rolls were 3, 4, or 6 which heavily favored the ultimate winner. I can definitely tell who the better players are in our group because they _tend_ to win more, but if the dice don't cooperate, well, skill alone doesn't win the game. Too random for my taste.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An excellent multiplayer, social game with a nice balance of skill/luck (i.e. enough depends on skill that you have to plan your strategy well, but luck can kill a great strategy).  For a game that depends less on luck, use a dice/roll deck.  Also, to blance games have the best player/winner go first, with worst/last place playing last.

I have not played expansions, but look forward to trying them.

GAVE TO FAMILY
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
There was a day when I would have giving this game a much higher rating, but that was way back in the early days of my German game collection.  Having played the heck out of this game (and its expansions) I have come to dread both the foolish die roll that determines the fate of all players and the usually painful trade phase that I must suffer through.  I guess I have developed a dislike for trade games, having seen far too many foolish and game-breaking trades in my day.

RATING: 5
I still think it's a classic game and would be happy to play, but the game runs longer than I'd like for the weight of decisions to be made.

Needs to be something played socially, with an emphasis on making trades fun, to be enjoyable now. Cities and Knights is quite interesting, but moves to epic length. Seafarers is longer without the benefit or more interesting choices.

Expansions owned:
* The Cities and Knights of Catan (English third edition) (2000)
* The Seafarers of Catan (Mayfair Third Edition) (1998)
* The Great River (2005)
* The Fishermen of Catan (2005)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[WrenniePennie's copy]
The title that got me back into board gaming, and is very much like comfort food for me. Some of the mechanics that encourage resource hoarding seem antiquated and unbalanced nowadays, and the dice rolling, in hindsight, causes strategic placement and luck to crash rather than flow together, making resource-generating a frustrating affair for some members of the game. However, the random generation of land masses, building, and competitive factor in trading still make this one fun to play. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Head of the revolution.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
22 years. It took 22 years for me to finally get a chance to play this game. Despite its age, The Settlers Of Catan still holds up. Yeah, I could see having too many of the same resource being clumped together during setup cause balance issues, but that is a minor quibble. Trading, points for victory, a minor screw-your-opponent ability, and an innovative dice roll payout mechanics; its no wonder that tSoC took the world by storm and ushered in an era of interest in Euro board gaming.

There are so many versions of tSoC and expansions for the game, but were I ever to buy it, I would probably stick to the vanilla version as 3-4 players is probably the best for game length and a theme change doesn't interest me.

Oh, and despite the official shortening of the game to just 'Catan', I will probably always refer to it by its full title as it evokes memories of the reverence people held for The Settlers Of Catan in the late 90's.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

genious playing concept: building and trading (I only play cities and knights), problem: dice = luck (ever seen the 12 three times in 5 consecutive rounds?)

RATING: 4
I do not understand why this game is so much more appropriate for people to play than Monopoly.  You still are at the mercy of the dice and you can haggle your way into money/VPs.  

If faced with playing Settlers or Monopoly I suppose I would choose Settlers, however I still feel they are not that hugely different. The only reason this game gets more praise is because of the unnecessary hatred towards Monopoly.  I rate this higher because it is new to me and people in my life are less aware of it.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
The very first board game I ever bought! It will always have a special place in my heart, what can I say, I love it! This game is the game that introduced me to euro gaming, to modern board games, and to what I can easily say, one of my favourite hobbies. The gameplay is enjoyable, it has strategy, it has trading (which we actually use), it is extremely easy to learn as well as teach. Not much to say than an excellent choice as a gateway game. The only issue is it's player count. I really can't get this to the table because most of my gaming is done solo or as two players.

Note: This game has been played several times before I started logging plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Not sure if I can go back to base game after Cities & Knights. The unusual mechanism for gathering resources was revolutionary, but the downsides glare (to wit, the SOL/overpower factor if the initial positions are unbalanced; 4p game can last FOREVER if too many settlement/city positions are built 3 vertices apart). Pretty good replay value by comparison to its gateway peer (Carcassonne). 
----
I did go back to the base game for a quickie... it was tolerable because it was shortened to 7 points.

RATING: 7

RATING: 8
The one that started it all. I have played many many games of Settlers and have had a great deal of fun. I can play this with almost anyone and most everyone will get a kick out of the game. If you wanna get people into board games, this is a great place to start. That said, now that I have somewhere over a 100 games played, I can see where others have fault with it. It can go on long easily, many games feel like they have been rigged against you, and after many plays it can feel like going through the motions. It's still one of my favorite games, and I think it's more strategic than it's given credit for, and even if things turn sour early, you can still have a chance to win. Still a big fan.

Edit: I am not dropping the score even though Catan drives me up a bit of a wall now. If I got 100 plays of Catan, then I think it is at least worth an 8.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I was juggling between 8 and 9 for Settlers. Technically, I think the game deserves a 9 for being elegantly simple and always fun to play. I eventually bumped it up to a 9 for the game's uncanny ability to draw non-gamers into the Eurogame genre. I am one of those converts myself.

RATING: 6
Fun to play every now and then.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Vanilla Settlers is a good gateway game. I would recommend it with 3-4 people at most. Some people argue that luck plays too much a role, but I really think that it depends on the group of people you play with. A quiet non-negotiating group will play very differently than one where everyone is offering quick and clear trades. I've played the game for years, and I think that in many ways, although luck plays a role, the skill lies in assembling wins in spite of bad rolls or bad initial placement.  I think the game suffers more from the ability for a player to play kingmaker.

For gamers who desire something more complex, I would recommend playing with the Cities and Knights expansion, which adds more ways to win, while retaining the core mechanics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Update (15.5.2009) : My rating for Catan has shifted between 6-9 during my time on BGG. (Rating of 6 was when I had overplayed). Right now it feels that because of intense gaming experiences (when played with 4 players) it offers every time when you play it, it deserves at _least_ a rating of 9.

RATING: 6
I played all the time online, finally got to play in person.  The game is a bit too much luck based for me (I need luck in a game to really enjoy it, but this game is like 90% luck).

It's fun with the family, but it really feels like anyone can win at any time.  Because the robber can seriously cripple people with a lead (and more times than not the table will roll 7's like crazy and if you were the first one in a large lead, they'll just destroy you and not even realize when others are in the lead).  It's funny, but frustrating when you're on the ugly side of it.

So, fun for the family (so long as no one's a sore loser), but not a gamer's game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What can I say that hasn't already been said?  Fun game, different every time, good player interaction, excellent gateway game for newbies; but very random, and hard to stop an early leader.  

This is the game that got me back into boardgaming, circa 1996, when I started graduate school.  Thus, it has a lot of sentimental value for me.  Probably the game I have played the most in my lifetime, with Cosmic Encounter a close second.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
One of the most influential board games ever, Die Siedler is unfortunately becoming dated - other games have used the nifty ideas that made this such a blast (modular board, all players benefitting from one player's actions, combination of several ways to gain resources with building and negotiating) without incurring the same mistakes (a poor initial layout spells doom no matter how hard you try, winning players getting so much advantage after the start that the last half hour is just waiting for the kill). The replayability of the game can be raised if you add on some of its multiple expansions (choosing which one can be quite fastidious for non-hardcore fans of the game, though).

Overall, Die Siedler is another one of the classics everyone should have played at least once -being as popular as it is, it shouldn't be difficult to find it at a friend's-, but it's actually bigger for its influence than for the game itself.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
I doubt there's a lot I can say about this that hasn't always been said. A classic, a gateway, but still peculiarly requested by fans of the oblique and the obscure. But yet, I really really enjoy it every time it comes out. Classic? Or nostalgia? Who cares - there's a spark here that is close to timeless.

The one major gripe is that an initially poor position could end the game right there and then for you. Being fourth to speak on an unfavourable layout means you'll be playing catch-up all the time.

RATING: 10
The introductory Euro-game for me and the one which has achieved the best penetration amongst my non-gaming friends. Evidence: We hosted a Settlers tourney at our house with 24 players, and none of those people with the exception of myself owns a game invented since 1980.

Settlers has many attractive elements to it. The easy lingo, the constant engagement created by the resource-generation system, and the cute little network that you build are some standout features that are very appreciated by new players.

RATING: 8
Great fun, very well balanced. 

Tactics are important, and the role of luck is minimised as in this game you make your own luck by being aware of probabilities. 

The trading element is good fun, as you bargain with opponents and cut deals.  There are also various ways to go about winning, so you can try different approaches each time - especially as the board is made up differently each game forcing different strategies.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Christmas present 2011
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.71
[2010/01/01] +400 plays before recording

Wow... what can i say, one day in college i went to my friends house and had my first "go" at this game... and it opened the door to everything else. catan is the gateway game to be certain

so i learned this game "in person" the way it was meant to be played... it is soooooo much better that way, but it does take a while to set up... i think that this game is the perfect game to intoduce your friends who arn't board gamers into the genre

the reason "in person" is better is that skill level is leveled out through trading... if 2 novices play with an expert, the novices will team up to give themselves a chance...

as you may be able to tell I've also played online. one day my 2 catan buddies and i were playing catan, and we decided to see if there was and "online" version... WAS THERE EVER... it was cool because we just used the internet version to facilitate our gameplay... everything else stayed the same, but we were able to instantly have a new map and new scenarios... somthing that would take 10+ minutes in person (also there was realtime scoring)

in addition to that, the internet community had the cities and knights expansion built in (1st time seeing that)...which i enjoy FAR more...

so after "discovering" catan online, we all became closet catan players... i would literally play catan for 12 hours straight always playing "just one more game" the difference about playing online is that trading is so less personal, and that it become just another function.... games go extreemly fast, and everyone you play against has a great understanding for the tactics... I developed extreemly good tactics this way, but eventually I overdosed. 


I can still play catan, but now that i understand it so well, it's not as fun for me to play... everything seems too "random"

I highly recomend this game for anyone that hasn't OD'd on it... please play it in person a few time first though, The internet community is BRUTAL for people who are "slow" or inexperienced

RATING: 8
[b]Catan[/b]

[COLOR=#FF0000]UPDATE:[/COLOR]

[i]Unfortunately I haven't had the opportunity to play this again, so I don't have anything new to add. I've decided against getting a copy, I already have too many games to play with my family that are best with four so I'll just have to wait to play again.[/i] 

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]So it took four years in the hobby before I finally got a chance to play Catan and although it now seems to be easily dismissed, I found it to be great fun. I think it would still be a great gateway into the hobby since it feels familiar to games most people have played while also introducing player interaction via trading. Personally TTR would still be my gateway game of choice, but I'll probably pick up a copy of Catan because I think it'll be a hit in my house and with our extended family.[/i]

RATING: 5
I have a love-hate relationship with Catan. The luck element seems poorly placed. When I am spending a great deal of downtime waiting for my turn, only to lack the resources to do anything, I secretly get frustrated. And on the flipside, when things are going well, I often feel guilty that there's almost invariably at least one player at the table in the crappy position I am loathe to be in. It's the fact that the luck element affects the degree of player choice, oftentimes down to passing out a whole turn that seems broken to me. Will likely play it again on the rare occasion, as my copy and all its expansions went to my brother.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Of course I've known about this game for years, but after finally playing it (Feb. 2009), I found it intriguing, even though prior to playing I had a hard time understanding how a game of this sort could be interesting. There is much to think about, it's more competitive (and even a bit more cutthroat) than I imagined, and it's well balanced and can be tense. I'd agree with those who say this game has earned a place on department store shelves next to stuff like "Clue," "Monopoly," and "Sorry." In that regard, I'm happy to see games like "Heroscape" "Axis & Allies" and "Blokus" on such shelves. Too bad other new standards like "Scotland Yard," "Carcassonne" and "Ticket to Ride" aren't also there regularly. [Note: As of 2012 I'm seeing more of these new standards on shelves in stores like Target.] I bought "Settlers of Catan" for a friend and his 14-year-old son: he couldn't figure it out, so I took it back home with me (they live way out of town) and taught myself. Then, when my friend next visited (June 2009), I taught him and he took it back. That's one way to do it! As to whether I might buy my own copy of this, to date (April 2010) I haven't yet, and I'm guessing I won't, simply because there are many other games more interesting to me. But to repeat, this is a seminal game and definitely has its place in the pantheon of outstanding games. Since of my sons got into gaming after going to college and learned how to play "Settlers..." I figured my family would play it so I traded for a copy of the 4th Edition, December 2014.
