=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Good trading and gateway game. Some replay value, but gets boring if you play it too much. I burned out on this when I took it to Australia. I took a bit of a break from this game in 2005/2006 academic year, but since Autumn 06 I got back into it, then burned out again, and doubt I'll be keen to play it again since I realised how high the randomness really is. Also it is slightly too long. The game can get boring if your numbers aren't coming up.

Settlers is best with 4. 3 or 5 means it's too easy to expand, 5-6 is too slow. I think the expansions all make the game worse.

It was my first Euro. I also now realise that there is too much luck - early luck gets compounded, and players can be out of contention after 10 minutes (or 0 minutes if they put their 2 settlements in stupid places). Also it is kind of the same every time - there's only a few ways to get points so you end up doing the same things every game. Or every few games I suppose: you might get longest road one game, and largest army + VP cards the next, but there's not much strategy space to explore. Funny I'm saying this now, when I first played it I was impressed by all those multiple paths to victory.

Another issue I have is that 50% of the skill/important decisions in the game are the setup initial placement. After that the dice tell you what you should be building. The trading phase keeps me engaged because you have to pay attention and negotiate with the other players (that's the best part of the game), the robber and competition for longest road are good aspects.

These days when I see a bunch of Settlers-ers setting up, I like to watch the initial placement and then predict who will win based on resource access. More often than not I am right.

Bought Spring 2004, Sold 2009/10 via BGG
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Settlers of Catan deserves a place in the history books for how many people it has introduced to German-style board games. Personally, though, I'm all played out and would always prefer to play something else.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

And now that my eldest kid has graduated from Catan Junior to this we are playing it at home more often too.

RATING: 7
Bring it to the table if you want to infect friends with the gaming disease. Ticket to Ride can be a fairly quiet affair. So while TTR and other games might be more modern designs, the table talk from settlers makes it the better gateway game for me.

I've played most of the expansions, but the relative simplicity of the original has provided lasting appeal. RATING: 7
Kudos to my gateway game. I wish I knew of and had games like this growing up; now my kids and their kids do/will. This is the game that cut my teeth on quality games designed with various methods of earning  victory points.

I consider this to be the second REAL game I've ever played (second to Can't Stop). Though I rarley pull it out now, I still keep it because it is a very appealing gateway game, full of great art and components; still this game is not the perfect surefire gateway game for all situations.

The 4th Edition rulebook is terrible. Though the glossary is cool, because the emphasis was on the glossary instead of the rules, the rules seems overcomplicated or difficult to find.

RATING: 4

Basically, it's a mediocre game that has a long history. It should probably be semi-retired.

In time I learned how big and incredible the world of gaming is, and I left Catan behind. I rarely ever want to play that anymore. Perhaps because I played it so much, I now tend to avoid it since I really have no more interest in 'figuring this game'. 

Nonetheless, I played it so much as if it was the only game in the world.

RATING: 7
 Settlers started my return into modern boardgaming in 2005. For over a year it was my favourite game. But the more I played it the more annoying the dice were. Finely in 2007 I fed with Settlers up. I remember some games I lost or won only because of luck. Wining was even worse for me. Besides, if you used to play Settlers with the same people all the time you know each reactions enough to make trading very predictable and boring. Event Cards did not help - why should I trade with anybody if I get my resources sooner or later? Now  I play Settlers very occasionaly. I tried even Teuber`s official 2-players variant which is very nice to play baut a bit static.
 If you search for a family game choose rather Carcassonne - shorter, better, very portable, less luck, tactical decisions every turn, short setup, etc.

RATING: 6
Far too much depends on the initial placement of your 2 settlements.  I hear so much about how trading evens out the dice rolls.  But i do not care what you say, the person getting the most favorable dice rolls has a huge advantage that I do not believe trading can overcome.  Others have said this is one of those rare games that on your turn, you can actually help everyone except yourself.  This happens far more often than it should.  I found this game to be repetitive after about 10 plays and I lost interest.  I dunno, maybe I need to try an expansion?  I doubt I ever will though; too many other games on my list.

RATING: 8
The only game where I really approve of the use of dice.  Anyone who's talked to me about board games knows I generally can't stand the amount of randomness using dice introduces to a game, but in this case I feel it's appropriate.  There's no reason to make this mechanic anything more than random, and the bell curve helps influence initial placement.

จะเริ่มเล่นบอร์ดเกม เริ่มที่catanได้เลยครับ สนุกเร้าใจ เครียด เฮฮา มีครบทุกอย่าง

RATING: 8
My first euro-game. I don't think there can be any better introduction to gaming. Over the past few years that I've owned this game I must've played it hundreds of times and it really was the game that started it all.

My friends love playing it and it was great to see how wheeling and dealing our way to success was no longer held to chance or electronically. My immediate family also soon got into it and it's always a good way to have a family evening.

Then I brought it to holiday dinners and Catan was soon being begged for by everyone. It had topped Monopoly and Risk which were two of our classic favorites. 

It was one of the games that helped me forge my gaming group here at school. It's a great introduction into the genre and while lately it hasn't received much play and has lost some of it's luster to newer shinier games Catan will always hold a special place in my heart.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The random elements can detract from the game at times, as once you are behind you tend to stay behind. This can lead to profuse muttering of curses. Still the standard by which I measure any new game. I have probably spent more time playing this (live or on the net) then any other game.

RATING: 6
Uno dei pochi boardgame tedeschi che vendono nei supermercati, e in italiano: gli va quindi reso merito per essere una delle teste di ponte nella diffusione dei german game in Italia. Il gioco ha regole semplicissime, e c'è moltissima interazione tra i giocatori: oltre alla possibilità di sgambetto (col brigante e con la semplice occupazione territoriale) c'è lo scambio di materiali, indispensabile perché all'inizio è difficile essere indipendenti. Il gioco è enormemente influenzato dal fattore-culo (anche se la distribuzione normale dei tiri di dado aiuta chi non si distraeva alle lezioni di statistica), ma rimane godibile e leggero. Da giocare quando si ha fretta - anche se allo scopo ci sono in giro titoli migliori - o per catturare nella spirale dei giochi da tavolo gli amici non praticanti. Nota negativa: nella versione italiana la spiegazione delle regole è demenziale.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Settlers of Catan is the classic eurogame of building settlements and cities on the vertices of a hex map in order to produce resources when the numbers on those hexes are rolled.  Not only do you have to manage the probabilities associated with rolling 2d6, but also the types of resources you receive (which build different things) and the spatial aspect of having to build only next to things you already own.  Trading adds another thing to think about in the game, and can help mitigate the dice luck, but also can create player-enforced balance (no one trades with the leader).  After all these years, Settlers is still a favorite of mine. 

(5+ plays)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the great gateway games.  Always a pleasure to play, despite being overplayed while taking up the hobby.  The trading mechanic is what makes it special. Dime not shown
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game introduced me to Euro gaming and the entire genre. For that, I suppose I owe Klaus Teuber a debt (which I repaid by buying 4-5 expansions, Das Book, and the $400 "chest" version, plus 2 years on online play, and the Xbox version).

Played perhaps more than any game but Chess and Risk, hundreds of times online and on PC as well. I enjoyed this game, for a long time. Frustrated by poor setups, and bad runs of the dice, my solution was to play it more.

12/11/05 - after over 100 plays on MS site, 20-30 on BSW, and 30+ f-t-f, I am tiring of this game. It has it's place, but I wonder about it's affect now on some folks I've introduced it to. Is it better to get them hooked on PR, or PG? or PoF? I am winning 40+% of my online games, but what does this mean? I am clearly losing some games purely to chance, driving me to play more to counter-act this effect. But when I am winning, are others losing because of chance? How many decisions that I make really are decisions at all?

1/08 Dropping to a 6, but with no disrespect.
1/12 Dropping to a 5. Every year new stuff comes out that improves upon Settlers concepts. I do very much thank Klaus T. for designing this game and bringing me back into the hobby.

9/2014: My rating of 5 is simply my current desire to play. It in no way reflects how important this game was to me and my family. It literally brought me back in to hobby gaming, and had a strong hold on me for 10 straight years. Thanks again Klaus.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Willing to play when welcoming newbies to the room. Need to engage in active trading to appreciate this game. Need to play this several times in order to make productive trades. If I'm going to play something several times, I'd prefer another game. 
Overall, a decent gateway, and still a clever use of dice. There's a potential for disaster if some of the players have no grasp of the distribution of 2d6. 
EDIT: Thoughts as of 2012. Have you ever noticed just how long it takes to explain this, for a so-called gateway game? Also, it's been around so long that many folks seems to have learned it third- or fourth-hand, which is to say that many unintended house rules have mutated into the gene pool. Earns nostalgia points for having brought many of us into the designer-name-on-the-box world.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A classic for a reason.  Easy to pick up and play, Settlers is guaranteed to provide an hour or two of fun as you collect resources and expand your town.

If you're looking for an in-depth and full-featured experience, though, look elsewhere.  The frequent dice-rolling means players will start complaining about being unlucky (and rightfully so).  Be wary of the expansion packs; while they add some much-needed complexity to the game, some are worth your time more than others.

All in all, Settlers is a casual German-style board game that can be enjoyed with family and friends.

RATING: 6
While not my favorite game, Catan deserves a spot in board game history for really starting the whole "Golden Age of Boardgaming".  Catan opened up a whole generation to games outside of the Parker brothers millieu.  So many of today's games own their design to some of what Catan has done.  Part area control, part set collection, and of course, the fate of the die rolls.  Catan still is fun to play, it's just that in my opinion, it has long been replaced by other games.

RATING: 9
The ultimate gateway game, and the one that brought me into the euro-game fold. RATING: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Have played this with young kids and they picked it up nicely. There's a variety of strategies to follow and the advantages for the advanced thinker are somewhat mitigated by the dice and the dots on the number-disks. 

I bought this due to its wide popularity as a "gateway" game, and for the fact that so many seemingly hardcore gamers on this site boast about being past it. I'd recommend it as a starter strategy game for those who, like me, are hesitant to buy things with a heavy fantasy theme.

However, there are problems .... the resource cards are fiddly and the robber mechanism is a directed attack, which I think is kind of weak. It's also expensive.

A house "welfare rule" is strongly recommended to keep players interested during times when the dice aren't in favor.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This is a great game and gets played often in our group, however, it wasn&#039;t quite a ten. I think that the player who goes first/last during the round in which the settlements are placed is at a high disadvantage. (At least, that seems to be the case in the four-player games.) Also, during some games, you can tell very early on who will be the winner, or at least who will be contenders for the winning spot. If you are not one of the contenders, the game is a real drag and you have to finish out the game.

RATING: 6.5
卡坦島是三大桌遊之一，更有其歷史地位，現在的桌遊工業可以說靠著它才慢慢茁壯!它讓桌遊擺脫以往地產大亨給人的刻板印象，讓大家知道原來桌上遊戲的機制也是很有變化的!
玩家各自戰領不同的地形，蓋蓋城鎮或城堡，每個地形會產特定資源，並且用某個骰子點數來表示，每回合擲骰來獲取資源，資源可以任意打嘴砲交易，再用資源升級建築物，另外有一些特殊加分的額外獎勵，最後比分數，簡單介紹就是這樣子。

RATING: 8.5
This game has a little bit of everything.  A little luck, a little strategy, a little co-operation, a little "screw your opponent" with the thief.  The thief's presence blocking a good resource tile has turned out to be the far greater threat than the card he steals.  The only trouble is that it's a bit finicky with 2 players, so we don't get to play it that often.  And there are so many exciting games to play when we have enough people, this one doesn't get the attention it deserves.

RATING: 4
I played a number of games (including Dune) in high school.  I played this for the first time in college (2001) and didn't care for it or the people I played it with (their other big game was MtG, which I also disliked)- and I started to get away from gaming.  I've gotten back into gaming in the last few years, so I thought I would give it another go with new, friendlier people.  I still don't care for it. There is a ton of luck and the major luck mitigating mechanism is negotiation (one of my least favorite mechanisms in games).  It might be ok for me if it was much shorter.  I'd rather use Carcassonne or Ticket to Ride as a gateway game.

RATING: 8.2
We have the Dutch version, "The Kolonisten van Catan" from 999 games.  This is a much played game with us and friends.  Usually, we like to play it with the seafarer expansion set the most.

The first few times that I played this, I found it really boring!!!  After playing it with other beginners, I began to "get it" more and really started to enjoy it.  Now, I love it.

Since we originally purchased it, we have bought just about every expansion set out there... official and unofficial.  It is such an addictive, fun game.

One thing that we changed though, was we bought 12 sided dice, which evens out the chances of numbers being played.

I enjoy playing this game much more with expansions than the stand alone game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This was the game that ripped me from the tendrils of Risk and Monopoly and into the world of BoardGameGeek. It gets bonus points for that. Mayfair Games has released expansion after expansion - in my mind, each one making it just a tiny bit worse than the original. I honestly don't think, in retrospect, this is a good 'gateway game'. Necessary kingmaker effect (how does a new player accurately determine who's in the lead?). It leads to a lot of player manipulation that shouldn't exist for players new to gaming. It has serious runaway leader problems if there isn't a concerted team effort to lock that player down AND a series of fortunate rolls. That being said, it's a lovely game, and there's a lot of subtlety to what is technically an incredibly simple game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Sigh.  The eternally over-rated Settlers.  Why some laud this game, which is just as random and just as prone to hosing some players out of the competition early on, as a premiere example of the German style, is beyond me.  Don't get me wrong -- it's great fun -- but it's about as luck filled as Monopoly.

RATING: 6.5
Gateway game for me just like most people.  It isn't a bad game.  I actually like playing it online more than in person for some reason.   I think it might be with not having to deal with setup and online the pace is much faster.   If the pace is kept up, it helps with the fact that you don't really have that many choices that you can make each turn.  The game doesn't play you but you definitely are not overwhelmed with possibilities, which is probably why it is a gateway game. 

I have played the shit out of it online so my enthusiasm for it is probably a little muted. I know I have more plays of it than any other game.  It isn't a bad game by any stretch.  There are just other games that have similar mechanisms and are better.  I would give the game a solid 7.  There is nothing wrong with the game, I have kind of just played it out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Nice accessible game for all, but hardly what hardcore strategists are looking for. A game you eventually grow out of.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I HATE Settlers.  Is it a bad game?  No, anything but.  Why then?  Becuase we played nothing else for *months* when our group first moved from MtG to board games.  Once every 6 months is fine for me.

So why do I dislike it so much?  In an ideal game everyone would have equal luck with the resources at an equal time during the game.  However, the game can be skewed so badly by one player getting their share of the luck early on in the game. Once that player or even those players are ahead it is very difficult to rein them in simply because if they have not been stupid with their expansion plans they will be getting resources more often than everyone else. 
A good starting position while essential to win, in no way guarantees it.  How many 5 'n' 9's games have you had when you have been able to get a 6 and 8 for your starting villages.  Some randomness in games is a good thing, perfect information and grand strategy has it's place but for me the spice and seasoning is the little random events that make you re-think, re-evaluate and plan on the fly.  Settlers has far too much of that good thing. 
It is a frustrating game for that reason with a lack of control to go with it.  Sure over time the skillful player will win more games in the same way that an expert backgammon player will beat the novice every time over a set of games. 
Oh and heaven forbid that you as the unlucky one be adjacent to the "leader" in which case the robbers directed at them will happily sit on your resources as well.  
Yes it is a great game that can simply bring new and innovative mechanics to an audience raised on the gaming hind teat that is monopoly and Clue(do).  Yes it has been hugely influential in the expansion of this hobby and yes I hve probably played this more than any other game that I own.  
But there are better games.  Better games for gamers with more control ahd deeper thought; better gateway games for non-gamers with simpler rules and a more forgiving start. 

Settlers will always have a place in my collection the trouble is twce a year is more than enough for it to hit the table. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This where it all restarted for me in boardgaming terms. Each game you randomly form the island of Catan by linking hexagons. Each land hexagon (barring one, the desert) can produce one of five type of resources (wool, clay, ore, wood or grain) and is given a number from 2 to 12. At the beggining of each players turn two dice and each player that has a village or a city in one of the hexagon(s) with that number get that resource. Other ways to get resources inclue trading with your opponents and, of course, robbing them. With the resources you build more roads, villages and cities, as well as buying "development cards" that allow special actions or offer VP. First player to get 10 VP, wins.

12 years now since discovering Settlers and I still haven't got tired from it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
This is a game that strikes a nice balance of strategy and luck, and its pleasures and nuances become greater with every play. The luck factor needs to be absorbed since a long run of bad rolls can beat you down and create some very cranky players, but most bad luck balances out over several plays. I think this game deserves every accolade it has received and even writing about it now makes me want to play. This is a great game.

Update: After a couple of years of playing this seminal game, I stand by my original assessment. There are other games that have come after which I would often prefer to play now, but the fact is it remains the most requested and often-played game in my family. It also remains the most contentious, as the luck factor seems to make everyone rather edgy at least once during any given game. Still, it is often the go-to game on a night when everyone just wants to sit down and play something quickly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
*Generally in most game designs players will know well before their last turn where they stand (unless vps are kept secret such as in E & T) so robs most of the players of the excitement.I think one main reason why Settlers does it for me is that there are a few elements which makes the game less likely to be anti-climatic than any game design I have played before or since. 

Resource holdings are secret, so there is tense uncertainty (unless you have memorised the transactions) whether other players will overtake you in the vp race, which incidently is kept at a simple and visual level.

But the clincher is the dice which in their nature provides hopeful swings in fortune or devasting schaudenfreude. The use of the commonly rolled "7" has been used to great effect to put risk filled fear in the leader from hoarding and also the robber as another mechanic to try and level the playing field, in a thematic way. 

So the tension of declaring the 10th vp is often in doubt until the right resource is secured in a trade, the vp development card is drawn or worse you have accummalated more than 7 resources and fingers crossed no-one even yourself that a 7 is rolled. The development costs menu means that an internalised narrative of needs is established cranking up the climax.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
The first game for me (and for many others as well) that introduced me to the wonderful world of eurogames.  A great resource management type game, I just wish that the whole series was a little cheaper.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
-

This is a game that will still be played 100 years from now. A ground breaking game with all the attributes for becoming a classic.
A great game for the whole family. Unfortunately, luck plays a huge role and the initial placement of the settlements can often unfairly help or severely hinder a player.  The 5-6 player game is even worse in this respect. Furthermore, the game is susceptible to decisions based on meta gaming. For these reasons it has lost its initial appeal and I play it only occasionally now. Nevertheless, its mass appeal and staying power are  unmistakable.
[05/28/05: rating reduced from 9 to 8.]
[03/29/06: rating reduced from 8 to 7.]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Useful gateway game as the high luck element allows new players to win a decent percentage of the time, and it is easy to teach and learn. Trading provides interaction between players and makes it a social experience (without which it would be a very dull game). Unfortunately it is too easy to fall behind early and have no chance of catching up, through no fault of your own. Edit: Using the event deck instead of dice goes a long way toward mitigating luck. Still, two players had bad starts positionally on the board and were behind the whole game. If you place first and get surrounded you can be at a huge disadvantage. Still lukewarm on the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I've been playing Catan before I actually got into hobby gaming. I had an app for it on my XB360 and quite enjoyed it. Once I did get into modern board gaming, it made sense to pick up a physical copy, and I enjoyed playing it. That interest waned however, as there were other games that I would rather play. Catan simply became too luck based and long for us. We did enjoy the various mini-expansions from Traders and Barbarians, specifically the fish and harbormaster, event deck and two player rules. Sadly, they weren't enough to mitigate our growing issues with the game. It still holds a special place in my heart though, and would play it once in a blue moon (maybe).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
P: 3-4, T: 60+ min, SdJ-W
Classic and influential although flawed. Many people's first Euro; fairly lightweight gateway,

-Dice results can be frustrating (too much randomness); sometimes you have very little to do on your turn. Players can be blocked early and more motivation to just play Kingmaker. Open trading between players can be exploited by more experienced players. 2 player variants exist, but don't play well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The classic trading and resource management game. The initial settlement placement determines your entire game success. Unfortunately since resources are produced based on die rolls, even the best plans can result in utter failure. This game is best played with the Fisherman of catan mini expansion to even the resource collection spots out a little more, and no other expansions. The more expansions this gets, the more unwieldy it gets. This includes the 5-6 player expansion that removes the whole tension of rolling 7s by allowing players to buy between turns.

:nostar: Art and components
:nostar: Innovative mechanics
:star: Handles 5 or more players
:nostar: Good with min or max players
:nostar: Low time between turns
:nostar: Comfortable complexity
:star: Re-playability
:star::nostar::nostar: Enjoyment

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's common for gamers to sour on Settlers but its ability to get new people into the hobby can't be underrated. I think the reason it's proven so enduringly popular is its familiarity to non-gamers. Like Monopoly, you roll two dice at the start of your turn and do what they say. Like Monopoly you try to build houses to enable you to gather more resources. Like Monopoly you haggle and trade with other players to try and make up sets. And compared to Monopoly, the commonly-made gamer complaint that you can be hosed by unlucky placement and dice rolls pales into insigificance - at least you can't be eliminated! 

When I first played Settlers, I was blown away by how many clever things it does compared to the 'classic' games I knew: properly makes use of probability; continuously moves towards a conclusion; keeps everyone involved when it's not their turn. Sure I can see some of its weaknesses now, and it's a game that I don't really play with gamers. But I'll happily pull it out any time with my family - my non-gamer sister and her husband adore it.

RATING: 8
Sheep for wood?  There is something inexplicably satisfying about the method: acquiring resources through luck, trade and theft, steadily working toward near and long-term goals, cheering when the dice fall your way.  An important Euro that is responsible for bringing these games into the mainstream of the US, and a game that is reasonably approachable for most people, nearly every geek should own this.  It's not perfect, but there's a lot of charm here.

RATING: 7
I'm not as keen to play this as I used to be.  I would like to try it again with some variants/house rules to speed up play--e.g. the harbor master, tournament rules (second placement is a city rather than a settlement) and the welfare variant (if a player does not earn a resource from the die roll, they receive a coin; players can then redeem the number of coins equal to their victory points currently on the board for a resource of their choice).

Depending on how much they shorten the game time, these variants might even make the 5-6 player extension bearable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is the ONLY game my wife actually asks to play. I think the key to this games broad and sustainable success is: 
1. Non-violent
2. Fairly simple rules
3. A pinch of luck (that impacts all players uniformly)
4. Interaction through trading (but not unlimited interaction)
5. Random map combined with dynamic starting positions.

We much prefer playing with the Seafarers expansion and the use of unknown tiles that are discovered during play.

RATING: 7
Wonderful game with several possible strategies that plays differently every time. Always ends a little too soon. A good game for the introduction of 'full scale' Euros to new players. New players would enjoy the room of the 3-player game whereas gamers need the full 4. Better balanced than the card game due ganging up to 'get the leader'. Probably should be a 7 with repeated play. Actually prefer the older edition components to the 3D version.

Unless players are of equal experience, the newer player will likely not know who is in the lead when making trades and placing the robber.

RATING: 10
A great game. Simple to play, has a good balance of luck verses strategy. I Like how you are encouraged to trade to get ahead. The hand size limits imposed by the robber keeps you from hoarding.
It is easy to fall behind the development curve, but you can restrain a runaway leader by not trading. Anyway if some of the charity variants can level out the bad die rolls.
A good family game.

On of the best games I played was a 4 player settlers - on player announced that he was building a settlement for the win only to find out he didn't have one more. The look on his face was priceless

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A true classic family game. The new edition with the nice design and figures are wonderful and has a different atmosphere than the old edition from the 1990's. Despite it is an old Spiel das Jahres game, it is still a good game but should be played only with the extensions as the base game is flat and has a big luck factor due to the dice rolls. The Event cards which replaces the dice is definitely a must for every Catan game as it makes a better planned game (not sure why it is still not shipped with the new base game). The Traders and Barbarians or the Cities & Knights extensions give more complexity and better game experience why it still remains a family game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The agreed definition of a eurogame.
The gamers game closest to being mainstream (over 28k owners just here in BGG).
With a lot of reasons: it has a fantastic theme, nice bits, great mechanics, and offers fun, tension, interactiion, and a wide range of different options.
It has everything, a lot of strategy but also some randomness and even big screwage possibilities (here comes the robber...)
The negotiation is what makes this game so exiting.
We all enjoy it in our family and play iy pretty often.
But IMHO it is just a little heavy to be the ideal gateway game (maybe it could be the ideal step two game)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I understand the significance this has had for our hobby, but for me, the runaway leader problem kills this one. Someone can get boxed in with no decent expansion possibilities and have no hope of winning literally over an hour before the game ends. I understand this only happens when someone makes mistakes during the early turns, but if we're using this as an introductory game, it is very possible that someone's first experience with European-style board gaming involves putting down some starting settlements and then getting surrounded and feeling powerless for the rest of the game. That is board gaming at its worst; is that really what we want our first impression to be?

Historical rating: 10
Gameplay rating: 6

EDIT: After reading several interviews with designer Klaus Teuber, I can say that his presence in the games industry is an absolutely wonderful thing, and I admire his attitude and actions. I wish I liked his game more, but I have no trouble liking the man himself.

Klaus Teuber rating: 10/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Once upon a time, I liked this game, but once upon a time I liked Monopoly.  This game is far too long and far too random.  Initial placement decides the game nearly every time depending on whether more sixes or more eights are rolled.  Players with good rolls don't need to trade at all!  Would work better if each player was allowed to draw a card of their choice at the end of every turn - and it would speed things up.  Again, game is too long!

RATING: 6
An entry-level game for anyone who wants to start their board game adventure. Well produced and nice graphics but the mechanics are inherently based on luck with dice or luck with trading. If noone agrees to trade, the game can stall horribly, and if you trade too freely, your opponents will simply build things ahead of you. It really needs some variant that will force players into more interaction (i.e. resources aging and vanishing eventually, so it makes sense to trade, etc. etc).

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The only reason I hate Catan is because I know there are better things out there. That doesn't mean the game itself is terrible. I just feel like there's a disappointed parent hovering over my shoulder whenever I play, sadly whispering "I know you can do so much better, if only you tried."

There is a lot going for Catan, though, as an introductory game for non-gamers to the Wonderful World of the Euro. Unfortunately, the game feels like it's actually about 10 minutes long (initial placement + the first few rolls), since most of the game is decided then.

It also incorporates freeform trading, which I strongly dislike due to the fact that it creates a ton of kingmaking or blacklisting ("I don't like you, so I won't trade with you even though you're behind and it's beneficial to me to do so") opportunities.

I have a standing rule for myself that I limit playing games of Catan to about once every 2 months. Any more than that and I'd probably rather just do something else instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Interesting game which I played for the first time recently as many non-casual gamers fear it like the vampire fears the cross, I am not sure why. The game and the fun you have while playing it depends on who you are playing it with, some people enjoy the fierce competition and trying to blockade each other, refuse trading etc., others may find it too vicious. The random element is a nice idea, also experienced players have a big advantage. Another flaw in my opinion is the accumulative nature of successes, the more resources you have, the more you can build and the more you build the more resources you have, which can be a pain in the ass should the starting conditions be unbalanced because that will be hard to flatten out later in the game. Still, a neat little game which could have done with some better artwork and theme instead of the plaster-on. I reckon that the expansions add a lot to it but I am not sure whether Ill ever be able to give those a go, considering the general reluctance of geeks to play it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I give it recognition for getting a ton of people in board gaming, but it's not a game I would seek out to play. I might be convinced to play a game if I was stuck in a cabin in the mountains with a group of people, miles from civilization and it was the only game available.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Settlers, Settlers, where to start.

In the late 90's I was looking for a board game that was better than, or at least equal to but different from, Talisman.  People kept telling about Settlers of Catan and I eventually found a copy at a local game store.  After playing it turned out to be a big dud.  I eventually got a copy of Robo Rally and that turned out to be the next best thing to Talisman at the time.

Back to Settlers, I had a copy of the game, didn't like it much, bought all the expansions (the local game store only had Warhammer, CCGs and Settlers so what else was there to buy?) to see if they would add that little spark to the game.  I became somewhat fond of the six player all expansions way of playing.  All my friends liked it so I ended up playing it quite a bit (my copy of the game is quite beat up).

Why didn't it work for me?  Because Catan is a negotiation game.  And when you play with people (myself included) that love to argue about the minutest detail even vanilla Catan can become a two hour slog.

The game is just not designed for the purpose of fierce competition.  It's a family game where people get to build cool houses and cities.  These things increase a player's ability to produce.  So you feel like you are doing something as the game progresses even if you lose...except for when you get a sequence of bad die rolls that allow your opponents to cut you off at the beginning of the game.

The game is quite simple: roll dice, produce goods, trade with your opponents, build.  It's thrilling as any dice game is.  Everyone is invested in every die roll so the game can provide a fun party-like atmosphere.  It's not the greatest game, nor is it particularly revolutionary, but it is fun, interactive, popular and allows players to build cool things.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Easy to play...
Very, very, verrrrry random game.

Could offset the balance of the world time continuum.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I don't really like this game but I will give it respect and give it a 4. That being said this is where it ends. I don't understand why this is still highly touted because I'd rather play every game I have in my collection over this one. It's heyday was in 1995 people. It's 2016! This game is for beginners, yet so many people play this game and only know this game! You need to get out more. What's the appeal? There are so many better intro level games out there that fit the euro game style.. here are several for you to look into -- Carcassonne, Ticket to Ride, Alhambra, or even Forbidden Island. Don't see why this is at all used as a gateway gamer except getting peer pressured into play this game by gamers who call themselves gamers just becuase they know Catan.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
One of my "gateway" games. When I first played, I was sucked into an experience that I had never seen in board games before. First game I was confused, next 5-6 games I was amazed. After that I realized that the luck factor and the low amount of depth really wasn't what I was looking for, and looked to branch out. However, I am unsure on this being the "go-to" gateway game as players are often at a huge disadvantage the first time playing, its difficulty to teach compared to other gateways, and its relatively long play time (which feels longer when you're losing! haha.) 

Anyways, lots of props to this game for sucking me in and others into the hobby. Still using it today to help people get into boardgaming. It's pretty darn player independent, and has relatively wide appeal. However, I find it annoying when people ask to play it AGAIN and AGAIN, when there's other games that these people are capable of and enjoy as well.

I feel like this game has really low strategy, and is often determined on who rolls the best. This can be solved with a deck mechanic that I have yet to try, but I would just save my time for other games. Components are nice, theme is good, and execution for what it is is spot on. 

The interaction with 5-6 players is a lot more enjoyable though, and I would be willing to play Catan with friends if its with that expansion (comments on that should be somewhere around here). It bugs me when people pride themselves in winning Catan though, as I feel like it is very luck-based. Just my 0.02 ;)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Revised down to 5.

I played a tournament of Settlers of Catan.  This game is NOT a good tournament.  WAY TOO RANDOM!  The judges even said so much.  It is a fun family game.  For me it is on its way to being a better version of Monopoly.

Played two games in June '06.  The endgame seems laborious.  Or there inevitably becomes a king maker.  However the game is very good.



=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.99
= 2012-05-21

The game that started it all. Some friends introduced us to this game in January of 2012 and now I have a BGG account, two shelves of board games and a wishlist that grows by three for every one I remove.

I won't say we've "moved on" from this game, but it hasn't had much play since being used as a gateway game. I blame this on us mostly wanting to play two player games and there are just so many better two player games out there than any two player variant of Catan.

= 2014-02-14 - R:6.99

Happy Valentine's Day. In sticking with the theme for the day, I'd like to share some love for this game. I gave it a 6 because, on the official BGG scale, it's a game I admire but would only play when in a certain mood. That mood is more situational than anything. There are many times when my wife and I want to play a game together and we'd like that game to have the feel of Catan, but so far we haven't been able to capture that feel in a two player game. When we do have enough people over to be able to play a four player game, I rarely want to play board games. So poor Catan never makes it to our table even though I think I want to play it. In honor of how much Catan influences our search for other games, I'm bumping the rating from 6 to 6.99.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
The Settlers of Catan is a marvelous 'gateway' game for those who have only played Monopoly or Clue.  It is incredibly simple to learn, yet strategic enough to allow for some deep gameplay decisions.  It very much serves as a bridge between a game like Monopoly and a game like Puerto Rico.  If you're trying to get some of your friends to dip their toe in deeper games such as the ones lauded on this website, this is definitely the game to start with.

RATING: 7
I like the element of chance and the great player interaction, combined with the considerable strategic and tactical choices to make.  Plays fast, no player elimination and no 'analysis' problems.  Overall, a great game that's usually a lot of fun. Not rated as highly as I used to rate it, because I see now it suffers from chance having far too much effect in the first few turns: if you don't get resources early while your opponents do, you're hosed for the rest of the game, and it's not much fun. I've dropped my rating of this game once again, after another un-fun game. I don't need to WIN to have fun, but when I've managed to build only one section of road while other players have built their third settlement and two cities, it's something wrong with the game. But don't forget, I said "It's usually a lot of fun" and I mean it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
so I finally played the granddaddy of them all, and all I can say is: the jury is still out for me on this game. The random set up and production rolls can lock a player out from contention early on. i don't like having to play a game for 30 more minutes with no chance of winning. Some resources seem more useful than others--why would anybody trade brick with you? seems to suffer from a rich get richer problem. those who can build roads can build settlements, can gain more resources, etc. maybe some of the problems were due to a very weird random board set up--like resources were all lumped together and a we had a full compliment of 6 players, which seemed to add to the length and randomness. I would like to play this again with just four.  

o.k. i've played this again this time with 3 players and i enjoyed it a little more. i can see where the appeal of this game with people who aren't game enthusiasts lies. very easy rules to teach and learn. the modular board is attractive and so different from what most people who don't play games as a hobby are used to seeing in a game, that the game can draw in uninitiated players  right in. 

i like how the trading stimulates player interaction, which is an element of the game that is much different for people only familiar with mass market US games. though, in my opinion,  the trading mechanism doesn't quite work 100% well, or is mostly uninteresting. 

there are some commodities in some games that will be more valuable than others because of the random production roles. players in the lead will at some point in the mid to late game find themselves never lacking. when they do need a trade, however, its in order to put them close to the win or to just win outright. this puts players who are behind, in a kingmaker position. sometimes to be able to do anything useful you will be forced to trade somebody something that's infinitely more useful to them because of their position in the game. your only other choice is to not make trades to these players and languish, or put another player in a position to win. if you don't trade, it becomes a matter of sitting there and waiting for the players in the lead to get lucky and have their production numbers come up, so that one of them can build whatever it is they need to win. how fun.

i enjoy the game up into the mid to late game where it gets boring, and it's obvious who is going to win, but the game nevertheless continues. 

i just don't really feel that a player's decisions amount to much in this game. production roles: luck. stealing resources with the robber: luck. drawing cards from the development deck: luck. 

still i'm happy to have this game on hand, despite my negative comments, because it something to play with people who aren't big on games due to the reasons i listed above.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]RO:[/b] [i]12/17/2015[/i]

What is there to say about Catan? Well, a lot actually. Of course, there is it's prestigious (and hardly arguable in my opinion) claim to bringing "German-style" board gaming to the world. For most of us, Catan was probably the first non-American classic you played, or at least heard of. 

My group and me mispronounce the name, at first ignorantly, and now out of habit as "Kay-ten", of course the correct pronunciation is "Cuh-tahn" but we've grown so used to it, that the simple misnomer "Kay-ten", or occasionally, "Settlers", is almost always how we refer to it.

There is a lot of luck here, resource generation is dice based but player investment is constant because resources can flow into your [-]sweaty hands[/-] warehouses even when it isn't your turn, and trades are flying this way and that on a regular basis. It can drag, if luck isn't on your side or you placed your settlements poorly, but overall it is leagues beyond your normal Monopoly, Risk, or Life game in terms of interaction, interest, and ability to influence the outcome through clever play. It is always fun, even if it occasionally overstays it's welcome. Many "better" games have come along, but there is something about the nostalgia and brilliant design that will keep most coming back.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This was the first considerable board game I had played since I was a child playing Monopoly.

And I must say, I love it.  The game seems simple on the surface, and is relatively easy to pick up, but strategy permeates the entire game.  From placement, to building strategies, and trading for resources, every action has consequences and there are always multiple options to choose from.  Often, a single card can change your entire strategy; I often see players about to build a development card, make a good trade, and shift gears into building a city or a settlement.  With so many ways to gain points, and so many ways to build up, there are always different strategies to try.  Combined with the interaction between players and the random board designs, there is no perfect strategy, requiring players to constantly be aware and plan their next moves accordingly.

My only complaint is the fact that dice rolls determine what resources you get.  While a little randomness keeps things changing and unpredictable, resources are so important that an unlucky streak can break even the best strategy.  Combined with the exponential productivity growth, a slow start due to unlucky rolls can quickly separate the winners from the losers.  This sometimes results in people giving up mid-game, complaining that they've already lost and making unreasonable trades to break everybody else's strategy.  There's a lack of sportsmanship apparent here, but the fact that players can get into an unstoppable losing or winning position can make the rest of the game less fun.

Still, this is an excellent game that I have played dozens of times over the last couple of years and I still enjoy playing to this day.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I always find this game exciting.  Catan, more than almost any other game I play, makes me feel like I'm building a little civilization. I feel such pride when I build a road, or when I put up a new settlement.  It's also quite exhilarating to roll the exact number needed to get the resource that you need just as it's devestating to roll a seven when you've got a hand full of cards.  With as many times as I've played this game (I got it before I started keep close numbers on my play stats), I still enjoy it a lot.

The only thing that I find frustrating is the dice rolling.  If Catan had no dice, and instead had some other way of allocating resources, it would possible be in my top ten.  Instead, it's a game that I play sometimes because it's a classic and because it's a game that I discovered fairly early on in my development from game enjoyer to game enthusiast.  

***Update***

I haven't played Catan in months because I'm just not that interested in it now that I've passed the gateway stage.  The dice just bother me so much that I never take it out and play it.  Rating lowered to a six.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This was my "gateway game" that introduced me to the broader aspects of boardgaming.  It doesn't get played much now that I have a 200+ collection, but I pulled it out recently and it still held.  I find the dice a bit frustrating, but not so much that I would use cards, because that aspect of it is part of the appeal to the game I think.  Having played this probably 50+ times, I do find myself always going for similar types of strategies, etc. but it's still a fun game.

I really like the totally open trading aspect of this game, which is something that other games still don's seem to replicate all that well.  Other games with trading tend to have restrictions on them, whereas in settlers you can trade things like port use, robber placement, intentions on where you are building, etc.  (I know these aren't all strictly following the rules, but we allow pretty much anything in trades in the games I play).

RATING: 8.96
There's a reason it's a classic!

Stale?...I think not!  However, I do agree that the opening set-up can be a little too powerful in some games.  But if you find yourself in a less than ideal game setup then it's time to go for the upset of the century.

Also, don't forget to trade.  This game is about trading.  If you refuse to trade because you don't want to help anyone then it's not really within the spirit of the game, IMO.  If you play that way, I could see why that game (and many games) would not be desirable for you.

The good part about Settlers is the excitement associated with each role of the dice....everyone is interested in the outcome.  Half will yell:  "yeah!!!"  and half will yell:  "Noooo!!!"     It's just fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
In Settlers of Catan, players try to be the dominant force on the island of Catan by building settlements, cities, and roads. On each turn dice are rolled to determine the current production on the island. Players collect raw materials to build up their civilizations to gain enough victory points to win the game.

Highly recommended to anyone who wants to see how short, deep, and fun a board game should be!

RATING: 7
I think this classic is still a very good gateway Euro game, especially for families. There is quite some interaction with trading (especially if played not uber-competitively) and at the end of the game, everybody has increased his settlements. So even if you are not the winner, you can look down at the board and feel good to have build something from the ressources you produced or traded. That is probably the major appeal of Catan, which is still working nowadays.

RATING: 7
This game is very popular, but is not as good as have rating. Game has several problems: 
1. If your first move (placement initial vilage) is wrong game is lost for you. 
2. Be richer, be better. If you have advantage, your oponents has small chance to catch you.
3. Your moves are mostly automatic. No real choice. Often only wait for right dice. 

Majority games with rating 7.0 or more is better than this game. But this game is legend...

RATING: 8
Uno comodato da Camilla...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Previously played Settlers online many years back a lot (a LOT!), and decided to buy a physical copy for my playing group which consists of my fiancée, my family and/or her family, and my friend (who is a semi-gamer) for the following reasons:

1. Good components - components are excellent, and the hexagonal map is modular allowing for different set-ups each time [variability]

2. Mechanics - well thought out and put together, which work really well with the theme, and more importantly has a fair degree of player interaction even during other players turns

3. Simple and logical rules - concise and build upon the theme and mechanics. Very cohesive

4. Interaction - fair degree of player interaction through trading, blocking roads, and moving the robber

It may be fashionable in some quarters to bash Settlers for its success and market penetration, it still holds up as a worthwhile game (unless you detest any form of luck in games), is still relevant, worthwhile, and fun to play now. 

Settlers is no longer an automatic shoe-in as the default gateway game (testament to the vast range of excellent games available), however it is a worthwhile choice as a gateway game. One that I still enjoy playing (unlike TTR, which wore out its welcome after 2 plays).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

"I've got sheep. Does anyone have wheat?"

"No, no wheat has been rolled for 4 turns."

"How about 2-to-1?"

"No one has wheat."

"Ok, 3-to-1?"

"Again, no one has wheat."

"It's a really good deal!"

"What is it about no one having wheat that you don't understand?"

Ugh. The people who hold the game hostage while trading are the worst.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6
Players: 3-4
Time: 60-90 min.

Players place settlements on the island of Catan and attempt to build cities, roads and armies to be the first to 10 points. Players acquire goods to build these through lucky dice rolls and trading with other players. In addition, a robber roams the island and steals resources. Losing players can use the robber to catch up to the current points leader. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Good game.  Will likely not turn it down if someone suggests it, but also will probably not suggest it unless someone hasn't played a "real" boardgame before.  Like the trading aspect and like the building.

Made better by Cities and Knights.

Update Jan 2015: Played this game with my brothers over Christmas.  Awesome.  Simple enough for everyone to come up to speed quickly and liquor-fueled trading interaction was great.  And I really like how the development cards provided another path to victory if someone was locked out of building cities.  This game is classic and should be the game the general population points to when they think of "boardgames" and relegate Monopoly to the dustbin of history.

RATING: 7.7
this game is simply but a good introduction to euro type games.  Combines trading with with area control in a easy to understand package.  I gotten many non-gamers to play this.  There is a bit of a run away problem if the die rolls don't work out to get you resources  and there is no catch up mechanic but just keep up if you can.  Games can also run a little long for what it is.

Like most people, this was my first introduction to Designer Games and I really enjoy it. The game does grow stale after a while, however, as I found the winning strategy of cornering the market on a frequent resource type and securing the associated port, all in the opening turn.

I also find that I don't like the 5-6 player expansion as much. It's too long and the island gets too restrictive, often cornering players into a weak position and preventing their advancement.

RATING: 5
My wife and one of our gaming friends both absolutely love Settlers (which I find strange - both are experienced gamers), so there was quite a long period where I was forced to play it on an approximately weekly basis (that has thankfully stopped, the game now only gets played when they have someone else to play it with). As you can probably guess, I've never been a fan. To be fair, it's not that bad as a game, what is there works reasonably well - but there's nothing particularly good or interesting about it, and any individual game is too dependent on the dice rolls (or other luck like which cards get stolen). And it throws up incredibly frustrating moments, like finally getting that brick when a 5 was rolled for the first time all game, only for an opponent to play a monopoly card for it before you can use it. Or getting picked on even when you're already doing terribly, just because the opponent who just rolled 7 knows that one of your 2 cards is that precious wheat. And many many more. I can understand why this game became popular 20 years ago, but really, even for a gateway game there are dozens (at a very conservative estimate) of better and more fun ones around now.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pre-Catan, I used to like Board Games, but wouldn't have really been that into them.
Post-Catan, I realised that what I knew of board games was very out-dated. 

I'd say that my experience of playing Catan is similar to so many people. Our friends introduce us to Catan and it serves to bridge the gap in our appreciation for board games. We realise that Monopoly, Cluedo and Game of Life are not really "good" games at all. We realise that player elimination is a bad thing. We learn that the mechanics of the new wave of board games are so much more of an experience than what we had as kids. Most of all, we learn that board games are now really fun!

The mechanics of the game are very simple, but can bring out great strategy. Luck can be a factor, as in any game with dice, but dice go both ways in games. Of course, good strategy and luck with dice can be overcame by players scheming and grouping up against one player - so it's always unlikely that one player will always win!

While I don't get to play Catan as often anymore, I'm still usually happy to join a game when it's suggested. And for a new gamer, it is still part of my armory to try and get them hooked. 

Catan will now and forever occupy a favorable place in my memories of gaming!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

PROS: continual player interaction, no text dependency, die roll anxiousness
CONS: players can feel hopelessly behind, endgame becomes ganging up on leader

RATING: 8
Purchased the Spanish version. The European manufacture is better than the American IMO. Even though the game's theme isn't everyone's cup of tea, it's still a great game with enough luck and strategy that it doesn't become boring or dull. The randomization of tiles is a pretty cool system.
The only problem is when you pick up a place with less frequent numbers for your first settlements, since these will be the foundations of your entire game. It's crucial to understand dice statistics before playing, otherwise it can be very frustrating for some players. A very good and fun game, overall.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Warning: Nasty review about a weak game. Do not buy it!

Catan is the game that singlehandedly delayed me from getting into board gaming by some 10 years. 

Catan was all my few boardgaming friends wanted to play back in high school. Which made me stick to computer and videogames for my gaming fix. Because I like having fun, I don't like dying inside.

Even today I have friends who love it. And honestly, I've judged them terribly in silence. With time, however, I've come to realize that they simply haven't played any good games and thus have no basis for comparison. Which is a mitigating factor for sure. Because if getting punched in the face is all you know it's probably not that bad. (Some of them own Carcassonne though... and I would rather live in a Carcassone big box for a year than play a game of Catan. So I don't get that.).

Playing Catan is like religion because all you do is pray, hope and wait for that unlikely miracle. (I also tend to think alot about death and the afterlife while playing.) You don't really have any meaningful choices. Either you get the rolls you need, or you don't. Either you buy the thing you can afford, or you wait until you can afford the other thing. Either people want to trade resources with you or they don't. There is really very little you can do to affect the game aside from refusing someone a trade or placing the robber. Where to build is the only choice of any importance. And it is a rare occurence.

The game was weak when it came out and is hopelessly dated today. If you want an easy dice chucking game, get Champions of Midgard or something.

I guarantee that if you take just 15 minutes to look you will find a game you'll have more fun with than Catan. All the other classic gateway games are better. Even Yahtzee has more meaningful choices. Rock-paper-scissors has greater replay value. An afternoon nap is more exciting.

Don't get it!

The copy in our collection is my girlfriends. Thankfully she quickly realized its utter worthlessness when introduced to mediocre-or-better games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Mejor 4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
http://www.ronkkonen.com/boardgames.html#Settlers
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
 Excellent introduction to german games for a number of reasons:       The number of brain parts stimulated in the game is large, though stimulation is fairly gentle.  This is not your hitachi magic wand vibrator that focuses on one organ and wiggles the hell out of it. no.  it's more like a vibrating tub of warm, soft jello that you jump into hairless and naked, all nerve endings exposed. there's cajoling, laughter, tension, secrets and bluffing, memory, press your luck, arms races, strategic thinking, tactical considerations, the joy of building.     there's just a *little* viciousness, enough to make the game juicy, but not enough to provoke any real hurt feelings (for most people).    virtually zero downtime for anybody, as everyone is interested in everything that happens at all times.   the game has been designed to give every person playing the hope of winning at all times, even if it's the smallest glimmer.  the person that is waay too far in the lead can be effectively slowed down by other players, leading to close, tense finishes.  Some here have argued that this aspect makes it an inferior game, as skill is constantly being stymied by luck and group-lynching, but I believe that a game for non-gamers should allow everyone the possibility of winning.    

 On the minus side, the start-up is intimidating (to a non-gamer), as rules are moderately complicated, and the board looks geeky, with the hexagons and #s and pips.  But most non-gamers with whom I've played have warmed to the game after playing just two rounds, and are extremely enthusiastic (and exhausted) by the end.  Complexity is an issue, however, for grandma or grandpa who have trouble with all the rules.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
DUI
(Nauwelijks taalafhankelijk)

= Het bordspel.

OMSCHRIJVING: Handels- en resourcemanagementspel.
De spelers strijden tegen elkaar om de grootste kolonisatiemacht uit te bouwen op het eiland Catan. Dit doen ze door het bouwen van wegen, dorpen en steden. Hiervoor hebben ze vele grondstoffen nodig, die ze verkrijgen door het strategisch bouwen van de vernoemde nederzettingen (een aangrenzend bosgebied levert bijv. hout op), maar ook door onderlinge onderhandeling.


--> 3 tot 4 spelers

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This was my gateway game into the world of Eurogames. The first time I played it I was blown away. There is, indeed, a lot to like in this game: trading, route building, player interaction, blocking, long term strategy, short term tactics, etc... However, the more I played it, the less I enjoyed it. Especially after I became a more experienced Eurogamer. It took me a while to figure out what I didn't like, and I think what it comes down to is the simple fact that- when everything is boiled down- the key to winning the game is simply getting more of the correct resources than other players in order to build quicker than them. How do you get resources? They are randomly dealt out through dice rolls. Sure you can play the probabilities, but that doesn't always help. I've played most of a game without an 8 being rolled. It's in the "Monopoly" mold of distributing currency randomly. I didn't like it in that game and I don't like it here either. You can plan and carefully line up your pieces, but it doesn't matter if the dice don't roll your number. You are at the mercy of the dice for nearly everything in this game. The simple fact is that some people get more resources through sheer luck and not due to good or smart play. I really don't mind randomness in games, but having your entire economy run by random dice results is ludicrous. Looking at the game now, it looks to me like the whole trading aspect was simply added on to try and fix the inherently broken economy of the game and isn't entirely successful.

Then there is the fact that this game is just much too long. After I came to the realization that it was the dice that bothered me, I bought the dice deck of cards which evens out the luck. After playing it with those cards, I found my experience with the game didn't really improve much. Perhaps I'm simply burned out on the game, but for me Catan is a trial to get through. It drags on and the fun is over long before the game is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Good game, but with too many expansions and the wrong players, it takes too long and frustrates me. LOVE playing it against CPUs on the computer and ipad... they don't take forever to make decisions.

RATING: 9
An almost perfect game. Mechanics are beautifully elegant, plays very quickly (40~60m with my group), negotiation makes the game very fun and interactive. The only downside is that randomness has too much impact on the game for my taste. I agree that the game should contain some randomness, but if it was more controlled, I would consider this a perfect board game.
A great game nonetheless. Strongly recommend it for light gamers.

RATING: 7.6
Darryl & Annetta, G&H
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
The best game for you if you don't play board games. Friends and girls love it. Best trading and social game so far (if you let it). Never get mad to the dice. Just have fun playing. A little to much luck but you can use some variants to put it in check. I advise you 2 new house rules:

If you don't receive any resource, place a token (Catan doesn't come with any, so add them to the game) in front of you. Once you have x tokens equal to your points, trade it (on your turn) for any resource. Tokens can't be stolen and don't count as cards in your hand.

If the same number (besides 7) rolls again (two times in a row), you MUST add or subtract, a value of 2, to the number (you choose, but can't never use a value of just 1). This rule is inspired from Elasund.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Anyway, the reason I don't own the game is because everyone else does. Like literally everyone else.

RATING: 8
I rarely win Catan, but I still have loads of fun. It is a strategist's game; someone who can loves looking at the board and predicting everyone's future moves and how to block them. It also has a decent amount of random luck, which, in my opinion, every game needs otherwise it would be like Chess. If I wanted to play chess, I would play chess.
Settlers of Catan is a timeless game. One that I can bring out and have fun with without any of the expansions. Personally I don't think it needs expansions, the core gameplay elements would be ruined I think if you threw in some crazy ideas. Then again, I can't really talk since I haven't played a whole lot of them.
Overall, Catan is a great game with great player interactions and great mechanics. Love it.

RATING: 7
----------

This was my gateway game.  I played it and loved it for 2 years until I picked up Cities and Knights and Seafarers.  Cities and Knights has spoiled me... the base version is now too bland for my tastes, but this game is still a classic.  

If you would've asked me a rating 100 plays ago, it would've been a 10 all the way.  As it is now, I could care less if I ever played it again.

However, I'm keeping it in my collection so I can introduce friends to eurogaming in the future.

RATING: 7
SDJ

[b]Unique Component[/b] - Modular board and number tiles for random resource production.


[b]Unique Mechanic[/b] - Rolling dice for random resource production.


[b]Quick Thoughts[/b] - I really enjoy this game.  I was inventive and bit ahead of its time.  I also think this games gets a lot of unwarranted crap from gamers.  It is an old game, but it still shines in my opinion.



Most certainly one of the better games ever made.  It is  a great gateway game and the game responsible for me being a big board gamer today.  The original is fine, but much better with Cities & Knights.  Always played with Cities & Knights and sometimes with the Great River and/or the Fisherman.  Rarely played with Seafarers and never with the event cards.

2008 Plays = 1
2009 Plays = 2
2010 Plays = 2
2012 Plays = 3

RATING: 7

Most importantly, Settlers is the biggest hit with my non-boardgaming friends.  It has been such a treat to have found a game with the universal appeal of mainstream games and the strategy/depth of a very good contemporary board game.

RATING: 6.7
--05Aug2004-- Bumped down to 7 due to increasing grumpiness with the effect of roll distributions on results.  While this is a really good gateway game - particularly for people that have been exposed to classic roll&move fare - there simply aren't enough rolls of the dice in a given game to even out a typically lumpy distribution.  As a result, a theoretically 'good' play can easily fail to be rewarded.  In the face of superior competition, then; there are other things that I would rather play.

RATING: 9.3
[color=#CC0000]

Every time I play I think I have it figured out, and as the game progresses I have to change my strategy.  The game is legendary, you owe it to yourself and to your kids to have a copy around the house.  Catch-phrases from Settlers are entering mainstream culture the same way "Do not pass Go" and "Free Parking" have from Monopoly.  This may be the one game from the last quarter of the 20th century to establish ubiquity.

The discussion after any game will give you a good clue about how good a play it is.  Settlers [b][i]always[/i][/b] produces a good post-game show.

[/color]

RATING: 6
english 5th edition, wrapped in shrink
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2 hours long replayable trading/tactical/skill/luck family strategy.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Easy to learn, hard to master
- You can learn main rules very fast (and search for more precise rules later)
- Good variability:
--- modular board
--- different starting positions
--- different tactics to win (you need to adapt to your position and cards)
--- trading between players
- Appropriate game length considering complexity

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Boring for player who positioned their settlement unwisely on the start or have bad luck with dices. But these games are often much faster so the misery is over soon.

[b]Note:[/b]
I'm still trying to measure luck involvment in this game. Currently I'm thinking about 50% luck / 50 % skill
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This game is very easy to learn, but not at all deficient in terms of strategic content. There is luck involved, but the strategy is based partly on understanding the probability distribution (the game and rules are designed to remind us of this ad nauseum) involved, and each game ought to provide a large enough sample of dice throws to have a fairly normal distribution.

It is not easy, however, to pick an optimal strategy. Like Go, it seems that this game cannot be reasoned out by brute force-- players must be able to adapt to their current situation and pick an optimal move using a sort of sliding time scale.

I have only played this game a handful of times, but I expect that I will continue to enjoy it and refine my strategy for a long time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Amazing fun, playable even with non-boardgamers.

EDIT: I still like the game a lot, but have moved it down from a 9 to a 7. It is great for playing with people who normally aren't into games. However, it does suffer from the problem that you can go for long stretches without being able to do anything because you get bad dice rolls for resources. I have nothing against luck in games, but sitting around waiting for your numbers to come up can be a bit dull.

RATING: 6.4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the games that brought my sister and me beyond the borders of the known boardgame world. When we were kids, my mom used to play the Catan computer game, and when she found a copy of the boardgame at a local toy store, she bought it and taught it to us during our weekly summer holiday in the Austrian Alps. From then on, for about ten years, we would be playing Catan all week long while on holiday - but not during the year. This changed in the last few years, when I got more involved in boardgaming, and we've played Catan during a weekend now and then.

Even though this game could be considered old, I think it still holds up against its competitors nowadays. Catan has become a well-known game in the mass-market, and I think that's a good thing.

I like the game. Even if you're losing, you can still set your own small goals, achievements to be reached in your own personal struggle. I also like that the level of 'viciousness' is completely adaptable to the group's desires, while still staying within the framework of the rules: I once had a player who allowed another player to decide where he'd put the robber, as long as that other player promised to make a certain trade with him during that turn - on the other hand, I've also had games where the robber got parked out of harm's way because the player decided everyone had been punished enough by having to discard half of their cards.

There's an interesting variety of strategies available to players: will you invest in long road networks to grab and hold the longest trading route, or buy develoment cards in search of victory points (and the biggest army), work towards building up your infrastructure with many villages (preferable on tile numbers that already grant you resources) or upgrade your villages into large cities?

This may sound weird, but Catan leaves me room to develop a story. An epic tale about how the different civilizations on the island flourish or wither away. One remarkable thing about our copy, by the way, is that the red - statistically most likely to be rolled - numbers often get rolled less than the weird numbers with low oddes, like 2's, 11's or 12's.

N.B.: I also prefer the wooden bits from my old copy over the ones from the wooden 15 year anniversary edition (though the wooden resource and number tiles are cooler) and especially over the plastic ones from newer editions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This game has its place and is a great stepping stone into better games, I'm just over it currently.

RATING: 6.75
Like for many people, this was my gateway game; I remember holding the rulebook for the first time and thinking how impressive it was that any game could have so much material to learn.  I had a lot of fun with the game and introducing it to all my friends allowed me to bring them into the hobby with me.

Now, the game only gets played occasionally.  Is it a good game?  I think so, I guess, but I don't feel particularly compelled by it anymore.  I may have become too familiar with it, and maybe the same thing would happen with some of my current favourites if I were to play them as much and as often as I did Catan, but I have a feeling the games that I now rank among the best have a little something, or maybe a few things, that Catan just doesn't bring to the table.
