RATING: 5.25
Catan is sometimes enjoyable, but always outclassed. Other economically focused games have more interesting engines, and other negotiation heavy games have meatier negotiations.

Catan suffers from a long list of relatively minor problems that add up to create an unnecessarily frustrating gameplay experience. Trading is hampered by the fear of the "Monopoly" gambit, bad die rolls can punish good strategies unfairly, and bash the leader elements ensure the game goes out with a whimper.

---

http://claycrucible.com/2014/07/clay-crucible-settlers/

I do want to try Catan with this variant. I've heard good things (supposedly makes it feel a lot more like Concordia).

RATING: 8.5
26th Birthday from Sarah & Matt

We first played this game at our friend Rich's house as 3 couples. We were all new players although had heard of it because of the TV show The Big Bang Theory "I need wood".  As a party game with lots of people fighting for resources and to build as quickly as possible we had great fun and raved about it to other friends.

So quite unexpectedly on my my birthday the friends I had raved about it too had bought it for me. We've played this many more times than I have recorded and still love haw tactical you have to be to scoop a win from under your opponents noses many times it has come down to the final roll.

I've just purchased the first add on for this game seafarers so I'm looking forward to adding an extra dimension to the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have played this game with all of its expansions more times than I can possibly count.  Early on it was great fun because it was my first venture into strategic gaming.  My friends and I played multiple evenings every week.  However, as we progressed we realized the fatal flaw of this game--the heavy weight of the dice rolls.  You can have great strategy and still lose horribly if there is a string of rolls that don't go your way.  This is especially maddening when you choose the numbers that should be rolled more frequently like sixes or eights and someone else wins because they set up shop on threes and they got rolled a ridiculous amount.  I still play this game occasionally, usually when we are hanging out with people that aren't as used to strategic games.  It is a good game to use to cut your teeth on, but it has little value to grow with the player over the years.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[-]I've had a couple plays now and while it is good fun; I don't think there is that much strategy to the game.  If you have good initial placement and a few good rolls then you'll do well.[/-] I wish this game was 30 minutes. Most of my non-gamer friends know it and really enjoy it. These days I'll only play if I can't get them to learn something else.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Settlers of Catan is a classic board game predicated on resource trading and area control and is fun for older children. I have played it with a variety of people and would say that it is suitable for 12+. It can get a little serious for an gateway board game and I have had people lose it because they have been directly hindered by another player's actions. It is not as bad as Diplomacy, however. It is a game that probably works the best on its own and doesn't really need any expansions. Best played with 3 or 4 works fine too. Further expansions such as Cities & Knights actually change the flavour of the game as opposed to adding to it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My gateway game, and still an amazing piece of work.  I just seem to have some of the worst luck with dice when playing this game, which frustrates me in comparison to other games like Power Grid, Puerto Rico, etc.

RATING: 6
I think this is a great game for playing with certain light gamers. It serves as a benchmark by which all my games are rated.

This can degenerate into a really mean game in the right (wrong) crowd. There's the potential for one sided trades to assist blocking the leader, multiple bashing the leader on the same turn through the black knight, etc. I only want to play this one with the kids - keep it away from the serious competitive gamers.

I really can't stand the Mayfair edition - I don't like the colours and why does the ore symbol on the player mats use the same colour as the clay bricks?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What can I say that hasn't been said yet about this game?  A classic, the cause of Eurogames' boom, a really good game.  Players are colonists in an island trying to develop roads, towns and cities getting and using different raw materials, trading and avoiding thieves.

RATING: 10
The grand-mother of Euro games and up there with Ticket to Ride as the best gateway game out there.  Dice rolls produce resources, for each player on every turn, that they can trade or use to build bigger roads, settlements and cities for VPs and even more resources.  An accelerating game, it is always a sprint at the end, rather than a crawl like American counterpart games.  And must have addition to any gaming closet.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm not saying anything new when I call this game a classic. I like to play with a random hex and number setup. The game is easy to setup and play, and offers quite a bit of strategic depth. Dice adds a little luck to the mix, but only over the short term. How do I maximize my resources? Should I compete for the biggest army or biggest road bonuses? UPDATE: Dropping my rating from 10 to 8.5, since there are so many other games I'd rather bring to the table before this. Still a great game.

UPDATE Jul-12-2010: Dropping it solidly to an 8, since this game fails the "always want to play it" test. Also, I think I was mad to say the game has only a "little luck." The game often never gets to the "long term" for the resources to even out -- it's only played to 10 points.

I really need to get a newer edition of this game. The '96 Mayfair edition has some visual design issues that make it difficult for new players to tell the resources apart. Specifically, A. the hexes and cards are all photographs (and dark, at that) and B. there are different images for the terrain (e.g., forest hex) and the resource (e.g., timber). The resource is illustrated as a circle. The player aid shows the resource circles only, and of course the hexes just show the terrain, but the resource cards have both. I was aiming for a conversion of an older player into a gamer, but instead I turned him off to "complicated" games such as this. :(
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What can anyone say about this game? I think that every board gamer should own it...You will always find people to play it and love it...The only disadvantages of the game are 1.the 4th and sometimes the 3rd place in the middle of the game are obvious and almost withdrawn from competition (they get bored...) basically due to 2. The starting positions are extremely crucial and if you make a mistake or you are cut off it's almost impossible to win and 3. Only 4 players can play it. Ok these disadvantages seem little serious but all in all the game is GREAT. Fun, arguments, strategic play, screwing others and negotiations guarantee a pleasant time, satisfaction in the end and multiple plays in the future...

PS For me it is also an entry into the more strategic games out there.

RATING: 9
The game that got me started on the voyage of board gaming... this game took the original idea of board gaming and turned it upside down on its head. Certainly, games of its caliber had existed before, but this raised the bar for how gamers while away their hours. Also helping it was the fact that it is very newbie friendly. Its greatest strengths are its elegant simplicity and variable map board. It has enough building and options to keep you entertained. It is criticized heavily for randomness in the dice rolls though, but that doesn't bother me too much.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Settlers of Catan moved me from Chess into board games. If I mess up in Chess, it's my fault and I am punished through the rest of the game. In Settlers of Catan, if I mess up, I have many options to recover. Let's face it, Settlers is the best game out there. People complain about luck and dice and, well, that's life, suck it up. This allows experts to have an advantage, but it always allows other players to be included. Strategy, interaction, little downtime, re-playability - Settlers of Catan has it all. Don't let people complain about thinking that it has too much luck. It is good to lose sometimes, even though you are as prepared as possible. This got most of us into board games, and is available everywhere for good reason.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Don't believe the negative hype from many other BGGeeks!: this is a solid game, and it should replace all others as the introduction to modern designer board games. It's dirt-simple, and it's balanced like a dream. I rarely have games finish that aren't incredibly tight.
Don't let the group get addicted to it; pull out Alien Frontiers or Small World to get them into something slightly more advanced.
But think about the Milton Bradley games you may have grown up on... all the roll and moves and totally one-sided games of Monopoly. Then consider that you can buy Settlers at most major department stores. We live in a golden age, people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A great game to introduce to people who only know MB style games - open up a whole new world to them!  A few too many rules for non-gamers, but otherwise a game people ask for over and over again.  Because of it's popularity there are tons of workable variants on rules, plus expansions.  If a piece of the gameplay bugs you, it's easy to find a variant that fits you better.

RATING: 9
I can't praise this game enough. It has HANDS DOWN the best player interaction out of any game ever made.

People criticize it for having too much luck, but that just means they aren't very good at it. If you play well, the dice should be heavily mitigated.

The only real flaw with this game is that it's pretty easy to get completely shut out within the first few turns if someone blocks you. This can particularly happen in a 4 player game. Generally this only happens if there are some newbies at the table though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's like a mature version of Monopoly. People have complained about the die rolling, but I have no problem with it. Getting screwed by a die roll only really affects you if you only play the game once, or once in a long while. When you like a game and play it frequently, then it's no big deal if you lose 1 game to a bad die roll. 

Quite frankly, it should take more than just a couple bad die rolls to lose a winning game... people who say they lost to bad rolls probably weren't going to win anyway.

11/12/07: It's been quite some time now since I fully agreed with the above statement. After playing a lot more eurogames, I have gotten way too sick of the frustration associated with being on the 5, 6, 8, and 9 and still not getting resources all game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Owner: David M.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I want to hate this game, I really do.

But I gave it 6 stars because of how many friends I have that really enjoy this game for some reason. I'll play with them, I can manage, and even have a small amount of fun, but I usually hate this game.

Why?

It's nothing but luck with a dash of strategy.

Most games that are out now a day have a way to mitigate bad dice luck, take a look at Dead of Winter for instance.

This game however, it doesn't matter if you have settlements in good locations, bad dice rolls in a row, top with players who are specifically targeting you make this game terrible.

So why 4 stars?

It's such a basic and easy game to get into that you could teach this to a stick and it would be able to play. The simplicity and small learning curve allows for players of all ages and all types to have fun while engaging in this game.

I don't reccomend it.

Play something else, I'll even recommend Pandemic (A game I don't particularly enjoy) over this. There are so many better games out there that are casual, involve strategy, and are better executed.

This review is based off of the core set, it may be subject to change if expansions change my opinion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One of my favorite things to do in all of board gaming is to plan for and play the Monopoly card.

RATING: 7.5
You know... this is a darn good game.  I periodically get reminded of that when some of my friends (who are much bigger fans) force me to play it.  Makes for an enjoyable evening.

Best features:
1. Gaining resources on other players' turns (partial reinforcement schedule).
2. Spatial element of map. Worrying about which direction to build in, being cut-off, possible ports to utilize, etc.
3. Use of the Robber to keep the leader in check. 

Worst features:
1. Drags on too long, esp. if people haggle over trades.
2. Repetitive, without much of an "arc".

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
[COLOR=#663300][b][size=11]Settlers of Catan[/size][/b][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#663300][i]Note: My numeric ratings disregard BGG's associated verbal descriptions.[/i][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#006600][b]Comments: [/b][/COLOR]

We [b][i]always[/b][/i] play with a variant I found on an old version of Herr Teuber's site.  (I haven't seen this particular variant listed anywhere in the years since.)  As in "Poverty Is No Dishonor", a player who receives no resource on any single dice-roll receives a chip.  On his turn, if he has as many chips as he has visible points, he must trade them in to the bank for a resource of his choice.  This mitigates luck and helps less as a player's position becomes stronger.  I would not rate this game so highly if we did not play with this variant.

[COLOR=#006600][b]Why we own it: [/b][/COLOR] 

This game is comfort-food for my gamer's soul.  In all the years since discovering Settlers, I think it's fair to say that almost all of our game purchases have been in the hopes of finding other games that please us as much as Settlers.

[COLOR=#006600][b]Details:[/b][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#006600]Version played: [/COLOR]Kosmos original, Mayfair 3rd & 4th editions
[COLOR=#006600]Play History: [/COLOR]
 [COLOR=#006600] • 3 players: [/COLOR] Many times — Space is less crowded; play is more relaxed
 [COLOR=#006600] • 4 players: [/COLOR] Many times — Space is more crowded; play is more competitive
 [COLOR=#006600] • 5 players: [/COLOR] Not good
 [COLOR=#006600] • 6 players: [/COLOR] Not good

[COLOR=#006600]Instructions: [/COLOR]It's been years since I've read the rules, but I do recall feeling daunted by the separate rules and almanac booklets in the third edition.  That much printed material made the game seem more complex than it actually is.  I do appreciate the distinction between rules (for learning the game) and almanac (for clarifying details).  The fourth edition was printed in color, making the illustrations that much more helpful.
[COLOR=#006600]Learning Curve: [/COLOR] Rather involved, yet intuitive.  In only a couple of rounds, a new player will have the gist. (Best to learn from an experienced player, rather than from the rulebook.)
[COLOR=#006600]Depth: [/COLOR]Placement and expansion are quite strategic, but the social aspects dominate.
[COLOR=#006600]Luck: [/COLOR]Dice can be cruel, so initial placement is crucial.
[COLOR=#006600]Downtime: [/COLOR]Production and trading affect all players on all turns, so downtime is minimal.  Some friends have complained that the game bogs down during the trading phase. 
[COLOR=#006600]Fiddliness: [/COLOR]Set-up is a bit fiddly.
[COLOR=#006600]Components: [/COLOR]Some editions are sturdier than others, but they're all attractive.
[COLOR=#006600]Player Interaction: [/COLOR]Trading is at the heart of this game, so player interaction is high.
[COLOR=#006600]Conflict: [/COLOR]Particularly in a four-player game, room to expand can be tight.  This often means players will block one another's roads.
[COLOR=#006600]Theme: [/COLOR]The theme is rather diffuse: settling a new land, and expanding and improving one's holdings.  The mechanics represent the theme well.

[COLOR=#006600]Travel related: [/COLOR][COLOR=#CC0000]Unsuitable.[/COLOR]
 [COLOR=#006600]• Size: [/COLOR]Medium
 [COLOR=#006600]• Weight: [/COLOR]Medium
 [COLOR=#006600]• Table Required: [/COLOR]Yes
 [COLOR=#006600]• Footprint: [/COLOR][COLOR=#CC0000]Large[/COLOR]
 [COLOR=#006600]• Component Trackability: [/COLOR][COLOR=#CC0000]Poor[/COLOR]
 [COLOR=#006600]• Replaceability: [/COLOR]Excellent
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
A little thematically boring, but otherwise balanced, easy, and fun to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
This is a well done game. Balanced, takes 2 hours, and most important - it is a social game! We have fun with every couple we introduce this game to. It's nice combination of strategy, luck, ignorance ("I don't care who is first, I need sheep!"), and what I personally love - it allows different strategies. What's not to love?

Played some other games and now I really appreciate one for me the most important attribute of tSoC - it's very social, superb blend of group play and competitiveness.

RATING: 6
After 6 games over a period of 3 years, I have warmed up to Settlers, if only by a little. I think my first victory, after a history of consistently finishing last, may have had some effect on my outlook on this. 

I don't disagree with the general positive assessments of the game – it teaches casual gamers about resource collection and conversion, it's interactive and has a good sense of progress. But the fun only lasts as long as your luck is at least average. If dice rolls don't go your way early on and you end up lacking resources. Playing a trading game without the capacity the actually [i]trade[/i] due to bad luck is a horrid way of spending an hour.

RATING: 10
The modular board and trading are fantastic mechanics for replayability and player interaction. Settlers provides a nice balance between long-term planning and randomness. Its always a thrill to have your cities start producing after clawing your way forward in the early game. 

I've always preferred vanilla Settlers to the expansions. For a so-called gateway game Settlers has a LOT of rules. Adding in expansions doesn't seem like a productive way to recruit new board game enthusiasts. Why complicate a fantastic game when you can pull out any number of other games that will introduce new mechanics?

ASIDE: I also have the Korean version (카탄), which is basically the Kosmos version. However, the new plastic mold pieces were missing from the box! If only I knew who to contact. Kosmos did not reply to my email. Oh well.

RATING: 7
[57 plays] The first German game I introduced to our family and friends. Stumbled onto it somehow in 1999 years before I discovered BGG. We played this nearly to death over the course of a year or two. In recent years it has come out one or two times each year for some fun and nostalgic play. This game deserves so much credit for the popular revival of intelligent boardgames in America. I would say more but it isn't necessary as there is just such a wealth of information out there on what a great game Settlers is both for casual play and introducing non-gamers to the world beyond Monopoly.

Enjoy the social play (although it can be mildly contentious), respect the game for how much it does for newcomers, and relax - knowing the whims of the dice can sometimes take control of much of your destiny.

Most recent play 12-31-09 -- a 4 player game with Barb, Tony, and Shelly.

RATING: 7
The classic German Game. Settlers is simple, interactive, and has good replay value. It's a nice entry level game, and I even got my non-gamer inlaws to like it. The downsides are that you're at the mercy of the dice rolls and initial positioning is crucially important. In fact, the most interesting decisions are made during the setup, before the game even begins. But I do like the trading system, and the game can be fun from time to time as a lighter alternative.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Well, I've played this classic enough times now to give it a firm rating. I have to choose giving it a 3 because I really don't want to play it again. For starters, it's actually a rather long game given its very narrow decision tree. In Settlers, you roll the dice, and players with wooden blocks bordering tiles receive goods if the numbers on the tiles match the number on the dice. You also get opportunities to trade five different types of good, and an opportunity to build things. Building things gets you victory points, and the first player to ten victory points wins. Once your initial little houses or villages or whatever have been placed, it's in your best interests to focus on upgrading them to cities (which give you double goods on the correct dice rolls), build the longest road (which gives you a couple bonus points), and build more villages. But the game offers little in the way of long term strategy. You simply hope the rolls are good, try to get others to trade you what you need, and grind on. Of course, this simplicity is also what makes Settlers easy to teach, and has been a contributor to its success as a gateway game.

Settlers is an impressive game in some ways, foremost in that it's accessible. It also introduces gamers to trading, odds, and the concept of victory points. But it suffers from too many liabilities compared to the games it inspired. For me, it's kind of brain dead. I would much rather play one of Teuber's other games. There aren't many interesting decisions. Assuming a table of reasonably intelligent players, way too much of the outcome rests on initial village placement. So much so, that I now have no interest in playing. This isn't sour grapes on my part, but last game I played I had to watch my wife and one other player twiddle their thumbs for an hour because although they were still "playing" Settlers, they had no chance to win. None. Zip. It was like playing Monopoly when one player is clearly dominating, and everyone's just going through the motions until the end game condition has been met. This is a massive strike against Settlers, even more damning than the anemic play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my all time favorite games.  I love the strategy, rule set, and potential quickness of play.  When you get four good strategists together for Catan, you can have hours of fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Catan... Every time I start playing it, I wonder why I haven't played it for a while: It's so fun! But then, by the time the game is half done, I remember why. The game is sloooow, as player after player asks everyone else if they want to trade, and discussions go back and forth... And then, if you get a bad start, you really have very little chance of getting back in the game, unless the dice gods favour you. So... nah. I'll play if asked, but I won't ask.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Catan, such a classic game. This is the definitive board gamer's game. It is expandable, full of strategy and is truly the definition of next level of board game beyond the Monopolys and Sorrys of this world. I have had a great deal of game nights in which the only game we played was Catan, and while I cannot say it is my all time favourite board game, I can say it is in the top 10. The only issues Catan struggles with is how brutal bad luck can be. Running low on luck (especially in the 4 or 6 player games) can make the game painfully slow and impossible to win if you get locked in.to a corner. This doesn't happen often to skilled players, but when it does it can just make the game drag on. I also added Harbor Master to the game and kept it at 10 points to win to keep things moving smoothly towards the end of the game. Overall, Catan is a classic everyone who is a gamer should own.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the classics that often introduce new players to a style of board game outside of the traditional American "Milton Bradley" games.

The type and feel of each game is very much dominated by the board set up and the personalities of the players.  Dice can dramatically swing the outcome of the game, so using the deck of cards instead of the dice can even out the distribution and help eliminate the "bad luck" component.  Personally, I feel that luck is a part of the game and figuring your way out of a crappy situation is part of the fun.

Great game to play again and again; and a great way to bring new players into Euro-style board games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
[2012-08-25]
Fiatalkorom másik kedves játéka. Rengeteg partit lenyomtunk belőle. Hatszögletű területekből épül fel a térkép, amik különböző nyersanyagokat termelnek. A játékosok a hatszögek csúcsába házakat, az éleire utakat építenek. Céljuk minél több ház és hosszú útrendszer felhúzása. Ezekhez alapanyagokat a hatszögek termelnek, amiken egy-egy szám szerepel. A játékos körében dob két kockával és a dobás függvényében az adott hexa termel, a csúcsaiban levő házak tulajdonosának nyersanyagot. Szerencsefüggő, konfliktusos játék, abszolút nem az én stílusom, de akkoriban imádtuk.

RATING: 8
OK, this is 'THE' classic game that exemplifies european gaming. If I am introducing some one to euro games for the first time, this is the one that I use and the game that hooks 'em all.

CONS: can get a bit repetative after several plays - buy some expansions. Players get the opportunity to amass resouces and build. This is where its capacity for further play ends. Strategies are limited.

Pros: While strategies are limited, because the game is an excellent blend of luck AND strategy, the game play is still somewhat fresh with each game. This one is a classic and it should be the law that every gamer owns a copy.
:)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Absolutely brilliant design. Totally deserving of my high rating.

I have a facepalm moment whenever somebody calls this game "random".

Look, the split in 10 coin flips is unpredictable. Flip it 10,000 times, and it becomes extremely predictable. This game makes sure there are enough dice rolls for luck to even out. Note:
[b]Every player[/b] rolls dice on [b]every turn[/b]. The result affects [b]everybody[/b].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Bad: The game is just resource trading

RATING: 9
At one time I used to think this was one of the greatest games ever made.  Now I know better.  Still, though, it can be fantastic, but it really is prone to certain circumstances.  If the dice get screwy it can make for a long and arduous game. When playing with 4 there is enough opportunity to yield resources so that when your turn comes around you have something to do, but of course one player gets the bone usually and gets pinched out (although there are enough other things that they can still do to win if they don't get too worked early on in the game).  With 3 even more dependent on dice rolls to yield for you to be able to do anything that turn.  I would never give up my copy, as it still hits the table fairly often.

UPDATE: You know, the rating on this has gone all over the place depending on how jaded I am, but in reality, this is a damn fine game.  Really one of the best of its kind.

RATING: 9.5
At first, I was a little wary about Settlers, with its dice rolling mechanics and such.  However, after playing it, I have to say that Settlers is what gaming should be about - great social aspects with viable strategies and tactics.  Sure, the dice may be unfriendly and give you nothing for a while, but for the most part, the game rewards the players who plan best and make the best choices.  When I first got onto BGG, this game was still rated an 8, but now it's fallen quite a bit.  I understand this is not truly a gamer's game, but I think people are either rating it based on no plays, or only 1 or 2.  This game needs to be played - it's fun and quite addicting =)

RATING: 8
I have some reservations about my "8" rating, which stems, primarily (the reservations, not the rating) from my lack of personal success with the game. I just am not very good at it. But as I began to play it more and more, familiarizing myself with its particular idiosyncracies, I was able, at least to make some progress toward victory, albeit without really attaining one. I suspect, therefore, that my personal bias would lend itself to a lower rating, while my recognition of its simple mechanics, delicious decisions and the opinions of "respected" others elevates it to the "8" I gave it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The game that started me down the Euro path... I like it a little less each time I play it, though. I've pretty much decided that, with a few exceptions (Twilight Struggle, Backgammon), if there's dice in the box, I'm not all that interested.

The trouble with this one is that there really is no way to mitigate the dice results. In just about any game, there will be one person (usually me, if I'm playing) who grabs up a nice couple of towns next to (say) 5's and 6's only to see 8's and 9's come up every turn. Then when the dice do finally decide to smile on the right lands, look who's here! The Robber. There's no alternate strategy, no way to work around it: I'm just screwed. After a few turns with nothing to build and nothing to trade, I start looking forward to playing a different game. 

There's a lot to love about Settlers, and I do enjoy it still. It can be exciting, and the dice cards do help to even things out some. But I'll usually reach for something else when I'm looking for a good gateway game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
TRADED AWAY, THE MAN THE MYTH MATH TRADE.

A used dutch version of Settlers from 999 games. First edition. The pieces are in near mint condition and are all there. The cards are the smaller size only found in the early editions (slightly larger then the size of a zippo lighter).

The box top is slightly dished but the bottom is fully sound. The only drawback of the game is a previous owner wrote english translation on the road building and victory point cards (6 cards overall) and on the "building" legend cards, longest road, and largest army scoring cards.

Otherwise this edition is pretty cool. I'll include copies of the english rules if desired.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The game has a good deal of intertia, in terms of developing slowly and to a good deal due to initial placement. The staged nature (initial expansion through roads and ships), however, gives way to intensive expansion (upgrading cities), and that's where the pattern of the game may change quickly. The US version seems to be designed/implemented somewhat more poorly than the original German Die Siedler: the tiles are of rather weird and poorly understandable colors. The expansion potential is nice. The give away that we allow for our 7-yr old is to let him start with more cities.

RATING: 5
I have about 10 plays prior to 2005 when I started logging plays on BGG. No recollection of the dates of play. An okay game, in my opinion. I have friends who back in the day would always drag this out. It was interesting at first, but started to dread it after the fifth or so play. I'm not sure what all the hype is around it... I think there are much better games of this kind around, but I do appreciate its place in gaming history, and how it opened up Euro-style games to the masses.

RATING: 3

Sure, sure, you CAN trade resources, but nobody is ever going to unless they get a far better deal in return.

"Catan" is the new "Monopoly."

RATING: 8
Solid
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This may actually be a 6.5 for me, but it is difficult to distill my feelings on the actuall game play and design from the warm feelings it gives me as my first eurogame. It really is an excellent game in many ways, but two unfortunate parts plague it. For one, the luck factor screws it up for me. You roll two dice each turn, and these rolls give you your resources, which ultimately determine your success in the game. Of course, you place yourself on the map to best take advantage of the probabilities, but anyone who plays this game will tell you, dice sometimes have a mind of their own, and will often disregregard the probabilities. The other part that bothers me is how completely malicious the robber mechanic is - amazingly brutal for a gateway type game. 

Having said all that, I'll also say that the Traders and Barbarians expansion neatly wipes out both of these issues for me, so get the expansion if my issues with the game seem sound to you. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I was quite late to the Settlers party, and it's hard for me to have much historical appreciation for the old warhorse.  I get that it opened a lot of eyes to the Euro possibilities here in the States, but I just wasn't blown away.  I got my Gateway on playing Carcassone H&G and Ticket to Ride Europe, and that was enough to send me on my way.  By the time I got to Settlers, I was all, "Oh.  That was...nice."

The best part of this game is that it can be very social and very tense.  The worst part is when it's neither social nor tense.  The VERY WORST THING about Settlers is that you can go several rounds (or half the game) without doing anything on your turn.  Roll the dice, pass the dice.  Yuck.  Basically, I think that the set collection and building mechanics were improved upon quite a bit with the Ticket to Ride franchise.  

I'll play this when my just-getting-into-gaming friends suggest it, but I'll never offer to play it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The great classic. Probably the first game people think of nowadays after relics like Monopoly, Classic Risk and Cluedo.

+ It is satisfying to slowly expand your civilisation and see your settlers thrive.
+ Easy too learn, hard to master. 
+ The gathering of resources and using them in specific combinations to build seems mundane now, but every other game that does this partly builds on the legacy of SoC.

+/- a few of the problems with the game can be fixed with expansions. (Seafarers makes wool worth more, Fishermen makes coastal settlements less of a waste)

- The runtime can be too long if people take too long negotiating.
- It is a tad too luckheavy for my tastes. If the dice are not on your side you won't have anything to do in your turn. 

It's still part of my 'introduction trinity' with Pandemic and Ticket to Ride

RATING: N/A
One of my most favorite games. Overall set up strategy in the begining, and you can then pay as much or as little attention as you want to the game. Just buy what you have cards for, or strategically save up for items. Never feel lost or confused about what's happening in the game, or your progression compared to others. Little to no direct confrontation with other players either (i.e. little to no arguing)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is the most influential game for me in my collection, because it was my gateway game to the world of board games. 

I have great memories but in the end I have outgrown it because there are so many better games. This game has been around so long that I don't need to talk about it's strengths rather I'll point out the two things I don't like. 

The biggest problem I have with this game now is too often people are left playing catch up all game. This is due to the driving mechanism of dice giving resources. Also near the end everyone seems to go into an isolationist mode because they are now able to bank roll themselves through various means.  

This game though is the catalyst for all the games I love, I feel it was the key to the evolution for strategy board games.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Catan would be a great game if not for the games when the dice just hate you. The snowball effect means that a few unlucky rolls in the beginning can cut you out of contention. That, and players unwilling to trade can muck it up for everyone. For that reason, I prefer Seafarers: it makes sheep more valuable and opens up more strategies. I also think that the original game is a bit too crowded with four, but not quite interactive enough with three. While decisions are less frequently as interesting as I would like, Catan is a classic. At a table with casual gamers, I'm usually up for a game. In any other context, I'd opt for something else.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An old favorite, and a classic! Lots of randomness with the initial setup and, of course, all the dice. But the forward/reverse starting setup rule, and the wheeling and dealing of the trades more than make up for it. I still think it's a great game, but I just don't play it very often any more -- hence the slight drop in rating.

I wouldn't introduce euros to a total newbie with Settlers, without a lot of hand-holding: they'd get slaughtered if they didn't understand the importance of the starting set up, and trades later on as people get within striking range of the magic 10. But it's a classic for a reason! These days, though, I prefer it's descendants (e.g., Cities and Knights, America, etc.).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An old favorite, and a classic! Lots of randomness with the initial setup and, of course, all the dice. But the forward/reverse starting setup rule, and the wheeling and dealing of the trades more than make up for it. I still think it's a great game, but I just don't play it very often any more -- hence the slight drop in rating.

I wouldn't introduce euros to a total newbie with Settlers, without a lot of hand-holding: they'd get slaughtered if they didn't understand the importance of the starting set up, and trades later on as people get within striking range of the magic 10. But it's a classic for a reason! These days, though, I prefer it's descendants (e.g., Cities and Knights, America, etc.).

RATING: 6
One of the first games I ever played. I don't dislike the game, I just dislike the randomness it has. I know there are strategies, taking the key resources with the most common numbers so that you have the highest chance to do something or trade effectively... but... it's still very much luck dependent. And I don't like being screwed so much by bad dice rolls, when you can spend few turns just doing nothing, because you have no resources due to bad dice rolls and have nothing to trade to get the needed resources. I won a few times too, don't get me wrong, there is strategy involved, I have no doubt about it. I just rather play games I can influence more than this one.

RATING: 6
BestWith:4>3_not5,6 [Dice rolling, Resource Management, Building, Trading] Play 2 Variants:
Variant 1: Robber 7's are rerolled for the first 2 times round the table.
Variant 2: Food Stamps: If a player doesn't receive a resource during the Raw Material Phase, he gets a Chip. If a 7 is rolled, all players get a Chip. At any time on his turn a player may turn in chips equal to his current Victory Point total to receive a resource card of his choice. (Victory Points includes Largest Army and/or Longest Road/Trade Route, but not hidden Victory Point cards.) Spiel des Jahre 1995.

RATING: 5
The appeal is obvious: you can start playing the game within a few minutes and the luck factor allows you to just roll with the punches if you like, while there's enough strategy to give yourself a lot to think about if you'd rather go in that direction. Unfortunately things can get repetitive very quickly; the trading element which appeals to so many makes me personally want to tear my hair out as I hear "I have X; does anyone want it for Y?" over and over and over again, with later trading rounds becoming ever more ridiculous as players (usually newer ones) close in on victory and slow the game down with desperate offers and hopeless propositions. And then the robber comes along to lengthen the proceedings even further. I'd probably enjoy this somewhat with seasoned gamers who know to only trade in certain situations.

RATING: 7
Settlers used to be THE game I wanted to play. I found it endlessly fascinating and challenging. I loved how the board was different for every game. But somehow, time has taken the shine off this game for me. I've begun to find that there are games where, when if I'm losing, I spend the entire game losing without any hope of recovery. The dice just don't go my way, a resource is scarce because of the board layout and my settlement placement order, etc. Settlers really offers a limited way to win, and if you can't get there, you WON'T be able to get there, and it's frustrating. I've seen many games of Settlers completely stall. It's a good game, and maybe I've just had some bad games recently, but on the whole, I prefer Cities & Knights.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Copycat purchase.  played many times prior to joining BGG.  of course, this was the game that got us into boardgaming, just like so many others.  PROS:  variable board set up, initial placement of settlements is the highlight for me, collection of resources for road/settlement/city building/development cards, relatively short playing time.  CONS:  dice(when rolled unfavorably, there is NOTHING you can do to gather more resources), in our group the negotiation/trading does NOT work, therefore we tend to have more downtime than other groups.  OVERALL:  after our honeymoon period, the dice were the killer of our love for catan.  the excitement of the initial placement of settlements could not overcome the droughts of bad rolls or the constant 7's that plague us.  i will always remember catan fondly for introducing us to the boardgame hobby, i may play with a newbie at their insistence but i will probably never ask to play it again.  
4/18/17:  gave it to another family that will give it some love.  thank you catan for lighting the boardgaming bug in us.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This was my gateway game as an adult back into the boardgaming world.

People complain of randomness but I don't mind it at all.  To me it's part of the game. Like in Monopoly if you don't get your rolls you're not going to get Park Place and Boardwalk.

However, there is so much more here in terms of strategy and different paths to victory.

It's a great gateway game and a very fun game which is the most important point above all other criteria when evaluating a game for yourself, whether you're into strictly highly strategic games with no luck or a newbie who loves high change light games.

For me, this is a great family fun game in the Medium to Light category, played in about an hour and we always have fun playing it. There's a bit of player interaction with the robber (you can choose to gang up on the leading player to an extent), and trading cards with others, creating longest road or largest army and stealing the points from the current leader, or blocking opponents paths with your roads.

Haven't had a chance to add the expansions which I think would allow one to tailor the game and make it even better for them and longer.

As you can tell from the way it exploded in North America as a gateway game it appeals to a higher percentage of the population and non-gaming people than most other games. Some people just don't want or can't handle too complicated and strategic a game.  They want it medium/light for a reason - to relax and have fun and Catan hits the spot extremely well!

I'll always remember it as the game that got me back in...and Love It!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This gets to the table more than it ought, but it's fast, light and easy access.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great gateway game, but it suffers in repeat playings. While who wins ultimately depends on die rolls, the game always feels more or less determined when everyone has 3 settlements. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A very, very fun game.  I have both the travel and regular edition.  The regular game is so much fun, always random and new, and, no matter how likely your starting spots should gather resources, they don't have to.  We played a long game of 4 people in which a 6 was only rolled twice.  Twelve popped up 6 times, 2 at least 3.  Cest la vie!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dull.  I have played too many games where one person ends up with a hand full of nothing or resources nobody wants and then proceeds to sit there miserably for the majority of the game.  Often, I have been that person.  Even though I know how to play the odds, it sometimes happens that an 8 never rolls in a game while an 11 will roll 5 times in a row.  You can't control that and half the time you can't even mitigate it.

I don't really think Settlers is necessarily a bad game, but the dice mechanic makes it so.  I have always contended that trying a new mechanic, such as card drafting or something else would make the game quite fun.  Hell, I rather enjoy Settlers of America: Trails to Rails in spite of the dice rolling because the gold coin mechanic and the sheer number of ways you can DO things with your resources really helps to avoid the rut that Settlers can induce.

EDIT: my opinion of Settlers has improved. I now consistently do well and can appreciate the game despite the age of the design. I've still played it too much to enjoy it more than a 7, though.

RATING: 10
This is the game that got me really into Eurogames back in '96. I had a (very) small selection of Euros at that time, but was mostly playing Magic and Warhammer FRP. Settlers and the Settlers card game were the games that changed it all. But even if another game had been my introduction, I still would appreciate Settlers for what it is: an instant timeless classic, that got a whole generation back to the playing table. I don't play it as regurarly anymore (certainly not the base game only), but it's always a blast when I do. I'm really looking forward to play this with my girls one day.

RATING: 9
This game is ancient but we play it on the local game night when everyone has had a hard week and just wants a relaxing game. The game is easy to play so conversation flows as you play it. It is just a feel good game. 

If you are playing a game like Caverna - a popular favourite at the game group - then everyone is thinking and the conversation pretty much goes out the window until the end.

As a family game Settlers (sorry, "Catan") is fantastic. I am a bit disappointed I had to splash out so much to get 5 player extension. This is why I have held off getting seafarers expansion because it is expensive with the 5 player extension.

RATING: 9
I can not count how many times I have played this game at this point. Well over a hundred I'm sure counting the times I've played with the seafarers and cities and knights expansions. Not to mention star trek catan as well.
Some people grow tired of this game after a while and others like myself just don't. Either way, most people will end up playing this game many times because it holds a very high replay value.
It's strategic enough to offer a challenge for more seasoned gamers but easy enough to teach the base game in just a few minutes.
The expansions also hold great additional content if you find yourself looking for more variation. And the cities and knights expansion makes the game far more intricate.
This will always be a game that I have in my collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Here we have the "Monopoly" of the Modern Age of board games - roll the dice, possibly collect some resources, negotiate with the other players, perhaps build a house or two, and move along to the next player.  I hesitate to speak negatively about a game that is of such importance to the world of board games, and that is indeed my wife's personal favourite board game.  After all, it's probably not an exaggeration to state that Settlers was largely responsible for the rapid rise in popularity of German games, as well as for introducing, or at least re-introducing, many of us to the hobby of gaming.  But that being said, I was never very impressed with the game.  Sure, it has some fun elements of gathering resources and spending them to expand your settlements, but the fact that you are so much at the mercy of rolls of the dice really takes away the fun of it (unless you have the "Event Card" expansion).  Add to that the fact that a player can get blocked in right from the beginning of the game (I've played a few games where I sat and did very little all game, watching helplessly as other players expanded across the board), and you can end up with a pretty frustrating playing experience.  (For proof that it is not the fact that I often do poorly at this game that influences my decision to give it a poor rating, see my reviews of "Cleopatra and the Society of Architects", and "Fury of Dracula".)  When played with the "Seafarers" and "Cities and Knights" expansions my rating goes up to a 6/10, even though the already tedious set-up and play time becomes painfully long.  However, you can save yourself the trouble and expense of purchasing all the expansions and just get "The Settlers of the Stone Age", which in my mind is a much more fun stand-alone version.  Game design: 3/5  Personal enjoyment: 2/5  Total: 5/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
The classic Euro Gateway game.  If you are one of the 5 people on the planet who hasn't played this game you really should.  It has all the features I really like in a game: a modular board, meaningful player interaction, resource management, a decent play time (about 1 hour) and moderately challenging tactical choices.  The down side is that luck can figure somewhat prominently in the game and players can make very foolish trading decisions with other players that ends up hurting you; however, that just means you have to do some table talking and stronger negotiating.  This adds in some interesting player interaction that often gets overlooked by people who don't like this game.  It's not a perfect game of course, but I think it is a good classic game that is still the gateway of choice for many.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[Mayfair third edition w/ pre-2007 adapter kit] {Catan, Civilization, gateway; trading, modular-board, development, dice-rolling, resource management; optimal 3p} Settlers of Catan is a decent family game with a strong development theme. It is fun and exciting. The game flow is very smooth and has less down time. It's not a heavy strategy game but it provides many tactical options. It is of good player interaction from the trading, robber and the competition of roads. The dice rolling, though luck-driven, adds excitement to the game.

It has several novel mechanics - dynamic board, rolls for production, etc, which have been re-used in many other games.

Beginners' setup should be used when introducing this game to your friends. No matter how you remind them, they will easily overlook the importance of initial placement of settlements and priority of resources at different stages of the game. They will then feel desperate that they are blocked from the game.

If you're going to play regular Catan, at least add Cities & Knights, which adds some more good decisions and available routes to resources (e.g. bonus cards).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game that re-started it all for me!!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a great game for all those people out there who think Risk and Monopoly are good games. It will show them the error of their ways and open their eyes to the beauty of the non-department store games. Settlers is colorful, easy to learn, and most importantly; random. The pieces are layed down in random fashion, then the number tiles and ports are randomly applied. Players then choose their starting positions and begin rolling the dice. The game has some minor balance issues, but the only great fault I have found, is that if a player has a run of bad luck early in the game it can leave them hopelessly behind, and trod upon by their fellow gamers. Less mature gamers often want to give up part way through when it is clear they are not going to win. The Seafarers expansion was weak, but the Cities and Knights expansion, while a bit complex, is a nice addition once the original has lost some luster. Not my favorite game, but it will have a place near the top of my game stack for many years to come.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
So much in the game is based on lucky rolls or draws. Not enough interesting decisions for me.

RATING: 7

Da oltre 15 anni milioni di persone in tutto il mondo competono commerciando e costruendo nel classico gioco creato da Klaus Teuber. E il numero dei fan è sempre in aumento!

CATAN ...

... è il nome che tu e i tuoi compagni avete dato all’isola che avete scoperto. Voi siete i suoi primi abitanti.

Costruite insediamenti, poi strade. Scambiando materie prime, i villaggi diventano presto città.

Talvolta c’è argilla in abbondanza, altre volte minerali. Il baratto apre nuove possibilità per te,

ma anche per i tuoi avversari.

Ma lo spazio già scarseggia sull’isola – e una lotta per la supremazia, la terra e le risorse comincia.

Alla fine è presto chiaro – ci può essere solo un Signore di CATAN. Vuoi essere tu il colono più influente?

Preparati alla sfida!

RATING: 2
This is a game that too often then not revolves around the dice/luck element and not enough about tactics. Every game I've played of this has involved someone losing badly through no fault of their own (8's being rolled when they needed 6's)

Played again and once again someone had a load of early luck and easily won the game with it's snowball affect. 3's and 11's being rolled more than 8's. Also only about three times was a 4 rolled in the entire game.

Latest play confirms all that I've said above and more, this time I had 10's and they only appeared 3 times in the entire game, the 4's must have been closer to 20 times. Needless to say the player who only gained resources on a 3,4,5 or 11 original and never throughout the game gained off a 6 or 8 won easily 12pts to 4pts to 4pts. His win was of course purely down to the phenomenal dice rolls.

A total luck fest, a game seriously flawed that allows players to sit there doing nothing for 15 minutes at a time through no fault of their own

RATING: 10
A venerable classic to some people, to me it’s a relatively recently discovered game that led to many other new games.

Simple, involving, different each play. A game where luck is a virtue, forcing trading, attention to hand-limits and use (& defence against) the blocking robber.

A gateway game that’s a wonderful destination in its own right.

While the basic game is a 10, almost every expansion adds complexity or downtime, and reduces the rating.

RATING: 7
Just about the perfect gateway game. The rules are easy to explain and pick up and the dice mechanic and trading is a great equaliser for newbie players against experienced. After many plays I am no closer to hitting on a perfect, winning strategy because the mix of resources is different every time and the interaction of the various mechanics means there are very few "cut and dried" decisions. It's also a very sociable game with lots of talking and little downtime or brain burning. A classic.

RATING: 6
OK game. If I'm looking for a trading game I'd prefer to play Chinatown, but this game does have some interesting elements.

Must play with the "Harbor Master" (A settlement on a harbour is worth 1 "harbour point". A city on a harbour is worth 2 "harbour points". The first player to reach 3 harbour points gets the "Harbour Master" card and the 2 VP that go with it. A player who achieves more harbour points than the current Harbour Master takes the card and becomes the new Harbour Master.) and play to 11 VP to balance the game out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game single-handedly revived my interest in playing games. It's so simple yet so complex at the same time. It reminds me of diplomacy in this manner. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I used to really like this game, and have played it dozens and dozens and dozens of times. Usually it is a lot of fun, and can be pretty exciting with the right people. However, it can also get really frustrating, and I have seen some people get pretty mad when their road gets cut off (or something equally trivial). 

I think my rating has also been skewed some by the "this is a 'really light, introductory game' to the game boarding world, and thus it doesn't deserve a high rating" mentality.

In any case, I have only played it once in the last two years. Whether it is because of how I personally feel, or how those who play with me feel, this does need to be reflected in the rating I give.

RATING: 7
After Monopoly and Risk, Catan is possibly the most well known board game. The gateway game for many of today's boardgamers, Catan is iconic. And while Catan is an excellent gateway game, it's just that, a gateway game. Most board game players will eventually grow tired of Catan and move on to more complex and newer games. But Catan retains a spot on their game shelf, fondly reminding the owner of past games with friends. We feel indebted somehow to the game, a first love with a special place in our hearts. And when it's time to introduce someone new to board games beyond Monopoly and Risk, Catan waits on the shelf - smooth, simple, easy to teach - ready to welcome a new gamer to the hobby.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Expect to buy the 5-6 player expansion along with this game as a requirement.

RATING: 7
We normally play with Cities and Knights and Seafarers.  We build the normal central island, surrounded by a ring of water, surround by 4 sets of 3 hex islands face down.  The outer islands are 2 of each resource and 2 gold mines and are revealed when a ship is placed next to the one.  The 'Intrigue' card may be used to move the pirate.  You need 15 points to win.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Light resource/civilisation game let down by a few too many flaws. Players place settlements adjoining different types of resource, which contain numbers. If the number is rolled, the players gain resources, which in turn allows them to develop their civilisation (upgrade settlements to cities, build roads, acquire development cards etc), which will often gain them victory points, the first to 10 winning the game. The game is simple and seems to strike a chord with players new to gaming but beyond that there are too many flaws that will keep seasoned players away. The main problem arises from there being far too much luck involved with the rolling of dice for resource production, an element you have absolutely no control over and which drives the game. It can become quite galling to place a settlement next to a hex containing a number with a high probability of being rolled only for it never to appear (or only when the robber has been placed on it). For me, this game can become far too frustrating on too many occasions to be enjoyable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Folks

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is the epitome of streamlining and elegance.

The rules are so simple and so clearly comprised on a few cards, yet you can do vastly different things, you win on only 10 victory points, get some "haha" moments against your opponents that feel like your master strategy being executed but still maintain a non-gamer friendly level of luck and have no real downtime on your opponents turns as you also get resources and look what they do.

Compared to e.g. Stone Age, this truly is a non-gamers game.

So, why no perfect 10 rating? 
After years I just grew a bit out of the simple base mechanics, the luck factor is too large for my taste and the game does not bring forth that much exitement for me anymore. Still gladly playing it though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pros:  
+ Good and simple game to play
+ Good for board game beginners
+ Decent mechanics ( Ex. Robbers to keep hoarders/monopoly of a single resource in check)
+ Good for competitive people
+ Quality components and have some waterproof ability (spilled beer on it and cardboard only got a little wet on sides)
+ Decent Strategy as there are many ways to win
+ Fun to play with many people
+ Playing time is moderate, not too long and not too short.

Cons:
- Luck of the dice roll
- Only max four players.  need to get expansions for 5-6 players
- Might get hurt in competitive game (slap on wrist when opponents know you are monopolizing a resource) :/
- Maybe too much downtime:  Ex. Wish there is a timer on your actions when a player has 32 card resources on their hand and trying to figure out how to use them best
- Could cost a bit w/ 5-6 (maybe around 40-50 bucks).  Better strategy games out there for that kind of cost.
- Wouldn't be great to play multiple times in the same day.
- Many expansions.  Could cost a lot more for certain people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Resource cards size is 51*79 mm.

RATING: 7
This was a good one.  I must admit, it was a little disappointing to play though.  I think the disappointment came because of all the hype about this game and how great it was.  I thought it would be much better than it was. It just felt like it was missing something but maybe it was the fact that I didn't see what all the hype was about. With that being said, I still felt like it was an enjoyable game.  If the hype factor wasn't included, I may have enjoyed it more.  There were lots of decisions to make and several ways to win.  Everybody was in the game to the end.  The game is worth a decent rating because it is a good game.  It is not worth the "Cult-like" reaction that I see so much on the site and elsewhere.  Not the best Eurosnoot out there and really doesn't see the table of my gaming group more than once every few months.

RATING: 9
"blessed are the flexible, for they will not be broken"
i really like tactical games that force you to modify your strategy during the game. this game is good for those who can best capitalize on whatever cards they have, good or bad. some say this is one of those "gamers games" but i can get almost anyone to play. once they play, they like it. slight element of luck allows even weak players to win one every so often. i usually play with 4 people total. once i played with 2, didn't like it. it will be a long time till i'm sick of this one. also get the computer version at www.the-underdogs.org

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
So done with this game, see comments for star trek catan. there are some great things this game did, but a number of bad design choices ruin this. Really if the game took about 30-45 min. it would be really good, I cant devote 2 hrs plus to this. Last game took 2.5 hrs; 2.9.17 (andrews place)

Let me also add to the star trek comments: the Longest Road and most military are stoopid, and obviously tacked on mechanics that dont add anything to the theme. Drawing cards hoping for an army is about as unimaginative and as far from developing an army as anything. And when was building a long road a strategy? OK maybe the Burma road, but modern thinking even questions that strategy. So dumb.

The tedious trading mechanic is one of several irksome features. It's actually a very good mechanic of generating production with a randon iterative proces (rolling dice), so it's worth checking out. But it takes too long for what it is and that is perhaps the only reason I rate it this low, if this could play in 45 minutes, it would probably be at least a 6 or 7.  Too many scoring systems detract from any pretence of "classic" feel. Monopoly with proper house rules, that rein in the time, is better. ALso dont like the placement strategy of roads and cities as this seems too simplistic. The new version of settling america looks more sophisticated and better. (original comments 4.20.13; rated 6 in june '14))

This game is a trusted friend. Highly recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My wife and I used to love this game, but the enjoyment tapered off fast. First, it was the sense of futility that we got when we realized that our initial settlement placements had been sub-par; we'd spend the rest of the game as non-contenders, having no fun. Then it was the addition of Cities & Knights, which did nothing to mitigate the value of initial city placement, ramped up the 'take that' factor with barbarian attacks and knight fights, and lengthened the whole, lousy experience by at least an hour.

I've played once with Seafarers since then, and found that, due to the increased value that having a settlement on the shore gives you, it felt a little less predetermined. More plays are needed to decide if I need to move Settlers' rating back up or not.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun little game.  Getting the right combination of resources for trading and building is the key.  Unfortunately, there's just enough luck with getting your numbers to come up, and not rolling 7s when your hand is large, to be problematic.  Inevitably someone gets the short end of the stick, and just can't seem to get resources, or gets his resources robbed.  Even just drawing a victory point card instead of "another militia" can make the difference.  It's a design decision for sure, but it's a tad more variance than I like.
Nonetheless, playing it occasionally, and still enjoying this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Catan is the gateway game that it's touted to be because it cohesively has a little of everything: dice rolling as the bridge from the classic family games of old, Euro-style resources, route building, hand management, a modular board consisting of hex tiles, and even a social aspect via trading. And light enough to teach in just a few minutes and play in about an hour. I've never had a game of Catan last two hours, and most games with veterans finish in under one.

Player Count 6 (with 5-6 expansion)

RATING: N/A
German edition with SdJ
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is hailed as the new Monopoly, not because of its gameplay, but because of its incredible mass adoption by big retail chain stores.  It is the poster child for bringing a new generation into the world of board games.  It in large part represents a renaissance of the market, and for that reason this game has transcended the significance of its own gameplay.  

If you play the game with all of that cultural importance aside, I think that is best.  You play the role of a settler, building settlements, cities, and roads across the landscape. The twist and main meat of the game is that you can strike deals with other players to get vital resources for your colonies to expand.  Since I have played the heck out of this game, I'm not too keen on playing it anymore.  I think the game is excellent, but at this point I think it has largely been outclassed by newer and more interesting games.  There's too much out there to choose from for this to be THE game you play first as an introduction to the world of board games.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This was the gateway into "hobbyist" games for me and many others. While the element of random chance can prove frustrating at times, it does keep things interesting, and trading, the heart and soul of the game, is fast-paced and often hilarious.

RATING: 8
A true classic. I find it the best game to introduce to newbies. It's interactive, it's a rather luck-driven (which is a good and bad thing), and it has excellent yet simple concepts. Even playing the 2-player variant is fun.

2017-12-25: It's been almost 10 years since I reviewed this game. In all honesty, I haven't been this game in years. But it still holds a special place in my heart, and I have not found a game with so much tension and cut-throat negotiations, even though it is very random.

I'm still downgrading this from a 10->8 though, simply because it's not something I'd play given the choice.

RATING: 9

Nearly 8 year old son liked to collect soldiers to have the largest army so that was his tactics. I did win the game tho so that will ensure another game or two :b

Second game and I like it a lot more, DS ( now aged 8 ) won. His tactic of buying the Development cards a lot of the time is not such a bad idea!!

Update: Sept 2007, the three of us, dh, ds age 8 and myself are loving this game so have upped the rating from 6 to a 9

RATING: 5
My rating is now a weighted average: just Catan, 4; +Seafarers with a fixed scenario, 6; +Seafarers, exploring (flipping or drawing new tiles), 8; +Seafarers +5/6 expansions, exploring to a higher ending score (~20 points, not necessarily with 5/6 people), 9.

To my mind, the "real" game is Settlers plus Seafarers plus both 5&6 player expansions played on a big random map. This is just way too expensive for what is a light weight Euro.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.5
I really wanted to like this game, but in the end I decided this type of game is not to my style.  Basically, it is roll and trade.  The dice introduces both a (large) element of luck in the game, as well as strategy because of the different probabilities of rolling a particular number when two dice are rolled.  Unfortunately, the only thing that this game has going for it is the trading aspect-- if you dislike trading games (as I do), then you won't like this game.  I love trading when it is one element of a greater game, but not when it is, essentially, the whole game.

RATING: 10
What can I say that so many have not already said of this hit.

Hate the Robber.

Lastly, THIS game at mere mention of playing it has my kids off their computers, putting their tablets down, and other forms of passive entertainment away.   It's a real family together time game, major success.

RATING: 10
House rule: Lakes are Volcanic Atoles. If double 1s or double 6s are rolled, roll again. If double 1s or 6s are rolled again, the Volcano erupts and all items touching the lake are removed from the board and returned to the player.

RATING: 7
I kinda think it was the world’s greatest gateway game. I have the same cliches about blowing Monopoly and Risk out of my personal waters. I still think that for non-gamers this can still be the ‘I didn’t know it could be like this’ moment that brings them to our side. But, after about 50 plays, including (especially) the app, it can be super frustrating that it relies on dice, the more normally distributed 2d6 notwithstanding. So now, I won’t play it unless some wide eyed newbie just heard about it and wants to play. After all those plays, I think that’s about all you should expect from a game - this one goes in the hall of fame.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Still enjoyable after all these years. The standard four player game is my favorite. Nice blend of player interaction (trading) with resource management. I find it amazing that the dice rolling alone turns some people off.

Here's a nice quip about the game:

"You don't like the dice? Go do Sudoku puzzles and cram your statistics textbook up your ass. The dice make the game dramatic, variable, and it forces players to adapt and adjust throughout the game. With trading, you are _never_ screwed unless you're one of those shrewish gamers who's afraid to speak up at the table to get what you want. Without a doubt, one of the greatest games ever published and a timeless classic." -- crackedlcd81
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Settlers of Catan is the first German game that I ever played, and it has definitely led to an addiction.  I know a lot of people have played Settlers to the point of burn-out, but I am no where near that point yet.  I love the interaction of the trading phases, playing the seemingly fickle bell curve (Another six??? How's about an eight every once in a while??), and beating an opponent in a race to a crucial intersection.  We are still developing theories about the relative importance of each commodity (Good ol' rock, nothing beats rock), discussing whether nines are actually better than eights due to the robber effect, and making lots of sheep jokes.  To put it simply, Settlers is a lot of fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
New

My personal Gateway Game.

Although more strategic than most games that are called "Gateways", Catan is a game that is easily taught and you can start playing quickly (even though you don't know what you are doing yet.)

We have worn out one set of cards. We don't play it as much which is sad.

Just a great game.

Oversaturation to the point where people are tired of seeing CATAN, you are deceiving yourself if you can't see the quality of this game.

RATING: 7
My group has a great time playing Settlers of Catan. What makes the game fun for my group is the negociation aspect. Our trades are generally pretty creative. We trade current and future resources, and agreements not to steal resources. We also have a fun time convincing the person using the robber not to steal from us. If my group wasn't a high interaction group this game would definatley fall a minium of 1 points on my ratings.Most of our stradegy comes at the begining of the game as we take turns placing the terrain tiles and the numbers on those tiles individually. Our games runs from 2=2 and 1/2 hours.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
It's an ok game, but I'm not much a fan for a few reasons:

1) the initial settlement placements are by far the biggest influence on the final outcome, making the rest of the game sometimes feel like a slog,

2) luck of the dice and card draws become too much of a boom and bust for the players, becoming another major factor on the final outcome,

3) there's inconsistent capacity for player agency in that a player who suffers from a bad run of dice rolls really can't do anything while a player who benefits from a good run can build an insurmountable position,

4) 90 minutes is simply too long for a strategy game that's more about luck than player decisions.

I'd like to try it with Cities & Knights to see if that wins me over.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

5th ed
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
To be clear, my 8 stars is trying to be objective... if I'm being honest, I'd love to never play this game and you'd need to brow-beat me to get me to at this point... But that because I've played it SO many times because it is just SO good. It's a genre-breaker and a classic for a reason, it's a brilliantly designed game fit for causals or hardcore tacticians, total nerds or family game night with grandparents and nieces; it's simple, quick, and bland enough to not intimidate anyone, while complex enough to please real gamers. It's only redundancy and the fact recent games have filled the niche better that have this collecting dust on the shelf at this point... it definitely covered it's price tag in the day.
My one big piece of advice? Avoid the exapnsions. Like the plague. It's like how various "Battle chess" rules alterations to the namesake can't every live up to the original... the game is already in a good place tactically... Adding elements is supurfluous, and it makes it so you aren't getting better at Catan, you're getting better at screwy fake Catan. Being a grand-master chess player is impressive, nobody cares how you'd rank nationally in like Fantasy Chess or whatever... just get good at the game itself (or better yet, branch out to its successors... I suggest Machi Koro if you want something else outsider approachable, or Valeria Card Kingdoms if you want something deeper and nerdier.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I like this game alot but with all the newer games out there it's hard to get this one on the table.

RATING: 8

But people forget, the reason those tropes exist is because of LOTR. Catan is no different for the BG world.

RATING: 9
An increadibly balanced game that suffers slightly from its random nature. At the same time, the random aspects keep the game interesting, ensuring that no two games are ever exactly the same and allowing new players a chance to compete with the more experienced. Settlers is a fantastic "2nd step" for new players that have tired of A Ticket to Ride and Carcassonne and are ready to try something new.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Culled - First wave; Gifted to Kelly

Why we culled it: Catan remains a wonderful game that deserves a place on "gateway game hall of fame" lists everywhere. We've played it a lot and have enjoyed it. Catan does a lot of things which have been done better in the two decades it took for the hobby to explode, and we found that we have discovered even better games to bring new friends into the fold. Catan sat for a long time, and I realized the best thing I could do with it was to send it to a group that was still just scratching the surface of the system. It continues to expose people to this wonderful hobby, and I'll happily join a game when it hits the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.8

RATING: 7.5
I have nothing to say about this that hasn't been said.

It is a quality game and I like to play it.




Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 1
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 1
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 2
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 3


Overall - 1
