=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I like Catan, but I'm just not super excited about playing it because there are so many things I'd rather play. The chance of the dice rolling doesn't bother me in and of itself so much as the fact that really the whole game boils down to that, it seems. I also wish there was more meat in the diplomacy aspects and more potential for direct competition and conflict. The Cities & Knights expansion is a must.

That said, it's a good game and a lot of fun and I enjoy the social aspect of trading. I also like that it has such broad appeal. If everyone and their uncle didn't own a copy, I might want to own it more badly. Maybe some day.

In the end, I find myself neither wanting to sing Catan's praises (the people who are like OMG, CATAN IS THE BEST/ONLY BOARD GAME), but nor do I totally get all the hate it gets from the pretentious board-game elitists.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
At one time, no gaming get together was complete for my group without yet another game of Settlers (with expansions). Such was the enthusiasm that they readily embraced any new add-on and quirks and took them to their hearts, leaving me increasingly baffled, as the full house Settlers with everything added in is barely less complicated and slower than allegedly 'difficult' games that they constantly shied away from!

However, once everyone had had at least one game where they were squeezed into a tiny area of the board, with no hope of winning and some hours to go, the magic well and truly wore off.

It's a nice little game for 5, poor for 6 and too limited for 4 or fewer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I played dozens of unlogged games of this before finding BGG, including quite a few when revisiting the game in the last quarter of 2006.  A great gateway game that is still fun to play.  I picked up [gameid=1137] and [gameid=926], but my interest has waned some and I haven't played any of those expansions (I traded [gameid=926] without giving it a go).  This will still get play every once in a while, but I'm not sure if it has a third wind now that I've plunged headlong into gaming.

RATING: 10
The game mechanics work together in perfect harmony, the game has variable lengths of play per play and most important it's fun and emersive.

A moment of clarity sprung itself on me as I found myself openly and feverishly bartering for the attention and trade of two sheep for one wood over a competitors bid of two ore for one wood...........great stuff, I dived straight back in of course. 

My favourite game of all time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The historically quintessential German gateway game, and also the one game I find in the hands of people who have heard of little more than Monopoly.  It was the first game I bought when I decided to get serious about collecting German-style games, but I'm getting a bit worn out on it as I get deeper into the territory. 
 
9-2-08: Have to move this down to a 6.  I appreciate what this game has accomplished, but I've thought about trading my copy and would, were it not for the sake of respect, nostalgia, and some degree of hope that I'll find some resurgence in interest through one of the expansions, or the right group, or what have you.  As it is, can't think of a time when I wanted to pull it out even for old time's sake, and I'll even try to avoid playing it.  That probably means I should rate it a 4.  I'm not one to rag on a game just because it's popular, so that's not "it."  I think, at the risk of being inconsistent, it's ultimately the dice that do me in on this one.  I generally don't mind games which rely so heavily on dice rolling, but this is one that can really make me look at my watch if lady luck is canoodling with one of my rivals--there seems to be too little I can do in too long of a game.  

12-24-07: Played the game again recently on Xbox Live.  Maybe it's the extra options, the built-in session report, the detailed statistics tracking, or the sense of playing with an  animated version of the collector's edition, but I give it an extra point over the base board game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I enjoy this game, but I think the randomness just strikes me the wrong way.  I like randomness in my games, but the particular interaction between luck and skill in Settlers can just be frustrating.  I mean, it's been three turns since I've seen a new resource, and, oh look another 7!

I really like the variant where you reroll 7's for the first round.

Honestly just playing this sparingly enough makes it a better game :)

RATING: 9

I highly recommend getting this for anyone looking to get into the more advanced board games but don't want to dive into the big expensive monsters quite yet.  

Instruction manual is easy to read and to look up things.  Also the useful website where they had game tutorials on how to play helped a ton.  I was able to pick up the game in one night.  Fairly simple game but still very strategic

RATING: 7
This baby got me into board gaming. I played around 500 games of this before I realised that maybe I should see if there are other similar games out there :)

I strongly recommend the Cities and Knights expansion. Once you've figured out the few basic strategies of this it basically comes down to the dice - Cities and Knights opens up multiple paths to victory, and the game actually becomes quite strategic. Of course it is always gonna come down to die roll still, but I think it's a vast improvement if you don't mind more complexity. 

The rating is a bit down partially cause I just don't play it anymore since I've almost seen every possible because the newer games today, having improved upon this, scenario played out multiple times, also partially are just so amazing and well made that I have to rate this lower than those.

"So I hear you like board games. What games are your favorites?"

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is the game that got me to love board games.   After this game gatewayed me to other designer games the fire to play has diminished severely.  Fun for a social environment, or if used as a gateway game.  Repeated playings will show the few number of real decisions for a player in the course of an hour.  I now think of it more as a party game,  and compare it to Apples to Apples and Scattergories.   This game holds its own.  Don't mess with the expansions or other "Things of Catan".  This is the gem.

The modular board and random placement of chits does not infuse a ton of replayability.  The strategies are the same, it just toggles the strength of them slightly.  The reason I probably over rank it based on my current desire to play it is with new players its way too slow for what the game has to offer, and with players who can get at this quickly there are games I enjoy more I'd rather be playing.  With that being said,  with a couple of cold ones the pacing of a snail does lead to a nice casual very social experience so I can't imagine ever turning down a game of vanilla settlers.

I gave it a whirl after it's been ages sinces I've fired this up.  It is still a good game, but not one of my favorites.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Terrific game that plays well with serious gamers and light gamers.  It's only flaw is that dice can sometimes shape the game too much with luck.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Settlers was for me, like many others I'm sure, THE gateway game, and will always hold a very special place in my heart.  I actually learned Settlers in 10th grade, every week I would go to a club at Cornell University where a bunch of the college students gathered to play games, almost exclusively Magic: The Gathering. I had been going for a couple years and would continue going for a couple more years, and throughout most of that time I mostly just played/traded Magic, spending far too much money in the process.  One fateful evening, I looked over and saw people playing this rather odd boardgame. Up until that point in my life I'd only played Monopoly, Risk, Life, Backgammon, etc. It looked so strange and interesting, I actually tore myself away from Magic for a few moments to watch. I became so engrossed that I watched the entire game. In fact, up until last year I'd never even read the rule book for Settlers, I simply learned by watching that game very closely. So throughout the years I started to play Settlers from time to time at that club at Cornell.  Eventually I even bought my own copy, which I found at the local comic book store; I bought the old brown Mayfair edition.  And I played this, and I played it some more, actually I played it for years and years.  All the time never stopping to realize that there might be more games out there like this one.  I loved Settlers, but somehow it didn't occur to me that there were other games of the same or similar ilk.  Fast forward a bit, I move to Chicago and go to college, I meet a couple good friends, and show them Settlers, the three of us end up playing Settlers almost every week together, and all this time, never think that there could be any other games out there I should be checking out.  So then I leave the country to study abroad, and while I'm away one of the friends I'd been playing Settlers with tells me about this board game fair on Navy Pier in Chicago and how he found out about and saw all these neat board games somewhat like Settlers but different and great, and they even had a giant life-size 3D version of Settlers.  I'm very jealous, but my interest is piqued.  Shortly thereafter, that same friend goes to California to visit someone, and comes back raving about this incredible game called Carcassonne that he was introduced to and that I just have to play. I'm like Carca-what?  He's like, you haven't heard of it?  I thought you were all into board games, isn't that your thing? And I'm like, uhh, no, I like Settlers, but haven't really ever played any other good games.  Anyway, I blame it all on him (or rather I thank him profusely) because from that point on I decided that maybe board games should be my thing, so I got Carcassonne shortly thereafter, played it, and fell in love with it.  My collection began to grow very quickly indeed, and now I'm as addicted as ever.  So it was Settlers that I played first, and Settlers will probably always be the game that I played most, I still can't believe it didn't occur to me for so long to see if there were more games I might like.

Purchased: Date unknown
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I have played this a lot and still enjoy it.  Has a fair amount of luck, but that is what makes it fun!  The roll of the dice affects everyone and is met by cheers and groans each turn!  I also think that there is a lot more strategy and skill involved than many people give it credit for.  If you play board games to have fun with your friends and family, then you should check out this game.  When I play with my family I stick it to my brother by blocking his roads and trading tough, but I'm nice to my mom by giving her what she needs in trades.  This is one of the few games where you can be both nice and mean, which makes it suitable for most any mix of people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
At first this game was, in my mind, a 10 Perfect Score.
But after hundreds of games in person and on the mobile app you begin to realize that the game is basically 75-80% luck and the strategy really relies on the 1st move of the game. 

After the 1st and 2nd move you basically watch as the game plays you. 

Still a great game though but look for even better games.

RATING: 8
Great game. A nice hand management game with strategy as a major component. Very easy to learn and teach. Secure resource tiles by placing settlement or cities via roads and use those resources to build more cities and settlements, can also buy economic cards to in crease resources or even an army. Enough depth to keep comming back to this game for hardcore gamers and not to complicated for the new or casual gamer.

RATING: 7
One of the games that introduced our group to the wonder of games beyond the Game of Life and Monopoly this is always a fun game that incorporates resource management and negotiation skills! The chance factor comes in the rolling of two dice for resource production, other than that the most crucial factor is deciding where to start. This game can only really get unfair if in a custom game the hexes and counters favour one/two people and screw the rest over. Usually a fun game it always ends up with one person shut out and feeling dissatisifed therefore I would also like to see a variant of random/forced trading to even things out.

RATING: 9
I'm new to Eurogames and I readily admit to loving this one. I've only played a handful of games, but it feels well-balanced to me, if not a bit iconography-challenged. (I'm sure others have ranted about the ore/brick color schemes.)

I'm in the honeymoon phase where I will enlist nearly anyone to play with me. I have not, however, endeavored to teach it to my kids yet (currently ages 7 and 5). They are swimming in new eurogames, and I would like them to enjoy the ones they're currently playing for a while longer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is a great game system and an essential for any collection.  20 years after its release, it is still a fantastic gateway game, and I often have friends that don't play board games asking to play.  There is a reason why this game has been able to break in to the American market when so many others have failed; it implements mechanics that most haven't seen in games (resource management, trading, engine building) in an extremely elegant and simple way.  The game is perhaps too simple and luck-reliant to have longevity for a lot of hobby gamers (the expansions do help with this problem), but it is worthy of the popularity that it has.

RATING: 8
This is the original board game I played that drew me away from games like "Skip-bo", and "Monopoly".  I always loved board games, but these games drive my obsession.  The level of strategy offered is so much greater than games I grew up with, and this was the catalyst.  However, it's mechanics are a little weak compared to some of the others.  Mainly, you can still lose to the dice, rather than lose to the opponent.  And while I don't dare rate this game any lower than an 8, it really has fallen out to just a good game that I like to play.

RATING: 8.5
A great game that I often use as a gateway to get my friends involved in playing boardgames. Most people who are used to playing things like Monopoly and Scrabble are a little intimidated at first with the "large" amount of rules, but learn it pretty quickly and quite enjoy it after a round. The hardest thing to grasp is the fact that initial placement can have a lot to do with the outcome of the overall game.

RATING: 7.5
A good family game with a lot of luck and some negotiation that can be fairly nasty, via the robber and trading boycotts.  This nastiness is surprising, given how popular the game is in Germany.  It makes one wonder whether the "conventional wisdom" among German publishers that player conflict is to be avoided is actually accurate for the German market...

When all's said and done, I tend to prefer vanilla Settlers to its various variants and expansions.

RATING: 2.3
After 10 times of playing it, I still can't remember really enjoying my experience with Settlers; you spend the whole game trading for cards and then once you have the cards you need there are only 4 different possibilities to use them.  It seems like the same thing always happens: the robber always visits the same spots, someone who had a bad starting position can never do well, and lastly whoever is close to winning the game will meet the demise of other players refusing to trade w/ him or her.  The only true remaining value I see in this game is that it is a good game for new gamers because of how easy it is to learn and the time length 45-90 minutes.

RATING: 8
1/16/11: I've been playing this a lot lately because my six year old son really enjoys it.  He doesn't get the nuances of balancing probabilities, and his trades are often very lopsided (I'll give you three ore for your sheep).  But we have fun, and I'm reminded of what a great, replayable game this is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good:
-Trading
-Lots of player interaction
-Borderline gateway game
-Easy to understand and execute strategies
-Cheering for die rolls

Bad:
-Waiting on rolls
-Balance issues (city strategies are too good)
-Encourages mean-spirited play
-A little long for what it is
-Starting villages typically determines who will win

Overall:
The player interaction that comes from trading adds a lot of interaction and seems to be the main selling point.  But trading slows the game down and gives savy players an even bigger advantage.  This was one of the best gateway games when it came out and holds a special place in my heart but I now struggle to find a reason to play it.  It's not deep enough for play with hobbyists, not a top-tier family weight game, and not ideal for introducing the hobby.  While I definitely got my moneys worth, it will be collecting dust for the foreseable future.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not a bad little game. Placement and die rolls can kill you, but as long as the map is not overcrowded usually you can give it a good go. Negotiation is not a "bad" feature as long as everyone knows the game and knows how to wisely negotiate. Playing with someone who gives another player whatever they want or because they are charismatic will kill it though.

RATING: 6
A classic that completely deserves all the international awards (and commercial success) it received. Still, in my humble opinion, it did not stand the test of time very well. When compared to modern day classics, it suffers from a lack of options and the fact that it really only shines with three players (with four, one player runs out of building sites very, very quickly). Much, much better with the Cities & Knights expansion. As far as cosmetics are concerned, I much prefer the original version with its wooden components.

RATING: 5
Rating given for a three player, bog standard game. 

Four player games tend to become tedious and too frustrating for enjoyment. The strength of the game lies in its simplicity, and any expansion or "improvement" detracts from this.

NOT a gate-way game. My first encounter with Settlers almost put me off German games for life, but then the rules were poorly explained and I was constantly being clobbered by the robber.

RATING: 8

RATING: 9
Excellent game. There are so many things to like about this game. Everyone is involed every turn so there is no "dead time" between your turns. It is simple and it is short but there is a lot to it. I really like the trading aspect of the game. If you are shrewed and trade well you will win a lot of games. Also the other players tend to gang-up on the leader which tends to make every game a close finish which is always exciting. We have played this to death but still enjoy it everytime we play.

RATING: 9
I accidently bought the cards for this game instead of the card game - ughs Ebay kills me sometimes! If you want nice new cards for your settlers game - let me know!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Settlers of Catan fits the definition of gateway game quite well.  There is a good balance of luck and strategy.  The game can be easily taught in ~7 minutes and anyway, a new player can learn 90% of the game by just being the last player (i.e. watch the others play).  Negatives include the initial setup time and difficulty in recovering when behind (i.e. generally 1 or 2 players do really well while the rest aren't even close).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game by which all others are judged. Although it suffers from a lot of hype, it is still a fantastic game. There are so many strategies that can be employed and different opponents often require different counterstrategies. This one really got me into the hobby.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Instead of houses and hotels, you have settlements and cities.  Instead of Income and Luxury Tax, you have the Robber.  Instead of Boardwalk and Park Place, you have wood and sheep.  Instead of Community Chest and Chance, you have development cards.  Instead of trading, you have... trading.  Instead of "roll 2d6 and pass the dice", you have... roll 2d6 and pass the dice.

It may have a slightly more manageable timeframe and no player elimination, but let's face it: Settlers is really Monopoly in disguise.

And that's why it's so successful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

At this point I'll only play it if someone else really really wants to play it.

RATING: N/A
Weight: 2.4 - Players: 3-4 (4)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
If you are only considering the game design and the ratio of luck to strategy, there are definitely better games than this. However, I have more memories of awesome times I have had playing this game than with any other game. It is very much dependent on the people playing, as I had played games that were not much fun because the players played too seriously or one player accepted pretty much any trade offer. I have won this game by only building on two hexagons before (I had four cities and believe it or not, Longest Road.) I have played a game where we combined two base sets and played to 25 VPs. It lasted three hours, but it was awesome and one of the most fun times I have had playing a board game. I love the intellectual challenge and brain burn of other games, but with the right players, Settlers is a blast, and still has enough strategy and tactics to keep me interested.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game opened the door for me to the possibilities of board games, circa 1998.  The only reason it's this low is that our copy has literally been played to death, with massive amounts of wear and tear on everything.  If I logged them all, there'd be hundreds of plays of this game for me.

RATING: 8
Messer Teubers classic. Plays very well with 3 or more (whilst it can be enjoyed with 2). Mayfairs production is good and workman like but dont expect the quality of DoW, FF, Alea, Ravensburger or the like. You are going to need polybags and rubber bands for this one. This one should be every gamers collection.

RATING: 4
I only played it twice, but that was enough to realize the game was not for me. It is a game where the rich gets richer, which also leads to the runaway leader problem and thus, to king making. I also didn't like the constant bickering about the resource trading which just slowed the whole game down.  In both games, I could pretty soon say who's gonna be the winner which made the entire experience pointless. I sincerely don't understand such a love for this game. I could see myself playing this a few more times, but I doubt I gonna change my mind.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I realized the reason why Catan is so great is that your settlements and cities reach their ideal productive capacity right as the game is ending.  That feeling of getting 3 Ore in a turn, or 4 resources overall - it feels really good, and you want to have it again, so you play again.  I feel like it's hip to badmouth Catan and it wouldn't be my first, fifth, or even tenth choice to play were it my option, but I've played it live more than any other game; it's held up pretty well.

EDIT 11/17 - I'd like to lower my rating of Catan, but it's me that's changed and not the game - I've just played it too many times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Settlers of Catan is worthy of being in every gamer's library, and serves as a wonderful gateway drug.

The random setup and dice-rolling aspects of this game can infuriate players who have grown accustomed to more refined Euros, but this is one of the first crossovers that introduced many of us to grown-up board games, as we know them.

Resource management and negotiation somewhat mitigate the randomness, which is why I consider this game a notch better than Carcassonne.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Cons: high level of luck, trading mechanism sometimes falls flat

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Got me re-interested into board gaming around 1999 as my first foray into the world of Euro-games. Better yet, it got my spouse into board gaming and was easy to introduce to family members and friends, even if they didn't want to play nearly as often as I'd like. Loved the modular board adding replay value, the non-traditional use of dice in a game, indirect confrontation through competition for spaces, and interactivity brought about through trading - all in a game that runs 45-90 minutes. 
Some minor flaws: bad initial placements can lock a player out early, serious opportunities for kingmaking if losing players freely trade with leaders close to finishing, while unbalanced starting boards that make resources unusually scarce or group dynamics that don't favor trading can result in games that drag longer than they should. Played 20+ more times than logged on BGG.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
However recently I've played this game - even if I've just played it twice on the trot - I'll always want to play it again.  I've played it many, many times and it is still as enjoyable as ever.  That's how addictive it is.  I still find the basic game superior to any of the expansions because of its elegance and simplicity.

[i]"Poor. Likely won't play this again although could be convinced."[/i]

Showing its age. Front-loaded importance of decisions, poorly controlled variance, and despite theoretically engaging all players at all times it has great potential for downtime or even essentially wasted turns.

I don't like the politics in it either but admittedly that's the thing that makes it unique. Archipelago embraces this more fully and is a better game for it.

RATING: 6
Still love this game for what it was. It was an obsession for a solid year before I found other board games.  Playing it again recently though, it's showing it's age. Board is so crowded with 4 that it doesn't feel like you're getting anywhere. Everything is so luck driven.  Monopoly cards can feel overpowered yap to the right time.  Robber can be devastating and obnoxious. Turns can drag. Border tiles warp.

I'd like to try some expansions, but I don't think I'll go back to the base game again.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
1st update (Sep 2010)[6]: My very first "real" board game. I have played this game tens of more times than anything else, and it would still be one of the go-to games for my family. Nowadays I rarely play it, since it can take hours to complete, and we'd rather play something more rewarding. It IS a very good game though, and the rating given is of how often I play it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
My feelings echo Phoebe Wild's : 

"Yes, it was "the" first game I played which got me into strategy games and Eurogames to start with, but I find now that I get sick of it 15 minutes into a game and start counting points hoping for someone to win. I think this is because it's a game with limited options, and limited things a player can do to improve their options. Beyond the initial placement of settlements, resource gaining depends on dice rolls and the kindness/naivety of the other players. And if neither of those are in your favour, you can watch turn by turn pass not building anything, while everyone else picks up 5 resource cards a turn. It either goes splendidly or horribly, but either way it isn't really in your control."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I love negotiation games, and this is no exception. I think my favorite part of the game is extorting other players while still maintaining a diplomatic relationship.

"Well, it's not like I want to block off your road, but I just don't have the resources I need to do anything else this turn. If you give me some stone to upgrade my settlement I won't have to block you anymore."

The 5-6 player extension is a trap.

RATING: 6

RATING: 7.5
A great game that keeps hitting the table for it's simplicity and easy set up. This is the gateway game for new board game groups. Highly addicting initially, and still a good time after many plays.
There's a lot of luck and it can be frustrating when your resources are not rolled or when you get hopelessly blocked in. A good strategy will only take you so far. I suppose this is what makes it good and fair for experienced and new gamers.
If you like it and want an expansion then the best one is Catan Cities and Knights hands down. You don't need any other expansion and in fact many of them don't combine well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Fantastic light play.  This is the game for non-gamers that I always trot out.  Moves along quickly, and doesn't encourage overly competitive new gamers (you know who they are) to get angry at others.  It also has enough strategy to satisfy the gamers in your group.  I don't tend to play it with other serious gamers anymore, but it got much of my group and me into the gaming scene.  Its reputation as a classic is well-earned.  Revolutionary then, and still revolutionary for most people now.

RATING: 6
The classic euro. My gateway game. I'm not sure why this is such a good gateway, maybe it's the negotiation aspect, the dice, the simplicity of the building/resource management; maybe it's the notoriety or the "brand" that keeps people from being turned away. I think everyone should have this game in their collection. It's not my favorite game, or even my favorite gateway game, but it's *the* classic gateway euro, in my opinion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rated after 23 confirmed games with different opponents. In first games there was lots of interaction between players, but later the interaction level drops down when players don't try to propose every possible trade. In the end, when players have more or less experience, the interaction between players is quite scarce. A good game in good company, but the benefit of experience means this is not a game I would like to introduce to new players.

Randomness in the setup means that this game is very playable for long time. Unfortunately my latest games have used the beginners' setup.

Updated after 24th and 25th plays, introducing the game to new beginners despite the comment above. After all, this is a classic game everyone should know. Let's say, I won't introduce this one to non-players very easily. :) Updated the rating from 7 to 8. Now three plays of Catan on three consecutive Tuesdays, but still without expansions...

I have several small expansions for this game, looking forward to try them sometime, when there are no beginners around.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Settlers is a light-weight game that works well for a family get together setting. Its greatest asset is the trading mechanic. This can be a hard-core strategy gamer's nightmare with all the dice-rolls. It takes a  little too long to play for my taste and sheep can be an over-abundant resource if you play it with the base game only (an issue fixed by Seafarers). Still, it is easy to bring this out on the table more often than not and everybody loves to hate the Robber.

RATING: 7
One of the 'founding fathers' of modern board games.  Cata is straight forward, has a high level of interaction, and is compact.  That being said, starting position and early rolls have a HUGE impact on your chances to succeed.  This game is largely focused on dice rolls - so luck/randomness is a major element in Catan.

Catan isn't a fair game, but it's still quite a bit of fun due to resource trading interaction between players.

RATING: 3
Gave it a 3 because I could MAYBE be talked into it. Hoping to never play again though. Owned it for a few years and played it on a few family get togethers with people who don't usually play games.  That's kinda the problem right there, is that this is a game for non-gamers.  Those people all seem to like how simple and stupid and random it is.  I got an expansion hoping it would make it better, but it was a whole lot of time for an abysmal game experience.  My wife and I never wanted to play again after that.  Gave the thing to the local thrift store. 

How is this game grouped into the strategy game category when games with WAY more strategy are left out?  This game is a trend that will one day totally die out, just like Trivial Pursuit.  The game play and game design are below average.  I would rather play Monopoly any day.

RATING: 8
One of the new classic games. Luck plays a role. Might Wanda try the rule below:

The random dice drove me nuts. I'd be sitting on a 6, 8, 5 and 9, and everyone would be rolling 4's and 10's. I later learned of a rule used in Settlers of America: If your number isn't rolled, you gain 1 gold coin. On your turn, you can exchange 2 gold for any 1 resource at. You can do this twice per turn (you can spend a max of 4 gold per turn). If a number is rolled but is blocked by a robber, that player does not receive gold.

RATING: 1
I honestly don't care for this game. It's too simple and slower than I wanted it to be. I hate the dice rolling and the amount of time spent collecting random resources. Dice were a bad call, I think. It's also hard to care about who wins or loses as the game is pretty bland theme-wise. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
With a "difficult" starting position and a few unlucky rolls of the dice you may practically be out of the game after a few minutes, and the rest of the game is an exercise in enduring an hour of pointless boredom to wait for someone else to win the game. Avoid.

Yeah, yeah, yeah - the bad luck evens out over several games, but why play this poorly designed game several times when there are hundreds of much better games, today.

Luck in games is perfectly fine to change your odds or to determine your available options etc. - but not to determine if you are in or out of the game from the beginning or after a few rounds.

Buy it and put it on your personal "boardgame museum" shelf, next to Monopoly, of classic, but bad and never to be played again, boardgames, if you must, but there are many, much better games to buy and play.

Would only ever play this game again to try the "Welfare variant" (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/150443), or the "Event cards variant" (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/20038) which may solve/reduce the luck problems.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Klaus Teuber; In Settlers of Catan, players try to be the dominant force on the island of Catan by building settlements, cities, and roads. On each turn dice are rolled to determine the current production on the island. Players collect raw materials to build up their civilizations to gain enough victory points to win the game. This game is a Spiel des Jahres (German game of the year, 1995) winner, primarily because of its amazing ability to appeal to non-gamers and gamers alike. Die Siedler von Catan was originally published by Kosmos and has gone through multiple editions. It was licensed by Mayfair and has undergone at least 4 editions as Settlers of Catan. It has also been re-published in a travel edition by Kosmos and in yet a different edition for Japan/Asia, Settlers of Catan : Rockman Edition. Settlers of Catan is the original game in the Catan Series. Expanded by: The Seafarers of Catan, The Cities and Knights of Catan, 5-6 Player Expansion. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3.5
------------------------------
NOTICE : Due to my poor spoken & written English, the rest of my comments will be written in French only but you can read my profile for more informations about the kind of games I prefer and how I rated them.
------------------------------

►ÉDITION : Filosofia, français, 2006.
Éditeur, nb joueurs : 3 à 4 joueurs.
Éditeur, durée : 1h00 à 2h00/partie.
Éditeur, âge : 10 ans et plus.

►PUBLIC(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
☺ Jeu tactique (plus d’éléments aléatoires et/ou de hasard raisonné).
☺ Jeu familial (pour jeunes et/ou adultes).

►JOUEURS, NOMBRE(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
# Meilleur : 
# Recommandé : 3, 4
# Non-recommandé :
# Non-essayé :
3 joueurs : moins de risques qu'un joueur se retrouve bloqué dans la construction de ses routes et cités mais il y a moins de partenaires d'échanges.
4 joueurs : plus de partenaires d'échanges mais plus de risque qu’un joueur se retrouve bloqué dans la construction de ses routes et cités. Personnellement à 4 joueurs, je conseille fortement l'utilisation des tuiles de l'expansion "5/6 joueurs" pour agrandir l’île afin que tous y soient à l'aise.

►COMMENTAIRE(S) ABRÉGÉ(S):
± THÈME : plutôt plaqué; mais agrémente le jeu.
+ Aide de jeu : 1 par joueur. Bien détaillé.
+ Configurations multiples : disposition modulaire.
- Déroulement répétitif : peut donner l’impression que toutes les parties se ressemblent.
- Durée du jeu : certaines parties peuvent s’éterniser.
+ Icônes : sont faciles à comprendre ou à mémoriser.

►REMARQUE(S) PERSONNELLE(S):
1e jeu de type "Allemand" que j'ai essayé, suite à un achat "au feeling", et qui a marqué le début de ma découverte des jeux Allemand & Euro. Personnellement, je m'en suis lassé rapidement parce que je le trouve trop hasardeux et répétitif. Cependant, il est fort apprécié par mes joueurs occasionnels (qui demandent régulièrement à y rejouer) et je pourrais le présenter aux novices curieux de s’initier aux jeux de ce genre. À noter qu'il s'agit d'un classique et qu’à ce titre, il vaut bien une partie d’essai ne serait-ce que pour son importance dans l’histoire des jeux et pour mieux comprendre tout le chemin parcouru depuis.

►EXTENSION(S) ESSAYÉE(S): 
… voir chaque extension pour plus de détails.
& "La grande rivière" : incluse avec mon jeu de base (voir ci-dessous).
& "5/6 joueurs" : Oui.
& Je n'ai jamais essayé l'(les) autre(s) extension(s) parce que je ne crois pas qu'elle(s) puisse(nt) améliorer mon appréciation du jeu de base.

=========================

EXTENSION(S) INCLUSE(S) AVEC MON JEU DE BASE:

¶ "LA GRANDE RIVIÈRE"
& Je n'ai jamais essayé cette extension parce que je ne crois pas qu'elle puisse améliorer mon appréciation du jeu de base.

RATING: 8
Having played it more times, I've dropped my rating a point.  It's too easy to get hosed for an entire game, thanks to the bad luck of the roll or others' unwillingness to trade.  There's also the possibility of winning the game strictly off of a blind draw from the deck, but to be fair, you still have to set yourself up to be in the position to pull that sort of thing off.  Additionally, I think it plays better with 4 than with 3, because there are more people involved, more numbers being rolled, and more trading going on.  In short, it has more possibilities.  It's still a fun concept, and still a great game!

20+ plays: computer
2 plays: 3 players
4 plays: 4 players

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
We like the mechanic whereby you collect commodities (wood, clay, sheep, ore, grain), which you then invest to purchase appropriately themed items (settlements, roads, cities) on the board.

The die-roll mechanic for determining what is harvested can be cruelly unforgiving (even if you hedge by placing settlements adjacent to as many different numbers as possible). We've tried the event cards and our initial reaction is positive. But, for a fairly quick empire-building game involving trading and luck - it's fun. My BGG plays record only a small fraction of the nearly 100 times we've played this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This one of the best strategy games ever created.  No 2 games are ever the same.

RATING: N/A
In Settlers of Catan, players try to be the dominant force on the island of Catan by building settlements, cities, and roads. On each turn dice are rolled to determine what resources the island produces. Players collect these resources to build up their civilizations to get to 10 victory points and win the game. Multi-award-winning and one of the most popular games in recent history due to its amazing ability to appeal to non-gamers and gamers alike.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I hate how the most complex decision is at the very beginning of the game, when you place your first settlement. After that, it is often close to autopilot (trading is pretty easy, despite what anyone says) and very luck based. This makes the flow of the game pretty anticlimactic. People go into huge AP as they place their first settlements, and then just sort of sit there while the dice determine the winner. This can be immensely frustrating, since after agonizing over the correct play and finally placing the settlement perfectly, you often just lose to variance anyway. For how difficult placing your settlement tends to be, it's often not worth the mental effort.

The game is also MEAN. Placed your road the wrong way? Too bad, player 3 cuts you off in the settlement placement and you're screwed for the entire game. Are you winning? OK, expect the robber baron to land on your settlements every time a 7 is rolled. This is just NOT ok for a casual, luck-based game - I want my casual games to feel casual, not like some cutthroat brawl.

The game gets better if you play with only 3-4 players on the 6-player expansion. There, there's enough room so that people get randomly screwed less, and placing settlements is also easier due to the large availability of "good" places.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A solid game, but not one I really go out of my way to play. I completely understand the game's popularity and its historical significance. Without Settlers, board games would still be relegated to the toy aisle. I also realize that many people cut their Eurogame teeth on Catan and most of those who did are still absolutely loyal to it. I get it, but I still would rather play something else.

As one of the first Euro's to cross the pond, it often gets a free pass for the parts that don't always work. I'm not usually one to bitch about randomness, but I have had more than a couple of experiences where I've had to sit around for half an hour doing nothing because my territories simply would not produce. Again, I know that's just a dice thing and it's not likely to happen ALL of the time. It just seems to really irritate me when it does happen...and it always seems to ruin my experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Does a lot of things well, in particular the fairly open trading rules, but there are two major issues I can't get past. First, there's enough strategy that you have to play well to win, but the dice add just enough randomness that the best strategy often will lose to a decent one. I've lost games I should have won due to dice, and worse still, I've won games I had no right winning because of them. In some ways, this is almost more irritating to me than games that are mostly luck, because it gives you the illusion that your strategy matters. As of this writing, the most recent game I played is a good example of this. I was on two 9 hexes of the same resource, which I had a 2:1 harbor for. Another player was on several of the 6s and 8s, and had high probabilities for all resources - but no 9s. We proceeded to roll something like 7 9s in 10 turns, allowing me to rally and take the lead to win. Some might call that risk/reward; for me, that was a hollow victory. My bigger problem with the game is that the structure makes it so that some players may face a fate worse than elimination: being mathematically eliminated from victory but forced to sit through until the end of the game anyway. Some have argued that a shrewd trader can still come back, but it's very apparent when someone cannot do it themselves, so only a pity trade could help them, and nobody likes a pity trade. This probably sounds overly negative, and it's probably a testament to the rest of the design that I still give it a 6 after all that complaining. Those two points are pretty much the only faults I have with the game itself. (Mayfair's pricing practices are another matter...)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Old classics, was my gateway game into board gaming. Still play it sometimes with family.

RATING: 5
Can see the appeal of this being an entry game.  However, the game is pretty much all about initial placement then letting the game play itself out. One bad placement and you're stuck doing nothing for the entire game, leaving unfortunate players bored for a really long time.  The game could use a serious catch up mechanism or at least something to do that doesn't involve a heavy dependency on a dice roll.

Would only play again if it was only the base game with 3-4 players with no house rules and if someone REALLY wanted to play it because they didn't know any better.

If I was rating the horribly house-ruled 5-6 player version I played in Japan, it would have gotten a 1.

RATING: 10

Even young children can play the game (mine wanted to change over from the kid version to the adult version at around age 6). Depending on the group you play with this can be a very communication intensive game as the trade aspect will decide the game most of the time. There is however a chance that luck will screw you but I play the game with statistics in mind, so I know things like that smooth out with the size of the sample ;)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Sigh - poor Catan. I get it. I get what was great about it. It was 1995. If you haven't found at least 30 games that do it better by now, you're in a rut and need to get out. Alternatively, you think you're not in a rut and I will never play with you.

As I keep saying elsewhere in my comments, I'm yet to see any game nail negotiation. In real life, negotiations fulfill the purpose of mutually benefiting both sides. This is inherently against the spirit of competition in board games, so there's no point in negotiating fairly or justly. Catan is the quintessential example of negotiation prolonging the game far beyond any acceptable period of play time.

RATING: 8
Routine gamers like to hate on this game but I still like it. Sure I like a heavier game at times and I'm not a hardcore gamer but this game still has it's place. Just enough luck to allow less experienced players to win from time to time but still experience driven. You can't say it's all luck if the same 2 people win 90% of the time :-p. I'll always keep this in my collection and pull it out from time to time. I don't care for the expansions though (only played seafarers and cities/knights) except for the 5-6 player expansion. I feel the expansions complicate the base game enough to make it less fun for newer players but don't add enough to make it much more fun for experienced players.

RATING: 9
This game kind of got old, but it still works. There are no other game that does things this game does. Getting the income based on where you are and trading and all that just goes so well together. There is a minor take that element, but if people use it wisely, not just for revenge, it's a integral element of the game as the catch up mechanism and even though I usually hate this kind of stuff, it's not a big deal here, and it's so fast it doesn't really hurt. This and the hand limit is a constant pressure to use your resources as soon as you can which is great to keep the game just going fast and smooth.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Catan receives way too much hate these days. On the surface there's loads of luck involved in gathering resources, but this is part of risk management in this game. Without randomness and unequal distribution of resources players would have no incentive to negotiate and trade. That player interaction and convesations around the table are the very things that make playing Catan an enjoyable experience. And although there are tons of better games around, Catan still holds up pretty well after all these years. You just need to play with an easy-going group of friends who are willing to actively participate in negotiations. I had fun playing this game and would gladly revisit it some time in the future. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As most people this is the game that did me decide to go into boardgames. Although it is not very balanced and the factor "luck" is very prominent... it remains one my all time favourites. Especially with one or more expansion sets :)

RATING: 6
Hm.  Love/hate with this game.  It is a great gateway game and I will give it credit for that.  I do believe it is a skill game and not just luck based.  True, sometimes the dice are not in your favor and you will go down.  But in the long run the better player will triumph.  You may see some people here on the Geek really bashing this game calling it outdated, and there may be some truth to that.  But the game is enjoyable for many people, it is a great start for getting your friends into gaming who have only played Monopoly and Clue, and it can be played with a wide array of gamer-types.  All that said, I hope I never have to play this game again.

RATING: 7
OK, I finally played my first game of Settlers. It was the 2 player variant where you play to 15 and roll the resource dice twice. Anyway, I liked it a lot. We'll definitely play again.

My only problem with the game so far is that I am red/green color deficient. So all those reds and browns and greens are a little rough to tell apart. Although there is some detail on the cards it's not high contrast so it doesn't help much. Also - it would help if there were pictures on each tile of the resource that the tile produces. It was hard for me to just look at a tile and know what resource was associated with it. I had to keep looking at the resource cards and then try to figure out which background matched the tile. Ugh.

RATING: 7
Solid Game. 

Always a great "gateway" game to get people past monopoly.  

It has done wonders for the board game industry.  

At this point I've played over 100 matches, and while I'm done with it, there is a lasting fondness for it in my heart.

Yeah, there are better games.  But let's be thrilled about it for what it is.

Favorite Expansions:
* Old Fisherman of Catan (impossible to find)
* Cities and Knights (very complex though)
* Event Deck (out of print and thus more expensive than it's worth)

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game basically got me into modern board gaming.  Once I started playing, I couldn't stop.  It's simple and addictive.  However, after having gotten into board games and having played many others, Catan doesn't quite hold up.  First off, there's too much luck involved.  This can overcome with good building placement, but there are some games where 6 or 8 (the numbers that should come up more often when rolling 2 die) just never come up but 3s or 10s come up over and over again, rewarding the lucky player who just happened to chose those resource hexes with an easy victory.  Bottom line is: if your numbers aren't rolled, you lose.  And the game gets very frustrating and/or boring when you're hopelessly losing since the better you're doing, the easier it is to do even better.

I recommend new gamers give this a try.  It's fun and will get you into gaming.  Then, to add some complexity and replay value, get some of the expansions.  The Cities & Knights expansion makes the game great by adding the needed complexity.  Explorers & Pirates is also really fun, though it basically makes it into a different game. I've never been a big fan of Seafarers, it doesn't really add a whole lot in my opinion like the other expansions do.  Traders & Barbarians, in my opinion, is the best at fixing the original game without changing too much.  Some of the additions (especially fish and the cards instead of dice additions) really make the game less about luck and more about strategy.  

Catan is not my favorite game, but I keep comping back to it.  It holds a special place in my heart I guess.  It's worth playing for sure.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Also have 5-6 player's expansion.
Players try to be the dominant force on the island of Catan by building settlements, cities, and roads. On each turn dice are rolled to determine the current production on the island. Players collect raw materials to build up their civilizations to gain enough victory points to win the game.
Awards
1995 Spiel des Jahres
1995 Deutscher Spiele Preis 1st Place
1995 Meeples' Choice Award

RATING: 6.995
I find myself neglecting Catan in favour of newer and more shiny games, but it really is a classic.  It's not that it's the best game or my favourite game, but (along with Carcassonne and Ticket to Ride) it feels a bit like the Monopoly or Risk of the modern generation of games.  It's got a fair bit of luck, but also a fair bit of choice - it's not a 'heavy' game that will go on for hours, but you do have a sense of building something and your island will look differently at the end (and start) of each game.  It's a good solid game.

RATING: 8
About as elegant as a game can get.  Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, and the games that have copied this one in some way are almost countless.  It has since been surpassed by some games (Puerto Rico and Agricola for starters) - or perhaps it hasn't been surpassed but only seems so because of its age.  Definitely a classic of classics.

The one major problem (for some) is the randomness, where unlucky dice rolls can ruin the best strategy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great example of the differences between skill with controlling randomness and luck with trusting to randomness.  (A skill relying player will almost always beat a luck relying player.) The trick is not to always go for the best odds (as a 2d6 curve is rather flat), but to understand why lesser odds may be a better build (to spread numbers for instance).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I only play this game if people ask for it. I have bought the 10 years edition for 5 and 6 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Complete, excellent condition
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I grew up with this game. Settlers replaced Skat(!) in our local pub as the game you could play every evening – there were always players coming to the pub wanting to play Settlers and the pub soon purchased a game so nobody had to bring his own. I was still a little kid accompanying my parents, later it was the favourite boardgame to play with friends for many years.

Two aspects of the game that stand out for me: random drawing of the whole island and the trading aspect. The trading is the core of the game – you roll the dice to earn resources that you can trade. And you can trade everything: three corn make one beer, three sheep to drive me home tonight. Again, this is meant to be a social/pub game as the players do not play just for themselves against each other. As for the random aspect, this game is so customizable. You could use the 6 player expansion or just a second base game to build a bigger map and/or play up to 15 or even 20 points. You can also make one or two resources very scarce or even non-existent. Endless variations.

One bad thing about the game is that it can be boring or frustrating if there are players of different levels as the random aspect is not as big as in, say, Monopoly. Settlers is quite easy to learn (as for the rules of the game) but better players play much faster and know what things to do in certain situations. Peacefully developing your stuff turns into hecticly buying basically everything you can get. So this may be one aspect Settlers share with Skat – you might play it with players at the same level as you are slowly getting better at it. In my opinion, this game is mainly made for three players. So again – sort of a Skat replacing board game... Just be sure to get the old edition with wooden parts and cleaner artwork or even the anniversary wooden box. The newer edition with plastic parts is just ugly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Settlers was my introduction to "real" boardgames, as I suspect is the case for many. I still enjoy vanilla Settlers, though Cities and Knights is my favorite. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

https://boardgamegeek.com/article/20856728#20856728

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Probably not much more can be said about this game, but it's historically probably one of the most played games in my collection with a variety of groups. Nowadays I play games mostly with family, and this is one of our standards. I probably would not choose it as often as we play it, but it has stood the test of time and is still an entertaining enough game that I don't mind playing it when other people make the request. 

The variable game board and luck of the dice rolls make each game different enough to avoid to much same-ness from game to game. Good for just about everyone, but probably less enjoyed by those who dislike lucky swings in games as it relies heavily on the aforementioned dice rolls. There is some room for strategy in what spaces you choose at the start and where you decide to build, but really the success of those choices is relegated to the dice. That doesn't bother me as I like a little luck shakedown in my games (probably because pure strategy isn't my strong point!)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

(3,[4]) - 90' - 75% - 2,4W

RATING: 7
I was really into this game until I grew tired of it. A lot of fun for me is dependent on the group I'm playing with an their willingness to trade goods. I've played games where no-one was willing to trade among the players, and I disliked those plays severely.

Another thing I've gone to dislike about the game, is that when playing with more than 2 people, 2 people can band together to try and 'wall in' a village of the third person, very likely putting that player at such a disadvantage that he/she can no longer play a competitive role in the game and has to basically wait out the game while 'giving' away goods to the remaining players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A decent game for its time, but suffers from a few flaws which will likely keep me away.  First, while it seems that the luck factor is low, luck actually ends up having much too large an impact on the game.  The fact that there really aren't THAT many die rolls means that being on the losing end of too many of them pretty much kills you no matter how good your strategy.  Also, it is far too easy to stifle a player using the robber, and luck plays in to this, too.  If you don't like this type of screw-your neighbor, you will really dislike Settlers, because it can be nasty.  The robber is really the only mechanism to haul in a runaway leader, other than a "stay close" strategy, so it suffers badly for that as well.  Negotiation plays a big role, except that negotiation is often worthless, as everyone can very plainly see what you are after.  Could maybe use a little hidden information.  Just doesn't quite do it for me, but might play on occasion if it is strongly desired by others.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
There is not much to be said about this amazing game. It plays quick, people may talk a lot while playing (I really like the "social" part of eurogames), and it is easy to teach for people who don't usually play boardgames at all.

THE SETTLERS SOUNDTRACK

01. New Player, Check This Game Out
02. The Board Is Immaterially Different Each Time, Game Must Be Good
03. It's Not Roll-Move, It's Roll-Collect (Radio Edit)
04. I Will Never Trade You Ore
05. Arbitrary Seven-Rape
06. Why Are We Rolling More 3's Than 5's, More 10's Than 9's, and Twice as Many 8's as 6's?
07. Is Anybody Trading Brick? I Really Need Brick. I Will Trade Any Resource Except Ore for Brick. 
08. Dude, Nobody Has Any Brick
09. Okay Well In That Case I Will Trade One Wheat for Two Sheep. Or I Can Trade Sheep Wood for Wheat Wheat. I Can Also Do Wood for Sheep Sheep or Wheat Wheat or Sheep Wheat for Wood Wood. I Guess I Can Trade Ore I Guess But It Would Have to Be For Wood Wheat Sheep, Wood Sheep Sheep, Wheat Sheep Sheep--
10. Drawing Eight Soldiers is Gay (DJ Assault mix)
11. My Numbers Aren't Being Rolled, I Can't Do Anything
12. Game Over, I Just Drew Monopoly

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great game! Very easy to learn and pick up. Strategic nonetheless! Settlers of Catan was my gateway game.

The only reason why I don't want to give it a 10 is because it's pretty easy to tell who is going to win the game about 7 or so rounds in. You can snowball very easily in this game, however the incorporation of the crippling "7" roll can definitely balance things about. Plus, development cards can become VERY useful, depending on the timing.

What's nice is there is some variability from game to game. You will never have the same game twice. Replay-ability is definitely HIGH.

I would give this game a 9 if there were some way to buy resources from other players, much like in 7 Wonders. I don't want to talk too much about the mechanics, but you get the point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Huh, What comment can I make about Settlers? I don't want to say I like it, I feel so torn about it. There are way better games now, but this game is still good for what it is. Settlers feels like an awkward High School Romance that just sorta faded away, never had an explosive/dramatic break-up, You both know its over but it doesn't stop you from wondering if there [i]wasn't something there.[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
Great entry game, but too much relying on dice.  Adding a 'charity deck' that follows the same rule as the starfarers' charity rule is a must for us now.  It makes the game much more enjoyable for all.

For an enjoyable 2 player game, implement the charity rule, and throw seafarers & knights in; make a big map with lotsa islands, then use two colors of peices each & set the winning points at 20 to 24.

RATING: 6
I love this game. We used to play big 8-player games of Catan all the time with some family friends. I own three editions of the game, the first two from Mayfair, featuring different colored tokens, enabling you to play with as many as 8 players, and then the Swedish edition and 5-6 player expansion. Mayfair's double-island scenario really rocks.

Contains pieces in the following colors:

* Black
* Blue
* Green
* Orange
* Purple
* Red
* White
* Yellow

RATING: 7
I used to rate this a 7, and I do still enjoy it, but after having seen (and been) someone hammered down due to bad-roll after bad-roll, over a lengthy game, I do feel that the luck element is a little too heavy (and illogical - I can understand dice-rolls for, say, combat, but it seems odd that an island can only produce a certain few yields a year, of seemingly random produce). I appreciate the part it plays, but it takes me out of the game.

Still, a very solid game. Interesting mechanics, an attractive board, and with engaged players an excellent game. A high 7.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This was the first game I played of the more modern games. It led me from the world of Risk, Monopoly, Clue, Life, and other classic games to a whole new world. The map is random and changes each time you play it. Build roads to expand your influence and built more towns. The dice determine the game play but there is some strategy involved. Trade with other players but be careful not to have too many resources or you may have to give some up if someone rolls a 7. Focus on getting the longest road or building the largest army. Winner is the first person to 10 points. Great 1.5 hour to 2 hour game for beginners. Seasoned players may take 1 to 1.5 hours. Played well with 3-6 players. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a great game.  I've even got a number of non game players enjoying it.  Fast to learn and always changing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6
Quick to learn simple game.  Not much going on with it and just the right amount of luck to have things turn around or give someone who isn't as good a chance.  My biggest complaint would be the opening setup is far more important than the rest of the game.  Could use some balance making later decisions mean a little more so a bad start doesn't need to rely to much on luck to claw your way back.  Games go quick enough though when that does happen to fix your mistakes in the next game.  Overall a great game that most people will enjoy.

RATING: 7
This is the game that got me back into board games after a ten-year hiatus.  I can't say a bad word against it.  People tend to overstate the extent to which luck is involved, and it has become fashionable to bash it, while conveniently ignoring that (a) it came long before many of the supposedly superior games and (b) is THE game that made North Americans hope for and expect something better than Risk.

RATING: 7
This game was more or less the first Eurogame I played.  It's a nice game, but no matter how many people talk it up and say how great it is, I cannot escape the fact that every turn is decided by a roll of the dice.  I've seen people occupy every number except for the 3, 4 and 8 and watch 7-8 turns pass before being able to get a resource.  It's a little too random for me, and admittedly I burned myself out on it.

You never forget your first, but you do normally move on to greener pastures.

RATING: 8
After 10+ Plays: Great fun.  Sure, there are more strategic games, but this combines interesting strategic options, tactical decisions, a good helping of luck, lots of friendly player interaction, and just the right amount of backstabbing (via the robber, competition for city placement, and my favorite, breaking up people's longest road.  Best with 4.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's a classic for a reason. Probably most people's introduction to real games, and it's still cute when a friend will tell me, "I've played this game, you might not have heard of it... it's called Settlers of Catan".
Aww.
It's done a great service by introducing more people to our hobby, but I think that the randomness (HOW CAN 2 BE ROLLED FOUR CONSECUTIVE TURNS?!) limits its ability to be higher. The lack of catch-up makes the end game fairly predictable, and the negotiations are pretty simple. But still, if someone is excited about it I'll happily play, but only as a vehicle to open them up to more exciting games.

RATING: 5
Although this is the game that got me interested in boardgames, I never have an urge to play it anymore. The problems include:
1. Lots of downtime
2. A whole bunch of dice randomness, which leads to
3. Some players doing well early, building stuff and getting more stuff while other players are screwed, having to sit at the table for an hour and a half taking joy in how well others are doing. In all the games I've played, at least one of the players has been out of contention very quickly.

RATING: 6
Of the "Holy Trinity" (Settlers, Ticket to Ride, Carcassone), this is easily my least favorite. It's just so fiddly compared to the others. The rules aren't super simple. And it's the only one that uses dice as a major mechanism. Don't get me wrong, I'll play the game, and I understand its elegance -- especially at the beginning wave of modern board games, but... I'll go elsewhere.

RATING: 8
Fun game but it can take a lot more time than expected. And with longer games, I've had some not-so-serious people lose interest in the game. The more people are willing to trade, the quicker the game goes. But it's hard to have that because everyone can see how close everyone is to victory. That can sometimes lock up a game.

RATING: 10
Fantastic game both by itself and with expansions, I'd play it any time!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In my opinion this is a retheming of Monopoly with slight improvements. You are still determining resource generation randomly with dice rolls, though it is now tied to a bell curve rather than moving around a track. Then the main part of the game centers around negotiating and trading with other players to get what you need to improve your board position. It's a baby step away from main stream games into designer games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Who hasn't heard of this game? Anyway, I blame [url=http://www.wired.com/gaming/gamingreviews/magazine/17-04/mf_settlers]Wired Magazine[/url] for introducing me to this and other modern boardgames. While I do not consider it to be the most elegant of games, I do recognize how it changed the gaming landscape. It introduces players to basic euro mechanics after all. The only time I feel that strategy is involved is during initial settlement placement. It's all somewhat random and dependent on other factors afterwards. Fortunately since its inception Klaus Teuber has released countless expansions that add replay value.

RATING: 10
12/18/08 - It took me a *long* time to warm up to this game.  I guess I was just too daft to understand it before.  Now that I'm enlightened, I guess there really isn't much more to say about it that hasn't already been said (by its advocates).  I will say, however, that comments that this game is random reek of more ignorance than just about any other stereotypical BGG comment.  I guess this is yet another example of a game whose ultimate pay-off has turned out to be inversely proportional to my original dislike of the game (Ra, Dune, Antiquity being a few others).

RATING: 7
Proof that 2d6 don't bell curve.

It's one of the better intro games out there (me being here is proof of that). The random element actually helps pull in non-gamers as does the quick playtime.

The novice-appeal goes down exponentially the more expansions that are added. Still, I want this game to have something to play with my parents from time to time.
